summary: This clinical trial aims to investigate the psychological factors associated with nociplastic pain in patients with chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia. The study will assess personality traits, defense mechanisms, central sensitization, and childhood traumatic experiences in these patients. The trial will involve administering self-report questionnaires to participants in each group, as well as a control group without chronic pain conditions. The primary outcome measures include central sensitivity, traumatic experiences, personality traits, defense mechanisms, mental pain, and environmental sensitivity. Secondary outcome measures include psychological symptoms, quality of life, alexithymic traits, perceived social support, sexual satisfaction, genital pelvic pain, and sexual functioning.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two different mattresses in preventing pressure ulcers in bedridden patients. The study will have two groups: one group will use a massage mattress with a cube/block system, while the other group will use a standard mattress. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients without pressure ulcers after four weeks. The study will also assess the pressure sore area in both groups. The study design is randomized, with parallel assignment and triple masking. The eligible participants are adults aged 18 years and above of any gender, and the study accepts healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effects of exercise with augmented reality glasses on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values, and quality of life in children aged 10-12 with Type 1 Diabetes. The study will involve children who have been diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes for at least six months and do not have any other chronic diseases or psychiatric diagnoses. The intervention will consist of moderate exercise sessions using augmented reality glasses, which will be conducted twice a week for a total of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures include changes in HbA1c levels, body mass index, and quality of life over the 12-week sessions. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment, with the control group receiving no intervention.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on preoperative anxiety in patients undergoing abdominal surgery. The study will use preoperative anxiety scales and data collection tools such as patient information forms, VAS-A (Visual Anxiety Scale), and a smart wristband with stress level measurement feature. The sample will consist of individuals who meet the selection criteria and volunteer to participate in the research. The study design is experimental, with a parallel assignment of participants to different groups. The intervention group will watch a virtual reality video with virtual glasses, the placebo group will watch the plain version of the video without virtual glasses, and the control group will receive anxiety control. The primary outcome measures are the preoperative anxiety levels measured before and after watching the video using the smart wristband and VAS-A scale. The study aims to provide insights into the effectiveness of virtual reality in managing preoperative anxiety before abdominal surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical performance and safety of a device called Suture-TOOL for abdominal wound closure in both men and women undergoing elective open abdominal surgery. The study will measure the proportion of patients with a specific suture length to wound length ratio, as well as secondary outcomes such as stitch count, number of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeon's comfort with the device, and surgeon's satisfaction with the closure result. The study design is a single-arm prospective interventional study, and the participants will be assigned to the experimental group receiving the Suture-TOOL device. The study does not accept healthy volunteers, and the minimum age for participation is 18 years.

This clinical trial is titled "Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma" and aims to evaluate immune biomarkers in patients with salivary gland tumors. The study includes three groups: an observational group with salivary gland carcinoma, a control group with benign salivary gland tumors, and a control group with functional diseases of the nose or ear. The participants will undergo sampling of blood, saliva, and stool for immune characteristic evaluation. The study will measure changes in immune matrix, immunophenotyping, cytokine expression, metabolic state, and microbiomic state in the participants over a period of up to 5 years.

This clinical trial aims to determine the compliance to the Mediterranean diet, its impacts on walking and quality of life in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will use various measures, such as the Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale, Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale, MS Gait Scale, and Expanded Disability Status Scale, to assess the participants' diet compliance, quality of life, walking abilities, and disability status. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year, with measurements taken at different time frames. The eligibility criteria include being between the ages of 18-65 and having been diagnosed with MS. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial, called the SIIT-CD Study, aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with Crohn's disease. The study will include patients aged 18-75 years old who are in the active period of the disease. The primary outcome measure is the difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive induction regimen and the standard induction regimen. The study design is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, controlled study with two participant groups: the SIIT group receiving the selective intensive induction therapy and the non-intensive induction therapy group.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the preferences of a culturally and linguistically diverse population for second-line therapy for overactive bladder (OAB). The study will use a discrete choice experiment, where participants will fill in a questionnaire and choose between two fictive therapies with different characteristics of onabotulinum toxin A (botox) and sacral neuromodulation (SNM). The primary outcome measure is the completion of the discrete choice questionnaire. The study is open to adult patients with OAB, with a minimum age of 18 years. Healthy volunteers are not accepted for participation.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, and cost of using continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) devices among people living with type 1 diabetes in South Africa. The study will involve three arms: Arm 1 will use CGM continuously for 9 months, Arm 2 will use CGM intermittently for 2 weeks every 3 months for 9 months, and Arm 3 will follow standard of care (self-monitoring of blood glucose) for 9 months. The primary outcome measure is the impact of CGM use on blood glucose levels. Secondary outcome measures include the impact on glucose variability, hospitalizations related to diabetes complications, quality of life, acceptability and feasibility, and cost. The study will involve multiple study visits and qualitative methods such as focus group discussions and interviews. The study design is a pragmatic randomized controlled trial.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of Stereotactic Ablative Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) with focal dose escalation on the dominant lesion in localized prostate cancer. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of this treatment in terms of biochemical progression-free survival and local control. It will also assess the incidence and severity of urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events, both acute and late, as well as patient-reported outcomes and quality of life. The study will involve male participants with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate. The intervention will consist of Prostate SBRT with a focal boost, delivered in multiple sessions. The study design is a single-group assignment without masking. Minimum age for participation is 18 years, and healthy volunteers are not accepted.

This clinical trial, titled "Serious gaMes as Emerging E-health Interventions for Young People With neurologicaL or rEspiratory disoRders" (SMILER), aims to study the effectiveness of a serious game intervention for children with controlled asthma. The intervention involves using a serious game (SG) that incorporates physical exercises and collects real-time data to adapt the game experience based on the child's motor skills. The study will measure outcomes such as pediatric quality of life, skills and difficulties, and the conserved transcriptional response to adversity. Participants will be divided into two groups, with one group receiving the SG intervention and the other following standard treatment. The study will last for 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effects of stress on Pavlovian to instrumental transfer (PIT) and its neuroimaging correlates in individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD). The investigators will also examine the relationship between cognitive control abilities and the costs of interference in PIT. Additionally, the trial will compare PIT and its neural mechanisms between different drugs of abuse by including participants with AUD and smokers. The trial consists of three experiments and will involve various interventions and assessments, including fMRI imaging, behavioral tasks, questionnaires, and diagnostic tests. The primary outcome measures include neural and behavioral PIT effects, chronic stress levels, cognitive control measures, and acute stress induction. The secondary outcome measure is alcohol consumption after 12 months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the optimal time to wean premature neonates off of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) in order to reduce failure rates. The trial will involve infants born between 23 0/7 and 29 6/7 weeks gestational age and will take place in four Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs). The researchers plan to recruit 130 infants and will implement a standardized weaning protocol for the treatment group, while the control group will undergo weaning based on unit-specific practices. The primary outcome measure will be the number of participants with CPAP weaning failure. Secondary outcome measures include stimulation events, length of hospital stay, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids and antibiotics, re-intubation, duration of respiratory support, need for supplemental oxygen, pulmonary air leaks, nasal deformities, time to establish full tube and oral feeds, nosocomial infections, intraventricular hemorrhage, retinopathy of prematurity, and weight gain.

This clinical trial is a randomized, double-blind, Phase 3 study comparing the efficacy and safety of the drug Frexalimab (SAR441344) to a placebo in adult participants with nonrelapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS). The study aims to measure the time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP) over 6 months as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures include the time to onset of composite cCDP over 3 months, time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed disability improvement (CDI), number of new and/or enlarging T2hyperintense lesions per scan as detected by MRI, percent change in brain volume loss, change in cognitive function, change in multiple sclerosis impact scale scores, change in fatigue levels, annualized relapse rate, and the occurrence of adverse events. The study will also monitor antibody levels, serum Ig levels, plasma neurofilament light chain levels, and Frexalimab plasma concentration over time. The study will include adult participants between the ages of 18 and 60 years.

This clinical trial aims to compare the outcomes of two different surgical techniques for repairing unilateral cleft lip. The study will involve infants between the ages of 2-6 months with unilateral cleft lip. The two techniques being compared are the modified Millard technique and the Mishra technique. The primary outcome measures will include measurements of vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtral length, which will be assessed 3 months post-operatively. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with three groups: a control group, a group receiving the Mishra technique, and a group receiving the modified Millard technique. The trial will provide valuable data for evaluating the effectiveness of these two surgical approaches for repairing unilateral cleft lip.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of endoscopic management of controlled colo-cutaneous fistula as a complication of acute sigmoid diverticulitis. The study will include patients with recurrent fistula who have failed conservative measures and are in good general condition. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the endoscopic group or the surgical group. The endoscopic group will undergo endoscopic management of the fistula using clips or endostitches, while the surgical group will undergo sigmoid resection with primary anastomosis. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of recurrence of the fistula, and the secondary outcome measure is the incidence of side effects of endoscopy.

This clinical trial aims to improve the screening and early diagnosis of heart failure in high-risk patients. The study will compare usual care to an intervention group that will undergo early heart failure testing. Participants will be recruited through primary care electronic health records and sent invitation letters. Those who do not opt out will receive a patient information package and be randomized into either the usual care or intervention group. The intervention group will undergo NT-proBNP testing, and if elevated, will undergo further assessments including physical examination, electrocardiogram, and AI echocardiogram. The primary outcomes of the study include the number of participants diagnosed with heart failure, the number of outpatient heart failure visits, the number of urgent heart failure visits, and the number of heart failure hospitalizations. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of prescription for guideline-recommended heart failure therapies and heart failure events in patients with reduced ejection fraction. The study design is a randomized, un-blinded trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of propofol dosage based on lean body weight in patients with a body mass index (BMI) below 35. The study will include patients over the age of 18 who will undergo general anesthesia for 2-6 hours. Total body weight, ideal body weight, and lean body weight of the patients will be calculated, and propofol infusion will be started according to total body weight. The study will assess the relationship between the doses given and the BMI of the patients. The primary outcome measure is the ratio of propofol dose with sufficient depth of anesthesia according to total and lean body weight. The study design is observational, and routine anesthesia procedures will be applied to the patients.

This clinical trial is an open-label study that aims to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of oral letermovir for cytomegalovirus (CMV) prophylaxis in heart and lung transplant recipients. The study will compare subjects exposed to letermovir with those who received standard valganciclovir prophylaxis in the pre-intervention period. The primary outcome measures include CMV viral load and the proportion of days during which appropriately renally-dosed prophylaxis is administered. Secondary outcome measures include the frequency of acute cellular rejection, development of CMV resistance, development of neutropenia and severe thrombocytopenia, unplanned discontinuation of certain medications, and incorrect renal dosing. The study design is a prospective cohort with a single group assignment. Participants in the experimental arm will receive letermovir for up to 365 days.

The PHYSIOSCORE questionnaire was developed and validated to assess the complexity level and physiotherapy care in hospitalized patients. The questionnaire consists of 106 items divided into three domains: respiratory, imaging, and neuromuscular. The validation process included a committee of physical therapists who classified and evaluated the items based on their importance and relevance. The questionnaire was then tested for interrater reliability using a cohort of 110 patients hospitalized for cardiac conditions. The final version of the PHYSIOSCORE was found to be reliable and valid for assessing physiotherapy care in hospitalized patients. The study also includes an intervention arm for assessing respiratory and neuromuscular variables in patients undergoing different ventilation methods. The primary outcome measures include respiratory variables such as lung function, breath sounds, and chest X-ray, as well as neuromuscular variables such as muscle strength and postural control.

The SAVAL clinical trial aims to evaluate a selective adjuvant therapy approach for patients with HPV-mediated oropharynx squamous cell carcinomas (OPSCC) based on residual circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) levels. Patients with p16+ OPSCC who are candidates for TransOral Robotic Surgery (TORS) will be enrolled in the trial. After TORS, patients will have ctDNA drawn within 2-14 days post-surgery. Based on ctDNA levels and pathological criteria, patients will be stratified into low risk, intermediate risk, and high risk groups. The low risk group will be observed without radiation, the intermediate risk group will also be observed without radiation, and the high risk group will receive adjuvant treatment (radiation with or without chemotherapy). The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival at 2 years post-treatment, and secondary outcome measures include rates of recurrence, salvage, locoregional recurrence, overall survival, freedom from distant metastases, xerostomia, dysphagia, PEG-tube rate, and rate of recurrence stratified by risk group and post-TORS ctDNA levels.

This clinical trial is comparing ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) to partial breast irradiation (PBI) in the treatment of breast cancer in women. The study aims to assess the acute and late toxicity of the two radiotherapy regimens, as well as their effects on local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life. The trial will involve participants who have undergone breast-conserving surgery and meet specific inclusion criteria. The study design is randomized and participants will be assigned to either the WBI or PBI group.

This clinical trial aims to explore the use of symptom monitoring and digital life coaching (DLC) to understand the impact of multiple myeloma on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and overall well-being among a diverse U.S.-based sample. The study will evaluate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of a DLC intervention for individuals with relapsed/refractory (R/R) multiple myeloma. Participants will be enrolled in a 3-month digital health coaching program and will receive a Fitbit device for activity tracking. The primary outcome measure is the feasibility of the DLC intervention, with a retention rate goal of 70%. Secondary outcome measures include changes in cancer behavior self-efficacy and perception of treatment experience.

This clinical trial aims to explore the effect of a 4-week intervention using dried chicory root, known as WholeFiberTM, on patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). The study will assess the impact of the intervention on fecal calprotectin levels (a marker for gut inflammation), IBD complaints, quality of life, serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota, and short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) levels. The trial will include 12 patients with mild to moderate IBD and will evaluate whether there is a difference in response between patients with Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and Crohn's Disease (CD). The study will also include questionnaires to assess the feasibility and acceptance of the intervention.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in treating localized gingival recessions. The trial will compare the use of PADM in combination with coronally advanced flap (CAF) to CAF alone. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of gingival recession height, while the secondary outcome measure is the thickness of keratinized tissue. The trial will be conducted on participants aged 18 to 60 years, with eligible participants selected based on specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study design is a parallel assignment with random allocation and quadruple masking. The time frame for measuring outcomes is at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of conventional physical exercise and virtual reality exercise on heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients during hemodialysis. The study will assess the differences in heart rate variability modulation between the two exercise interventions and determine the relative effectiveness of each in improving heart rate variability modulation. The trial will involve two groups of patients, with one group participating in virtual reality exercise and the other group participating in physical exercise on a cycle ergometer. Various measurements, including heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation, will be assessed throughout the study. The study design is a longitudinal crossover clinical trial with random allocation. The primary outcome measure is heart rate variability behavior, while secondary outcome measures include blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation. The study will provide valuable insights into the benefits of virtual reality exercise for chronic renal patients during hemodialysis.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial. The study will measure dyspnea using the Dyspnea Visual Analog Scale (D-VAS) and the Mechanical Ventilation Respiratory Distress Observation Scale (MV-RDOS). Ventilatory variability will be measured using the coefficient of variation (CV) of chest expansion and frequency analysis of the respiratory signal. Surface electromyography will also be conducted to assess inspiratory extra-diaphragmatic muscles. The trial will include 100 patients, both communicative and non-communicative. Statistical analysis will be performed to compare variability indices and dyspnea intensity, as well as to predict dyspnea or failure of the weaning trial. The primary outcome measures will be clinically significant dyspnea based on D-VAS and MV-RDOS. The secondary outcome measures will include the intensity of dyspnea, the success or failure of the weaning trial, and the EMG signal of the respiratory muscles.

This clinical trial aims to compare the outcomes of a modified mini-incision approach versus the conventional approach for carpal tunnel release. Patients with primary carpal tunnel syndrome who have failed conservative treatment and meet the inclusion criteria will be randomly assigned to either the mini-incision group or the conventional group. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in carpal tunnel syndrome-associated pain, assessed using a visual analogue scale. Secondary outcome measures include pillar pain, recurrence of neuropathic symptoms, operative time, and scar effect. The study will follow up with patients at various time points up to 6 months postoperative.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of an intervention using observation/action therapy (AOT) among patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI). MCI is a transitional state between normal cognitive changes associated with aging and early dementia. The study plans to compare the outcomes of patients with MCI who observe a therapist, patients with MCI who observe patients without cognitive impairment, and a control group. The intervention involves a 5-week exercise program based on observation and action, focusing on upper and lower limb functionality, activities of daily living (ADL), balance, gait, and cognitive status. The primary outcome measures include changes in cognitive impairment, ADL, functionality, upper limb dexterity, balance, and gait. The study will involve residents or day care center users without visual or auditory impairments, aged 65-100 years. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and no masking. The intervention groups will undergo AOT either led by a therapist or by observing individuals without cognitive impairment. The control group will receive standard treatment. Data will be collected before and after the intervention.

This clinical trial aims to study the effectiveness of central line placement using an ultraportable ultrasound device. The study will involve patients aged 18 years and above who are scheduled to have a central venous line placed. The participants will be randomly assigned to either receive a central venous line placement using the ultraportable ultrasound device or the conventional ultrasound technique. The primary outcome measure of the study is the length of the procedure, which will be measured in seconds.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of Erbium:YAG laser treatment in postpartum patients with episiotomy scars. The study will assess the effect of the laser treatment on scar tissue healing and reduction of vulvar pain. The trial will include adult females who have given birth in the last 6 months and have vulvar pain and dyspareunia. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the Er:YAG laser treatment or a sham treatment. The primary outcome measures will be the change in vulvar pain and scar tissue healing after 6 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the improvement in sexual function and the incidence and severity of device-related adverse events.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of Sense for Kids therapy compared to motor therapy in improving upper limb sensorimotor outcomes in children and adolescents with unilateral cerebral palsy. The study will be a randomized, controlled, evaluator-blinded trial involving 50 participants aged 7 to 15 years. The primary outcome measure is bimanual performance/functional hand use, assessed using the Assisting Hand Assessment. Secondary outcome measures include functional hand use, bimanual coordination, proprioception, tactile registration, and tactile perception. Participants will receive three 45-minute therapy sessions per week for 8 weeks, and outcomes will be assessed at baseline, post-intervention, and 6 months follow-up. The study will also explore the potential role of clinical and neurological baseline characteristics on treatment response.

This clinical trial aims to understand the role of the gut microbiome in gallstone disease and its impact on patient outcomes. The study will collect data from 75 adult patients with newly diagnosed gallstone disease and analyze their stool samples to assess the diversity of bacterial species present. The researchers will also collect clinical history, diagnostic investigations, and other relevant data from electronic patient records. The goal is to identify differences in the gut microbiome between patients who experience complications of gallstone disease and those who do not, with the ultimate aim of reducing the development of these complications.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the association between elevated initial APRI (aspartate aminotransferase to platelet ratio index) values and the development of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) in adult patients with sepsis. The study includes sepsis patients aged 18 years and above, excluding those with chronic liver disease, viral hepatitis, and other specific conditions. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of SALD within 30 days after ICU admission. The study will also assess mortality at 30 days after ICU admission as a secondary outcome measure. The intervention/treatment involves the use of the initial AST to PLT ratio index. The study design includes the non-SALD group and the SALD group, with both groups receiving antibiotics therapy and other supportive therapy.

This clinical trial is evaluating the immunogenicity and safety of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) in people aged 18 years and older with different immunization programs. The study is randomized and double-blind, with a parallel assignment design. The primary outcome measures include the number of adverse events and laboratory markers of immunity after two doses of the vaccine. Secondary outcome measures include additional laboratory markers of immunity and immunogenic end points. The study aims to assess the effectiveness and safety of the vaccine in preventing coronavirus infection.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the impact of early skin-to-skin contact on maternal-infant bonding and perception of traumatic birth. The study includes puerperant women who gave normal birth in a specific hospital. The sample size is determined as 338 women, and they are divided into two groups: the experimental group receiving skin-to-skin contact and the control group receiving standard midwifery practices. Various scales are used to measure maternal attachment and traumatic birth perception at different time points. The study is designed as a randomized controlled experimental study and has a parallel assignment. The primary outcomes measured are the scores on the Maternal Attachment Scale and the Traumatic Birth Perception Scale.

This clinical trial investigated the effect of an ultrasound-guided sacral erector spinae plane block (ESPB) on post-operative pain in patients undergoing lumbar discectomy surgery. The study included 54 patients who were randomly assigned to either the ESPB group or the control group. Both groups received standard general anesthesia, and the ESPB group also received the sacral ESPB at the end of surgery. Pain scores were assessed using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for 24 hours, and total opioid consumption and patient satisfaction were recorded. The study aimed to determine if the ESPB would reduce post-operative pain in lumbar discectomy surgery.

This clinical trial aims to develop and validate a biomarker for lumbar myofascial pain using multimodal ultrasound imaging. The biomarker will be sensitive to changes in relation to treatment. The study will focus on the echogenicity of trigger points, tissue deformation in the thoracolumbar fascia and multifidus muscle, and the viscoelastic properties of the fascia and muscles. The goal is to create a predictive biomarker that can classify myofascial pain and predict its response to treatment. The trial will involve participants with chronic low back pain and healthy individuals. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of different myofascial pain categories, while the secondary outcome measure is the presence of substantial myofascial pain. The study will use standardized clinical examinations to determine these outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of a telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use in opioid-naïve adult patients with musculoskeletal pain. The study will randomize 200 patients into two groups: one receiving the video intervention and the other receiving usual care. The intervention group will watch an educational video and provide feedback on multiple-choice questions. The primary outcome measure is the combined pain severity and interference scores at 3 months. Secondary outcome measures include pain severity, pain interference, opioid use, physical function, global health, and healthcare utilization. The study will last for 2 years.

This clinical trial aims to assess the impact of a neuro-linguistic programming (NLP) program on the academic performance of primary school students in Lebanon. The study will focus on triggers, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) symptoms, and their effect on behavior and academic performance. The intervention will involve a neuro-linguistic program developed by three specialists, consisting of six sessions for teachers and students. The study will measure outcomes through questionnaires and assessments related to identifying school triggers, measuring strengths and difficulties, and assessing concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning. The study will be conducted over a period of two months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the ECOX Teaching Tool in improving the performance of medical students in OSCEs (Objective Structured Clinical Examinations) in the emergency department. The study will include medical students who are 18 years or older and are participating in the ECOS (End-of-Course OSCEs) at the end of their internship. The intervention group will use the ECOX tool, while the control group will use other revision methods. The primary outcome measure is the students' average score on the end-of-course OSCEs. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the psychological status and behavioral assessment of students. The study will last for 10 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of a web-based health care program on symptom management, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life in patients with pulmonary hypertension. The study will involve a web-based health care program intervention and will measure outcomes such as pulmonary arterial hypertension symptoms, social support, activity ability, and quality of life. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with a single masking. The primary purpose of the study is prevention. The intervention group will receive the web-based health care program, while the control group will receive usual care. The study will assess the effectiveness of the program over a six-month period.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study will include ALS patients who choose or decline life-prolonging treatment with long-term mechanical ventilation support, as well as their families. The primary outcome measure is the overall quality of life assessed by the Quality of Life Scale, and secondary outcome measures include health-related quality of life, caregiver burden, and disease-specific quality of life. The study design is non-randomized, with parallel assignment and no masking. The study will assess these outcomes at various time points up to 21 months after inclusion. The trial will accept participants of all ages and both sexes, and it also accepts healthy volunteers. The intervention involves the use of long-term mechanical ventilation support or no long-term mechanical ventilation support. The study will help determine the impact of long-term ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families.

This clinical trial aims to study the neurologic deficits and recovery in patients with chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH). The participants will undergo surgical evacuation of the hematoma and will also receive subdural electrocorticography (ECoG) monitoring to assess the presence or absence of spreading depolarization. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of postoperative neurologic deterioration, as assessed by the decline in Markwalder grading scale or Glasgow coma scale. Secondary outcome measures include the Extended Glasgow Outcome Scale, Montreal Cognitive Assessment, NIH Toolbox Cognitive Battery, PROMIS 29 profile, TBI QOL, and Headache Disability Index. The study will follow up with the participants at 30, 90, and 180 days after the intervention.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial that aims to compare the impact of annual versus biannual infusions of ocrelizumab in patients with active multiple sclerosis (MS) after 2 years of initial treatment. The study will measure the freedom from radiological disease activity at 2 years by evaluating the absence of new or enlarged T2 lesions on cerebrospinal MRI. The trial will include patients aged 18 years or older who have received informed consent and meet certain inclusion criteria. The study design involves parallel assignment and masking of the treatment. The primary outcome measure will be assessed at 24 months by an independent radiologist.

The clinical trial, titled "Organ SPARring Surgery vs. Standard Resection for Early Stage COLon Cancer in Elderly Frail Patients," aims to compare the outcomes of combined endoscopic laparoscopic surgery (CELS) with standard resection in elderly frail patients with early stage colon cancer. The study will measure various outcomes, including patient-reported postoperative recovery, exercise capacity and physical condition, quality of life, frailty, duration of surgery, blood loss, complications, conversion rate, resection margin, histopathological risk factors, long-term oncological outcomes, Clavien-Dindo classification, comprehensive complication index, length of hospital stay, 90-day mortality, hospital readmissions, and rate of secondary standard resection. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking. The intervention involves CELS, which is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for large local excisions of the colon, and the control group will receive standard surgical resection following oncologic principles. The study aims to provide evidence on the efficacy of organ sparing surgery for elderly frail patients with colon cancer.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of nebulized hypertonic saline in reducing respiratory exacerbations in individuals with neuromuscular disease or neurodisability. The study will include participants aged 5 years and above who have a history of at least one respiratory exacerbation requiring antibiotic treatment in the 12 months prior to recruitment. The trial will compare the use of nebulized 6% hypertonic saline to nebulized 0.9% normal saline as a control. The primary outcome measure is the course of antibiotics for respiratory infections. Secondary outcome measures include lung clearance index, respiratory resistance and reactance, lung ultrasound, electrical impedance tomography, airway inflammation, bacterial diversity, ease of airway clearance, health-related quality of life, treatment satisfaction, family impact, and health economics. The study is a phase 2 open-label pilot study and will last for 52 weeks.

This case-control study aims to assess individuals with paraphilic disorders, sexual addiction, and parasomnia to understand the risk factors for sexual violence. The study involves a structured medical assessment, questionnaires, neuropsychological testing, and blood samples. The participants will be evaluated for psychiatric diagnoses and undergo treatment as usual. The study will measure outcomes such as exposure to violence, mental disorders, impulsivity, depression, quality of life, loneliness, sleep problems, and DNA/epigenetic markers associated with sexual violence. The study also includes qualitative interviews and evaluates the type of treatment received and convictions for sexual offenses.

This clinical trial aims to develop a new metabolic imaging approach called aMRI for evaluating neurological disease in patients with gliomas. The primary objective is to characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter kᵢₒ*V differs in tumor versus normal brain and compare it to a standard metabolic imaging approach, ¹⁸FDG PET. Secondary objectives include using post-gadolinium T1 MRI to distinguish the contrast-enhancing ring region indicating the metabolically active tumor periphery from the less viable tumor core, and to assess the utility of aMRI in differentially assessing these regions compared to ¹⁸FDG PET. The study also aims to characterize how the metabolic aMRI parameter differs in various normal appearing brain sub-regions unaffected by tumor, and to compare how the aMRI metabolic parameter changes with different disease types, disease stage, and treatment status. The study will involve patients with glioma who will undergo simultaneous MRI and PET scanning after receiving ¹⁸FDG IV and gadoterate meglumine IV to obtain post-contrast MRI. The study will measure the mean values of kᵢₒ*V in the entire tumor region and normal-appearing contralateral regions, as well as in the tumor periphery and core regions. The data will be evaluated for efficacy in metabolically distinguishing these regions and correlating with ¹⁸FDG PET data. The study will also quantify the aMRI metabolic parameter in different normal appearing brain sub-regions and evaluate its efficacy in metabolically distinguishing them. The study will take up to 1 year to complete.

The GDMT Research, Education & Assist Trial for Heart Failure Care (GREAT-HF Care) is a cluster randomized study that aims to evaluate interventions to improve Guideline Directed Medical Therapy (GDMT) in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). The study will randomize clinicians into three groups: usual care, multi-pronged clinical decision support (CDS) with a GDMT order set, and multi-pronged CDS with referral to a pharmacist for co-management. The study will also assess the benefits of education in combination with these interventions. The primary outcome measure is an increase in HF GDMT prescriptions within 30 days of the index visit. Secondary outcome measures include additional HF GDMT prescriptions within 60 and 90 days of the index visit, as well as the addition of specific medications for HFrEF within these time frames. The study aims to improve the implementation of GDMT in heart failure care.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) alone versus ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy in clearing upper ureteric stones. Patients with single upper ureteric stones ranging from 6-15 mm in size and a history of less than 6 months are eligible to participate. The study will have a randomized design with participants assigned to either the ESWL alone group or the ESWL combined with tamsulosin therapy group. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients cleared from ureteric stones, which will be assessed at 4 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of interventional therapy for tracheal stenosis following percutaneous tracheotomy. The study will measure the rate of successful decannulations after the intervention, as well as technical success, reinterventions required, type of intervention, clinical success, and the need for additional treatment. The eligibility criteria include having tracheal stenosis after percutaneous tracheotomy and being at least 18 years old. The study does not accept healthy volunteers. The time frame for measuring the outcomes is 12 months.

The clinical trial titled "DRIVE-Mind II" aims to evaluate the impact of sustained psychiatric intervention on viral exposure and mental health in injecting drug users in Haiphong, Vietnam. The study will compare a psychiatric intervention group with a control group, measuring outcomes such as viral exposure, severity of substance use, quality of life, HIV treatment effectiveness, difficulty accessing care, psychiatric disorders associated with methamphetamine use, HIV/HCV incidence, incidence of psychiatric disorders in the control group, and cost analysis of the intervention. The intervention group will receive community-based psychiatric intervention, while the control group will be free from psychiatric disorders. The study will enroll 600 participants, with 200 in the intervention group and 400 in the control group. The study is a prospective cohort study with non-randomized allocation.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of conventional endodontic treatment with endodontic treatment combined with photodynamic therapy (PDT) in patients with apical lesions. The trial will be a randomized, controlled, and blinded study with three parallel treatment groups. The first group will receive conventional endodontic treatment alone, the second group will receive conventional endodontic treatment with PDT using a diode laser for 10 seconds per canal, and the third group will receive conventional endodontic treatment with PDT using a diode laser for 20 seconds per canal. The success rate and disinfection of the root canals will be evaluated using clinical and radiographic examinations. Adverse events will be monitored. The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of PDT in disinfecting root canals in patients with apical lesions.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of psychiatric orders in the psychoanalytic treatment of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study will involve participants with ASD and will assess the effectiveness of psychoanalysis, as well as the use of sertraline and duloxetine medications, and cognitive-behavioral therapy. The study will measure various outcome measures related to anxiety, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, agoraphobia, self-esteem, and personality beliefs. Secondary measures will include heart rate and blood pressure monitoring. The study will be conducted over a 90-day period.

The clinical trial focuses on using liquid biopsy to tailor treatment and companion diagnostics for Trastuzumab Deruxtecan (T-DXd) in patients with metastatic breast cancer. The trial aims to assess the ability of liquid biopsy to monitor disease progression and identify alterations associated with resistance to T-DXd. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of circulating alterations, including changes in HER2 status. Secondary objectives include molecular stratification of patients, lead time assessment, and the association between HER2 status and progression. Participants will receive T-DXd treatment and undergo serial blood samples for liquid biopsy.

This clinical trial aims to implement Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) in earthquake-affected individuals in Türkiye who have mental health problems. The study will be a pilot randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of individual CPT to an Enhanced-Care as Usual (E-CAU) control group. The treatment will consist of 12 one-hour sessions delivered in three phases: education, processing, and challenging. The primary outcome being measured is post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and the secondary outcomes include symptoms of depression, anxiety, and well-being. The study will include 30 eligible participants who will be randomized into either the CPT group or the control group. The assessments will be conducted at baseline, post-intervention (one week after the 12th CPT session), and one month after the post-assessment. The study is designed to provide evidence-based psychosocial interventions to meet the increasing mental health needs of earthquake survivors in Türkiye.

This clinical trial aims to assess the perceived quality of family planning counseling among reproductive aged women in El-Dakhla District, New Valley. The study will utilize the Quality of Contraceptive Counseling (QCC) Scale, which measures information exchange, interpersonal relationship, and disrespect and abuse in contraceptive counseling. Data will be collected through a semi-structured interview administered questionnaire. The study will also investigate factors associated with counseling quality such as client, provider, and visit factors. The results of the study will be used to plan interventions to improve the quality of family planning services. The study will be reviewed and approved by the Ethical Committee of Assiut Faculty of Medicine, and informed written consent will be obtained from participants.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two different ablation strategies in patients with persistent atrial fibrillation (AF). The study will use a new method called pulsed-field ablation (PFA) and multielectrode ablation catheters. The primary endpoint of the study is the recurrence of AF lasting more than 30 seconds, assessed through repeated 7-day ECG Holter monitoring. Secondary endpoints include AF recurrence on anti-arrhythmic drugs, hospitalization rates, number of electrical cardioversions, PFA-related complications, assessment of quality of life, and feasibility of achieving complete blockage of certain areas using PFA. The study will be a randomized, parallel assignment with two treatment groups: pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) only, and PVI plus additional lesions. The study will enroll patients with persistent or long-standing persistent AF. The minimum age for participation is 18 years, and the maximum age is 75 years. The study will measure outcomes over a 1-year follow-up period.

The Catholic Health Initiatives (CHI) St. Joseph's Children Home Visiting Longitudinal Study aims to investigate the effects of a three-year home visiting program on child development, child behavior, child abuse, child neglect, parenting, delinquency, and criminal behavior. The study will include first-born children aged 1 to 3 months and their families living within a specific county area. The intervention group will receive home visits and follow the Partners for a Healthy Baby curriculum, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The study will measure various outcomes, including child development and school readiness, maternal health, child health, child maltreatment, positive parenting practices, family economic self-sufficiency, and reductions in juvenile delinquency, family violence, and crime. Data will be collected through questionnaires, school records, administrative records, and various screening tools at different time points throughout the study.

This is a Phase I clinical trial to assess the safety and immunogenicity of the malaria vaccine candidate RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-MTM using two dosing regimens. The study will involve healthy adults aged 18 to 50 years who meet certain eligibility criteria. The two dosing regimens include a delayed regimen and a delayed fractional regimen. The study will measure the occurrence of solicited and unsolicited reactogenicity signs and symptoms, as well as safety laboratory measures and serious adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the humoral immunogenicity of RH5.1, comparing anti-RH5 serum IgG functional immunogenicity between the two groups, and analyzing innate immune responses.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the impact of a personalized treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine on the quality of life (QoL) of individuals with Multiple System Atrophy (MSA). The study will recruit 46 individuals with MSA and assess their QoL over an 18-month period. The participants will undergo various assessments and examinations at baseline, with follow-up visits at 6, 12, and 18 months. Some participants will also receive additional telemedicine visits for neurological, psychological, and rehabilitation consultations. The study will also include an observational component for informal caregivers of individuals with MSA. The primary outcome measure is the change in EQ-5D-5L score, which assesses the improvement in the patient's QoL. Secondary outcome measures include changes in MSA-QoL score, motor and non-motor scales, time to clinical milestones, changes in individual healthcare preferences, and satisfaction surveys. The study will also assess healthcare costs, medical complications, and the QoL of informal caregivers.

This clinical trial aims to study the genetic determinants of response to growth hormone treatment in children with idiopathic short stature. The study will include children who have been diagnosed with idiopathic short stature and have received at least 1 year of growth hormone therapy. The participants will be divided into two groups based on their response to the treatment: good responders and poor responders. The study will measure the frequency of genetic variants that differ between the two responder groups and the enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway. No treatment will be provided to the participants as part of this study. The primary outcome measure is the frequency of genetic variants, and the secondary outcome measure is the enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway. The study will take place over a one-year period after growth hormone therapy.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of neurochecks on sleep in critically ill adults with cerebral aneurysm. The study will involve adult patients who have undergone uncomplicated elective coiling of an unruptured cerebral aneurysm. Patients with certain conditions or characteristics, such as past or current intracranial injury or disease, sleep disorders, pregnancy, or cognitive impairment, will be excluded from the study. The study will be randomized and involve two groups: one group will undergo hourly neurochecks and the other group will undergo neurochecks every other hour. The primary outcome measure will be sleep efficiency, while secondary outcome measures will include wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and subjective sleep quality. The study will be conducted within 24 hours of enrollment.

This clinical trial aims to determine the prognostic importance of extranodal extension (iENE) on imaging in patients with head and neck cancer. The study will assess the accuracy of radiologists in identifying iENE compared to histopathology, evaluate the prognostic significance of iENE in terms of overall survival and recurrence rates, and stratify patients based on HPV status and N stage. Secondary outcomes include improving the diagnosis of iENE, assessing the utility of existing diagnostic classification systems, and measuring interobserver variability among radiologists. The trial will include patients treated between 1999 and 2020 and will continue until December 2023.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness and safety of bedside blind bone biopsy (BB) with conventional BB in patients with Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis (DFO). The hypothesis is that bedside BB is non-inferior to conventional BB in DFO outcomes and can be used as a simpler alternative procedure. The primary outcome measure is the remission of DFO at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include clinical efficacy, microbiological results, occurrence of adverse events, and various cost-related factors. The study will include subjects with diabetes and Diabetic Foot Ulcer (DFU) with a suspicion of DFO. The study design is an open-label controlled randomized non-inferiority trial, and the interventions are the bedside blind bone biopsy procedure and the standard bone biopsy procedure.

This clinical trial aims to address the disparities in end-of-life (EoL) care for African Americans (AA) by developing a training program for clinicians. The program, called 'Caring for Older African Americans', will be adapted for urban-dwelling AA adults in Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York. The program will focus on cultural concordance, systemic racism, and implicit bias management. The study will involve a comparative ethnographic study, adaptation of the training program, and a cluster randomized trial. The primary outcomes measured will be patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance and family-reported goal-concordant care. This study is the first of its kind to address culturally aligned care, systemic racism, and implicit bias management in partnership with AA communities in the South and North of the US.

This clinical trial aims to assess the genomic alterations and expression profiles in HPV+ versus HPV- head and neck cancers. The study will analyze the molecular profiles of tumors using genetic analysis techniques. The primary outcome measure is the molecular profile of HPV+ and HPV- tumors. The study will provide insights into potential predictive markers for more effective and less invasive treatment options for patients with HPV+ head and neck cancers.

The clinical trial titled "Validation of Visual Analog Scales to Measure Satisfaction and Well-being at Work (SoWell-VAS)" aims to validate the use of visual analogue scales (VAS) in measuring various aspects of satisfaction and well-being at work. The study will assess outcomes such as burnout, anxiety, job demand, job control, social support, effort-reward imbalance, work addiction, and life satisfaction using VAS and questionnaires. The study will also collect data on sociodemographic factors, occupation, work hours, alcohol and tobacco consumption, physical activity, stress levels, and other related measures. The trial will include voluntary adults with a professional activity, with a minimum age of 18 and a maximum age of 80. The study design involves measuring these outcomes at inclusion and one week later.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the soft tissue contour and radiographic changes in alveolar ridge preservation using different techniques. The study includes participants who are over 20 years old and require tooth extraction for dental implant or denture fabrication. The interventions include alveolar ridge preservation with different techniques such as bone particle grafting with subepithelial connective tissue graft, vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue graft, collagen membrane, and Cytoplast. The study will measure soft tissue and hard tissue alterations using cone-beam computed tomography data and STereoLithography files. Secondary outcome measures include changes in keratinized tissue width and patient-reported visual analogue scale scores.

This clinical trial aims to study the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with Essure contraceptive implants compared to control patients with endometriosis or adenomyosis. The study will measure the level of cytokine IL10 in the peritoneal fluid of participants. The trial will include women over 18 years of age and will take place between January 2021 and November 2022. The study will not include individuals who are unable to understand the information given, are deprived of liberty, or are under guardianship. The trial does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial is a retrospective and prospective cohort study of patients with autoimmune liver disease (primary biliary cholangitis and autoimmune hepatitis) who are infected with COVID-19. The study aims to compare the infection rate, disease severity, clinical biochemistry indicators, hospital stay, and prognosis between patients treated with ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) and those who are not treated with UDCA. The study will collect data on patients' demographics, treatment information, COVID-19 infection and incidence, clinical symptoms, biochemistry, imaging, and treatment information. The study will also observe the occurrence and treatment of COVID-19 infection in patients during the prospective observation period. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of COVID-19 infection, while secondary outcome measures include disease severity, COVID-19 nucleic acid disappearance time, and COVID-19 infection outcome. The study will enroll patients from January 2021 to December 2023 and will continue clinical observation of autoimmune liver disease and COVID-19 infection. Patients eligible for the study must be 18 to 65 years old and have autoimmune liver disease.

This clinical trial aims to study the effect of preoperative prone position training on postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery. The study will involve two groups of participants: the experimental group will receive prone position training, while the control group will receive standard care. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications, while secondary outcome measures include arterial partial pressure of oxygen, extubation time, peak airway pressure, arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide, and oxygenation index. The study design is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial, and participants will be enrolled based on specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid when combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic EGFR wild-type non-small cell lung cancer. The trial will include patients aged 20-70 years old who have not received previous treatment and meet certain eligibility criteria. The study will have a phase I component to determine the dose-limiting toxicity and recommended dose level, followed by a phase II component to assess efficacy. The primary outcome measures include determining the dose-limiting toxicity, recommended dose level, and overall response rate after 4 cycles of combination use. Secondary outcome measures include overall response rate after at least 1 cycle of combination use, rate of grade 3/4 hematological toxicity, and effect on quality of life. The study design is non-randomized and open label.

This clinical trial, titled "AGE SELF CARE: Promoting Healthy Aging Through a Group Visit Program," aims to assess the effectiveness and feasibility of a virtual group visit program for community-dwelling adults aged 65 and older who are pre-frail. The intervention consists of 8 weekly 90-minute virtual group visits that focus on chronic disease management, healthy lifestyle education, home adaptation, and anticipatory guidance. The study will measure various outcomes including recruitment rate, completion of testing, attendance, completion of home practice log, participant satisfaction, proportion lost to follow-up, frailty index, loneliness, self-reported health, physical activity, self-efficacy, depression, anxiety, sleep, and physical performance. The study will be a single-group feasibility/acceptability pilot study.

This clinical trial is a pan-European study on geriatric rehabilitation after COVID-19 disease. The study aims to gain insight into the course of functional and medical recovery in geriatric rehabilitation patients affected by COVID-19 in Europe. It also seeks to understand the treatment modalities employed and the organization of geriatric rehabilitation for post-COVID patients in Europe. The study will collect data on demographic factors, hospital information, admission and discharge information, follow-up data, and qualitative data about GR care services and triage systems. The data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics, paired sample t-tests, multilevel models, and descriptive analysis. The primary outcome measures are change in Activities of Daily Living (ADL) functioning and change in quality of life. The study will enroll patients who have recovered from a COVID-19 infection and require geriatric rehabilitation. The study design is observational and does not influence therapy or treatment decisions. The study aims to include a minimum of 250 participants in total.

The PREPARE-iVAC Trial is a multicenter, open-label, controlled, randomized study that aims to investigate whether replacing Mycophenolate Mofetil/Mycophenolic Acid (MMF/MPA) with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients leads to a superior immune response after COVID-19 vaccination. The study also examines the impact of the replacement on humoral and cellular immunogenicity, as well as safety outcomes. The trial involves two parts: run-in and COVID-19 vaccination, and an optional part for herpes zoster vaccination. The study will be conducted across seven participating sites in the Netherlands. Participants will be randomized to either continue immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA or replace it with everolimus. The primary outcome measure is the virus-neutralizing capacity of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies. Secondary outcome measures include SARS-CoV-2 antibody concentration, SARS-CoV-2 specific T-cell response, varicella zoster specific antibodies and T-cell response, solicited local and systemic adverse events, serious adverse events, and safety of kidney transplant.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes in patients who have suffered burns. The trial will include 60 patients with burns covering 30% to 50% of their body surface area. The patients will be randomly divided into two groups: one group will receive resistance exercises in addition to their physical therapy program and medical treatment, while the other group will only receive the physical therapy program and medical treatment. The primary outcome measure of the study is the level of plasma liver enzymes (AST and ALT enzymes) after two months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of upper trapezius stretching on neck pain, range of motion, and disability in patients with cervical spondylosis. The study will include patients with a confirmed diagnosis of cervical spondylosis and neck pain lasting at least 3 months. The intervention group will receive upper fibers of trapezius stretching exercises under the guidance of a physical therapist, while the control group will receive standard care. The primary outcome measures will assess changes in neck pain intensity and range of motion, while the secondary outcome measure will evaluate changes in neck disability. The study will last for 4 weeks with follow-up assessments at 3 months.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of tecarterapy on the performance of amateur athletes. Tecarterapy is a non-invasive electrothermal therapy that uses electrical currents within the radiofrequency range to generate heating of deep muscle tissues. The physiological effects of tecarterapy include increased blood circulation, vasodilation, increased temperature, removal of excess fluid, and increased cell proliferation. The study will involve athletes between the ages of 18 and 30 who participate in sprinting and jumping sports. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the tecarterapy group or the sham group. The primary outcome measures will include changes in 30-meter sprint time and electromyographic activity during sprint. Secondary outcome measures will include countermovement jump, isometric leg extension, and electromyographic activity during countermovement jump and isometric leg extension. The study aims to determine if tecarterapy can improve functional variables related to sports performance in amateur athletes.

This clinical trial aims to quantify cell free DNA in patients with endometriosis undergoing medical assistance for procreation. The study will involve taking blood samples from patients before and during IVF treatment to measure cell free DNA levels. The primary outcome measures include the rate of cell free DNA in serum before IVF stimulation and in follicular fluid on the day of puncture. Secondary outcome measures include oocyte quality, fragmentation rate, embryo development, clinical pregnancy, and live birth rates. The study design is non-randomized with parallel assignment and participants will be divided into experimental and active comparator groups.

This clinical trial aims to compare the treatment outcomes of fully edentulous patients with maxillary implant overdentures retained by either bars or locator attachments. The study will assess the change in peri-implant marginal bone level after 10 years, as well as measure implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa health, and patient satisfaction using a questionnaire. The study design is an observational study with non-randomized allocation and parallel assignment. The primary purpose is treatment, and the intervention model is a prospective comparative study. The study will include patients who were referred to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery in the Netherlands 10 years ago due to problems with retention and stability of their dentures. The minimum age for participation is 18 years, and all sexes are eligible. The study will not include healthy volunteers. The primary outcome measure is the change in peri-implant marginal bone level after 10 years. The secondary outcome measures include implant survival, overdenture survival, pocket probing depth, plaque score, peri-implant mucosa condition, and patient satisfaction.

This randomized clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of a designed exercise program on pain and quality of sleep in patients with sickle cell disease anemia. The study will include fifty adult patients with sickle cell disease who will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group or a control group. The experimental group will receive a designed exercise program consisting of diaphragmatic breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, a combination of stretching and strengthening exercises, and walking. The control group will not receive the exercise program. The primary outcome measures will include the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and the Visual Analog Scale for pain severity. Secondary outcome measures will include the WHOQOL-BREF for quality of life, the Fatigue Scale, and the Perceived Stress Scale. The study will analyze the mean values within and between the two groups using t-tests and repeated measure analysis of variance. The expected results will be significant at a p-value < 0.05 and a confidence interval of 0.95%.

This clinical trial is a two-armed pragmatic trial investigating the use of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) for dementia. The study aims to compare the effects of CST referral to standard of care on cognitive decline and improvement in patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia. The trial will use cognitive assessment tools to measure cognitive changes at baseline and 6-month follow-up visits. Secondary outcomes include referral acceptance rate, participant attendance, and participant attrition. The study will be randomized and open-label, with participants assigned to either the CST referral group or the standard of care group. The trial will last for 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The study will involve diagnostic tests such as high-resolution manometry, upper-GI endoscopy, and pH-impedance testing. The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of anxiety and depression using the HADS questionnaire. The study will assess the severity of anxiety and depression symptoms and their relationship to reflux symptoms. The study will include patients with GERD who have completed the HADS questionnaire and undergone the diagnostic tests. The study will be conducted at the University Hospital of Cologne in Germany.

This clinical trial aims to personalize the treatment for women with disordered eating using mobile technology. The intervention involves self-guided personalized treatment delivered through smartphones. The study will assess changes in disordered eating symptoms, anxiety, depression, clinical impairment, and quality of life over an 8-week period. The trial is open to women aged 18-65 who meet the eligibility criteria. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking. The primary purpose of the study is treatment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system for detecting neoplastic lesions in patients with Lynch Syndrome. The study will compare the adenoma detection rate (ADR) between the CAD-EYE group and a group using indigo carmine chromoendoscopy as a reference technique. Secondary outcome measures include the detection rates of specific lesions, the diagnostic performance of CAD-EYE, the rate of a resect and discard strategy, and the comparison of procedure times between the two groups. The study will last for an average of 2 years.

This clinical trial investigates the use of a water-soluble contrast-based protocol in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction. The study aims to compare the outcomes of patients who receive an enteral contrast challenge with those who do not. The trial is conducted at nine children's hospitals and includes children aged 1-20 years who undergo nonoperative management for small bowel obstruction. The use of contrast is at the discretion of the attending surgeon. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients who require an operation. Secondary outcome measures include total hospital length of stay and adverse events related to contrast administration. The study is designed as a prospective observational study with enrollment taking place between 2020-2022. The contrast protocol is not standardized across sites, but the overall study protocol is standardized. The study aims to enroll 314 patients to detect a 15% difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups. Data collection and analysis involve various patient demographics, clinical data, and statistical analyses.

This clinical trial aims to compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous Itepekimab when administered with an autoinjector versus a prefilled syringe in healthy participants with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The study design is a phase 1, single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel group, single-dose study. The primary outcome measures include assessing the maximum plasma concentration, area under the plasma concentration versus time curve, and other pharmacokinetic parameters of Itepekimab. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the time to reach maximum plasma concentration, area under the serum concentration versus time curve, and other pharmacokinetic parameters. The study will also evaluate the incidence of treatment-emergent anti-Itepekimab antibodies responses and the occurrence of adverse events.

This clinical trial is a multi-site study conducted in the U.S. to assess the impact of different e-liquid flavors on cigarette consumption among adult smokers. The study will last for 8 weeks and will involve participants using the study product, P12 Electronic Nicotine Delivery System, in their natural environments. Participants will self-report their consumption of the study product, combustible cigarettes, and other tobacco and nicotine products. The study aims to determine the number and proportion of subjects who reduce their cigarette consumption by at least 50% and the mean percent reduction in cigarettes per day at the end of the study. The study will also assess the safety and tolerability of the study product. Participants will be randomized into three study arms, each offering different flavor variants of the study product.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of subcutaneous Infliximab monotherapy with subcutaneous Infliximab and concomitant immunosuppression in the treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease. The study will measure the proportion of patients in corticosteroid-free clinical remission and endoscopic response at week 26 as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include endoscopic remission, clinical remission, clinical response, symptomatic remission, biochemical remission, quality of life, development of anti-drug antibodies, thiopurine metabolites, IFX concentration levels, histological healing, response of perianal disease, presence of extraintestinal manifestations, and adverse events. The study will include 158 patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease and will last for 26 weeks. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the monotherapy group or the combination therapy group.

This clinical trial aims to study the pharmacokinetics (PK) of the anticoagulants rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation. The study will assess the PK profile of these drugs and identify factors that may influence their PK profile in cancer patients. The primary outcome measure is the estimated area under the curve (AUC) of each drug, while the secondary outcome measure is the occurrence of thromboembolic events or major bleeding. The study will last for a duration of 3 years. Participants will be monitored throughout the study. Eligible participants must be 18 years or older and have a confirmed diagnosis of cancer with either venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation. Pregnant or breastfeeding individuals, those without health insurance, and those with a life expectancy of less than 3 months are excluded from the study. The study accepts both male and female participants.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the bronchodilator response in patients with bronchiectasis. Bronchiectasis is characterized by irreversible dilatation of the bronchial tree and is associated with chronic cough, sputum production, and recurrent airway infections. The study will use pulmonary function testing, specifically forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), to assess the lung disease progression and exacerbations in these patients. The trial will investigate the bronchodilator response in bronchiectasis patients and determine if factors other than bronchodilators contribute to this response. The study will also explore the association between bronchodilator response and various clinical factors such as age, gender, specific bronchiectatic disease, baseline FEV1, and use of inhaled steroids. The primary outcome measures of the study include the bronchodilator response compared to placebo in terms of change in FEV1 and forced vital capacity (FVC). Secondary outcome measures include assessing the bronchodilator response in specific bronchiectatic disease, comparing it to healthy controls, and analyzing its association with age, gender, bronchiectatic disease, use of inhaled steroids, history of allergy, baseline FEV1, history of pseudomonas, and severity of bronchiectasis. The study design involves a randomized crossover assignment, with patients receiving either Salbutamol or placebo before spirometry testing. The study will collect spirometry results at baseline and 15 minutes after each intervention.

This clinical trial aims to determine the impact of gender identity, genetic sex, and hormone status on pain sensitivity. The study will also examine social and psychological factors that contribute to pain sensitivity. Additionally, the trial will quantify differences in immune cell populations and activity between the different groups. The inclusion criteria require self-identification as one of the gender identities specified, age between 18-65, and understanding of verbal and written English. The exclusion criteria include various medical conditions and treatments that could affect pain sensitivity. The study will involve a single visit consisting of blood draw, questionnaires, body measurements, and pain testing using different stimuli.
