The study will measure various outcomes related to pain sensitivity, sleep quality, depression, social support, discrimination, hormone levels, and immune cell characteristics.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility of using technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation in the acute and sub-acute phases after a stroke. The study will be conducted at University Hospital Wishaw in Scotland, and participants will be stroke patients who have been deemed medically fit for rehabilitation. The intervention involves the use of commercially available technology, such as robotics, virtual reality, and wearable sensors, to enhance rehabilitation activities. The study will measure the duration of time spent on activities within the technology-enriched rehabilitation space, movement repetitions, rates of recruitment and attrition, and adherence to sessions. Additionally, audio-recorded interviews will be conducted to assess the acceptability of the intervention. The study is designed as a feasibility study with a single group assignment, and the primary purpose is supportive care.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on respiratory discomfort in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) who are treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV). The trial will be conducted as an open-label, randomized, controlled crossover study. Patients will receive both IVR therapy and music therapy sessions, with the order determined by randomization. The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of IVR on respiratory discomfort, while secondary outcome measures include the evaluation of IVR and music therapy on sensory and emotional components of dyspnea, comparison of the effects of IVR and music therapy on respiratory discomfort, and the evaluation of the acceptability of IVR.

The clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of selective reporting for antibiotic susceptibility testing on the prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics by general practitioners (GPs) in women with E. coli urinary tract infections (UTIs). The study will involve randomization of GPs into two groups: an intervention arm and a control arm. The intervention arm will receive an antibiotic susceptibility testing report that restricts the list of antibiotics according to four E. coli susceptibility profiles, with an emphasis on narrower-spectrum antibiotics. The control arm will receive a standard antibiotic susceptibility testing report. The primary outcome measure is the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, defined as the number of urine cultures associated with a prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics prescribed by GPs in the same practice. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, antibiotic de-escalation rate, and the impact of targeted antibiotic susceptibility testing on GP and patient characteristics.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the potential neuroprotective effect of sodium valproate in patients with acute ischemic stroke. Sodium valproate is a commonly used medication with known safety and tolerability. The study will randomly assign patients to receive either low-dose sodium valproate, high-dose sodium valproate, or a placebo, in addition to standard stroke treatment. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with a favorable outcome at 90 days, as measured by the Modified Rankin Scale. Secondary outcome measures include the distribution of Modified Rankin Scale scores at 30 and 90 days, NIH Stroke Scale scores at 3 and 7 days, changes in lesion volume, and length of hospital stay. The study aims to determine whether sodium valproate can improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke.

This clinical trial aims to determine whether a virtual coach can provide a better solution for weight reduction in ventral hernia patients with obesity. The study will include participants between the ages of 18 and 90 who have a BMI of 30 or above and have been diagnosed with obesity. The participants will be divided into two groups, with one group utilizing a MyChart enabled virtual weight loss coach and the other group using standard preoperative weight loss tools. The primary outcome measure will be the average net amount of weight change in each group after 6 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the number of interactions with the virtual coach, quality of life measured through a questionnaire, and satisfaction with the virtual coach. The study is non-randomized and open-label.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes in the treatment of moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients. The study will be a multicenter, randomized controlled, single-blind trial. The intervention will involve nebulized administration of the exosomes or a saline solution. The primary outcome measures include the remission time of symptoms after medication, improvement of serum inflammatory markers, and CT review and comparison. The secondary outcome measures include the length of hospitalization and the recovery time (nucleic acid turning negative). The study will assess the safety and efficacy of the exosomes in treating COVID-19 pneumonia. The eligibility criteria include age between 18 and 75 years, positive nucleic acid or antigen test, and meeting the criteria for moderate and severe COVID-19 infection.

This clinical trial aims to compare the clinical effectiveness of calcium silicate-based sealer and epoxy resin-based sealer in single-visit root canal treatment. The study will assess the change in pain intensity, pain relief, and treatment outcome evaluation over time. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either epoxy resin-based sealers or calcium silicate-based sealers. The study will measure these outcomes at various time points after treatment. The trial will help determine the efficacy of these sealers in root canal treatment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the immunogenicity of two domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui and Cecolin) compared to imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years old. The study will also assess the immune persistence of these vaccines. It is a multi-center, prospective cohort study with 3,000 participants recruited. The participants will be divided into three groups based on the HPV vaccine they received, with 1,000 in each group. Blood samples will be collected at three time points after vaccination to test for HPV type 16 and 18 neutralizing antibodies. The goal is to compare the immunogenicity of the different vaccines in adolescent females. The study title is "Two Domestic HPV Vaccines (Wozehui and Cecolin) and Imported HPV Vaccines in Women Aged 13-14 Years Study on Immunogenicity: A Multi-center Cohort Study in China." The study is focused on HPV infection, HPV vaccine, and cervical cancer prevention. The eligibility criteria include age between 13-14 years, completion of previous HPV vaccination, and willingness to participate in follow-up visits and blood collection. The study design involves two follow-up visits at 12 months and 36 months after the last dose of vaccination. The primary outcome measures include the neutralization antibody GMT and antibody positivity testing for HPV types 16 and 18 at baseline, 12-month follow-up, and 36-month follow-up.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility of integrating homeopathy as a potential treatment option for symptom control and improvement in quality of life in cancer patients. The study will assess patients' concerns, acceptance of the homeopathic approach, and gather retrospective subjective information through validated questionnaires. The study will be conducted at a comprehensive cancer center and will involve patients treated at the Division of Oncology in Rambam Health Campus. The primary outcome measures will include the feasibility of the supportive approach and the level of distress as measured by a questionnaire and a distress thermometer. The study will last for 6-12 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to describe septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheters and midlines. The study will involve using Doppler ultrasound as a diagnostic test. The eligibility criteria include adult patients with a central venous device or a midline and catheter-related bacteremia. The study design is non-randomized with parallel assignment and open-label masking. The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis. The study is expected to last for 90 days.

This clinical trial is a phase 3, open-label, randomized study comparing the safety and efficacy of Odronextamab combined with Lenalidomide to Rituximab combined with Lenalidomide in participants with relapsed/refractory Follicular Lymphoma and Marginal Zone Lymphoma. The study will assess various outcome measures, including the incidence of dose limiting toxicities, treatment emergent adverse events, progression-free survival, and overall survival. Participants will be assigned to different arms and receive the respective interventions. The study aims to determine if Odronextamab combined with Lenalidomide is a better treatment option compared to Rituximab combined with Lenalidomide.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of Proliverenol supplementation on liver function in patients with Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD). The study will consist of four treatment groups, each receiving different doses of Proliverenol or a placebo for 12 weeks. The participants will be evaluated for treatment efficacy and safety at regular intervals throughout the study. The primary outcome measures include changes in serum ALT and AST levels, while secondary outcome measures include USG examination for Controlled Attenuated Parameter (CAP) and Transient elastography (TE), as well as the AST to ALT ratio. The study design is randomized, with participants allocated to treatment groups in a double-blind manner.

This clinical trial aims to assess the impact of ozone application in periodontitis patients. The study will involve non-surgical periodontal treatment and ozone therapy using a device. The participants will be randomized into two groups, with one group receiving gaseous ozone immediately after non-surgical treatment and the other group receiving only non-surgical treatment. The primary outcome measures will include probing pocket depth, while secondary outcome measures will include plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, proportions of bacterial species, and inflammatory parameter levels in gingival crevicular fluid. The study will evaluate these measures at baseline and at the 3rd month. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with double masking.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the expression of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue. The study will enroll 60 patients with pterygium, with conjunctival samples collected from 30 patients as a control group. The expressions of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in surgically removed pterygium will be compared with tissue samples from the control group. The study will use IBM SPSS version 26.0 for statistical analyses. The primary outcome measure will be the immunohistochemical evaluation of the tissue samples.

The TINO study aims to identify the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in vital and frail older individuals. The study will include young adults, healthy elderly, and frail elderly participants. The study will measure the frequency, phenotype, functionality, transcriptomic cluster composition, clonality, and stability of nasal and blood T cell populations in the different participant groups. Other measurements include the comparison of immune cell populations, concentration of cytokines and metabolites, respiratory tract microbiota profiles, and the presence of viral infections. The study will also examine the effect of sex on aging effects and the frequencies of antigen-specific T cells in the nose and blood post-infection.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio as predictors of response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The study will involve cirrhotic patients with SBP and will use ascetic fluid study as a diagnostic test. The primary outcome measure is to determine if the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio can predict the response to treatment in these patients. The study will take place from April 19, 2023, to April 30, 2024.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate whether point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) performed by various emergency medicine physicians can increase diagnostic accuracy in patients with acute dyspnea compared to routine assessment. The study will be a prospective observational study conducted in the Emergency Department in Lund and Helsingborg, Sweden. Adult patients presenting with shortness of breath and other criteria will be included in the study. The physicians will first assess the patient using routine diagnostic procedures and estimate the likelihood of various diagnoses. Then, a physician certified in the dyspnea POCUS protocol will perform ultrasound and provide the findings to the initial physician. The initial physician will then reassess the likelihood of diagnoses with the ultrasound findings. The diagnostic accuracy before and after adding POCUS will be compared to the discharge diagnosis. The study will also include additional tests such as chest imaging and blood tests. The primary outcome measure is the discharge diagnosis of various conditions related to dyspnea. The study will help determine the added diagnostic value of POCUS in acute dyspnea cases.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of respiratory training and relaxation techniques in improving adjuvant radiation therapy for deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) in breast cancer patients. The study aims to reduce the dose to the heart, alleviate anxiety and stress, and improve the quality of life during and after radiation therapy. The trial will randomize patients to receive either respiratory training and relaxation techniques or standard-of-care management. The primary endpoint is the heart dose, and secondary endpoints include anxiety, quality of life, and clinic workflow efficiency. The goal of the study is to develop a patient-centered training regimen to improve cardiac health in breast cancer survivors.

This Phase IB clinical trial aims to assess the safety and tolerability of a combination therapy consisting of Canakinumab, Tislelizumab, Nab-Paclitaxel, and Gemcitabine in the neo-adjuvant treatment of patients with pancreatic cancer. The study will enroll patients aged 18-100 years who have histologically or cytologically confirmed pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. The primary outcome measures include the number of dose-limiting toxicities and the number of patients who proceed to surgical resection. Secondary outcome measures include overall response rate, R0 resection rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and the impact of the study drug on surgical outcomes. The study is designed as a single-group assignment with an open-label approach.

This clinical trial aims to use participatory design and community partnered participatory research to develop a mental health digital tool called Connected for Wellness. The tool will support mental health navigation and connect youth to a range of mental health services and resources. The trial will also study the effectiveness of mental health navigation models and the Connected for Wellness app for improving access to care for youth and families. The trial will be conducted in 10 Los Angeles County Schools and 10 Riverside County/University of California Riverside primary care clinics. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of youth referred to mental health services who initiate care. The secondary outcome measure is the proportion of youth completing a mental health screening who are referred to care. The trial will use a stepped wedge design and participants will be randomized to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will use the Navigator Plus App Intervention, which includes the use of the Connected for Wellness app.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of intra-myometrial oxytocin injection and intra-myometrial tranexamic acid injection in reducing postpartum bleeding after cesarean delivery in term primigravida. The trial will be conducted in a hospital in Cairo, Egypt, and will include fifty primigravida women undergoing elective cesarean delivery. The participants will be randomly divided into two groups, with one group receiving oxytocin and the other group receiving tranexamic acid. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of intra and postoperative blood loss to decrease the risk of postpartum hemorrhage. The study design is a double-blinded, randomized, comparative trial.

The clinical trial is titled "Innovation for Small-scale Experiments: ReceptIVFity Test" and focuses on pregnancy-related conditions and infertility in females. The intervention is the ReceptIVFity test, which involves a vaginal microbiome swab. The study aims to evaluate the rate of successful pregnancy, the number of successful IVF cycles, and the total number of IVF treatment cycles per patient. Secondary outcome measures include patient satisfaction scores, total treatment costs, and pregnancy outcomes in women of non-European origin. The study design involves randomized allocation and parallel assignment, with no masking. The target population is females aged 18 to 42 years. The study does not accept healthy volunteers. The study duration is 3 years.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed consumed as a tea in patients with hyperlipidemia. The study will involve 114 participants who will be randomized into two groups to receive either fenugreek seed tea or a control black tea. The fenugreek seed tea will be consumed at a dose of 5g/day for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measure of the study is the difference in mean change in serum triglycerides between the two groups. Secondary outcome measures include differences in mean change in total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, non-HDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, plasma apolipoprotein B, and plasma microRNAs.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of pioglitazone in vascular transcriptional remodeling in individuals undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). The study will include 20 male participants over the age of 40 who are non-diabetic or have diabetes for less than 10 years and meet other eligibility criteria. The participants will be randomized to receive pioglitazone hydrochloride 45mg/day for 5 days before surgery or no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in S1P content of isolated HDL between baseline and after treatment with pioglitazone. Secondary outcome measures include the difference in SPHK1 expression in various artery cells between groups. The study design is a prospective, randomized, and open clinical trial.

This clinical trial aims to assess the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of three new developed coated glucose beads formulations, one coated glucose beads formulation, and one uncoated glucose beads formulation in 20 obese healthy subjects. The study will involve single-dose administration under fasting conditions. The participants will be randomized and undergo a crossover design with five treatment periods. Blood samples will be taken to measure the levels of Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and caffeine, and glucose measurements will also be taken. Visual analogue scales will be used to evaluate appetite and stomach rumbles. The study will also assess tolerability and safety through 12-lead ECG, vital signs, clinical routine laboratory parameters, physical examination, and monitoring of adverse events. The study design is a single-dose, randomized, open-label, five-treatment, five-period, five-sequence crossover, and will take place at one study site. The primary outcome measures include various parameters related to GLP-1 levels and caffeine pharmacokinetics, while secondary outcome measures include glucose pharmacokinetics, appetite, stomach rumbles, and safety assessments.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of using different strips on reducing the most common error in panoramic imaging, which is the palatoglossal air space shadow. The study was conducted at the Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology Department of Tabriz University of Medical Sciences in Iran. A total of 270 patients were randomly assigned to three groups: one group used celluloid matrix strips, another group used fruit leather strips, and the control group did not receive any specific instructions. Panoramic radiographs were taken for all participants, and an oral and maxillofacial radiologist assessed the images to identify and record any errors related to the palatoglossal air space shadow. The primary outcome measure was the effect of using different strips on reducing this error. The study found promising results, with a 99% success rate in the celluloid matrix tape group and 90% in the fruit leather strip group. These findings suggest that using these strips can effectively reduce the palatoglossal air space shadow error in panoramic imaging.

This clinical trial aims to compare the acute effects of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT), kinesio taping (KT), and placebo ESWT on pain level, lower extremity functionality, and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis. The study will include adult patients diagnosed with plantar fasciitis who are willing to participate. The patients will be divided into three groups: ESWT, ESWT and KT, and placebo ESWT. The primary outcome measures will be pain level measured using the visual analogue scale (VAS), and lower extremity functionality measured using the Lower Extremity Functional Scale. The study will evaluate the patients before and one week after treatment. The interventions include ESWT, placebo ESWT with the sound of the device, and ESWT with KT. The study aims to provide insights into the effectiveness of these treatments for plantar fasciitis.

This clinical trial aims to establish a couple intervention program for adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study will involve behavioral couple group therapy as the intervention. The eligibility criteria include having either a diagnosis of ASD or a high autism spectrum quotient score, being able to communicate in Chinese, and having a Wechsler Intelligence score above 70. The study is designed as a single-group assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measures include the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule, Autism Spectrum Quotient, Empathy Quotient, Social Responsiveness Scale, and Quality of socialization questionnaire. The study will measure these outcomes over a period of 6 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of individually tailored physical exercise in patients with Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) after COVID-19. The study will include 60 adult patients diagnosed with POTS and post COVID-19 condition. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will undergo a 16-week individually tailored exercise program supervised by a physiotherapist, while the control group will receive standard care. The primary outcome measures include changes in time spent in an upright position and steps per day, as well as changes in health-related quality of life. Secondary outcome measures include changes in walking distance, oxygen saturation, dyspnea, leg fatigue, exertion, heart rate, self-reported POTS symptoms, anxiety, depression, fatigue, physical function, blood pressure, respiratory rate, orthostatic symptoms, insomnia, workability, muscle strength, post-exertional malaise, and pharmacological treatment of POTS. The study will also assess compliance to the intervention. Data will be collected at baseline, after 16 weeks, and at 6 and 12 months follow-up.

The BRANT study is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint, parallel controlled trial. The primary objective is to determine whether intravenous tirofiban is effective in increasing the proportion of excellent functional outcome at 90 days in patients with acute branch atheromatous disease (BAD)-related stroke. The study will enroll patients between 18 and 75 years old who can be randomized within 48 hours of stroke onset and meet the BAD Diagnostic Imaging Criteria. The study will compare tirofiban with standard antiplatelet therapy based on guideline. The primary outcome measure is excellent functional outcome at 90 days, and the primary safety outcome is the proportion of major bleeding. Secondary outcome measures include early neurological deterioration, NIHSS score, Barthel index score, ischemic stroke, stroke, TIA, composite endpoint, proportion of major bleeding, serious adverse events, adverse events, all-cause death, and various changes in blood test results.

This clinical trial aims to assess the utilization of personalized pacing to improve the quality of life in patients with sinus node dysfunction. The study will include patients who are 60 years old or above and have plans to implant a dual-chamber pacemaker. The intervention involves adjusting the pacemaker lower rate setting. The primary outcome measure will be the measurement of life quality using the SF-36 questionnaire score. Secondary outcome measures include measuring cardiac functional changes and assessing the correlation between elevated blood pressure and bradycardia. The study will be conducted within three months after the surgery.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of remote diagnosis and treatment on the 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure rhythm of patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The study will randomly divide patients into a telemedicine group and an outpatient group and compare the ambulatory blood pressure improvement after 3 months of APAP treatment between the two groups. The researchers will also compare healthcare costs, patient costs, compliance, subjective symptoms, and cardiovascular risk biomarkers between the two groups. The study will classify the subtypes of OSA and evaluate the response to blood pressure improvement after APAP treatment. The study has begun recruiting patients for the pilot study.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the influence of communication between nursing staff and patients on the analgesic response following a caesarean section. The study will be carried out at Carmel Hospital's maternity ward and will include patients undergoing an elective caesarean section. The study will have two arms: an increased communication arm and a normal communication arm. Each arm will consist of 40 patients randomly assigned. The dependent variable is the treatment efficacy, measured by changes in pain intensity one hour after analgesic administration. The study will also use the Self-Consciousness Scale (SCS-R) and the Short Suggestibility Scale (SSS) to assess relevant personality traits. The study design is a parallel assignment, with the primary outcome measure being the change in pain intensity on a 0-10 pain scale one hour after analgesic administration.

This clinical trial aims to assess novel biomarkers in participants undergoing targeted lung health checks for the detection of lung cancer. The study will involve adults aged between 55 and 74 years who have attended visits as part of the NCL NHS TLHC program. The primary outcome measure is to identify novel molecular, immune, and clinical biomarkers to improve the accuracy of lung cancer screening. The study will include proteomics, metabolomics, genomics, and immune repertoire characterization performed on peripheral blood samples. The study is expected to last for a duration of 5 years.

This clinical trial, titled "Evaluation of the Effectiveness of Telepharmacy on Clinical Outcomes of Patients With Arterial Hypertension: Celeste Randomized Clinical Trial," aims to assess the impact of telepharmacy on patients with arterial hypertension. The trial will compare the acceptance and clinical importance of pharmacist interventions between the telepharmacy and in-person groups, evaluate patient adherence to medication treatment and patient satisfaction in both groups, and compare satisfaction between the two groups. The study will include elderly patients with uncontrolled blood pressure and will measure primary outcomes such as controlling blood pressure, adherence to treatment, patient satisfaction, and the level of clinical significance of interventions. The trial will be randomized with parallel assignment and will involve pharmaceutical care via telepharmacy and usual care in the experimental group, and in-person pharmaceutical care and usual care in the control group. The study will last for three months.

The ICU LIBERATION Study aims to investigate the implementation of evidence-based ICU care for patients with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) and its impact on patient outcomes. ARDS is a condition associated with high mortality rates and functional impairments. The study will assess the current epidemiology and treatment strategies for ARDS patients, evaluate the implementation of ICU care, and examine its association with patient outcomes. The study will be conducted at multiple centers worldwide and aims to contribute to the development of ICU care guidelines and improve outcomes for ARDS patients globally. The study will measure mortality, compliance with lung-protective ventilation, implementation rates of the ABCDEF bundle (a set of interventions for ICU care), and the incidence of Post Intensive Care Syndrome. Patients on invasive or non-invasive ventilators who meet the diagnosis of ARDS are eligible for participation. The study will provide valuable data for future research and interventions.

The clinical trial, titled "Effect of Pomanox® on Skin Ageing (POMASKIN)," aims to evaluate the effects of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 on hyperpigmented skin spots in humans. The study also aims to assess the effects on other parameters related to skin ageing, collagen and hyaluronic acid metabolism, oxidative stress, the anti-glycan effect, the inflammatory system, and the composition of the intestinal and skin microbiota. The trial will be a randomized, parallel, placebo-controlled, single-center, triple-blind study with 66 participants. Each participant will have four visits over the course of the study. The primary outcome measure is the change in skin melanin index, while secondary outcome measures include changes in skin wrinkles, hydration, elasticity, erythema index, pores, acne, keratin, collagen and hyaluronic acid blood levels, oxidative stress markers, inflammatory markers, and microbiota composition. The study will also assess the participants' self-assessment of skin quality and various anthropometric measurements. The trial will assess the compliance of the participants, record any adverse events, and evaluate various lifestyle factors such as diet, physical activity, and exposure to ultraviolet radiation.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of gut microbiota in prostate cancer. The study will involve two participant groups: one with benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) who will receive 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors, and the other with prostate cancer who will receive androgen deprivation therapy. The gut microbiota and metabolite sampling will be collected before and after the medication treatment. The study will measure the gut microbiota signatures and metabolic characteristics in relation to the medication. The primary outcome measures include the gut microbiota signatures before and after the medication treatments, while the secondary outcome measures include the metabolic characteristics in the gut and systemic circulation.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) markers in glioma genomics. The study will include patients with glioma who meet specific inclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure is the correlation between metabolite concentrations measured by MRS and IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion derived from tumor tissue samples. Secondary outcome measures include correlations between diffusion MRI metrics and 1p19q codeletion status, metabolic changes during anti-tumor treatment, and diffusion MRI and amide proton transfer signal changes during anti-tumor treatment. The study design is a single group assignment with an intervention of MRI examination. The study does not accept healthy volunteers. The study is being conducted by the Centre Hospitalier Valida and the keywords associated with the study include gliomas, isocitrate dehydrogenase, 1p19q codeletion, MR spectroscopy, MRI, diagnosis, and treatment monitoring.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of a combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in patients with beta-thalassemia. The study involves administering hydroxyurea alone for 6 months, followed by the addition of thalidomide. Patients also receive aspirin to prevent thrombosis. Blood transfusions are given as needed. The study measures response to the therapy, changes in laboratory levels, and changes in liver and spleen size. The safety of the treatment is monitored based on certain parameters. The trial is open-label and includes patients with beta-thalassemia major and intermedia who have not responded well to hydroxyurea.

This clinical trial aims to determine the role of diagnostic imaging in the patient journey for individuals with active or healed leg ulcers. The study will assess current practices for venous leg ulcer management in primary care and in vascular scientist departments across the UK. It will also establish the minimum diagnostics required for this patient population and evaluate the cost effectiveness of implementing these practices in primary and secondary care settings. The study will involve questionnaire-based surveys for primary care practitioners and vascular scientists. The primary outcome measures will assess current practices and availability of services in primary care and vascular scientist departments.

This clinical trial aims to enhance prospective thinking in early recovery for individuals with stimulant use and substance use disorders. The intervention involves the use of virtual reality, specifically a virtual reality park experience with or without avatars resembling the participants. The study will measure outcomes such as reduced drug use, increased length of abstinence, increased overall abstinence, future self-identification, future time perspective, and delayed reward preference. The trial is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment study with a control group receiving treatment as usual. Participants must be between 18 and 1 year old and meet certain eligibility criteria.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the stability of short implants compared to standard length implants with internal sinus floor elevation in the posterior maxilla. The study will assess the crestal bone level using radiographs as the primary outcome measure. The trial will involve randomized participants who meet specific eligibility criteria, and the interventions will involve surgery for implant placement. The study design is a parallel assignment with a single masking.

This clinical trial is investigating the use of Wharton's Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cell (WJ-MSC) injections as a prophylactic treatment for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in patients undergoing hematopoietic allogeneic stem cell transplantation with a haplo-identical donor. The study aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose of WJ-MSC and evaluate its efficacy in preventing acute and chronic GVHD, toxicity-related mortality, relapse incidence, overall survival, graft-versus-host disease and relapse-free survival, and poor graft function. The trial is designed as a dose escalation study with a single group assignment and no masking. The study will enroll participants between the ages of 18 and 70, and healthy volunteers are not eligible to participate.

This clinical trial aims to implement a clinical decision support tool called eCARTv5, which combines a machine learning algorithm with clinical pathways to identify high-risk patients in medical-surgical units. The goal is to improve outcomes and allocate critical resources more effectively. The trial will compare the use of eCARTv5 to standard care in terms of ventilator utilization, length of stay, and mortality for high-risk patients. The study will also assess secondary outcomes such as total hospital length of stay, ICU-free days, and ventilator-free days. The trial will be non-randomized and will include adult patients with conditions such as sepsis, respiratory failure, and COVID-19. The intervention group will receive eCARTv5 monitoring, while the control group will receive standard care. The study will track these outcomes over a 12-month period.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) intervention in reducing perinatal depression in African-American mothers. The intervention targets the support of fathers in reducing maternal stress and promoting healthy maternal behaviors. The study will include 50 cohabitating or non-cohabitating fathers and African-American mothers who will be randomized into the intervention or comparator group. The primary outcome measure is maternal depressive symptoms, and secondary outcome measures include breastfeeding and parent-infant interactions. The study design is a pilot randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a proactive identification and digital mental health intervention approach for addressing the unmet psychosocial needs of individuals living with cancer. The study will focus on depression and depressive symptoms in cancer patients. The intervention includes the use of a Behavioral Activation Therapy app called Moodivate, which helps track daily activities, record mood, and identify new activities to improve mood. The control group will receive treatment as usual, including educational materials about mood management. The study will measure the proportion of eligible participants who enroll in the trial.

This clinical trial aims to assess new algorithms for detecting malfunctions in insulin pumps used by individuals with type 1 diabetes. The study consists of three phases: data collection in free-living conditions, induction of hyperglycemia in a clinic setting, and retrospective data analysis. The collected data will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of the algorithms in detecting insulin suspension. The study will measure the sensitivity of the algorithms in correctly detecting insulin suspensions and the number of false alarms per day. The trial is designed as a pilot study and will involve participants aged 18 to 70 years who have been using an automated insulin delivery system for at least 3 months.

This is an open-label, single-group study to evaluate the effect of Funk It Cycle Bites on premenstrual syndrome (PMS). The study will include female participants aged 18-40 with a regular menstrual cycle and mild to moderate menstrual pain. Participants must be generally healthy, willing to consume the test product with a ginger flavor, and refrain from taking any other supplements or prescription medications targeting the menstrual cycle or PMS symptoms. The study will assess changes in PMS symptoms, acne, pain levels, mood stability, and energy levels using survey-based assessments over a 4-month period. The study also includes a secondary outcome measure to assess participant enjoyment of the product. The intervention involves consuming 1 Cycle Bite per day, which contains various organic ingredients. The study design is an intervention model with a single group assignment and no masking.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of a personalized risk assessment tool (PERSARC) in reducing decisional conflict and increasing informed choices for patients with high-grade extremity soft-tissue sarcoma. The trial will be conducted in six Dutch hospitals and will compare standard care to care with the use of PERSARC. The outcomes will be measured at various time points, including decisional conflict, informed choice, regret, worry, involvement in decision-making, patient-reported outcomes, utilities for cost-effectiveness analysis, healthcare cost, and absenteeism from paid work. The study will also include a process evaluation to assess the use of PERSARC by patients and professionals, as well as satisfaction with its use. Patients eligible for the study must be at least 18 years old, have grade 2-3 extremity soft-tissue sarcoma, and be treated with curative intent.

This clinical trial aims to determine the prevalence of early childhood caries (ECC) in Jordanian children and its associated risk factors. It also seeks to study the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control material and its acceptance among parents. The study consists of a cross-sectional epidemiological survey of children attending kindergartens in Jordan, followed by a randomized controlled trial involving a subgroup of children who receive SDF treatment. The primary outcome measures include the prevalence of ECC, caries prevention, and caries arrest. Secondary outcome measures include the identification of risk factors for ECC and parental acceptance of SDF application. The study will follow the participants for one year.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine in preventing severe lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in older adults. The study will use a retrospective case-control design and a retrospective cohort design to analyze RSV-related outcomes and all-cause outcomes. The primary objective is to estimate the vaccine effectiveness of ABRYSVO against RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations. Secondary objectives include estimating vaccine effectiveness against RSV-related hospitalizations among high-risk groups, RSV-related acute respiratory tract infection hospitalizations, and emergency department visits. The study will also analyze vaccine effectiveness against additional all-cause acute respiratory infections and LRTIs. The analysis will consider factors such as comorbidity, RSV subgroup, severity, age, frailty, and demographic factors. The study will assess outcomes over a period of up to two years.

The OSsIRIS Study is a post-market clinical follow-up investigation to confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone in extremities and pelvis. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of bone grafting with b.Bone in promoting healing in surgically created bone defects or bone defects resulting from traumatic injury. The study will measure the radiographic healing/union after surgery as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include measuring patient-reported pain and quality of life, as well as evaluating the safety of b.Bone through adverse events and reinterventions. The study will enroll patients aged 18 and older and will not accept healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 24 months.

This clinical trial aims to study the prognostic significance of acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness in patients with acute on chronic liver failure (ACLF). The primary objective is to determine if changes in liver and splenic stiffness at day 7 from baseline can predict transplant-free survival at day 90. Secondary objectives include evaluating the associations between baseline and changes in liver and splenic stiffness with different etiologies of ACLF, grade of esophageal varices, pattern of organ failures, and levels of biochemical inflammatory markers. The study will be a 1-year prospective cohort study with a sample size of 200 ACLF patients. There will be no intervention in this study, and data will be analyzed using statistical methods. The study is designed to provide insights into the prognostic value of liver and splenic stiffness in ACLF patients.

This clinical trial aims to determine the optimal depth of injection for onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin in the treatment of glabellar lines. The study will compare the efficacy of injecting the neurotoxin at a depth of 2mm (superficial dermis) versus 4mm (intramuscularly). The primary objective is to assess the improvement of glabellar lines, while the secondary objective is to determine any adverse effects. The study will include patients aged 18 and older who are able to understand the study requirements and risks involved. Participants will be randomized to receive the neurotoxin injections at either 2mm or 4mm depth. The efficacy will be measured using the Merz aesthetics scale, and adverse effects will also be monitored. The study aims to establish the optimal depth of injection for maximum improvement of glabellar lines with minimal adverse effects.

This clinical trial examines the use of music therapy as a tool for reducing anxiety in localized breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. The study will evaluate the impact of music therapy on anxiety levels before the first and third chemotherapy sessions. The trial is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with one group receiving music therapy before the first three chemotherapy cycles and the other group receiving standard care with no intervention. The primary outcome measure is changes in anxiety levels measured using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate different conditioning regimens for HLA matched donor transplantation in severe aplastic anemia. The study will be a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled trial. The eligibility criteria include diagnosed severe aplastic anemia, availability of HLA matched sibling or unrelated donor, no active infection, and no serious organ damage. The study will have a treatment primary purpose and will use a parallel assignment intervention model with no masking. The primary outcome measure is failure-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include the incidence of mixed chimerism, regimen related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, incidence of graft versus host disease, incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation, incidence of transplantation related mortality, and probability of overall survival.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the safety and effectiveness of switching from the drug Emicizumab to Fitusiran for preventing bleeds in male participants aged 18 years or older with severe Hemophilia A. The study will assess the number of adverse events during the Fitusiran treatment period as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures include assessing thrombin generation, antithrombin levels, Emicizumab concentrations in plasma, overall treatment satisfaction, pain intensity, physical functioning and activity, joint health, and annualized bleeding rate. The study design is open-label, with participants receiving Fitusiran prophylaxis and other interventions as needed.

This clinical trial aims to translate and validate the Malay version of the painDETECT Questionnaire (PDQ-M) for neuropathic and nociceptive pain. Participants must be able to read and understand Malay, have been diagnosed with either neuropathic or nociceptive pain, and have a stable disease condition. The study will assess the reliability and validity of the PDQ-M by administering the questionnaire and collecting socio-demographic data. The primary outcome measure is the total PDQ-M scores, which will be assessed after 2-5 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to assess the safety and effectiveness of a community-based exercise program for stroke patients. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment trial. The intervention group will undergo a complex exercise program consisting of warm-up, flexibility exercises, aerobic exercise, interval training, strength and balance exercises, and a cool-down. The primary outcome measure is the 6-minute walk test, while secondary outcome measures include modified Rankin Scale, Berg balance scale, functional ambulation category, manual muscle testing, timed up and go test, grip strength, body composition, physical activity, Euro-Quality of Life-5 Dimension, geriatric depression scale, sit to stand test, flexibility test, and coordination test. The study will evaluate these measures at baseline and follow-up, which is expected to last an average of 6 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants aged 50 to 90 years with mild Alzheimer's disease. The study will assess adverse events, changes in disease activity, and how the oral ABBV-552 capsules move through the body. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either ABBV-552 or a placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog 14) score.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate cases of severe acute liver disease, specifically acute liver failure (ALF) and acute on chronic liver disease (ACLF). The study will assess the causes of the disease, complications, mortality and morbidity rates, and outcomes over a six-month follow-up period. Participants will be contacted for telephone interviews or follow-up visits. The study will include thorough history taking, clinical examinations, imaging tests, and laboratory investigations. The primary outcome measures will focus on liver and kidney function, as well as fluid overload. Secondary outcome measures will assess mortality and morbidity rates. The study is open to individuals aged 18 to 75 years, of any sex, and does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to determine the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on the quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study will be conducted at Adıyaman Besni State Hospital and will include individuals who have been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and are in the euthymic period. The sample size will be 54 participants. The data will be collected through face-to-face interviews using various scales and questionnaires. The primary outcome measure is the predictive effect of impulsivity on quality of life, while the secondary outcome measure is the predictive effect of coping skills on quality of life. The study will take place from October 2023 to February 2024.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the 2-year clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin restorative materials: OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma. The study compares these materials to the control group, Filtek Z250, which is a multi-color composite resin material. The primary outcome measures include retention, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, secondary caries, and postoperative sensitivity. The secondary outcome measures assess the clinical performance of the restorations according to the World Dental Organization criteria. The study design is a double-blind prospective randomized controlled trial, and the participants will undergo restoration with tooth-colored material. The study will assess the performance of the materials at 6, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of neuromuscular reversal agents on the time it takes to perform a neurological assessment after endotracheal intubation in critically ill patients. The study will randomize patients into three groups: a sugammadex group, a neostigmine group, and a control group. Neurological assessments will be conducted at regular intervals, and processed EEG and cerebral regional oxygen saturation will be monitored and recorded. The primary outcome measure is the time from administration of the neuromuscular blocker to the first available neurologic assessment. Secondary outcome measures include time to first available spontaneous eye opening, changes in Patient State index (PSi) values and regional cerebral oxygen saturation, time from intubation to extubation, length of hospital stay, and in-ICU and in-hospital mortality. The study will involve adult patients aged 19 years or older who have been intubated in the ICU. Patients with certain conditions or taking certain medications will be excluded from the study. The study design is randomized, with parallel assignment and masking.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia. The study will include participants with complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer. The intervention includes the use of a telemedicine behavioral weight loss program and the administration of progestin through a levonorgestrel-releasing IUD. The study will measure the number of participants with atypia-free biopsy with uterine preservation as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include time to resolution of hyperplasia, change in weight, change in cancer worry impact events scale, and atypia-free survival or endometrial cancer-free survival. The study design is a randomized crossover assignment with two arms: one receiving the behavioral weight loss intervention and the other receiving enhanced usual care.

The clinical trial is titled "The Coconut Technique - A New Method to Perform Safe Cholecystectomy for Acute Cholecystitis: Our Initial Experience." The study aims to evaluate a new laparoscopic technique called the Coconut technique for performing cholecystectomy in cases of acute cholecystitis. The technique involves cutting the inflamed gallbladder wall, making an incision at the junction of the infundibulum and the body of the gallbladder, and identifying the confluence between the cystic duct and the body of the gallbladder. The primary outcome measure of the study is the success of the technique in safely performing the procedure. The study includes patients diagnosed with stage II acute cholecystitis and excludes those with stage I cholecystectomy. The study is expected to be conducted over a period of two years.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effectiveness of a Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol enriched with virtual reality (VR) in addressing psychological problems experienced by athletes after anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) surgery. The study will involve 60 athletes and will use a mixed factorial design with four groups: CBT+VR, VR only, CBT only, and a control group. The primary outcome measures will assess re-injury anxiety, rehabilitation adherence, self-efficacy, and kinesiophobia. The study will provide valuable insights into the use of CBT and VR in supporting physical rehabilitation after ACL surgery.

This clinical trial aims to assess the development and implementation of the PT-PENCIL tool, an electronic clinical decision support tool for physical therapists in acute care hospitals. The tool is designed to guide optimal treatment frequency and improve the proportion of patients who are discharged home. The trial will analyze the effect of using the PT-PENCIL on the proportion of patients discharged home and assess its reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility. The study will include patients admitted for at least one overnight stay and will measure outcomes such as the effectiveness of evaluation on discharge home, reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL. The trial will last for 24 weeks and will involve physical therapists completing various measures to assess the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the intervention.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing in treating patients with metastatic colorectal cancer. The study will involve patients with documented adenocarcinoma of the colon or rectum, with an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Performance Status of 0-2 and a life expectancy of at least 6 months. The intervention will consist of a 7-Form of Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing program, lasting 60 minutes, three times a week for eight weeks, led by an experienced Tai Chi instructor. The primary outcome measure will be adherence rates, measured by the number of Tai Chi sessions performed. Secondary outcome measures will include fatigue, sleep quality, quality of life, anxiety, and depression. The study will be a single-arm, prospective, exploratory study, and will not involve masking. The study will enroll participants aged 18 to 75 years, of any gender, and will not include healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of an educational intervention called the Survivorship ECHO in improving provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices. The study will also evaluate the implementation of these practices into clinical practice and documentation. Participants will attend six sessions of the educational intervention over 12 weeks and may also participate in a one-on-one interview. The study will measure changes in provider understanding of key survivorship knowledge areas, as well as explore participant needs, the acceptability of the intervention, and barriers to accessing it. The trial will be conducted with providers from The James Cancer Network in Ohio.

This clinical trial compares the effectiveness of two interventions, post facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization, in improving range of motion in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow. The trial is a randomized controlled study with a sample size of 32 participants. The primary outcome measures include changes in pain rating, range of motion in elbow flexion and extension, and range of motion in forearm supination and pronation. The secondary outcome measure is changes in disability measured through the DASH questionnaire. The study design is a parallel assignment with double masking. The interventions consist of specific exercises and hot pack therapy. The study aims to determine which intervention is more effective in improving range of motion and reducing disability in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of a multidisciplinary approach for the early diagnosis of heart failure in high-risk patients. The study will include individuals aged 40 years and above who have at least two additional risk factors for heart failure. Participants will be randomized into two groups: the experimental group, which will receive an AI-enabled handheld echocardiogram in addition to standard care, and the control group, which will receive routine care. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of heart failure within 6 months from randomization. Secondary outcome measures include the diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and the use of guideline-directed medical therapy for HFrEF.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of Ringer's acetate and lower body negative pressure on central and cerebral hemodynamics and volume kinetics during experimental hypovolemia compared to euvolemia in healthy human volunteers. The study will measure cardiac stroke volume, intravascular volume, and middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity as primary and secondary outcome measures. The study design is a randomized crossover assignment with four participant groups receiving different interventions. The study will last for 120 minutes.

The clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects and cost-effectiveness of eMeistring, a guided internet-delivered psychological treatment, for moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. The study involves patients recruited through ordinary clinical patient pathways who meet the inclusion criteria and have computer and internet access. The intervention includes therapist-guided internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy sessions. The primary outcome measures include depression severity, social phobia, and panic disorder symptoms. The secondary outcome measures include health-related quality of life, work and social adjustment, anxiety severity, system usability, cost of healthcare services, medication use, work participation, and sickness absenteeism. The study will analyze the effectiveness, drop-out and adherence predictors, and cost-effectiveness based on patient groups and location differences.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of TLIP (Thoracolumbar Interfascial Plane) block and ESP (Erector Spinae Plane) block in providing perioperative analgesia for patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery. The study involves three groups: a TLIP group, an ESP group, and a control group. The TLIP group receives TLIP block anesthesia before surgery, the ESP group receives ESP block anesthesia before surgery, and the control group receives regular endotracheal anesthesia. All patients are monitored throughout the surgery, and pain relief is provided using paracetamol, ketorolac, and morphine as needed. The study measures the sensory blockade area, the effectiveness of pain relief during and after surgery, and the occurrence of side effects.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the accuracy of a wearable blood oxygen sensor called MABOS in patients of color. The study will include participants with skin tones associated with African, East Asian, and European descent. The participants will have both the MABOS sensor and a FDA-approved pulse oximeter called Nonin PureSat placed on them to collect biometric data for 90 minutes. The primary outcome measures of the study include assessing device safety and comfort through qualitative surveys. The secondary outcome measures involve confirming the device's ability to differentiate skin tone using light wavelengths and comparing the blood oxygen level estimation of the device to the FDA-approved oximeter.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of using FP-1201 (Interferon-Beta-1a) to prevent toxicities after CD19-Directed CAR T-Cell Therapy in patients with recurrent or refractory B-cell lymphoma or lymphocytic leukemia. The study involves administering FP-1201 intravenously for a specified duration, along with other procedures such as imaging, biopsies, and blood sample collection. The primary outcome measures include dose-limiting toxicity rates and the incidence of adverse events, while secondary outcome measures include cytokine release syndrome rates, immune effector cell associated-neurotoxicity syndrome rates, cumulative corticosteroids dose, overall response rate, and complete response rate. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial is a randomized, open-label, multicenter phase III study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Camrelizumab plus chemotherapy with or without Famitinib as neoadjuvant therapy in participants with triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). The study will assess the pathological complete response (pCR) rate as the primary outcome measure, as well as event-free survival (EFS), disease-free survival (DFS), distant disease-free survival (DDFS), and objective response rate (ORR) as secondary outcome measures. The study will include participants with an ECOG Performance Status of 0-1, early or locally advanced TNBC, and adequate hematologic and organ function. Participants must not have a history of breast cancer or invasive malignancy within the past 5 years, and must not have received prior chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiation therapy within the past 12 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either Camrelizumab plus chemotherapy and Famitinib or Camrelizumab plus chemotherapy. The study will assess the outcomes over a period of approximately 2 years.

This clinical trial aims to determine the early prediction of postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) based on their gestational metabolic and lipid profiles. The study will include pregnant women diagnosed with GDM between 24-28 weeks of gestation who are willing to participate and have no other pregnancy complications. The participants will be divided into two groups based on their postpartum glucose metabolism results, and a questionnaire survey and specimen collection will be conducted. The study will measure the serum lipidomics and metabolomics during the 24-28 gestational weeks to identify markers associated with postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in GDM.

This clinical trial, titled "Assessment of Sleep Quality of Hospitalized Patients Treated With EEG-guided Protection Procedures: Application in Intensive Care Unit," aims to assess the sleep quality of hospitalized patients in the intensive care unit (ICU) using EEG-guided protection procedures. The study will involve adult patients admitted to the medical ICU of the University Hospital of Poitiers. The participants will be divided into two groups: a control group receiving usual care and an experimental group receiving EEG-guided sleep protection. The primary outcome measure of the study is the proportion of continuous sleep on day 1. Secondary outcome measures include sleep fragmentation, environmental noise and light, sleep interruptions by caregivers, sleep quality on days 2 to 4, workload assessed by nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient-reported sleep quality, anxiety level, respiratory status, presence of delirium, unit care length of stay, and safety of the procedure. The study design is non-randomized with sequential assignment and open-label masking. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of EEG-guided sleep protection in improving sleep quality in critically ill patients in the ICU.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAR441566 in adults with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis. The study will last for approximately 149 days for each participant. The trial is a phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging study. Participants will receive either SAR441566 or a placebo in addition to methotrexate. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants achieving at least a 20% improvement in the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) score at week 12. Secondary outcome measures include changes in disease activity score, proportions of participants achieving at least a 50% improvement in the ACR score, adverse events, and plasma concentrations of SAR441566.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the performance of the in-vitro diagnostics medical device MaGIA IBC for the combined screening of HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C. The study will include participants who are at least 18 years old and receive care at Hôpital Européen de Marseille. The study will assess the diagnostic accuracy of the MaGIA IBC test in capillary blood and other matrices, such as veinous blood, serum, and plasma. The primary outcome measures include calculating the ROC AUC for HIV, HBV, and HCV diagnostics, as well as determining the proportion of positive and negative test results among participants with or without HIV, HBV, or HCV. The study will also evaluate the concordance of diagnostic results obtained from different matrices and assess any study-related adverse events.

This clinical trial is evaluating the effectiveness of the food supplement Endocalyx Pro in reducing sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure. The trial also aims to assess if Endocalyx improves physical limitations, fluid overload symptoms, quality of life, and microcirculation characteristics. Additionally, the study will investigate the working mechanisms of Endocalyx, its effects on tissue sodium content, total body water, body weight, blood pressure, peripheral resistance, cardiac output, systemic inflammation, and monocyte activation. The safety of Endocalyx will also be confirmed by comparing the incidence of adverse events with a placebo. The trial is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study and will measure various outcomes such as changes in NT-proBNP levels, blood pressure, total body water, body weight, hemodynamic parameters, monocyte subsets, and quality of life.

This clinical trial aims to optimize the treatment of adhesive small bowel obstruction (aSBO). The study will compare the use of nasogastric tubes (NGT) and water-soluble contrast (WSC) with other treatment methods. The participants will be allocated into three groups: one group treated without NG tubes, one group treated with NG tubes and WSC, and one group treated with NG tubes and saline. The primary outcome measure will be the quality of life assessed using the PROMIS-29 HRQOL instrument. The study aims to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of different treatment approaches for aSBO.

This clinical trial aims to test a novel combination therapeutic strategy for functional cure of chronic Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) infection. The study will involve the use of an anti-PD-1 antibody, NAs (nucleos(t)ide analogues), and Peg-IFNα (pegylated interferon alpha). The trial will include participants who are 18-70 years old and meet certain eligibility criteria. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to different treatment groups. The primary outcome measures of the study will include serum HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen), serum HBV DNA, and serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels at various time points. The study aims to assess the efficacy of the combination therapy in achieving sustained HBsAg loss and functional cure for chronic HBV infection.

This clinical trial aims to compare the wound healing outcomes of two different suture techniques (simple and continuous) in oral surgery. The study will include participants between the ages of 40 and 65, with no specific gender requirements. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the simple suture group or the continuous suture group. The primary outcome measures include scoring of wound healing according to the Laundry Healing Index and the Early Wound Healing Score at different time points (day 1, day 3, and day 7). Other measures such as suture time, knot looseness, pain at suture removal, and suture removal difficulty will also be assessed. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of different suture techniques in oral surgery wound healing.

This clinical trial aims to explore the feasibility and utility of using an in-home body weight support harness system in children with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA). The study will include children with SMA Type I and Type II who have a confirmed mutation in the SMN1 gene and 2 or 3 copies of the SMN2 gene. The intervention involves the use of a portable, adjustable body weight support harness system that allows for 360 degrees of mobility. The primary outcome measures include a caregiver survey to assess the perceived impact of the harness system on motor and non-motor skills, as well as measures of motor function using various scales. Secondary outcome measures include a harness use log to document frequency and duration of system use. The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to assess the serious complication rate and visual efficacy of DMEK Endothelial Keratoplasty in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery. The study will measure the occurrence rate of serious post-operative complications, such as graft detachment, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema, at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include the occurrence rates of rebulling, intraocular hypertension, and graft detachment, as well as the surgeon's subjective assessment of surgical complexity and the duration of the surgical procedure. The study will also evaluate the evolution of visual and refractive results, endothelial loss, corneal thickness, and posterior keratometry at various time points after surgery.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the mechanism of oral antibiotic prophylaxis in elective colon and rectal surgery with primary anastomosis. The study will focus on the correlation between septic complications and the microbiome, as well as other factors that may influence the microbiome, such as comorbidities, previous operations, and systemic intravenous prophylaxis. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving oral antibiotic prophylaxis along with mechanical bowel preparation, and the other receiving only mechanical bowel preparation. The primary outcome measure will be the presence of a correlation between septic complications and the microbiome. The study will take place over a postoperative period of 30 days.

This clinical trial aims to assess the utility of measurements made at the point of the maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The study will involve patients with CTS and healthy controls who will undergo nerve conduction studies and ultrasounds to measure the cross-sectional area, diameter, and echogenicity of the median nerve at various points, including the point of maximal stenosis. The location of the stenosis will also be evaluated. The study will compare these measurements between patients and healthy volunteers and correlate them with the clinical severity of CTS. The primary outcome measures include differences in the diameter, cross-sectional area, and echogenicity of the median nerve between patients with CTS and healthy controls. Secondary outcome measures include correlations of these measurements with the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire score and the grade of electrophysiological severity. The study is expected to be completed in approximately 1 year.

This clinical trial aims to optimize the safety and symptom burden of Tocilizumab in patients with multiple myeloma undergoing autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation following high-dose melphalan conditioning. The study will assess the severity and impact of cancer-related symptoms using the MDASI questionnaire and record any adverse events. The trial will include patients aged 18 to 70 years and will be randomized with parallel assignment. The intervention group will receive Tocilizumab, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The study will evaluate the outcomes at day -7 and day 100 after stem cell transfusion.

This clinical trial compares the outcomes of two different approaches, Testicular Sperm Aspiration (TESA) and Microfluidic Sperm Separation (MSS), in couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation who are undergoing ICSI (intracytoplasmic sperm injection). The study aims to determine which approach is better in terms of clinical pregnancy rate and the number of utilizable blastocysts obtained. Men with high DNA fragmentation (>20%) are eligible to participate. The study will compare the outcomes of TESA-ICSI and Zymot-ICSI.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance in archery athletes. The study includes 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18 who have been engaged in archery for at least 1 year. The athletes will undergo evaluations for musculoskeletal system, stability tests at the cervical, lumbal, and scapular levels, and assessments for pain, balance, posture, and upper extremity performance. Shooting performances will be evaluated with target shootings. The study will measure outcomes such as cervical stabilization, lumbar stabilization grade, scapular dyskinesis type and amount, sportive performance, balance assessment, posture, disability, upper extremity performance, hand grip strength, and muscle tightness.

This clinical trial aims to develop and test a chatbot communication training intervention to improve contraception discussions between pediatricians, adolescents, and their mothers. The study will involve three stages: characterizing communication interactions, developing an AI communication training tool, and testing the tool's effectiveness. The intervention involves training pediatrician learners with a chatbot that simulates a mother and daughter for practicing contraception communication. The study will evaluate the quality of communication interactions before and after training and assess the acceptability and feasibility of the tool. The primary outcome measures include questionnaires to determine communication interactions, while secondary outcome measures include acceptability and feasibility questionnaires.

This clinical trial aims to investigate healthcare disparities in vitiligo, a skin condition. The study will estimate the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo in the overall population and different sociodemographic groups. It will also analyze health-related disparities in people with vitiligo, including mental health conditions, healthcare utilization, and work impact. The study will use survival models and statistical analyses to assess associations between baseline characteristics and the outcome of interest. The trial will be a population-based cohort study conducted in the UK, and it will involve observational analysis of usual care without any intervention. The primary outcome measure is the disease burden of vitiligo measured using cumulative lifetime incidence against age. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence and prevalence of mental health conditions, primary care encounters, dermatology referrals, mental health referrals, unemployment, and time off work. The study will include adults and adolescents aged 13 and above, and the maximum age for eligibility is 95 years.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of behavior modification using a hybrid mode on stress, self-efficacy, relationships, and conflict in caregivers of toddlers receiving early intervention. Caregivers were randomly assigned to either the hybrid group or the self-learning group. The hybrid group received online sessions, individual consultation sessions, and reminders, while the self-learning group only received a description of the course goals and reading material. The outcome measures included intervention fidelity, parenting sense of confidence, parenting stress, conflict tactics, and satisfaction. The study design was a randomized, parallel assignment with a single-blind assessment. The data will be analyzed using statistical tests. The primary outcome measures were intervention fidelity and parenting sense of confidence, while the secondary outcome measures included parenting stress, conflict tactics, and satisfaction.
