This clinical trial aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose and recommended Phase II dose of trotabresib in combination with vinorelbine for the treatment of HER2+ breast cancer with central nervous system or leptomeningeal metastasis. The trial will measure progression-free survival, overall survival, and response rate as primary and secondary objectives. The study will consist of two cohorts, with patients undergoing radiation therapy followed by trotabresib and vinorelbine treatment. The trial will also explore other exploratory objectives, such as disease monitoring and evaluation of treatment response using imaging. The study will collect data on adverse events and will involve various procedures, such as biospecimen collection, computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, radiation therapy, and resection. Eligible patients must have a histologically or cytologically confirmed diagnosis of HER2+ breast cancer and newly diagnosed or progressive brain and/or leptomeningeal metastases. The study design is non-randomized, and participants will be allocated to different arms based on their treatment plan. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of the treatment regimen and follow patients for up to 1 year.

This clinical trial aims to modify and adapt a program to be a culturally-relevant digital health tool for treating binge eating and weight management in Black women with obesity. The trial will examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health tool in a randomized clinical trial. The intervention involves a digital treatment of Appetite Awareness Treatment (AAT) and behavioral weight loss treatment (BWL) delivered remotely over 6 months. The primary outcomes measured include feasibility, retention, and attendance, while the secondary outcomes include changes in weight regain and number of binge eating episodes. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with an open-label approach. Participants must be over 18 years old, have a BMI ≥ 30 kg/m^2, regularly use a Bluetooth-enabled smartphone, and report at least one binge eating episode weekly. Exclusion criteria include pregnancy, substance abuse treatment, involvement in another weight reduction program, history of anorexia, purging, current treatment for eating difficulties, and consuming >4 alcoholic beverages/day. The study will recruit eligible adults and assess their retention and attendance rates over a 6-month period, as well as measure changes in weight regain and binge eating episodes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of different doses of beetroot juice supplementation on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise. The study will explore the potential benefits of beetroot juice, which is rich in inorganic nitrate, on muscle contractility, force production, and blood flow distribution. The trial will assess the impact of low, moderate, and high doses of nitrate-rich beetroot juice compared to a nitrate-depleted beetroot juice placebo. The study will measure various neuromuscular performance parameters, such as power, velocity, and jump height, as well as plasma nitrate and nitrite concentrations. The trial will provide valuable insights for practitioners and scientists interested in enhancing performance and exploring the efficacy of beetroot juice as a dietary nitrate supplement.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of two different intra-abdominal pressure levels on mechanical power in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The study will measure the mechanical power values during the operation and record any cases of ventilator-induced lung injury. The trial will include patients with ASA 1-2 and exclude patients with ASA 3-4, lung disease, pregnancy, morbid obesity, and unstable conditions. Two groups will be formed with different intra-abdominal pressure levels (12 mmHg and 14 mmHg) during the surgery, and mechanical power values will be measured at various time points. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of ventilator-induced lung injury.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) as an alternative to Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT) for assessing furcation involvement in molars. The study will include patients with grade II or III furcation involvement who require a CBCT. Patients with contraindications to MRI will be excluded. The primary outcome measure will be the assessment of horizontal furcation defects, while the secondary outcome measures will include horizontal and vertical bone loss. The study is open to participants of all sexes and accepts healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to compare the plaque removal efficacy of electric toothbrushes between children with Attention Deficit and Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and healthy children. The study includes 52 children, with 26 in the ADHD group and 26 in the control group. The children are divided into subgroups based on the type of toothbrush used (electric or manual). The effectiveness of the toothbrushes is evaluated by measuring the Gingival Index, Turesky modification of Quigley-Hein Plaque Index, and Approximal Plaque Index at baseline, 1st month, and 3rd month. The study also measures the DMFT index and dft index to assess the risk of dental caries. A questionnaire is used to gather information on nutrition, diet, tooth brushing habits, and sociodemographic factors.

This clinical trial is a prospective, single-arm, open-label study that aims to investigate the feasibility and stability of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) using a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead in patients with symptomatic bradycardia. The study plans to enroll 120 consecutive patients, with an estimated sample size of 150 due to a potential 20% dropout rate. The patients will undergo LBBAP implantation using Solia S leads in combination with any legally marketed BIOTRONIK pacemaker system. The primary outcome measure is the implant success rate at 12 months, which includes evaluating the ability of the system to appropriately sense and deliver pacing. Secondary outcome measures include fluoroscopic exposure time, intra-operative intracardiac electrogram, post-operative imaging data, changes in paced 12-lead electrocardiogram and intracardiac EGM, changes in echocardiography parameters, and changes in pacing parameters. The study is open to adult patients aged 20 years and above with standard bradycardia pacing indications.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two sonic electric toothbrushes and two manual toothbrushes in reducing gingival inflammation in pregnant women aged 18 to 40. The study will randomly assign participants to one of four groups, each using a different type of toothbrush for three months. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of gingival bleeding during pregnancy, with secondary measures including bleeding on probing, gingival inflammation, dental plaque, gingival attachment, periodontal pocket probing depth, and customer satisfaction. The trial will provide valuable insights into the efficacy of different toothbrushes in managing gingival inflammation in pregnant women.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of yoga-based breathing styles on the human brain, specifically focusing on memory performance. The trial will involve adult participants with no prior experience in yoga or meditation. The main questions the trial seeks to answer are whether there is an improvement in memory performance through yoga-based breathing exercises and whether there is a reduction in subjective stress levels. Participants will undergo a memory test while performing controlled nasal and oral breathing. After the test, they will undergo a two-week training period with daily nasal or mouth breathing training or no training at all, depending on their assigned group. The nasal breathing group will be compared to the mouth breathing group and the comparison group to determine if nasal breathing results in a significant improvement in memory capacity. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with an open-label approach. The primary outcome measure is the improvement of learned images, while the secondary outcome measure is the reduction of subjective stress levels.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of calisthenics exercise and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function in patients with burn injuries. The study will measure the concentration of liver enzymes in the blood before and after the treatment. The participants will be divided into three groups: one group will perform calisthenics exercises, one group will receive pulsed electromagnetic therapy, and one group will receive both interventions. The interventions will be conducted three times a week for three months. The study will include patients aged 20-45 years with burns ranging from 30% to 50% of their body surface area. The trial will be randomized and double-masked.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of a nutritional intervention on the bioavailability and immune activity of PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study hypothesizes that high energy/high protein nutritional supplements can decrease protein clearance, including drug clearance, in NSCLC patients receiving anti-PD-1 ICI, leading to improved treatment response. The primary objective is to assess the variability of pembrolizumab clearance during a 12-week nutritional intervention period. Secondary objectives include evaluating the feasibility of patient recruitment and compliance with the study protocol, as well as gathering data on various parameters related to nutrition, immune function, and microbiome status. The study design involves patients starting the nutritional intervention prior to the first ICI infusion and continuing for 12 weeks. Blood samples, questionnaires, and fecal specimens will be collected at various time points during treatment. The study is expected to provide insights into the impact of nutritional intervention on PD-1 ICI efficacy and patient outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to identify common signaling pathways and molecular targets in anxiety and major depressive disorders. The study consists of two parts: one involving human participants and the other involving murine models. In the human part, 10 patients with anxiety-depressive disorder and 10 healthy controls will be recruited. Participants will undergo clinical evaluations, neuroimaging sessions, and assessments of depressive and anxiety symptoms. The neuroimaging session will include T1-weighted image acquisition, fMRI, and 1H-MRS to study brain structure and glutamatergic neurotransmission. In the murine part, Pcdh9 deficits will be studied to assess their effect on excitatory synapses. Glutamatergic signaling and the interaction between integrin β3 and Protocadherin 9 will also be investigated. The study will provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying anxiety and major depressive disorders.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the association between cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and the intestinal microbiome using multi-omics big data. The study will collect data from patients with cardiovascular and neurological diseases, as well as healthy individuals, including blood and stool samples. Genome and transcriptome sequencing will be performed on the collected blood samples, while metagenomic sequencing and metometabolic and proteomic sequencing will be performed on the fecal samples. The primary outcome measures include stool sampling and blood collection. The study plans to involve nearly 500 sequencing objects and yield hundreds of terabytes of omics data. The findings from this study will contribute to the understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and may provide targets for their diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the prognostic value of a combined approach using KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations and pre-therapeutic FDG-PET/CT radiomic analysis in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with PDL1 ≥ 50% who are treated with pembrolizumab. The trial seeks to identify biomarkers that can predict patient response to pembrolizumab and survival outcomes, specifically looking at progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). The study will include patients with stage III and IV NSCLC who have not received previous systemic treatment for NSCLC. The primary outcome measure is PFS, while the secondary outcome measure is OS. The study will also analyze the presence of KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations and conduct radiomic analysis using FDG-PET/CT scans.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical efficacy of sacituzumab govitecan (SG), either alone or in combination with atezolizumab, in patients with rare metastatic genitourinary (GU) tumors such as small cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder/urinary tract, renal medullary carcinoma, and penile cancer. The study is open-label and non-randomized, with two arms. All participants will receive SG, and those without prior treatment with PD-1/PD-L1 axis immune checkpoint inhibitors will also receive atezolizumab. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate (ORR), while secondary outcome measures include duration of response, overall survival, progression-free survival, clinical benefit rate, and safety of the treatments. The study will enroll participants aged 18 years or older and is not open to healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation and eccentric exercises with acute electrostimulation on professional paddle tennis players. The study will measure the participants' vertical jump and ankle dorsiflexion range using specific tests. The trial will include a proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation group and an eccentric exercises and electrical stimulation group. The study design is a parallel assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measures include the vertical jump and range of ankle dorsiflexion. The trial is open to both males and females between the ages of 18 and 50, but does not accept healthy volunteers.

The clinical trial, titled "Influence of Nutrition in Depression Treatment (INDEPT)," aims to assess the effectiveness of dietary counseling promoting the Mediterranean Diet (MedDiet) as an adjuvant treatment for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) in adults with elevated inflammation biomarkers. The trial will involve a 12-week multicenter randomized parallel-group open controlled design, with a follow-up assessment at 6 and 12 months. Participants will be randomized into two groups: an intervention group receiving nutrition consultations promoting adherence to the MedDiet in addition to MDD treatment as usual, and a control group receiving only MDD treatment as usual. The primary outcome measure will be changes in symptoms of MDD, assessed using the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) scale. Secondary outcome measures include changes in inflammation biomarkers (IL-6 and/or CRP). The study will adhere to Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) guidelines, and data analysis will be performed using statistical models. The study aims to recruit a minimum of 190 participants.

This clinical trial aims to support parenting and improve family mental health in refugee shelters in Tijuana, Mexico. The study will use a participatory research model, including focus groups and small group discussions, to prioritize parenting skills and adapt a learning curriculum to the local context. The participants will be divided into two groups, with one group receiving the adapted curriculum during month 3 and the other group serving as a control. Various questionnaires and measures will be used to assess parenting knowledge, child behavior, parental efficacy, observed parent-child interactions, and parental stress. Feedback interviews will also be conducted. The data will be analyzed and shared with the community at different stages of the study. The researchers aim to draft a manuscript and share the final results with the community and partners.

This clinical trial aims to improve the healthcare experiences of patients with incurable Head and Neck Cancer (HNC) through a qualitative investigation and co-design approach. The study involves longitudinal interviews with patients and family carers, as well as focus groups with healthcare professionals. The interviews will be conducted at regular intervals to capture changes over time and explore the impact of healthcare services on patients' needs and experiences. The focus groups will gather insights from different perspectives to identify areas for improvement. The study will also include co-design workshops to generate potential solutions and prioritize areas for intervention development. The findings will inform the development of an intervention to enhance the experiences of patients with incurable HNC and their families.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical application of indocyanine green (ICG) fluorescence imaging in assisting the identification of nerve roots in endoscopic spinal surgery for patients with disc herniation. The study will involve three experimental groups receiving different doses of ICG intravenous injection before surgery, and a control group receiving standard endoscopic spinal surgery without ICG. The primary outcome measures include the fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, fluorescence signal ratio of nerve root to back fluorescence, and time taken to find the nerve root endoscopically. Secondary outcome measures include ICG-related adverse reactions, pain scores, functional impairment scores, surgical complications, and length of surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a home-based parenting support program called "Parenting Young Children" for parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDDs) who are at risk for neglect. The study will include parents with IDDs, including those with intellectual disability, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The intervention involves structured coaching sessions over a period of at least six months, focusing on parent-child interaction and child care skills and safety. The study will compare the effects of the parenting support program to treatment as usual provided by social services. The primary outcome measures include changes in the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (performance and satisfaction subscales), while secondary outcome measures include changes in the Parental Sense of Competence Scale and Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire. The study design is non-randomized, with parallel assignment to the experimental and control groups. The study does not involve healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to gather information on male patients undergoing surgery for stress urinary incontinence using either an artificial urinary sphincter or a male sling. The study will collect data on patient characteristics, surgical procedures, and post-operative outcomes. The primary outcome measure is the success rate of the surgery, defined as urinary continence without the need for pads or with the use of 1 light security pad. Secondary outcome measures include time being continent, time being revision-free, revision-free rate, patient-reported quality of life, post-operative adverse events, and specific adverse events related to the surgical procedure. The study will assess these outcomes at various time intervals up to 5 years after surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 to detect 5T4 expression in malignant tumors. The study involves injecting the drug intravenously and using PET imaging to analyze the standardized uptake value (SUV) of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 on the lesions. The primary outcome measure is the establishment and optimization of the imaging method for 68Ga-NOTA-H006 PET. The trial includes patients with pancreatic, lung, and bowel cancer, aged between 18 and 65 years old. The study design is a single group assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the biological mechanisms behind resynchronization therapy (CRT) in heart failure patients. The study will collect blood samples, heart tissue, and clinical data from heart failure patients eligible for CRT and a control group on medical therapy. Patients will be assessed at multiple time points and various analyses will be conducted on the collected samples. The study will measure biomarkers to differentiate CRT responders from non-responders and evaluate endothelial function. The study design is observational and the interventions include diagnostic tests such as proteomics and miRNA studies.

This clinical trial aims to study the medication strategy in heart failure patients who are intolerable to guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT). The study will include patients aged 18 and above who have been hospitalized and diagnosed with acute heart failure. The primary outcome measure is the risk of all-cause mortality or worsening heart failure in 180 days. The study will also measure changes in symptoms and signs of heart failure, NT-proBNP level, left ventricular ejection fraction, left ventricular end-diastolic diameter, left ventricular end-systolic diameter, left ventricular fractional shortening, blood pressure, and blood potassium. The study will have two participant groups: one consisting of heart failure patients who are tolerable to GDMT and another consisting of heart failure patients who are intolerable to GDMT. The intervention for the first group is guideline-directed medication treatment, while the intervention for the second group is not specified. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to improve patient-reported outcomes (PRO) adherence in cancer patients through the use of behavioral economic strategies. PRO monitoring has been shown to improve patient outcomes, but real-world adherence is often low, particularly among marginalized subgroups. The study will compare two interventions: encounter-based PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts, and remote PRO monitoring with the same reminders and alerts. The primary outcome measure is PRO adherence, measured as the proportion of expected PRO questionnaires completed per patient. Secondary outcome measures include documentation of PROs in patient notes, time to alert response, acute care utilization, treatment delays/modifications, and duration of therapy. The study will be conducted using a randomized, parallel assignment design.

The ProgESC study aims to understand the prognostic awareness of patients referred to the Enhanced Supportive Care (ESC) service for advanced cancer. The study will assess patients' level of prognostic awareness, psychological distress, quality of life, trust in medical professionals, and perceived quality of care. The study will include adult patients with advanced cancer referred to the ESC service, excluding those with cognitive impairment or already referred to palliative care services. The study will be cross-sectional and prospective, with participants completing a questionnaire. The primary endpoint is patients' prognostic awareness, assessed by the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire. Secondary endpoints include patients' preferences for receiving prognostic information, symptoms of depression and anxiety, quality of life, trust in medical team, and perceived quality of care. The study aims to include 100 patients and will analyze associations between sociodemographic or clinical variables and outcomes. The study will provide valuable insights into the prognostic awareness and psychological burden among patients with advanced cancer referred to ESC services.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of direct-from-blood bacterial testing on antibiotic administration and clinical outcomes. The trial will be conducted as a pragmatic, randomized controlled clinical trial with parallel group assignment. The participants will be divided into two groups: one group will receive usual care, including standard blood cultures, and the other group will receive direct-from-blood testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel in addition to usual care. The primary outcome measure is the time to the last dose of intravenous vancomycin received by the patient within 14 days of randomization. The secondary outcome measure is the time to the last dose of systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic received by the patient within 14 days of randomization.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of temperature-elevating armbaths on participants with arterial hypertension. Fifty participants will be randomized to either an intervention group or a waitlist group. The intervention group will perform the armbaths on 5 out of 7 days per week for 8 weeks, while the waitlist group will continue with their usual treatment. Blood pressure measurements and other secondary outcome measures will be taken at the beginning of the trial, at 8 weeks, and at 6 months. The study will assess the effectiveness of temperature-elevating armbaths as a therapeutic option for regulating blood pressure in people with arterial hypertension.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effects of acupuncture on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study will include participants aged 18 to 65 who have self-reported perceived stress symptoms for at least one month. The intervention will consist of manual standardized stress acupuncture (MSSA) and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR). The study will measure the participants' perceived stress levels using the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures include the Insomnia Severity Index, the Short Form Health Survey, and journal logs. The study will be randomized and open-label, with participants assigned to either the experimental group receiving both MSSA and MBSR, or the active comparator group receiving only MBSR. The study will assess the outcome measures at baseline, two weeks post-interventions, and four weeks post-interventions.

This clinical trial aims to determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in Punta Arenas, Magallanes, and the Chilean Antarctic Region. The study will include adults aged 18 to 100 years who have had at least one positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-qPCR test between July 2022 and July 2023. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence of persistent COVID-19, and secondary outcome measures include sociodemographic data collection, psychological profiles, sleep quality and disorders, psychosocial exposures, standard laboratory parameters, inflammatory biomarkers, immunological repertoire associated with persistent COVID-19, function of the musculoskeletal system, and diagnosis of prevalent COVID-19.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two different procedures for managing post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) in obstetric patients. The study will randomly assign participants to either have their epidural catheter re-sited or have an intrathecal catheter placed after a dural puncture occurs. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of PDPH at 24 hours from the occurrence of the dural puncture. Secondary outcome measures include PDPH intensity at 24 and 48 hours, quality of analgesia, adverse events, chronic pain at 1 and 3 months, readmission to the hospital, and patient satisfaction. The study is open-label and will include female participants aged 18 years and older.

This clinical trial compares the use of sectional matrix versus circumferential matrix for reconstructing proximal contact in Class 2 restorations. The study will involve local anesthesia, isolation of the tooth with a rubber dam, and the application of either a sectional matrix or circumferential matrix. Resin composite restorations will be completed using the manufacturer's instructions. The tightness of the proximal contacts will be evaluated using dental floss. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of the two matrix systems in achieving optimal proximal contacts. The primary outcome measure is the tightness of proximal contact immediately after the procedure. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with single masking. Participants will be divided into experimental and active comparator groups. The experimental group will receive the sectional matrix band, while the active comparator group will receive the circumferential matrix band. The study is open to individuals aged 18 to 60 years and accepts healthy volunteers. The study aims to determine the best method for achieving strong proximal contact in Class 2 restorations.

This clinical trial is evaluating the effectiveness of a Pay for Performance (PFP) program for individuals with psychotic disorders, bipolar disorder, and substance use disorders who have a history of extensive utilization of 24-hour psychiatric services in Santa Clara County, CA. The PFP program involves tailored mental health and addiction treatment services provided by a contractor, with financial incentives for the contractor based on the utilization of care. The study aims to measure the total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services at 12, 24, and 36 months post-enrollment, as well as secondary measures such as the cost of specific services and the proportion of patients who experience incarceration. The study is designed as a randomized, open-label trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of culturally adapted cognitive behavioral therapy (CaCBT) and culturally adapted family intervention (CulFI) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with early psychosis in Pakistan. The study will include 390 participants and will be conducted in multiple centers. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU, or TAU alone. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, months 3, 6, and 12. The study will also include process evaluation and economic evaluations. The primary outcome measure is the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) score. Secondary outcome measures include measures of depression, quality of life, disability, insight, caregiving experiences, carer well-being and support, illness perception, anxiety, and adherence to treatment.

This clinical trial is investigating the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 Bispecific Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T Cell Therapy, in participants with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL). The study will consist of a Phase 1 dose finding part followed by a Phase 2 part. The primary outcome measures include the incidence of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) and other treatment-emergent adverse events, investigator-assessed complete response rate, and proportion of participants who receive the target dose. Secondary outcome measures include overall response rate, duration of response, median progression-free survival, and concentration of IMPT-314 cells in peripheral blood. The study will involve both CAR T-experienced and CAR T-naïve cohorts.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) on cognitive performance and physical activity in middle-aged individuals. The study will include voluntary participants diagnosed with MetS and a control group of healthy individuals. Participants will undergo assessments of cognitive performance and physical activity. The study will measure various outcome measures including waist circumference, blood pressure, triglyceride levels, HDL-C levels, fasting plasma levels, Metabolic Syndrome severity score, cognitive assessment scores, and physical activity levels. The study will provide valuable insights into the relationship between MetS, cognitive function, and physical performance in adults with chronic disease.

This clinical trial aims to increase COVID-19 vaccination rates among individuals with anxiety or depression. The study will recruit participants from a large US cohort and test the effectiveness of two brief digital interventions compared to conventional public health messaging. Participants will be assigned to one of the interventions and their vaccination outcomes will be measured at 4 weeks post-intervention. The primary outcome measure is self-reported receipt of a COVID vaccine dose. Secondary outcomes include vaccine hesitancy and self-reported receipt of a COVID vaccine dose at 6 months post-intervention. The study design is randomized and participants will be assigned to intervention arms in a 1:1:1 ratio. The interventions include attitudinal inoculation, cognitive-behavioral therapy-informed intervention, and conventional public health messaging. Participants will receive text message reminders to get vaccinated. The study will also examine the mechanisms of action of the interventions and adjust for differences in baseline variables.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effects of binaural beat music on sleep quality, heart rate variability, and depression in older individuals with poor sleep quality. The trial includes participants aged 65 years and older who have a PSQI score greater than 7 and can understand and communicate in Mandarin or Taiwanese Hokkien. The study design is a randomized controlled trial, with participants assigned to either the binaural beat music group or the control group. The primary outcome measures include the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and heart rate variability (HRV). The secondary outcome measure is the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). The intervention involves listening to 20 minutes of music three times a week for two weeks. The results will be measured on day 14 of the intervention.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the implementation of a Personalised Follow-up (PFU) pathway for patients with Head and Neck Cancer. The study will assess the acceptability of the pathway to patients and healthcare providers, as well as the safety and sustainability of the pathway. Participants will be provided with study information and their participation will be voluntary. Data will be collected through interviews and questionnaires, and patient-identifiable information will be stored securely. The study will measure various outcomes, including the acceptability of the pathway, patient and service provider experiences, and the sustainability of the pathway. The study design involves the implementation of the PFU pathway and the collection of data at the end of the study period.

This clinical trial compares the use of intrathecal bupivacaine-dexmedetomidine to intrathecal bupivacaine-neostigmine in elective caesarean sections for anesthesia. The study aims to measure the time it takes for a bilateral sensory block to occur after intrathecal injection. The trial includes participants who are female, aged 18-40, with ASA physical status I and II. The study design is a randomized, double-blind trial with parallel assignment. The interventions include the administration of either dexmedetomidine or neostigmine along with bupivacaine. The trial includes three participant groups receiving different interventions. The primary outcome measure is the time it takes to achieve a bilateral sensory block at T10.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an air-polishing device in preventing white spot lesions (WSLs) and gingivitis during orthodontic treatment. The study will involve 60 patients undergoing orthodontic treatment for a duration of 2 years. Half of the participants will be treated with the air-polishing device every month, while the other half will receive standard treatment every six months. The prevalence of WSLs and gingivitis will be assessed using various methods, including clinical examination and sample collection. The study will also evaluate the antimicrobial efficacy and host-response through laboratory analysis. The incidence of bracket debonding will also be calculated and compared. The trial is randomized and will be conducted at a single center. The primary outcome measures include the appearance of WSLs and inflammatory lesions during orthodontic treatment. Secondary outcome measures include patient acceptance, tooth sensitivity, bacterial counts, inflammatory markers, and treatment time.

This clinical trial aims to analyze tissue from patients undergoing cardiothoracic surgery to understand the role of fibrosis in promoting and sustaining atrial fibrillation (AF). The study will include up to 10 patients, with samples obtained from patients in sinus rhythm and varying durations of AF. The analysis will involve histological and molecular techniques to examine the tissue. The primary outcome measures will involve histological and molecular analysis, which will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The study will provide valuable insights into the relationship between fibrosis and AF.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise on strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners. The study will involve two groups, with one group following an integrated resisted exercise program and the other following an isolated resisted exercise program. The study will measure endurance using a sit-up test, power using a vertical jump test, and strength using a 1RM maximum test. The study will help identify the most effective training methods for improving strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of play-based therapy and functional communication training in children with speech and language delays. The study will include participants with comorbidity of behavioral disorders, autism, and ADHD. The minimum age for participation is 2 years and the maximum age is 6 years. The study will have two groups, with one receiving play-based therapy and the other receiving functional communication training. The primary outcome measure will be the change in functional language ability assessed through a speech questionnaire after 3 months of therapy. The study design is a randomized parallel assignment with single masking.

This clinical trial aims to assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons, a digital intervention, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina for individuals with schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders. The trial will recruit clinicians and peer specialists from the clinics to evaluate the implementation strategies. It will also recruit individuals with first episode psychosis to assess client engagement with Horyzons and changes in psychological measures and use of state-funded services over a 12-month intervention period. The study design involves non-randomized allocation and parallel assignment of participants to different arms. The primary outcomes of the trial include qualitative and quantitative summaries of participant feedback on the implementation of Horyzons, while the secondary outcomes focus on changes in engagement with the platform and use of emergency and social services.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the gene expressions of inflammatory and anti-inflammatory markers in liver transplant patients before and after the operation. The study will measure the levels of various cytokine genes and biomarkers in peripheral blood samples obtained from the patients. Additionally, biochemical parameters such as liver markers will be measured. The goal is to find biomarkers that can predict rejection and infection after liver transplantation. The study will include both healthy volunteers and liver transplant patients. The primary outcome measures include the levels of biochemical parameters and gene expression parameters before surgery. The secondary outcome measures include gene expression parameters after surgery at different time frames. The study is designed to assess the immune response and potential complications in liver transplant patients.

This clinical trial aims to test the safety and tolerability of different doses of the drug BI 771716 in people with advanced age-related macular degeneration (AMD) called geographic atrophy. The study will include participants with geographic atrophy and will assess the occurrence of ocular dose limiting events and drug-related adverse events. The trial will also measure secondary outcomes such as the occurrence of any ocular adverse events, maximum serum concentration of BI 771716, and BI 771716 serum concentration. The study design is non-randomized and open label, with participants assigned to different treatment groups based on the dose of BI 771716.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of furosemide-induced diuresis with matched dehydration to standard diuretic therapy in patients with acute heart failure and overt fluid overload. The study will include patients aged 18 years or older with New York Heart Association functional class III or IV and estimated weight gain due to peripheral fluid overload of more than 4 kg. The primary outcome measure is the daily serum creatinine measurement for assessment of acute kidney injury occurrence, while the secondary outcome measure is the daily weight decrease during study treatment. The study design is randomized with parallel assignment and an open-label approach. The experimental group will receive furosemide infusion with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device.

This clinical trial aims to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention in pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain. The study will involve patients aged 12 to 18 years who have recurrent chest pain diagnosed as idiopathic or musculoskeletal. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a standard of care control group or a mindfulness-based intervention group. The mindfulness-based intervention group will use the Headspace app to complete mindfulness courses for 30 days. The study will measure participant recruitment and retention rates, adherence to the intervention program, program evaluation, survey response rate, pain coping strategies, perceived stress, patient quality of life, chest pain episode frequency, and chest pain episode intensity.

This clinical trial aims to assess the safety and immunogenicity of administering the Novavax vaccine and a 20-valent Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine (PCV20) together in adults aged 60 years and older. The trial will compare the combination of the two vaccines to each vaccine administered separately and a placebo. The primary outcome measure will be antibody levels on day 28. Eligibility criteria include being 60 years or older and not having received a previous pneumococcal vaccination.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the combination therapy of the anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint inhibitor durvalumab and the TLR-3 agonist rintatolimod in patients with metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The primary objective of the study is to determine the safety and clinical benefit rate of this combination therapy. The study will include adult patients who have completed standard chemotherapy and have stable disease. The intervention involves administering rintatolimod and durvalumab to the patients. The study will assess the safety, clinical benefit rate, immunogenic effect, survival rates, and quality of life of the patients. The study design is exploratory and open-label, and it will be conducted in two phases with a total of 22 to 43 patients. The study is expected to provide insights into the efficacy of combination therapy in PDAC patients.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the potential effects of diosmin supplementation on delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in female athletes. The study will be a randomized, double-blinded, and placebo-controlled trial involving approximately 40 participants. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving diosmin supplementation and the other receiving a placebo. The treatment will be administered orally before the intense dynamic exercise sessions. The study will evaluate the effects of diosmin on reducing muscle pain, systemic levels of creatine phosphokinase and oxidative stress, and improvement in muscular performance and balance. The study will also assess various clinical and blood parameters before and after the exercise protocol. The primary outcome measure will be muscle soreness, evaluated using a digital algometer and visual analogue scale. Secondary outcome measures will include muscle tissue damage, lipid peroxidation levels, antioxidant status, muscle function, and postural balance. The study has been approved by the Research Ethics Committee, and participants will provide informed consent before participating.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the short-term (3 months), medium-term (1 year), and long-term (2 years) effects of Intrathecal Baclofen (ITB) treatment on personal treatment goals in children with cerebral palsy (CP). The study will be conducted using the Netherlands CP register to collect data over a period of 4.5 years. The primary outcome measure is goal attainment scaling (GAS), which quantifies the achievement of individual treatment goals. Secondary outcome measures include spasticity, dystonia, range of motion, scoliosis, selective motor control, functional strength, gait analysis, questionnaires on activities and participation, and ITB treatment characteristics. The study will also analyze factors associated with treatment success. The study will enroll children and adolescents with CP who start ITB treatment in the Netherlands under the age of 16. Data will be collected at various time points, including before initiation of ITB and at 3 months, 1 year, and 2 years after initiation.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of vitamin D supplementation on the risk of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) in pregnant women. The study will be a randomized controlled trial (RCT) and will recruit pregnant women at high risk for developing GDM with low levels of vitamin D. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either vitamin D3 supplementation or a placebo. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of GDM based on the International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups Criteria. The findings of this study may inform clinical practice and public health recommendations for vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy.

This clinical trial, titled "Direct Access Carotid Artery Stenting Using the Neuroguard IEP System (PERFORMANCE III)," aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP Direct System for the treatment of carotid artery stenosis in patients at high risk for adverse events following carotid endarterectomy. The study will include eligible patients aged 20 to 80 years with de-novo atherosclerotic or post-CEA restenotic lesions in the internal carotid arteries or carotid bifurcation. The primary outcome measure is the composite 30-day rate of Major Adverse Events (MAE), including stroke, myocardial infarction, and death. The study will be a prospective, multicenter single-arm, open label study. The Neuroguard IEP Direct System is a 3-in-1 carotid stent delivery system consisting of an angioplasty balloon, an integrated embolic protection device, and a self-expanding stent.

This clinical trial aims to test the feasibility and safety of a Nordic Walking (NW) activity program for older adults at risk of falling or experiencing fear of falling (FOF). The study will be conducted in two stages. In the first stage, a two-arm, parallel, single-blind, randomized controlled pilot trial will be conducted with 40 participants. The intervention group will receive supervised NW training sessions and will practice independently, while the control group will receive regular phone calls discussing healthy lifestyle habits. Feasibility and safety data will be collected, along with effectiveness outcomes such as balance, mobility, and fear of falling measures. The second stage will involve qualitative interviews with the intervention group to gather feedback on the acceptability and perceived value of participating in the program. The study aims to recruit 40 participants and will use descriptive statistics, effect size calculations, and t-tests to analyze the data. The primary outcome measures include estimating the effect size of the intervention, evaluating adherence rates, and assessing safety. Secondary outcome measures include the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, Falls Efficacy Scale-International (FES-I), and the Four-Square Step Test (FSST) to assess balance and fall risk.

This clinical trial aims to develop and test online interventions to increase help-seeking for anxiety and/or depression in sexual and gender minority youth (SGMY). The study will use a user-informed approach to design and study intervention principles (IPs) that address the unique factors inhibiting help-seeking in SGMY. The IPs include intersectionality and identity, confidentiality, educating the community, and finding affirming caregivers. The study will involve a factorial trial with 96 participants randomly assigned to one of 16 combinations of the IPs. The primary outcomes will include feasibility of IP use, usability, acceptability of the intervention principles, and change in help-seeking intention. Secondary outcome measures will assess help-seeking intention from multiple sources, perceived need for treatment, social support, anxiety, depression, mental health stigma, beliefs about therapy, and various other factors related to mental health and well-being.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of a propofol and remifentanil mixed solution for sedation and analgesia in fiber colonoscopy. The study will compare this approach to intravenous combined anesthesia. The primary outcome measure will be the auditory evoked potential, recorded at multiple time points throughout the procedure. Secondary outcome measures include the time from surgery to reaching certain scores related to consciousness and recovery. The trial will involve participants aged 18-75 and will be randomized and single-blinded.

This clinical trial aims to predict the chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury (RAII) based on the expression level of immune factors. The study design is prospective, observational, confirmatory, and single-center. Participants are patients diagnosed with locally advanced rectal cancer who undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NCRT) and total mesorectal excision (TME) and develop RAII during NCRT or within 1 month. The primary outcome is the area under the curve (AUC) of the prediction model for chronicization of RAII, and the secondary outcomes include accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of the prediction model. The study plans to enroll 200 patients and will collect data through electronic case report forms. Statistical analysis will be performed, and the study adheres to ethical guidelines. The study started recruitment in March 2023 and has been approved by the Human Medical Ethics Committee.

This is a phase I clinical trial to evaluate the safety and tolerability of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta COVID-19 vaccine in people aged 18 years and above. The trial aims to collect data on adverse events occurring within 7 days of vaccination and assess the effectiveness of the vaccine in generating neutralizing antibodies against the Delta and Omicron strains. The study will also observe adverse events at the vaccination site and monitor pregnancy outcomes for subjects. The trial is randomized, double-blind, and placebo-controlled, with participants receiving either the vaccine or a placebo. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of adverse events, and the secondary outcome measure is the level of neutralizing antibodies after vaccination.

This clinical trial is evaluating the safety and performance of the ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA Left Atrial Appendage (LAA) Closure Device in patients with atrial fibrillation. The study aims to assess the device's safety by monitoring device and investigational procedure related serious adverse events at 7 days, 45 days, and 6 months post-procedure. The secondary outcome measure is confirming functional LAA closure at 45 days. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking. The minimum age for participation is 18 years, and all sexes are eligible. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Motivational Interviewing (MI) for patients with acute psychosis. Psychotic disorders are associated with high disability, chronic symptoms, and low work performance. While cognitive-behavioral therapy has shown efficacy in treating psychosis, there is a lack of research on psychotherapeutic interventions in the acute setting. The study will compare MI with supportive conversations as a control intervention. The primary outcomes measured are therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence, while secondary outcomes include symptom severity, motivation for psychotherapy, and self-efficacy. The study will be conducted with patients from the Psychiatric University Hospital of Zurich.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the application of chromosomal instability (CIN) in the early diagnosis of biliary tract carcinoma. Biliary tract carcinoma is a type of cancer with high metastasis and invasion ability. The early symptoms are nonspecific, leading to late-stage diagnosis and poor prognosis. CIN, which refers to chromosomal abnormalities, is commonly found in tumors and is associated with metastasis and treatment resistance. The study will use a new method called BileCAD to detect CIN in DNA samples from bile. The researchers will analyze bile samples from patients with biliary tract carcinoma and control groups without tumors to compare the specificity and sensitivity of the BileCAD test for diagnosing the carcinoma. The study will also compare the consistency of BileCAD microbial analysis results with clinical microbial culture results. The primary outcomes measured will be the sensitivity and specificity of the BileCAD test, while the secondary outcomes will include the consistency of microbial analysis results and the sensitivity of BileCAD to different types and locations of malignant tumors.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the success of lumbar plexus block in lower extremity orthopedic surgeries using Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS) to measure tissue oxygenation. The study will include patients aged 18-90 who are undergoing femoral neck fracture, femoral shaft fracture, or hip replacement surgery. NIRS devices will be used to measure peripheral oxygen saturation before and during the surgery. The primary outcome measure is the regional oximetry probe (rso2) placed on the operated extremity. Secondary outcome measures include sensory block level, blood pressure values, and fingertip SO2. The study is designed as a single-group assignment without masking.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of a digital platform to support the implementation and integration of task-shared care for schizophrenia in primary care settings in India. The study will assess the effectiveness and integration of the COPSI program, a psychosocial rehabilitation intervention, with the addition of a mobile application called mindLAMP. The trial will involve participants with a primary diagnosis of schizophrenia and will measure outcomes such as disability, symptoms, anxiety, depression, and cognitive functioning. The study design is randomized with two arms: one group receiving COPSI plus mindLAMP and another group receiving COPSI alone. The trial will help determine if the digital platform can enhance the delivery and effectiveness of the intervention for patients with schizophrenia.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the characteristics of cytokine response in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) who are treated with occlusal splint therapy. The study will include participants diagnosed with myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMD, and painful disk displacement. The participants will be asked to complete self-assessment questionnaires to evaluate various aspects of their condition. The occlusal splints will be fabricated from hard acrylic resin, and gingival crevicular fluid and blood samples will be collected for analysis of proinflammatory cytokines. The primary outcome measures include changes in cytokine levels in the blood and gingival crevicular fluid after occlusal splint therapy. Secondary outcome measures include changes in pain, jaw function, oral health-related quality of life, perceived stress levels, mood, anxiety, physical symptoms, and presence of parafunctional behaviors. The study will be a prospective, interventional study with a single treatment group.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of scalable digital training for addiction professionals in maximizing treatment admission and retention rates of Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) in affected families. The study will involve three levels of digital training: a digital tutorial, tutorial plus training materials, and tutorial plus training materials plus feedback and coaching. The study will assess the impact of the training on CRAFT knowledge, fidelity, and treatment entry and retention. The primary outcome measures include CRAFT procedure fidelity, while secondary outcome measures include CRAFT knowledge, program implementation potential, and new treatment entry. The study will be conducted over a 3-month period.

This clinical trial aims to describe the regional myocardial distribution of 3,3-diphosphono-1,2-propanedicarboxylic acid (DPD) single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) uptake in patients with cardiac transthyretin (ATTR) amyloidosis. It will also investigate the clinical, biochemical, and echocardiographic profiles in patients with ATTR wild-type (ATTRwt) and hereditary mutant (ATTRm) variants. Additionally, the study will evaluate the presence and extent of DPD cardiac uptake in asymptomatic ATTRm variant carriers. The trial is a prospective multi-center observational study that will include patients with Grade 1-3 cardiac DPD retention in scintigraphy and first-degree relatives of ATTRm patients. Various imaging and diagnostic tests will be conducted, and the collected data will be analyzed statistically. The study's primary outcome measure is to compare the regional left ventricle DPD uptake between patients with hereditary and wild-type cardiac ATTR amyloidosis. Secondary outcome measures include assessing right ventricular DPD accumulation and evaluating DPD cardiac uptake in asymptomatic hereditary ATTR amyloidosis variant carriers.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the postcovid syndrome in children aged 6 to 18 years. The study will involve laboratory tests, questionnaires, and physical examinations. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with postcovid syndrome. The study is designed as a single-group assignment and is open-label with no masking. The trial will last for 1 year.

This clinical trial aims to study the effectiveness of treadmill perturbation training in preventing falls after total knee replacement surgery. The study will involve 378 participants who are scheduled for knee replacement surgery. The participants will be assessed for various demographic and functional risk factors, and their physical activity level will be measured using accelerometers. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the perturbation training group or the education control group. The perturbation training group will undergo training sessions on a treadmill that simulates tripping or being perturbed to the side, while the education control group will receive written materials on fall prevention. The primary outcome measures of the study include post-training trunk angle, post-training trunk angular velocity, and fall rate during the first year after surgery. The secondary outcome measure is the fall status of the participants during the post-training test.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cadonilimab in combination with nab-paclitaxel for the treatment of recurrent or metastatic cervical cancer that is resistant to immune checkpoint inhibitors. The primary objective is to assess the objective response rate, while secondary objectives include evaluating the duration of response, disease control rate, time to response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and safety and tolerability of the combination therapy. The study will also explore potential indicators in tumor tissue or peripheral blood that can predict the efficacy of the treatment. The trial is a single-arm, open-label, multicenter phase II study and will include female patients aged 18 to 75 years. The intervention includes the administration of cadonilimab and nab-paclitaxel. The study will measure the objective response rate, duration of response, disease control rate, time to response, progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of adverse events, and health-related quality of life using various assessment tools. The trial will last for up to 2 years.

This clinical trial is a single center, prospective study comparing the visual performance of the Hanita Lenses Intensity SL IOL to the Alcon Panoptix IOL in patients with age-related cataracts. The study will include approximately 58 patients who will undergo bilateral implantation of the study or comparison lens. The primary endpoint is to determine if the visual acuity achieved with the study lens is not statistically significantly inferior to the control lens for distance, intermediate, and near ranges. The study will also assess secondary outcome measures such as defocus curve, contrast sensitivity, and patient satisfaction. The study design is randomized and unblinded, and the interventions involve intraocular lens implantation.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery. The study will involve a retrospective, observational, single-centre, cohort database analysis. The participants will be adults over 18 years old who have sustained a unilateral hip fracture and received surgery under low-dose spinal anaesthesia. The primary outcome measure will be the cohort mean non-invasive blood pressure taken at 2-minute intervals peri-operatively. The secondary outcome measures include the cohort prevalence of hypotension, mean depth x duration area under curve product for cohort hypotension, quantification of cohort systolic and mean arterial blood pressure changes, effective cohort duration of spinal anaesthesia, and correlations between hypotension and outcomes such as death at 30 days and length of hospital stay.

This clinical trial in Malawi aims to investigate the relationship between malaria, intestinal parasitic diseases, and COVID-19. The study will enroll 200 symptomatic individuals (index cases), their household contacts (around 700), and up to 600 vaccine recipients. The researchers will assess the innate immune responses of uninfected Malawians compared to Western controls and determine if these responses protect against infection and disease progression. Participants will be followed for up to 1.5 years to evaluate the acquisition and longevity of antibody responses and memory B cells. The study will also measure various outcomes such as the risk of asymptomatic infection, duration of neutralizing antibody responses, and changes in immune cell activation markers.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of hot-cold application to the bladder on postoperative urinary retention (PUR) in orthopedic surgery patients. PUR is a common complication after orthopedic surgery, leading to increased hospital stay times and associated costs. Nurses play a crucial role in managing PUR, and hot-cold application is one of the interventions used. Previous studies have shown positive outcomes with hot-cold application, reducing the development of PUR. The study will be a single-blind randomized controlled trial, with participants assigned to either the experimental group (receiving hot-cold application) or the control group (routine clinical functioning). The primary outcome measure is the prevention of PUR by applying hot and cold to the bladder in the first 6 hours of the postoperative period. The study aims to contribute to the effective management of PUR and increase awareness among nurses.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a deep-learning integrated model using clinical factors and radiomic features from high-concentration contrast-enhanced CT images in predicting the recurrence risk of acute pancreatitis within one year. The study will enroll a total of 694 eligible patients with acute pancreatitis and follow them for 12 months. The primary outcome measures include the sensitivity and specificity of the prediction model. Secondary outcomes include the number of subjects with recurrent pancreatitis at different time points, the sensitivity and specificity of the prediction model for overall recurrence, the image quality of the CT scans, and the sensitivity and specificity of the radiomic features in predicting different types and severities of pancreatitis.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on polycythemia in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The study will include patients aged 18 to 80 years old who have been diagnosed with polycythemia and moderate or severe OSA. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive CPAP treatment along with diet and conventional pharmacological treatment, or to receive only diet and conventional pharmacological treatment. The primary outcome measure of the study is the change in hematocrit levels from baseline after 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in hemoglobin levels, health-related quality of life, the relationship between hypoxic burden and hemoglobin and hematocrit, changes in sleepiness assessed by the Epworth scale, and the relationship between nighttime oxygen levels and hematocrit. The study design is a parallel assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to compare the vaginal axis on MRI in different surgical procedures for apical prolapse to sacrocolpopexy. The study will assess the preoperative and postoperative MRI images of patients undergoing lateral mesh suspension, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation procedures. The primary outcome measures include evaluating the vaginal axis and vaginal distances. Secondary outcome measures include assessing prolapse symptoms, urinary symptoms, postoperative dyspareunia, sexual functions, quality of life measures, and patient global impression of improvement. The study will involve female participants with pelvic organ prolapse, and the age range is 18 to 80 years. The study design is randomized with parallel assignment and a single masking.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of simulation training in electronic fetal monitoring management for midwifery students. The study will assess the students' knowledge, satisfaction, and self-efficacy in this area. The trial will involve a control group receiving theory training and an experimental group receiving simulation training. Various outcome measures, including information evaluation forms, student satisfaction and self-confidence scales, and self-efficacy scales, will be used to measure the effectiveness of the training. The study design is randomized and open label. The participants will be midwifery second year students who are taking a risky pregnancy course. The study will also evaluate the simulation design and its importance to the participants. The trial will provide valuable insights into the impact of simulation training on the management of electronic fetal monitoring.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the outcome and predictors of mortality in patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation. The study will be conducted in a hospital over a period of five months. Data will be collected and analyzed using statistical software. The study will focus on the clinical outcomes of critically ill patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation. The primary outcome measure will be whether the patient survived or died at the time of discharge. The study will help improve the care of patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation.

This clinical trial aims to compare the pharmacodynamic effects of two different approaches for reducing bleeding in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The standard approach involves dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor, but this can lead to increased bleeding. Two alternative strategies have shown promise in reducing bleeding while maintaining efficacy: DAPT de-escalation (switching from a potent P2Y12 inhibitor to clopidogrel while continuing aspirin) and potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy (continuing a potent P2Y12 inhibitor and discontinuing aspirin). This study will compare the effects of these two approaches on thrombus formation. Patients eligible for the study must be on maintenance DAPT for at least 30 days (for chronic coronary syndrome) or 3 months (for acute coronary syndrome). The primary outcome measure will be the area under the curve (AUC) of thrombus formation measured by the Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS) after 30 days.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the age-dependent effects of egg intake on HDL (high-density lipoprotein) and immune profiles. The study will involve participants aged 18-30 or 60-70 years old who have a BMI below 30 kg/m2. They will be required to consume whole eggs, egg yolks, or egg whites daily during the study periods while refraining from eating eggs during other periods. The study will measure the change in serum concentration of large HDL particles between diet periods as the primary outcome. The study design is randomized with a crossover assignment and no masking. The intervention arms include consuming egg whites, egg yolks, or whole eggs for 4 weeks. The study is expected to provide insights into the effects of egg intake on HDL and immune profiles in different age groups.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a patient-driven augmented reality-based rehabilitation system, called MyoTrain AR, in improving outcomes for upper limb amputees. The study will involve participants with trans-radial unilateral limb loss who are candidates for a myoelectric pattern recognition prosthesis. The intervention group will undergo functional task training using the MyoTrain AR system, which includes an augmented reality head-mounted display, kinematic trackers, and surface EMG electrodes. The control group will be provided with motor imagery exercises. The primary outcome measures include the completion time and grasp duration of the GaMA Cup Transfer Task. Secondary outcome measures include the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls (ACMC), task completion rate, and wrist activation. The study is designed as a randomized trial with parallel assignment.

The clinical trial titled "Gastrointestinal Stimulation as a Treatment of Postoperative Ileus Following Extensive Surgery" aims to evaluate the effectiveness of gastric electric pacemaker as a treatment for postoperative ileus. The study is a prospective, double-blinded randomized controlled trial. The participants will be divided into two groups: the treatment group, where a gastric pacemaker will be mounted on the stomach and connected to an external pacemaker set at specific settings, and the control group, where a gastric pacemaker will be mounted but turned off. The primary outcome measure is the time from surgery until the first stool. Secondary outcome measures include whole gut and regional transit times, length of hospital stay, medical complications, surgical complications, need for surgical or radiological interventions, re-hospitalization within 30 days, time till initiation of postoperative systemic adjuvant chemotherapy, and 90-day mortality. The study will provide valuable insights into the use of gastric electric pacemakers for postoperative ileus treatment.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in cancer patients receiving palliative care. The study consists of four groups: a music group, an aromatherapy group, a music and aromatherapy group, and a control group. The music group listens to specially composed music for 20 minutes a day for three consecutive days. The aromatherapy group inhales lavender oil for 15-20 minutes using a diffuser. The music and aromatherapy group receives both interventions. Pain, anxiety, blood pressure, pulse, and respiratory rate are measured before and after the interventions. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these interventions in improving the well-being of palliative care patients.

This clinical trial is testing the effectiveness of a device called the Somatosensation Device (SD) in enhancing feedback in lower extremities. The trial is focused on individuals with below-knee amputation or neuropathy in their lower limbs. The study will compare outcomes when participants use the SD device versus when they do not use it. The primary outcome measure is the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA), which tests postural stability and mobility while walking. Secondary outcome measures include the 10 Meter Walk Test, Mini-BESTest, Activities Specific Balance Confidence Scale (ABC), and Vestibular Disorders Activities of Daily Living Scale (VADL). The study design is non-randomized with a crossover assignment, and the intervention is an open-label treatment. The study will assess participants' performance with and without the SD device to determine its effectiveness in improving balance and mobility.

This clinical trial aims to treat the symptoms of vertigo using a device called the OtoBand. The trial will be conducted in a real-world setting and will use technology and virtual meetings to communicate with participants and collect data. The study seeks to enroll a total of 36 participants in the Moderate or Worse (MoW) group and 72 participants in the Quality of Life (QoL) group. Participants will be randomized to receive either the active OtoBand device or a sham device. They will be required to use the device during vertigo episodes and complete various questionnaires. The study will assess the effectiveness of the OtoBand in reducing vertigo severity and improving quality of life. The trial received Therapeutic Breakthrough Device designation from the FDA.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the multistrain probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active in preventing upper respiratory tract infections (URTI) in older people. The study will include participants who are 65 years or older and able to eat independently. Participants with exacerbations of chronic or metabolic diseases, mental incapacity, or prescribed long-term antibiotics will be excluded. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the experimental group receiving OMNi-BiOTiC® Active or the placebo group. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of URTI, while secondary outcome measures include the duration of URTI and changes in serum concentrations of leukocytes, immunoglobulin A (IgA), and other immune cells. The study will last for 12 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of Gong's and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques in treating Adhesive Capsulitis, a condition commonly known as frozen shoulder. Previous studies have shown that both techniques can improve pain relief, range of motion, and functional outcomes, but there has been no direct comparison between the two. The study will randomly assign participants to either Gong's or Kaltenborn's mobilization, and both groups will also receive routine physical therapy. Data will be collected at baseline, 1.5 weeks, and 3 weeks to assess pain, range of motion, and function. The goal of the study is to provide evidence-based insights into the relative effectiveness of the two techniques for clinicians treating patients with Adhesive Capsulitis.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of Disitamab Vedotin in combination with Pembrolizumab versus standard chemotherapy in previously untreated patients with locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma that expresses HER2. The study will measure the progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), control rate (DCR), and other secondary outcomes. The trial will include participants aged 18 or older and will be conducted in an open-label, randomized, controlled phase 3 design. The study will last approximately 5 years and will assess the safety and effectiveness of the treatment options.

This clinical trial aims to study the effect of lactoferrin on improving clinical outcomes in ICU patients compared to a placebo. Lactoferrin is a milk protein with various beneficial effects such as antioxidant, immunomodulatory, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antiviral effects. The trial will be a double-blind, randomized controlled trial with 650 ICU patients who will be randomly assigned to receive either lactoferrin or a placebo. The primary outcomes measured include the 28-day mortality rate and the incidence of allergic or hypersensitivity reactions. Secondary outcomes include the day of death, need for invasive mechanical ventilation, duration of oxygen therapy and ICU stay, and various blood parameters. The study will adhere to ethical considerations and patient confidentiality.

This clinical trial is a 10-week randomized double-blinded crossover trial comparing a chitin-glucan based formulation (BK003) to a placebo in patients with Crohn's disease in remission and experiencing irritable bowel syndrome-like symptoms. The study aims to assess the relief response rate, individual symptoms, stool consistency, stool number, IBS-related quality of life, anxiety and depression, serum CRP and fecal calprotectin levels, and adverse events. The trial will consist of a run-in period followed by two treatment periods with a washout period in between. Participants will be assessed through various measures and visits throughout the study.

This clinical trial aims to develop a novel biomarker, called virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA), for response prediction and prognosis of HBV-related hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients undergoing radiotherapy (RT). The investigators will test the consistency of junctional clones and quantify the changes in copy numbers of vh-DNA in pre- and post-RT serum samples and surgical tissues. They will also analyze the changes in plasma vh-DNA copies and correlate them with treatment response and overall survival.
