The study will further explore the clonality of recurrent/metastatic tumors using HBV integration patterns. The results will support the use of personalized vh-DNA for evaluating treatment response, disease monitoring, and designing future clinical trials. The study measures several outcomes, including the analysis of Capture-NGS, vh-DNA specific PCR, serial changes of serum vh-DNA copies, survival, concordance of vh-DNA copies between serum and plasma samples, and association of plasma vh-DNA copies with treatment response and overall survival.

This clinical trial focuses on developing an online individual intervention program called Meaning Centered Coping Program (MCCP) for women diagnosed with breast cancer. The program aims to reduce psychological distress and enhance the sense of meaning in life for individuals with breast cancer. The study will compare the effectiveness of MCCP to a control group in terms of improvements in meaning in life, post-traumatic growth, situational meaning, automatic meaning making efforts, psychological flexibility, and psychological distress. The trial will involve 44 women with breast cancer who will be randomly assigned to either the MCCP group or the waitlist control group. Various measurement tools will be used to assess the outcomes, and statistical analyses will be conducted using SPSS. The study has obtained ethical approval and will be conducted online via video conference.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in individuals with a lower limb amputation (LLA) and their association with clinical outcomes. The study will assess nutritional intake, diet quality, nutritional status, muscle mass, muscle strength, body mass index, and physical activity level at different time points post-LLA. Secondary outcome measures include mortality, wound healing, quality of life, potential level of functioning, and physical functioning. The study design involves no intervention, and participants must meet certain inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study will provide valuable insights into the nutritional and physical activity needs of individuals with a LLA and their impact on clinical outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility and advantages of conducting a remote clinical trial using multiple medications in patients with type 2 diabetes and elevated albuminuria. The trial will focus on the individual response to the SGLT2 inhibitor empagliflozin and whether suboptimal treatment responses can be overcome by adding or switching to the MRA finerenone. The trial will involve 10 participants who will undergo a 10-week treatment period. The primary outcomes will include participants' perspectives on the feasibility of a home-based trial and the number and percentage of missed urine collections, blood pressure measurements, and body weight measurements. Secondary outcomes will assess the individual response to empagliflozin in terms of urine albumin-creatinine ratio, systolic blood pressure, body weight, estimated glomerular filtration rate, and fasting plasma glucose. The trial will utilize digital technologies for data collection and will involve questionnaire assessments and remote monitoring devices. The study duration is expected to be 10 weeks, with an estimated time commitment of approximately 25 hours for participants.

This clinical trial aims to test the effects of high-intensity interval training on the physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college male ice hockey players in China. The study will involve a 12-week intervention using high-intensity interval training on the ice. There will be an experimental group and a control group, each consisting of 20 students. The experimental group will undergo specific training drills to improve their performance, while the control group will receive traditional training. The study will measure various outcomes, including maximal oxygen uptake, endurance performance, power performance, agility and skill performance, passing and shooting performance, and tactical performance. The results will provide insights into the effectiveness of high-intensity interval training for ice hockey players.

This clinical trial aims to study the effect of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash on the oral microbiome, salivary pellicle proteins, and vascular function in individuals with dental erosion. The study will be a double-blind, randomized crossover trial involving healthy control participants and individuals with dental erosion. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either an antibacterial CHX mouthwash or a placebo CHX mouthwash. Various samples and measurements will be collected from the participants during 15 visits. The study will assess the identification of salivary proteins, microbiome diversity, blood pressure, endothelial function, nitrate and nitrite levels, and oxidative stress markers.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether a Pain and Coordination Plan (PAC-plan) for patients after accidental injury can reduce opioid use and improve quality of life. The study will be a prospective randomized controlled trial, with patients recruited from a specialized hospital in Norway. The primary outcome measure is oral morphine equivalent (OMEQ) consumption 6 weeks after discharge, with secondary outcome measures including OMEQ at 52 weeks, pain intensity scores, health-related quality of life, and other patient-reported outcome measures. The study will also collect data from the Norwegian Prescription Database and the Norwegian Patient Registry. The intervention group will receive the PAC-plan, which includes an opioid management plan, a follow-up appointment with their general practitioner, and increased collaboration between the GP and hospital specialists. The control group will receive treatment and follow-up as usual. The study will provide valuable insights into reducing opioid use and improving pain management in patients after accidental injuries.

This clinical trial is titled "Guided Versus Standard Antiplatelet Therapy in Intracranial Aneurysm Intervention With Stents: a Cluster Randomized Controlled Cohort Study" and aims to compare the effectiveness of guided antiplatelet therapy versus standard antiplatelet therapy in patients with intracranial aneurysms who undergo stent implantation. The study will include patients aged 18-80 who have unruptured intracranial aneurysms and have been on standard dual antiplatelet therapy for at least 5 days before the stent implantation. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of ischemic events, such as ischemic stroke, transient ischemic stroke (TIA), and stent thrombosis, within 30 days after stent implantation. The study design is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study, with participants being randomly assigned to either the control group (continuing with the center's original antiplatelet regimen) or the test group (using a guided antiplatelet regimen based on platelet function testing).

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between bone mineral density (BMD), gross motor function (GMF), and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy (CP). CP is a neuromotor disorder that affects movement, muscle tone, and posture. Children with CP often experience motor impairments that can negatively impact their bone health, leading to reduced BMD and increased risk of skeletal complications. Gross motor function refers to the ability to perform coordinated movements using large muscle groups and is closely associated with bone health in this population. Understanding the impact of GMF on quality of life is crucial for comprehensive care and intervention planning. The study will involve children with CP aged 7 to 10 years and will assess BMD, GMF, and quality of life using standardized tools. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the factors influencing the holistic well-being of children with CP.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the dopaminergic mechanisms related to working memory, learning, and motivation. The study will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and a pharmacological intervention with the drug Sulpiride. The trial will assess various measures, including reaction time, accuracy, and BOLD-response during working memory gating tasks and cognitive effort investment tasks. Secondary outcome measures will include eye-blink rate, working memory capacity, depressive symptoms, impulsivity, and anxiety levels. The study will be conducted on healthy volunteers between the ages of 18 and 45.

The clinical trial, titled "Hypertension in High School Students: Genetic and Environmental Factors" aims to determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension in a cohort of adolescents, perform genetic analyses to identify links between specific genes and hypertension, and explore the relationship between urine markers and hypertension and cardiovascular risk. The study will enroll high school students from different regions of Italy and collect data through questionnaires, blood pressure measurements, urine and saliva samples. The study will also analyze genetic polymorphisms and perform urine tests to measure inflammation and oxidative stress markers. The primary outcome measure is to establish a link between specific gene polymorphisms and hypertension. The study will span over 2 years and includes participants aged 13 to 19 who are of Caucasian ethnicity.

This clinical trial, called the EPigenetic Consequences in Children of Intravenous vs Volatile Anaesthesia for Surgery (EPIVA), aims to investigate the impact of different types of anesthesia on epigenetic changes in children. The trial will randomly assign participants undergoing hypospadias surgery to receive either intravenous or inhalational anesthesia. Blood samples will be taken before and after the surgery for laboratory analysis, including epigenetic, biochemical, haematological, and redox testing. The primary objective of the trial is to assess the feasibility of conducting a larger-scale study on anesthesia and surgery in relation to epigenetic changes. The secondary objectives include exploring the association between anesthesia and surgery with epigenetic changes in whole blood and identifying the specific genes, pathways, and biological processes involved. The study will also assess recruitment and retention rates, protocol compliance, and the acceptability of the trial process for participants and clinical staff. The findings of the study will be shared with the scientific community and the legal representatives of the children involved.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of additional markers to improve laboratory diagnostics in hypothyroid patients using levothyroxine. The study will focus on patients with different forms of hypothyroidism, such as Hashimoto's disease, hypothyroidism after thyroidectomy, central hypothyroidism, and hypothyroidism during treatment for Graves' disease. The primary outcome measures will include the concentrations of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), free thyroxine (fT4), free triiodothyronine (fT3), and the ratio of fT3 to fT4. Secondary outcome measures will include total thyroxine (TT4), total triiodothyronine (TT3), reversed triiodothyronine (rT3), sex-hormone binding globulin (SHBG), acylcarnitines, and amino acids. The study will involve a single extra blood draw and completion of a questionnaire for each participant. The results of this study could improve the monitoring of thyroid hormone status in patients with hypothyroidism using levothyroxine.

This clinical trial, titled "Palliative NonOperative Management in Selected Elderly With a Limited Life Expectancy Who Sustained a Hip Fracture," aims to implement palliative non-operative management (PNOM) in all Dutch hospitals for frail elderly patients with hip fractures and limited life expectancy. The study will utilize shared decision-making between patients/families and medical specialists to determine whether surgery or PNOM is the preferred treatment. The study will consist of four phases, including interviews with healthcare professionals and patient representatives, development of educational modules, and implementation of the PNOM protocol. The target population includes frail elderly individuals aged 70 or older who live in nursing homes or receive similar care and meet specific criteria related to malnutrition, mobility issues, or severe comorbidities. The study design is a multicenter prospective cohort study, and data collection will involve automated data extraction and interviews with healthcare professionals and patients/proxy/next of kin. The primary outcome measure is nonoperative treatment after 6 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to generate proof-of-concept for using physiological MRI techniques to create a more precise clinical target volume (CTV) for radiotherapy treatment planning in patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma. The current standard CTV includes healthy tissue that does not need radiation, causing side effects. By using advanced MRI techniques to assess oxygenation status and cell proliferation, the researchers will create a physiological CTV that specifically includes microscale tumor invasion while sparing healthy tissue. The study will compare the physiological CTV with the standard CTV in terms of volume and location and will also analyze pattern-of-failure to assess tumor recurrence. The study population will consist of 10 patients diagnosed with glioblastoma who are scheduled to undergo standard treatment with radiotherapy. The intervention involves extending the MRI scan time to include advanced MRI techniques. The primary outcome measures will be volume and location analysis of the physiological and standard CTVs, while the secondary outcome measure will be pattern-of-failure analysis. The study is designed as a single-group assignment and will follow participants for up to 2 years.

This clinical trial aims to assess the acceptance and effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in systemic sclerosis patients treated with autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT). The study will compare the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 infection between SSc patients who underwent AHSCT and those who did not. Secondary outcome measures include the proportion of patients who refused vaccination, the time of onset of COVID-19 infection, the severity of symptomatic COVID-19, the occurrence of adverse events after vaccination, and the humoral response to the vaccine. The study will be conducted over a period of 18 months.

The clinical trial, titled "Connecting Families to Improve Parental Self-efficacy and Parent Psychosocial and Infant Health Outcomes in the NICU Using an eHealth Solution (The CONNECT Study)," aims to examine the effectiveness and implementation of CNH+ (an eHealth solution) in improving parental self-efficacy, parent psychosocial outcomes, and infant health outcomes in the NICU. The study will be conducted in four Canadian NICUs and will use a stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial design. The primary outcome measures include changes in parental self-efficacy, parental level of stress, parental level of NICU-specific stressors, parental level of depression, parental quality of life, perceived amount of family-centered care and family engagement in care, and infant weight growth, among others. Secondary outcome measures include infant neurological, hearing, vision, and development scores, as well as various infant health outcomes.

This clinical trial investigates the effects of physical activity on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in women at risk of osteoporosis. The study includes women with medium and high risk of osteoporosis and utilizes the Otago Exercise Program, which consists of strengthening exercises and balance exercises. Participants in the experimental group also engage in moderate-intensity walking exercise. The study aims to measure various outcomes such as lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, and quality of life. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking. The intervention group undergoes the Otago Exercise Program and walking exercise, while the control group does not receive any intervention. The study measures the specified outcomes before and after the treatment period. Additionally, dynamic balance is evaluated as a secondary outcome measure.

This clinical trial aims to determine the feasibility and effectiveness of a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents with overweight or obesity. The trial will be a two-arm pilot randomized controlled trial, with one arm receiving usual care and the other arm receiving a nutrition intervention through text messaging. The primary outcome measure will be the change in overall Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 score, and secondary outcome measures will include changes in urinary concentration of sodium and potassium. The trial will involve 14 adolescents aged 14-17 years who are at risk for poor diet quality. The intervention arm will include components such as personalized goals, meal timing, nutrition skills, and home food environment interventions. The trial will take place over a period of six weeks.

This clinical trial aims to predict the occurrence of cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS) after carotid artery stenting (CAS) by using multi-parameter characteristics based on cerebral autoregulation. The study will enroll 400 patients with carotid artery stenosis and perform transcranial Doppler (TCD) to identify CH. CH will be defined as an increase in middle cerebral artery (MCA) mean velocity by more than 100% within 48 hours after CAS. The diagnosis of CHS will be based on specific criteria, including the appearance of symptoms within 1 month after surgery and an increase in cerebral blood flow in the MCA. The study will also assess postoperative complications such as CHS, major stroke, and the incidence of hyperperfusion within 7 days after CAS. The intervention will involve carotid artery stenting, and the study will analyze various ultrasonic measurements and parameters before and after CAS. The study aims to identify the risk factors for CHS and improve the prediction of postoperative complications after CAS.

This clinical trial aims to test the effectiveness of an expressive writing intervention for informal caregivers of individuals with cancer. The intervention involves participants writing about their thoughts and feelings regarding their loved one's cancer and their role as a caregiver. The study will be conducted through group-based videoconference sessions. The primary outcomes being measured include psychological distress, general quality of life, and caregiver-specific quality of life. Secondary outcomes include depression and perceived stress. The study will use a randomized crossover design with a waitlist control group. Participants must be 18 years or older and English-speaking.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of intravenous Tranexamic Acid (TXA) in patients undergoing Gender Affirming Mastectomy (GAM). The trial will be conducted at the University of California San Francisco and will include patients who meet the WPATH guidelines for GAM, are ASA I-III, and are over 18 years old. Patients will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group receiving IV TXA or a control group that will not receive IV TXA. The primary outcomes of the study will include the presence of hematoma, seroma, and drain output, as well as the time to drain removal. Secondary outcomes will consist of thromboembolic events and wound complications. The trial will assess these outcomes over a 3-month postoperative period, with a 1-year follow-up review.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of smell training (ST) and trigeminal nerve stimulation (TNS) in treating COVID-related smell loss. The trial will include three groups: one receiving active ST, one receiving placebo ST, and one receiving both active TNS and active ST. The primary objectives of the trial are to determine the efficacy of ST compared to natural gains in function, the TNS-enhanced effects of ST on smell loss, and whether TNS+ST is more effective than ST alone in treating other symptoms of long COVID. The trial will measure various outcomes such as psychophysical olfactory function, perceived intensity and hedonics of odorants, olfactory-related quality of life, and the impact of olfactory loss. Secondary outcomes include changes in long COVID symptoms, sustained attention, cognitive function, mood state, sleep quality, excessive daytime sleepiness, symptoms of depression, and symptoms of anxiety.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of acupuncture therapy in treating primary insomnia. The study will involve participants with chronic insomnia who meet specific inclusion criteria. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the acupuncture group or the placebo acupuncture group. The primary outcome measure will be the change in insomnia severity before and after treatment, as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. Secondary outcome measures include fatigue levels, daytime sleepiness, anxiety, depression, and physiological parameters measured through polysomnography and heart rate variability. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and triple masking.

This clinical trial, titled "Shorter Anthracycline-Free Chemo Immunotherapy Adapted to Pathological Response in Early Triple Negative Breast Cancer (SCARLET), A Randomized Phase III Study," aims to assess whether a shorter chemotherapy regimen without anthracycline drugs is non-inferior to the standard regimen for early-stage triple negative breast cancer. The study also aims to compare various secondary outcomes, including pathological response rates, survival rates, and patient-reported outcomes. The trial will involve randomizing participants into two treatment arms and collecting blood samples throughout the trial. Participants will be followed up for up to 5 years.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP), which is an intensive case management intervention for pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during pregnancy. The program provides mothers with a case manager who helps them set goals, provides practical assistance, and offers emotional support. The trial seeks to establish evidence of the program's effectiveness in preventing the need for foster care, promoting reunification, and achieving other key goals such as parent recovery and preventing subsequent substance-exposed pregnancies. The trial will enroll 100 participants in Oklahoma and compare outcomes between a treatment group receiving PCAP-1 services and a control group receiving usual services. The study will measure outcomes such as the proportion of children not placed in foster care, mother's acquisition or maintenance of child custody, abstinence from drugs and/or alcohol, reliable use of birth control, reduction in costs to state agencies, stable housing, employment, enrollment in educational programs, receipt of public benefits, and criminal justice involvement. The study will use a non-randomized allocation and parallel assignment design, with the treatment group receiving PCAP-1 services and the control group receiving usual services. The study will collect data through surveys, interviews, and case manager reports. The findings will contribute to the evidence base for the PCAP program and inform its sustainability, spread, and replication.

This clinical trial aims to compare three optical measurement devices - Tomey OA-2000, Tomey CASIA2, and LenStar LS900. The study will include participants with cataract, aphakic eye, and pseudophakia. The eligibility criteria include age 22 and above, ability to follow instructions, and agreement to participate. Exclusion criteria include inability to tolerate ophthalmic imaging, current ocular pathology, active ocular infection, and history of ocular surgery. The study will measure the agreement between the test devices and the predicate device, the precision of the test devices, and the safety of the test devices. The study will last approximately 4 months.

This is a Phase III clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of rituximab plus zanubrutinib versus rituximab monotherapy in previously untreated patients with splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL). The trial aims to determine if the combination treatment improves progression-free survival (PFS) compared to rituximab alone. Approximately 120 patients will be randomized to receive either zanubrutinib and rituximab or rituximab alone. The study will consist of a screening phase, treatment phase, and follow-up phase. The primary outcome measure is the PFS rate at 3 years. Secondary outcome measures include complete remission rates, best response, time to next anti-lymphoma treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and treatment-emergent adverse events.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of continuous serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) with continuous thoracic epidural in managing pain during thoracic surgeries for malignancy resection. The hypothesis is that continuous SAPB can reduce opioid requirements, improve pain scores, and provide more stable intraoperative hemodynamics compared to thoracic epidural. The study will include 74 patients and will evaluate the total morphine requirement, intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to first analgesia, postoperative pain scores, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfaction. The participants will be randomized into two groups, and the study will be conducted in a double-blinded manner. The primary outcome measure is postoperative total morphine requirement. The secondary outcome measures include intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to first analgesia, postoperative pain, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfaction.

This clinical trial aims to enhance parent/caregiver engagement in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) through the use of a PICU journal intervention. The study will involve approaching eligible participants and obtaining their consent. Participants will then complete a short demographic survey and receive the PICU Journal along with instructions on how to use it. Data will be collected at three time points: 24-72 hours after admission, peri-discharge, and 3 months post-discharge. The study will measure outcomes such as parent/caregiver reported stress levels, care engagement levels, depression and anxiety symptoms, impact of events, PICU journal use and satisfaction, child reported impact of events, parent/caregiver experiences, and PICU staff perceptions. The study design is non-randomized and the intervention is the PICU Journal. The study aims to support parents/caregivers of children hospitalized in the PICU and improve their engagement in the care process.

This clinical trial aims to improve access to therapy services for Hispanic and Latino families with autistic children. The study compares two methods of stakeholder engagement, Design Thinking and Focus Groups, to gather input on the barriers and facilitators to accessing therapy for autistic children. The researchers will use this input to adapt an occupational therapy intervention manual for Hispanic and Latino autistic children. The outcomes of the study will provide data on the most effective stakeholder engagement method and a culturally adapted manual for clinicians and researchers. The study utilizes a randomized mixed methods design and will evaluate stakeholder engagement and the acceptability and feasibility of the adapted intervention manuals. The study will be conducted in Spanish and/or English based on participant preferences. The goal of the project is to improve the functional skills and health of Hispanic/Latino autistic children and their families.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate harm reduction products as a second line intervention for adult smokers who do not quit with nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). The study will include participants aged 22 to 65 who smoke at least 10 cigarettes per day. The study will involve different interventions, including Nicoderm, Nicorette gum, Nicorette lozenge, BIDI e-cigarette, and on! nicotine pouch. The participants will be divided into different groups based on their response to NRT and their preference for certain products. The primary outcome measure will be the change in smoke exposure for NRT non-responders, measured by expired air CO at week 10 compared to baseline. Secondary outcome measures include smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of the flipped learning model on nursing students' knowledge of asepsis and learning skills. The flipped learning model involves students accessing course materials, such as videos and presentations, before coming to class and then reinforcing their learning in the classroom. The study will be conducted with first-year nursing students, and the intervention will consist of presenting videos on asepsis to the experimental group. The study will last for 4 weeks, and participants will be tested on their knowledge before and after the intervention. The control group will receive normal course education. The primary outcome measure is the effect of the flipped learning model on the course success of nursing students. The study will be a randomized controlled trial.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the ability of Epitel's Remote EEG Monitoring System (REMI) to capture and record electroencephalography (EEG) data during seizure events in an ambulatory setting for extended periods of 14-28 days. The study aims to demonstrate that the REMI system can accurately record EEG data that clinicians can use to identify seizure events over extended periods, and that this extended clinical EEG data is valuable in diagnosing and treating seizure-related symptoms. The study will assess the number of ictal events identified in the first 14 days and compare it to the number identified in days 1-14 and days 1-28. The study will include patients with a reported history of seizures who are scheduled for an ambulatory EEG study.

This clinical trial aims to analyze and compare the effects of a multicomponent training program versus a continuous cardiovascular training program on blood pressure levels in adult hypertensive subjects. The trial will be a controlled, randomized, longitudinal, and prospective study, with three groups: multicomponent training, continuous cardiovascular training, and a control group. The study will recruit 75 hypertensive subjects between the ages of 40 and 65. The interventions will consist of 12 weeks of training, with two sessions per week, lasting 60 minutes each. The study will measure various outcomes, including blood pressure, body composition, strength, and cardiovascular capacity.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the observance of preoperative fasting time before and after a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting guidelines. The study will measure fasting time before surgery as the primary outcome, and secondary outcomes include preoperative oral carbohydrate loading, fasting exceeding 12 hours, preoperative anxiety and discomfort, feeling of thirst and hunger, preoperative nausea or vomiting, postoperative nausea or vomiting, patient satisfaction, post-operative quality of recovery, length of stay, and post-operative surgical complications. The study will include adult patients undergoing surgical procedures, and the intervention involves a sensitization campaign that includes lectures, reminders, fasting cards, and messaging services. The study will also assess keywords related to fasting, quality of recovery, and surgery.

This clinical trial aims to test the effects of a mentoring intervention on physical activity and health outcomes among overweight and obese children in rural Appalachia. The intervention involves structured peer mentoring delivered by high school students, with a family reinforcement program provided by parents. The study will be a community-based randomized controlled trial, with half of the participants receiving the mentoring intervention and the other half receiving self-guided modules. The primary outcome measure is the change in daily physical activity, while the secondary outcome measure is the change in body composition. The goal of the study is to reduce the rates of obesity and type 2 diabetes in Appalachia youth through effective interventions.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of virtual reality animation and ice massage on labor pain, duration of labor, and satisfaction. The study will include term primiparous and singleton pregnancies with a cervical dilatation of 0-3 cm. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive ice massage or watch virtual reality animation during labor. The primary outcome measures include labor pain, duration of labor, and birth satisfaction. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to study the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease in pediatric and adult liver transplant recipients in China. The study will include participants who have received their first liver transplant within 10 days prior to enrollment. The primary outcome measures include the observation of clinically significant CMV reactivation or CMV disease within 12 months of transplantation, the end of follow-up survey, and participant death within 22 months after transplantation. Secondary outcome measures include loss to follow-up and participant withdrawal from the study. The study will be conducted in both children and adult groups.

This clinical trial aims to address the treatment gap for cognitive rehabilitation of spatial neglect (SN) after right brain stroke. The researchers aim to develop a personalized approach to SN rehabilitation using prism adaptation therapy (PAT). They will identify specific neurobiological features predictive of PAT treatment response and develop a biomarker-based algorithm to assign SN rehabilitation. The study will validate brain imaging biomarkers that predict the presence of Aiming SN, examine the correlation between these biomarkers and improvements in daily life function after PAT, and determine if adding behavioral predictors accounts for additional variance in functional recovery. The overall goal is to establish the utility of a validated biomarker that can identify the best candidates for PAT and improve stroke care efficiency for Veterans. The study design is non-randomized and the primary outcome measures include SN type and functional independence improvement trajectory. Secondary outcome measures include SN severity assessed by the Behavioral Inattention Test and the Catherine Bergego Scale.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of liquid biopsy as a diagnostic tool for gliomas. The study will analyze blood samples obtained from patients with brain lesions suggestive of a glioma and detect and quantify the circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) using a ddPCR. The specific mutations present in the ctDNA will be identified to confirm the presence of a glioma and determine its classification as astrocytoma or oligodendroglioma. The study will compare the results of the liquid biopsy with the corresponding tissue biopsies and evaluate other variables such as time, cost, and impact on the patient. The primary outcome measure is the detection of circulating free DNA in blood samples using ddPCR. The study will take place over a period of one year.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and resection rate for patients with borderline resectable pancreatic cancer (BRPC) and progression-free survival for patients with locally advanced pancreatic cancer (LAPC) treated with a combination of chemotherapy (mFOLFIRINOX), quemliclustat, and zimberelimab. The trial also aims to assess the development of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula in the BRPC cohort after neoadjuvant treatment. Secondary objectives include measuring decreases in CA 19-9 levels, objective response rate, pathologic complete response rate, and overall survival. The study will collect blood samples and perform computed tomography scans throughout the trial, as well as collect tissue samples from patients with BRPC and perform core biopsies on patients with LAPC. The eligibility criteria include having previously untreated pancreatic adenocarcinoma with either borderline resectable or locally advanced disease. The study is designed as a single group assignment with an open-label approach. The primary outcomes measured include the incidence of adverse events, resection rate, progression-free survival, and the development of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula. Secondary outcomes include changes in CA 19-9 levels, objective response rate, pathologic complete response rate, and overall survival.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of probiotics on depression syndrome and risk factors of cardiovascular disease in hemodialysis patients. The study will include adults aged 20 years or older undergoing hemodialysis for at least 3 months. The intervention involves the use of MIYAIRI 588. The primary outcome measure is the change in depression score measured using the Beck Depression Inventory score at 3 months. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial, titled "StuDy AimED at Increasing AlCohol AbsTinEnce (DEDICATE)," aims to test the feasibility and acceptability of an integrated behavioral intervention called CM-PST to increase alcohol abstinence in young adults with Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD). The trial consists of two phases: a formative phase (K99) and a preliminary efficacy phase (R00). 

In the K99 phase, 20 participants will be recruited to test the CM-PST intervention, which involves 8 individual sessions delivered via videoconferences over 12 weeks. Participants will complete a satisfaction survey after each session. 

In the R00 phase, young adults aged 18-24 with AUD will be randomized into two groups: CM-PST (42 participants) or CM-only control (42 participants). Both groups will receive incentives for alcohol abstinence and urine samples. Participants will undergo baseline assessments and follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months.

The primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence, monitored for up to 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in AUD severity, AUD screening status, alcohol-related negative consequences, alcohol and drug use, reasons for drinking, and affect. The neural target engagement of positive affect, negative affect, and cognitive control will also be measured using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

Overall, this trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of CM-PST in increasing alcohol abstinence and reducing AUD severity in young adults.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of a triplet therapy (encorafenib, binimetinib, pembrolizumab) with a doublet/control therapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab) in patients with advanced melanoma. The trial will include approximately 150 participants with BRAF V600E/K-mutant melanoma who have progressed after prior treatment with an anti-PD-1 monotherapy. The participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive either the triplet or doublet/control therapy. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate, while secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, overall survival, and duration of response. The trial will also assess adverse events and patient-reported outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation applications on simulation-based learning, reflective thinking, and therapeutic communication skills in undergraduate nursing students. The study will be conducted at Hacettepe University Faculty of Nursing using scenarios based on diabetes mellitus. The research will include second-year nursing students who have completed the Nursing Fundamentals course but are not yet fully equipped to intervene with patients. The sample size will be 76 students, divided into two groups: one receiving high fidelity simulation and the other receiving high fidelity simulation and virtual reality. Data will be collected through pre- and post-tests using various scales and forms. The primary outcome measures include the Simulation Based Learning Scale, Reflective Thinking Skills for Problem Solving Scale, and Therapeutic Communication Skills Scale. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with masking. The interventions include high fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation. The data will be analyzed using statistical methods in IBM SPSS Statistics 23 program. The study aims to improve nursing education and raise awareness of simulation applications among students.

This clinical trial aims to compare the reduction of microemboli of air using a newly developed air trap called EmbolessTM during hemodialysis. The trial will include chronic hemodialysis patients who will be randomized to use either the EmbolessTM air trap or the standard air trap (Fresenius 4008/5008) in a crossover design. The microbubbles will be counted using ultrasound probes at the inlet and outlet sides of the air trap. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of air microemboli contamination, and the secondary outcome measures include the comparison of air contamination between hemodialysis and hemodiafiltration, as well as monitoring adverse events.

This clinical trial aims to investigate how repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (theta burst stimulation) affects movement in individuals with and without a history of concussion. The goal is to improve injury risk biomechanics and reduce the risk of musculoskeletal injury. Participants will undergo testing sessions where they will perform various tasks and receive theta burst stimulation. The study will assess reaction time, knee and hip angles, trunk flexion and lateral bending angles, as well as the NASA Task Load Index and Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia 11. The study design is a single-blinded cross-over design, with participants unaware of when they receive the experimental or control conditions. The intervention involves repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex or the vertex. The study will measure the effects of the intervention on various movement parameters and psychological factors.

This clinical trial, titled "Extended Pancreatic Neck Transection Versus Conventional Pancreatic Neck Transection During Laparoscopic Pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPDEXCEPT): a Multicenter Randomized Controlled Trial," aims to compare the outcomes of extended pancreatic neck transection versus conventional pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy. The study includes patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors of the lower common bile duct, Vater ampulla, head or uncinate process of the pancreas. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula, while secondary outcome measures include the location of the pancreatic duct in the pancreatic transverse section, surgical performance of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity, and postoperative mortality. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and no masking. The experimental group receives extended pancreatic neck transection, while the control group receives conventional pancreatic neck transection.

This randomized controlled clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of two types of concurrent training on functional performance, cognitive function, and quality of life in older adults. The two interventions being compared are traditional concurrent training, which includes strength exercises and aerobic exercise, and concurrent training consisting of strength training combined with dance classes. The study will assess various outcome measures, including dynamic balance, cognitive function, self-reported quality of life, static balance, seat to stand capacity, stairs climb capacity, leg strength and power, hand grip strength, and cardiorespiratory capacity. Secondary outcome measures include quadriceps muscle thickness, affectivity with the intervention, lipid profile, specific tension of quadriceps, and depressive symptoms. The study will involve participants aged 65 to 75 years who do not regularly engage in physical exercises and do not have certain health conditions. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of the intervention groups or a control group. The study design is a parallel assignment with a single masking. The outcomes will be measured at baseline, 8 weeks, and 12 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of a virtual reality-based sensory stimulation intervention in preventing delirium in intensive care units. The study will include ICU patients who are at least 18 years old and are admitted to the ICU for the first time with a Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale score of at least -3. Patients with certain conditions, such as dementia or end-stage cancer, will be excluded. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with participants assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive the VR-based intervention, or the control group, which will receive usual care. The primary outcomes of the study will include delirium incidence, duration, and severity. Secondary outcomes will assess patients' psychological well-being, clinical outcomes, quality of life, independence, and cognitive function. The study will measure these outcomes over a period of up to fourteen days or until the patient is discharged from the ICU or passes away.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the outcome of surgical fixation of multiple fractured ribs at Sohag University Hospital. The study will include participants with multiple fractured ribs who require mechanical ventilation. The intervention group will undergo surgical rib fixation, while the control group will receive no intervention. The primary outcome measures include the need and duration of mechanical ventilation and the severity of thoracic pain. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial is comparing the acute psychobiological responses to two different stress tests: the Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST) and the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST). The study will involve healthy, recreationally active men and women aged 18-35 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the MMST or TSST group. The primary outcome measure will be the change in saliva cortisol levels before and after the stress test. Secondary outcome measures include state anxiety inventory response, heart rate, and salivary alpha amylase levels. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with participants being allocated to the MMST or TSST group. The study aims to compare the psychobiological responses between the two stress tests.

This clinical trial aims to assess the efficacy and safety of probiotic lysate supplementation in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study will involve a treatment period of 3 months, during which participants will receive a twice daily oral dose of probiotic lysate or a placebo. The primary outcomes measured will be changes in hepatic fat content as measured by MRI-PDFF and ultrasonography, as well as changes in fatty liver index. Secondary outcomes include measures of hepatic steatosis, liver enzymes, liver stiffness, and various blood markers. The study will also assess body composition and metabolic markers. The trial will be randomized and include a placebo control group.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effectiveness of using virtual reality (VR) as an adjuvant therapy for sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) in pediatric patients in the emergency department (ED). The study will compare the outcomes of patients who receive VR in addition to standard medical therapy to those who receive standard medical therapy alone. The primary outcomes being measured include pain scores and patient disposition (admission to the hospital or discharge from the ED). Secondary outcomes include length of stay in the ED and time to ED disposition. The study will have a control arm that involves retrospective chart analysis and a trial arm that involves prospective sampling of patients who will receive VR therapy. The study design is non-randomized and open-label. The intervention for the trial arm is the use of VR goggles with guided meditation software in addition to standard medical therapy. The study aims to recruit participants aged 6 to 21 years with sickle cell VOC.

This clinical trial aims to assess the efficacy of a web-based empowerment program for secondary cardiovascular prevention in patients who have experienced an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The intervention involves personalized, agreed-upon, multidisciplinary coaching and education delivered through a web platform. The study will measure changes in risk factors such as BMI, blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and glycemia, as well as lifestyle changes and adherence to cardioprotective treatment. The primary outcome measures will be assessed at 12 months, and long-term maintenance of controlled risk factors will be evaluated at 48 months. The study design is randomized with parallel assignment and no masking. The intervention group will receive digital empowerment, while the control group will receive usual care. The study accepts participants aged 18-75 years of both sexes. The trial aims to determine the efficacy of the intervention in improving secondary prevention and reducing the incidence of symptomatic coronary events.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures. The study will consist of a feasibility phase and an active study phase. In the feasibility phase, novice PsUS users will receive training and then perform elbow exams on participants between the ages of 1-16. The images will be reviewed to ensure accuracy. In the active study phase, children with isolated acute elbow pain will undergo standardized elbow exams using PsUS. The images will be assessed for signs of fracture before any radiographic imaging. The primary objective is to determine the test performance characteristics of PsUS compared to radiography in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures. The study will also evaluate the feasibility of PsUS training and protocol for obtaining adequate image capture. The intervention used in the study is the Butterfly IQ pocket-sized ultrasound device. The study is designed as a single-group diagnostic study, and the primary outcome measure is the accuracy of PsUS compared to X-ray or bedside nursemaid reduction as the gold standard. The secondary outcome measure is the feasibility of the study training and protocol for adequate image capture. The study is open to children between the ages of 1-16 with elbow injuries or fractures. Overall, the study aims to determine the diagnostic accuracy and feasibility of using PsUS for pediatric elbow fractures.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of two different orthoses on individuals with hallux valgus. The study will randomly assign participants to either a group using a toe separator orthosis or a group using a dynamic orthosis. The primary outcome measures will be the hallux valgus angle and plantar pressure. The participants will undergo foot pressure analysis before using the orthosis, when first wearing the orthosis, and one month after using the orthosis. Secondary outcome measures will include the Manchester-Oxford Foot Questionnaire to assess functional and social effects, as well as an evaluation of orthosis satisfaction. The study will include individuals between the ages of 18-65 with mild to moderate hallux valgus deformity.

This clinical trial aims to prospectively evaluate speech function in children with velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) and isolated or combined cleft palate who undergo surgical treatment with a pharyngeal flap. The study will use patient- and parent-response outcome measurements to assess speech function before and after the surgery. The primary outcome measures include speech function evaluated through the patient response outcome measurement CLEFT-Q and the parent-response outcome measurement Intelligibility in Context Scale. The study will evaluate the change in speech function preoperatively and 1 year postoperatively.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of probiotics for the treatment of alcohol use disorder in adult males. The study will be conducted in two hospitals in China and Malaysia. Participants will be informed of their rights and assured of their anonymity. Adverse effects will be monitored and reported to the ethics committees. The primary objective is to determine the differences in the severity of alcohol dependence, withdrawal, and craving among patients receiving probiotics, placebo, or acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) at four time points. Secondary objectives include assessing changes in depression and anxiety symptoms, EEG characteristics, serum levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines, and gut microbiota profiles. Participants will be recruited from the hospitals' patient populations, and baseline assessments will be conducted. The participants will then undergo detoxification treatment, followed by random assignment to one of three groups: probiotics + conventional treatment, placebo + conventional treatment, or ACT + conventional treatment. The primary outcomes will be measured using various scales and assessments, and data analysis will be performed using SPSS software. The study design is a double-blind, randomized controlled trial, and the estimated sample size is 120 subjects per group. The study will assess the effectiveness of probiotics in treating alcohol use disorder and provide insights into the underlying mechanisms.

This randomized controlled trial compares the use of barbed absorbable sutures versus standard absorbable sutures for vaginal cuff closure after laparoscopic hysterectomy. The study aims to measure outcomes such as vaginal cuff dehiscence, vaginal cuff complications, hospital stay, operative time, intraoperative blood loss, post-surgical morbidity, quality of life index, and sexual function. The trial will include female patients over the age of 18 undergoing elective laparoscopic hysterectomy. The study design is a multicenter, parallel arms, open-label trial with participants randomly assigned to either the experimental group (barbed sutures) or the active comparator group (standard sutures). The primary outcome measures will be assessed at 30 days and 90 days after surgery.

This clinical trial aims to test a new neurobiological model of gambling addiction that takes into account inter-individual differences and the multifactorial nature of gaming addiction. The primary objective is to determine if there are two opposite brain phenotypes in gambling addiction: striatal hyper-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hypo-reactivity to emotional stimuli, and striatal hypo-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hyper-reactivity to emotional stimuli. The secondary objective is to determine if these brain phenotypes can predict gambling behavior in everyday life. The study will involve cognitive tasks performed by participants in an fMRI scanner to measure striatal and amygdala reactivity, as well as Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) to assess gambling behavior and emotions in real life. The study population will include individuals with gambling problems and a control group of healthy subjects. The study plans to recruit 60 gamblers and 60 healthy controls.

This clinical trial compares the use of a 2D 4K laparoscopic imaging system versus a 3D HD laparoscopic imaging system in bariatric surgery. The study aims to measure the operation time as the primary outcome, and intraoperative complications, workload of the operating surgeon, and postoperative complications as secondary outcome measures. The trial includes patients who meet specific eligibility criteria and will undergo gastric bypass surgery using either the 2D 4K or 3D HD imaging system. The study design is randomized with parallel assignment and masking. The trial will evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the two imaging systems in bariatric laparoscopic surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Huaier granule in the treatment of stage I primary ovarian cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and peritoneal cancer. The study will also analyze the impact of Huaier granule on the quality of life of patients and evaluate its efficacy in patients with BRCA mutation and BRCA wild-type ovarian cancer. The trial will include patients who have undergone tumor reduction surgery and are not suitable for or unwilling to receive chemotherapy. The primary outcome measure is the 1-year progression-free survival rate, and secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, overall survival rate, quality of life score, pain score, and rates of adverse events. The study will be a single-center prospective single-arm study. The intervention will involve administering Huaier granule orally three times a day for 28 days, with no planned treatment interruption between cycles. The study will assess the efficacy and safety of Huaier granule in these patients.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO) in critically ill patients. The study will use a modified hydrogen breath test to diagnose SIBO in mechanically ventilated ICU patients. The primary objective is to assess the prevalence of SIBO in these patients, while secondary outcomes include investigating the effects of SIBO on ventilator-associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate. The study will enroll critically ill patients in need of mechanical ventilation with an expected ICU stay of more than 48 hours. Abnormal hydrogen breath test results on the day of ICU admission, recent antimicrobial therapy, and certain gastrointestinal conditions or surgeries are exclusion criteria. The study will measure the proportion of ICU patients diagnosed with SIBO, VAP, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality.

This clinical trial investigates the effect of exercises of different intensities on exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) in patients after total knee arthroplasty (TKA). The study randomly assigned 38 patients to either a low intensity exercises (LIE) group or a high intensity exercises (HIE) group. The exercise programs lasted for five days during the hospitalization period. Pain severity was assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured before and after exercise. The study aims to determine if EIH is present after exercise in TKA patients and if it changes with exercise intensity.

This clinical trial in Nigeria aims to assess the effects of risk assessment and counseling on adherence to risk reduction recommendations among female relatives of breast cancer patients. The study will involve individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counseling interventions. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving standard care and the other receiving standard care along with the interventions. The study will measure the effects of the interventions on adherence to breast screening and lifestyle risk reduction recommendations. It will also analyze predictors of breast self-examination and time to first breast cancer screening. Secondary outcomes include determining the participants' perception and knowledge of familial breast cancer risk, as well as their knowledge, attitude, and perception towards genetic testing and breast cancer etiology. The study will provide valuable insights into breast cancer prevention and risk reduction in southwest Nigeria.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the interaction between CYP2B6 genotype and the drugs methadone and tizanidine when taken with efavirenz. The study will enroll healthy volunteers who are genotyped for CYP2B6 allele (*6 and *18) and will assess the metabolism, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of methadone and tizanidine before and after oral pre-treatment with efavirenz. The study will have three phases: a control phase, an efavirenz treatment phase, and a steady-state phase. The primary outcome measure is the magnitude of the effects of CYP2B6 genotype and efavirenz on the disposition and pharmacodynamics of methadone and tizanidine. The study will provide insights into the drug-drug interaction and its impact on the metabolism and effects of methadone and tizanidine.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the serum magnesium levels in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study includes a cases group and a control group, both receiving a diagnostic test for magnesium. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of magnesium in the serum, and the study will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The eligibility criteria include having type 2 diabetes mellitus and excluding patients with renal failure, type I diabetes mellitus, acute pancreatitis, hyperthyroidism, hyperparathyroidism, malignancies, and certain medications or conditions that may affect magnesium levels.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on serum levels of IGF-1 and IL-6 in elderly patients with sarcopenia. The study will include elderly patients diagnosed with sarcopenia based on specific criteria. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving Ophiochepalus striatus extract or the control group receiving a placebo. The study will measure the levels of IGF-1 and IL-6 in the serum as primary outcomes, and secondary outcomes will include SARC-F score, muscle mass, muscle strength, and physical performance. The study will last for a duration of 2 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a mobile app called 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program as a digital therapeutic for patients suffering from chronic pain. The study will be a randomized control feasibility study with two arms: an intervention arm that will use the mobile app along with treatment as usual, and a control arm that will only receive treatment as usual. The primary outcome measure will be the PROMIS Pain Interference Scale, which assesses the patient's perceived pain interference in their ability to function. Secondary outcome measures include the Patient Health Questionnaire 9 and the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7, which measure depression and anxiety symptoms, respectively. The study will also assess the feasibility of using the mobile app and an optional activity tracker, as well as the feasibility of conducting a two-arm trial. The results of this study will provide valuable information for planning a larger efficacy trial.

This clinical trial is studying the use of the Stentless Florence Robotic Intracorporeal Neobladder (FloRIN) in patients undergoing radical cystectomy for bladder cancer. The trial aims to compare outcomes between patients who receive the FloRIN procedure without a ureteral stent and those who receive the procedure with a ureteral stent. The primary outcome measure is the rate of mid-term complications, while the secondary outcome measure is the rate of perioperative complications.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of different storage conditions on removable retainers. The primary objective is to compare the microbial colony counts of retainers in wet and dry storage conditions. Secondary objectives include comparing the surface roughness, color stability, and compressive strength of the retainers, as well as evaluating the oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) of participants. The study will involve 24 participants who will be randomly assigned to different storage conditions for their retainers. Various tests and measurements will be conducted at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months to assess the outcomes. The statistical analysis will be performed using SPSS Statistics. Overall, the study aims to provide evidence-based guidelines for the storage method of removable retainers.

This clinical trial aims to test a new model of continuity of nutrition care for older adults diagnosed with malnutrition. The study will examine the impact of enhanced referrals and communication between hospital and community nutrition care providers on outcomes such as food security, quality of life, and determinants of malnutrition. The trial will use a stepped wedge cluster-randomized design and will recruit individuals from vulnerable populations, including Black, Latino, Indigenous, Native Americans, and those living in rural areas. The intervention includes nutrition care provided by registered dietitian nutritionists (RDNs) in the community, using a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design. The primary outcome measure is the change in quality of life, while secondary outcome measures include program sustainability, barriers and facilitators to implementation, change in the percent of patients receiving nutrition care and meals, food security risk, and malnutrition risk and diagnosis. The study will last for a total of 35 months, with patients being recruited and enrolled over this period.

This clinical trial aims to study the hemodynamic effects of modulating circulating ketone bodies with 1,3-butanediol in patients with heart failure. The study will include participants with chronic heart failure who have a NYHA class II-III and a LVEF of less than 40%. The intervention will involve the administration of either 1,3-butanediol or a placebo. The primary outcome measure of the study is cardiac output, which will be measured using LVOT VTI and heart rate. Secondary outcome measures include stroke volume, heart rate, LVEF, changes in circulating 3-OHB, and changes in FFA. The study is designed as a randomized crossover trial with a single masking.

This clinical trial aims to study the use of subpectoral bupivacaine for pain management in adolescent reduction mammaplasty. The study will involve recruiting patients and randomizing them into either the study group (receiving bupivacaine) or the control group (not receiving bupivacaine). The patients will be blinded to their group assignment. The primary outcome measure will be post-operative pain scores, recorded by the PACU nurse and the patients themselves. Secondary outcome measures include narcotic use, length of stay in the post-anesthesia care unit, return to full activity, and demographic information. The study will assess if the use of bupivacaine is effective in reducing post-operative pain in adolescent reduction mammaplasty patients.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of pencil beam scanning proton therapy on skin toxicities in breast cancer patients. The study will assess the degree of skin reactions through digital photos, self-report questionnaires, and medical chart documentation. The Spot Delete technique will be used to reduce radiation dermatitis, and the extent of skin reactions will be compared to historical data. The effectiveness of the technique will be evaluated using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) and the Radiation Dermatitis Severity (RDS) scoring system. The study also aims to investigate the correlation between the linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam and skin reactions. The study will involve 100 patients over a three-year period.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate versus reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation in women undergoing in vitro fertilization. The trial is a multicenter non-inferiority, randomized controlled trial. The eligibility criteria include infertile women under the age of 43 who are planning to undergo IVF treatment. The study will measure the cumulative live birth rate as the primary outcome measure.

This clinical trial is studying the combination of peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin in patients with metastatic leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas. The primary objectives of the study are to evaluate the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy, determine the recommended phase 2 dose, and obtain a more precise determination of adverse events. Secondary objectives include assessing the pharmacokinetics of the drugs, estimating the objective response rate and progression-free survival, and testing hypotheses related to soft tissue sarcomas and biomarkers of response. The study design is a dose-escalation followed by a dose-expansion study, and participants will receive the study drugs orally and intravenously. The study will measure dose-limiting toxicity, incidence of adverse events, objective response rate, and progression-free survival.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility and potential benefits of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong program for reducing back pain and improving sleep and quality of life in individuals with chronic back pain. The study will involve a prospective, randomized controlled trial with two groups: a t'ai chi and qigong exercise group and a waitlist control group. The primary objective is to determine if the t'ai chi program improves pain levels, sleep, and quality of life. The secondary objective is to explore if improvements in pain levels differ among smokers and those with an unhealthy BMI. The study will include 300 participants and utilize validated survey instruments to assess outcomes. The intervention will consist of a 12-week, twice-weekly t'ai chi and qigong exercise program. The study will also include qualitative interviews to assess barriers and facilitators to implementing the online intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) score after three months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in visual analog scale (VAS) scores for back and leg pain, SF-36 questionnaire scores, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) scores.

The EMBOL-AF study is a retrospective registry that aims to investigate the characteristics of systemic arterial embolic events after treatment of atrial fibrillation (AF) by catheter ablation. The study will focus on cerebral embolism (stroke and transient ischemic attack) as these are the most frequent and clinically relevant complications. The study will gather data from cases of arterial embolism that have occurred over the last 5 years in participating centers. The primary objectives of the study are to study the acute clinical profile, therapeutic management, and sequelae of stroke/TIA associated with AF ablation. Secondary objectives include studying the association of stroke/TIA with specific ablation techniques and other measures related to AF ablation procedures. The study will be conducted retrospectively and will not involve any interventions. The study is expected to start in the fourth quarter of 2023.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the pain, discomfort, and acceptance of using electrical stimulation to accelerate orthodontic teeth movement. The trial will involve patients with class II division I malocclusion who meet the inclusion criteria. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving electrical stimulation and the other undergoing traditional retraction of the front teeth. The levels of pain and discomfort will be self-reported using questionnaires with visual analog scales. Other secondary outcome measures such as burning, swelling, chewing ability, speech ability, analgesic consumption, patient satisfaction, ease of the procedure, possibility of repeating the procedure, and recommendation of the procedure to a friend will also be assessed. The trial will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and patient experience of using electrical stimulation for orthodontic treatment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the association between baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio and cognitive decline in men starting Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) for prostate cancer. The trial also aims to assess if ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio and if intensified ADT (iADT) leads to greater cognitive decline compared to ADT. The study will involve cognitive assessments, blood samples, and quality of life surveys. The primary outcome measures include the proportion and mean cognitive decline in the ADT cohort, as well as the proportion of participants with cognitive impairment after ADT. Secondary outcome measures include changes in mean plasma Aβ42/40 ratio and cognition scores. The study will last for up to 12 months.

The clinical trial, titled "High-dose Cephalexin for Cellulitis (HI-DOCC)," aims to compare the effectiveness of high-dose cephalexin (1000 mg) with standard-dose cephalexin (500 mg) in treating adult patients with cellulitis. The trial will be conducted at 8 Canadian emergency departments and will include 446 patients. The primary outcome measure is oral antibiotic treatment failure within 7 days, while secondary outcomes include clinical cure, clinical response, unplanned healthcare visits, adverse events, antibiotic intolerance, antibiotic allergy, medication adherence, and health-related quality of life. The study's findings may help inform future guidelines for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections.

This clinical trial aims to determine the Turkish validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes in children aged 8-12 years. The study will also provide a diabetes health literacy board game to these children. The trial will be conducted in two stages, with the first stage involving a general screening to determine the current situation using the Health Literacy Scale. In the second stage, intervention and control groups will be randomly assigned and evaluated through pre-tests and follow-ups at the 1st and 3rd months after training. The primary outcome measures include the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale and the evaluation of diabetes health literacy in children. The intervention group will receive education through the board game, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with a crossover assignment, and the primary purpose is supportive care. The study will evaluate the effect of educational play on diabetes acute complications and health literacy in children.

This is a randomized controlled pilot clinical trial comparing the accumulation of biofilm on the surface of zirconia implants versus titanium implants. The study will be conducted in a dental surgery and implantology center in Madrid, Spain, following the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. Patients who require a single implant will be selected based on oral and radiological examinations. The implants will be placed using standard surgical techniques, and patients will receive post-operative antibiotic and analgesic treatment. The study will evaluate the presence and quantity of bacteria in the peri-implant sulcus, as well as other factors such as implant survival, probing depth, plaque index, and bone loss. The trial will include 30 subjects (15 in each group) to ensure robust results for future investigations. The randomization of subjects will be done using the block method, and statistical analysis will be performed to compare the results between the two groups. The primary outcome measure will be the total amount of biofilm on the implants at 6 months and 1 year after crown placement. The study aims to provide insights into the biofilm accumulation on zirconia and titanium implants.

This clinical trial is titled "Scentsational Smiles: The Impact of Aromatherapy on Alleviating Dental Anxiety in Children." The study aims to investigate the effect of aromatherapy on reducing dental anxiety in children aged 6 to 9 years old who require tooth extraction. The intervention involves inhaling rosemary or lemongrass oil before the procedure. The study will measure various outcomes including pulse rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, and pain levels. The trial design is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of puzzles on nursing students' learning of vital signs concepts. Puzzles are known to be effective active learning tools that improve problem-solving skills and motivation. The study will involve first-year nursing students and will provide an active and fun learning environment using puzzles related to respiration, pulse, and blood pressure. The research will be conducted through a randomized controlled study, with an experimental group using puzzles and a control group receiving regular education. The primary outcome measure will be the students' knowledge test scores. The study is expected to contribute positively to the students' knowledge level and overall course success.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of a Transtheoretic Model (TTM) and motivational interview-based intervention program on smartphone addiction and sleep quality in nursing students. The study will include nursing students from Aksaray University Faculty of Health Sciences who have been using smartphones for at least one year and score above the cut-off score on the Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Form. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive the motivational interviewing program based on the TTM, or the control group, which will not receive any intervention initially. The primary outcome measures include the Personal Information Form, Smartphone Addiction Scale Short Form, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, and Classification of Stages of Change Scale. The secondary outcome measures include the same scales administered at the 16-week mark. The study is designed as a quasi-experimental study with pre-test and post-test, with the intervention and control groups randomly selected. The study aims to provide valuable insights into addressing smartphone addiction and improving sleep quality in nursing students.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of potassium-titanyl phosphate (KTP) laser alone versus KTP laser combined with ivermectin 1% cream for the treatment of facial rosacea. The study will involve participants with Fitzpatrick skin types I-IV and will assess the reduction of erythema as the primary outcome measure.
