The DSS includes sections on metastatic breast cancer, adherence to cancer therapies, promoting adherence, and an adherence diary. A machine learning web application is also used to predict patients' risk factors for adherence. The study will enroll 100 patients and assess adherence over a three-month period. Secondary objectives include identifying clinical and psychological factors that predict adherence and evaluating risk perception. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with an experimental group receiving the DSS and a control group receiving standard medical advice. The primary outcome is the effectiveness of the DSS in fostering adherence.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of weight bearing exercises with and without Jaffrey's core stability exercise training on dynamic balance and trunk muscle strength in children with Down Syndrome. The study will include children aged 4 to 10 years who are able to stand and walk, with no orthopedic limitations or significant cognitive impairments. The participants will be randomly assigned to two groups: one will perform weight bearing exercises, and the other will perform Jaffrey's core stability exercises. The primary outcome measures of the study will be the Pediatric Balance Scale and the Trunk Control Measurement Scale, both assessed after 4 weeks of intervention.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of melatonin, a dietary supplement, on glycemic parameters, cardiovascular disease risk factors, bone metabolism markers, and quality of life in peritoneal dialysis patients. The study will include patients who have been on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis for at least 6 months and have a body mass index (BMI) below 35. The study will compare the effects of melatonin to a placebo and will measure various markers such as lipoprotein-a, malondialdehyde, high sensitivity c-reactive protein, fasting glucose, and others. The study will also assess blood pressure, triglyceride and cholesterol levels, quality of life, depression, and sleep quality using questionnaires. The study will last for 10 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to optimize oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass. The study will include patients aged 18 or older who are scheduled for elective cardiac surgery at a specific hospital in France. The intervention involves the use of cardiopulmonary bypass as usual care. The study will measure primary outcomes such as D02 values calculated using specific software and hemoglobin values. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury, postoperative delirium, and vital status. The trial will last up to 28 days and aims to improve oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery.

This clinical trial aims to examine the changes in skin surface temperature of the lumbar region during auricular acupressure at the kidney point on healthy volunteers. The study will recruit participants who meet the selection criteria and do not violate the exclusion criteria. The participants will be randomly divided into two groups: one receiving auricular acupressure first followed by sham auricular acupressure, and the other group receiving sham auricular acupressure first followed by auricular acupressure. The study will monitor various vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, body temperature, lumbar region temperature, and side effects of the auricular therapies. The primary outcome measures of the study are the changes in temperature of the left and right lumbar region, which will be recorded using an infrared thermal imaging camera. The secondary outcome measure is the proportion of side effects from auricular acupuncture. The study is designed as a randomized crossover assignment with masking.

This clinical trial aims to compare different strategies of mean arterial pressure (MAP) management during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in cardiac surgery. The trial will compare the standard MAP range (50-60 mmHg) to a high MAP range (70-80 mmHg) and a patient-tailored MAP range. The primary outcome measure is the peak value of serum lactates during CPB. Secondary outcome measures include the area under the curve of serum lactates, evaluation of cerebral and pulmonary perfusion, assessment of cardiac function and neurological outcomes, and monitoring of complications such as acute kidney injury and gastrointestinal ischemia. The study will be a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial with 999 patients recruited from participating centers in Italy and Spain. The data collection and analysis will follow standard statistical methods.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the acute effects of furosemide in patients with acute heart failure. The study involves administering 80 mg of furosemide intravenously and measuring various parameters such as blood pressure, peripheral oxygen saturation, pulmonary fluid content, and cardiac filling pressures. These measurements are repeated at multiple time points until 6 hours have passed. The primary outcome measure is the change in pulmonary fluid content after furosemide administration. The study is designed as a single group assignment without masking.

This clinical trial is titled "Smartphone Application for University Students With Binge Drinking Behavior: National Randomized Controlled Trial." The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a smartphone application in reducing binge drinking behavior in university students. The intervention involves blood microsampling to measure the level of Phosphatidylethanol. The trial includes participants aged 18 to 25 with a history of binge drinking. The primary outcome measure is the change in the number of standard drinks per week over a period of 30 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in the concentration of Phosphatidylethanol at different timeframes. The study design is non-randomized with parallel assignment and triple masking.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the potential benefit of using Nitazoxanide as adjuvant therapy in patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. The study will include patients with a glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) between 7% and 9% and a body mass index (BMI) of at least 25 kg/m2. Pregnant or nursing women, those with Type 1 diabetes, liver or kidney disease, inflammatory bowel diseases, or a history of allergy or adverse reactions to the study drugs will be excluded. The study will have two groups, with one group receiving Nitazoxanide in addition to their current treatment and the other group receiving no additional intervention. The primary outcome measures will be glycemic control, measured by fasting blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin levels, after 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include insulin resistance, lipid profile, and serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin. The study design is randomized and open-label. The minimum age for participation is 18 years, and all sexes are eligible. Healthy volunteers will not be accepted.

This clinical trial aims to investigate clinical risk factors of autism in Egyptian children and to analyze the changes in the gut microbiome and metabolome in autistic children. The study will examine the correlation between these changes and the severity of the disease. The trial will involve autistic children aged 3-9 years and will collect stool samples for microbiome and metabolome analysis. The study will also consider prenatal, natal, and postnatal history as potential risk factors for autism. The primary outcome will be the identification of autism clinical risk factors, while the secondary outcomes will focus on the intestinal microbiome and fecal metabolome. No intervention will be administered during the study.

This clinical trial aims to develop an internet-based self-help money management program for adults with severe mental illness (SMI) to improve their financial self-efficacy and overall financial well-being. The efficacy of the program will be compared to a wait-list control group. The program consists of 4 weekly modules and incorporates key components of money management. The study will measure changes in financial self-efficacy, financial behavior, financial attitude, financial well-being, psychological well-being, anxiety symptoms, depressive symptoms, quality of life, treatment adherence, and treatment satisfaction.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effectiveness of Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy (START) in enhancing upper extremity function in individuals post-stroke. The study will evaluate the impact of START on training outcomes and skill transfer in stroke survivors. The primary outcome measures include changes in electromyography (EMG) onset and amplitude, movement onset and linearity, functional reaching task scores, sorting task scores, and dressing task scores. The trial will also assess the retention of functional reaching task scores and skill transfer scores one month after training. The study design is a randomized, parallel, controlled trial with participants assigned to either the START group or the control group. The results of this trial could have significant implications for improving stroke rehabilitation outcomes, particularly for individuals with low socioeconomic status.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of endoscopic lung volume reduction on diaphragm function and conformation in patients with COPD. The study will involve the insertion of endobronchial valves and will assess the changes in diaphragmatic strength and conformation before and 3 months after the procedure. The primary outcome measures include transdiaphragmatic pressure and diaphragmatic conformation, which will be measured before and after the valves insertion. The study has a single group assignment and is designed as a before and after study.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the two-year clinical performance of dual- and light-cure bulk-fill resin composites in Class II restorations. Participants with at least three permanent molars and premolars requiring Class II restorations are included. The study measures esthetic, functional, and biological properties using FDI criteria. The participants are randomized to receive one of three bulk-fill resin composites. The outcomes are assessed from baseline to the 2-year follow-up. The trial is designed as a parallel assignment with masking.

The clinical trial, called the NET RETREAT trial, aims to compare the effects of lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (177Lu-DOTATATE) and everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with metastatic/unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumors (NET) who have previously received peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT). The trial will also evaluate the toxicity and safety of the two treatments, as well as their effects on overall response rate (ORR), overall survival (OS), post progression survival (PPS), time to second objective disease progression (PFS2), and patient quality of life (QoL). The study will involve two arms, with patients receiving either 177Lu-DOTATATE or everolimus, and will include procedures such as biospecimen collection, computed tomography (CT) scans, and quality-of-life assessments. The primary outcome measure of the trial is progression-free survival (PFS), and secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), post progression survival (PPS), and time to second objective disease progression (PFS2).

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of the Mulligan technique versus McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction in patients with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The study will be conducted over a period of four weeks, with participants divided into two groups. The primary outcome measures include pain reduction measured using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale, functional disability measured using the Oswestry Disability Scale, and range of motion of the lumbar spine. The data will be analyzed using statistical software.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the long-term safety, tolerability, and efficacy of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP in children and adolescents with Achondroplasia. The study is a Phase 2, multicenter, long-term, open-label extension trial. The participants must have completed a previous clinical trial with TransCon CNP and their parent(s) or legal guardian(s) must be willing and able to administer the weekly injections. The primary outcome measures include the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events and height Z-scores, while the secondary outcome measure is the annualized growth velocity. The study design is a single group assignment with no masking. The study will continue for an average of 10 years.

This clinical trial aims to explore the impact of illness perceptions and coping strategies on the quality of life of patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study will use correlation analysis and mediation analyses to assess the mediating effects of self-efficacy, coping, depression, and anxiety. The primary outcome measure is the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12), which measures generic health-related quality of life. The study will measure quality of life at the start of the study and up to 24 weeks.

The LORENA Trial aims to assess the effectiveness of local excision as a treatment for early rectal cancer in preserving the rectum without the need for adjuvant treatment. The study will collect data on patient demographics, tumor details, intervention type, complications, histological details, and the need for further treatments. The sample size for the study is estimated to be 145 patients. Various clinical variables will be collected, including comorbidities, preoperative laboratory values, and operative data. Postoperative complications and pathological data will also be recorded. The study will follow patients for up to 36 months and will assess outcomes such as success rate, morbidity rate, radicality of resection, histological poor outcome predictors, and the quality of the surgical specimen. The study is designed to meet ethical and legal requirements and will be conducted in accordance with the Helsinki Declaration. The LORENA Trial aims to provide valuable insights into the use of local excision for organ preservation in early rectal cancer.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the outcomes of different surgical strategies for repairing Type A Aortic Dissection (TAAD). The study will assess the impact of center volume on mortality and determine outcome predictors in patients undergoing surgery for TAAD. The trial will also evaluate the long-term follow-up beyond 15 years. The study will include patients aged 18 to 90 years with TAAD or intramural hematoma involving the ascending aorta. The interventions include conservative root-sparing aortic valve resuspension, extensive ascending aorta replacement with aortic root replacement, extensive ascending aorta replacement with total arch replacement, and extensive root and ascending aorta replacement with total arch replacement. The study will measure various outcomes including operative mortality, rate of mesenteric ischemia, rate of permanent neurologic deficit, rate of major adverse events, rate of perioperative myocardial infarction, and rate of acute heart failure. Secondary outcomes include rate of transient neurologic deficit, rate of spinal cord injury, rate of acute kidney injury, rate of perioperative bleeding, reoperation for bleeding, rate of mechanical circulatory support, rate of major adverse pulmonary events, rate of reintervention, and rate of late survival.

This clinical trial aims to study the effects of virtual reality (VR) and traditional guided visualization on academic stress and performance in physiotherapy and nursing students. The study will enroll participants who are enrolled in at least 80% of subjects in an academic course and have no previous experience with guided visualization for stress. The intervention group will receive either a 4-week program of VR-guided visualization or traditional guided visualization, while the control group will receive no intervention. The main outcomes measured will include changes in academic stress levels, perceived stress levels, arterial tension, heart rate, salivary cortisol levels, and exam qualifications. Secondary outcomes will include differences in exam qualifications compared to the average qualification of the degree.

This clinical trial aims to compare the use of remimazolam and propofol as induction agents for morbid obesity patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The study will assess the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction as the primary outcome measure. The secondary outcome measures include induction time and total ephedrine dose. The trial will include 44 subjects in each group and will use randomization and parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to test the drug darolutamide in combination with leuprolide acetate and exemestane in patients with recurrent ovarian granulosa cell tumors. The primary objective is to determine the objective response rate of the treatment, while secondary objectives include determining the duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and toxicities of the treatment. The trial will also explore biomarkers predictive of response to the treatment. Participants will receive the drugs orally and intramuscularly, and various imaging tests and blood sample collection will be conducted throughout the study. The study will collect tissue samples and follow up with patients for a number of years after completion of the treatment. The study design is an open-label, single group assignment. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate, while secondary outcome measures include duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and incidence of adverse events.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of combining chemotherapy drugs (cisplatin and gemcitabine) with an anti-PD1 immune checkpoint inhibitor (nivolumab) in children, adolescents, and young adults with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). The primary objective is to assess the incidence of grade 3 or higher immune-related adverse events during the induction chemoimmunotherapy (CIT) phase. Secondary objectives include estimating the 2-year event-free survival, evaluating the objective response rate of neoadjuvant CIT, and assessing the feasibility of combining chemotherapy with nivolumab in this patient population. The study also includes exploratory objectives such as evaluating long-term outcomes, comparing different imaging techniques, and assessing quality of life measures. The study design is a single-group assignment without masking, and participants will undergo various procedures and treatments including biopsies, radiography, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and imaging scans. The study will measure the incidence of adverse events, event-free survival rates, objective response rates, and feasibility of the treatment regimen.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children aged 6 to 11 years with cystic fibrosis (CF). The study will use MRI scans to measure these parameters before and after starting elexacaftor/ivacaftor/tezacaftor (ETI) treatment. Participants will undergo MRI scans at baseline, 240 minutes post-ingestion of a high-fat meal, and 300 minutes post-meal. The study will also include a pilot phase with 3 CF patients and 3 healthy controls, followed by a main phase with an additional 12 CF patients. The primary outcome measure is the postprandial fall in small bowel water content. Secondary outcome measures include small bowel water content, liver volume, liver elastography, and lung ventilation. The study is open to children with CF who have at least one copy of the Phe508del mutation and healthy volunteers without a history of gastrointestinal disease. The study will assess the effects of ETI on these parameters over a period of 6 months to 1 year.

This clinical trial aims to compare the analgesic efficacy and safety of caudal methylprednisolone and dexamethasone in pediatric patients undergoing hypospadias surgical repair. The primary outcome measure is the duration of analgesia, and the secondary outcome measures include the severity of postoperative pain and side effects. The study is a randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study, and the participants will be assigned to either the dexamethasone group or the methylprednisolone group. The study will assess the effectiveness and safety of these two medications in providing postoperative analgesia in pediatric patients undergoing hypospadias repair surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the impact of adding hemodiafiltration (HDF) to ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) on the regeneration of marginal donor lungs. The study will include participants with lung diseases who meet the inclusion criteria and do not meet any exclusion criteria. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the treatment group (EVLP + HDF) or the control group (EVLP only). The primary outcome measures include assessing the suitability for transplantation of the lungs after 6 hours of EVLP with HDF and the presence of grade 3 primary graft dysfunction (PGD) at 72 hours after transplantation. The secondary outcome measures include survival rates at 12 and 24 months, length of mechanical ventilation, length of ICU stay, length of hospital stay, and lung function parameters at various time points after transplantation.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. The study will use a randomized controlled experimental design, with premature infants being randomly assigned to three groups: the control group, the white noise group, and the multisensory stimulation group. Outcome measures such as physiological responses, behavioral indicators, and examination success rate will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of the interventions. Trained healthcare professionals will perform the retinopathy examinations using standardized procedures. Statistical analyses will be conducted to compare the outcomes between the three groups. The study aims to provide insights into the most suitable intervention that can optimize the examination process and improve examination success rates while minimizing discomfort or distress experienced by infants. The findings of this study have the potential to contribute to the development of effective retinopathy examination protocols for premature infants.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a modified calculation formula for grading Meibomian Gland Dysfunction. The study includes participants aged 18 to 80 and excludes those who wear contact lenses, have a history of eye surgeries, or have systemic health conditions affecting ocular health. The study will compare the previous calculation formula with the modified formula. The primary outcome measures will include the area of the Meibomian Glands and the whole eyelids, as well as the WTW distance of the cornea.

This clinical trial aims to prevent oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. The study will be a randomized clinical trial with two groups: one receiving a medical device containing zinc gluconate and the other receiving a solution based on sodium bicarbonate. The primary outcome measure is the presence or absence of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. Secondary outcome measures include the time of onset and severity of oral mucositis.

This clinical trial aims to determine the predictive ability of a panel of biomarkers in saliva in both healthy individuals and those affected by periodontal disease. The study will involve a diagnostic test using salivary biomarkers, including C-reactive protein, interleukins, metalloproteinase, and other factors. The primary outcome measure will be the levels of these biomarkers in saliva. Secondary outcome measures will include age, gender, blood pressure, oral health indicators, and microbiological analyses. The study will categorize participants based on their periodontal health status. The eligibility criteria include being an adult, able to provide informed consent, and meeting specific health criteria.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of a dual-hormone artificial pancreas system to a single-hormone system with rescue carbohydrate recommendations in managing blood glucose levels in adults with type 1 diabetes. The study will involve a 12-hour controlled, randomized clinical trial that includes an unannounced exercise session and a meal challenge. The primary objectives are to evaluate the time spent below the target range and the occurrence of hypoglycemic events. The study will also measure secondary outcomes such as time spent within the target range, glycemic variability, and insulin and glucagon administration. The study will involve 15 adults with type 1 diabetes and is expected to last for four months.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance. The study is a randomized controlled experimental design with a sample of 84 infants. The infants were exposed to white noise, heart sounds, or the mother's most frequently listened to music during pregnancy for 10 minutes before, during, and after the procedure. The pain of the infants was measured using the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS), as well as the duration of the procedure and crying time. The study is designed to support the use of these interventions for reducing neonatal pain.

This clinical trial aims to compare two different methods of training and supervising facilitators in caregiver skills training (CST). One group will receive training and supervision remotely, while the other group will receive face-to-face training and supervision. The study will assess the impact of the training method on parent progress in CST. The primary outcome measure is the change in caregiver skills and knowledge from baseline to week 12. Secondary outcome measures include changes in parenting stress, adaptive behavior skills, social communication abilities, and caregiver adherence to the strategies learned. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of different training methods in CST.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) in the functional recovery of individuals with subacromial pain syndrome. The study will include 64 subjects who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (EG) or the control group (CG). The EG will receive a protocol of therapeutic exercises along with real TES, while the CG will receive a protocol of therapeutic exercises along with placebo TES. The primary outcome measures will include changes in pain and disability index, changes in the Western Ontario Rotator Cuff scale, changes in a visual analog scale for shoulder pain intensity, and changes in shoulder pain pressure threshold. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in shoulder muscle strength, changes in shoulder active range of motion, changes in joint position sense, changes in head forward posture, shoulder protraction, and kyphosis, changes in subacromial space width, changes in scapulohumeral rhythm, changes in mean signal amplitude and frequency of scapulothoracic muscles, and changes in mean signal amplitude of the primary motor cortex measured by EEG. The study will be triple blind and will be conducted over a period of 8 weeks with a follow-up evaluation at 3 months.

This clinical trial aimed to compare the verbal scores of children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who received hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) to those who did not receive HBOT. Children aged 2 to 17 years, diagnosed with ASD, and receiving applied behavioral analysis at Oxford Recovery Center were included in the study. Some of the participants received at least 40 sessions of HBOT for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA. Verbal scores were measured using two age-appropriate assessments, and any adverse events related to HBOT were recorded. The study design included a treatment group receiving HBOT and a control group receiving applied behavioral therapy without HBOT. The primary outcome measure was the change in verbal scores at 6 months, and the secondary outcome measure was the occurrence of HBOT-related adverse events.

This clinical trial aims to compare the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound guided adductor canal block and 4 in 1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The study will assess postoperative pain scores at various time points, including resting and dynamic pain. Secondary outcome measures include changes in blood pressure and heart rate, as well as postoperative opioid requirements. The trial will be a randomized, double-blinded study with parallel assignment. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving adductor canal block and the other receiving 4 in 1 block. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of these regional anesthesia techniques in managing postoperative pain in knee surgeries.

This clinical trial aims to determine if immediate lymphatic reconstruction with lymphatico-venous anastomosis can reduce the occurrence of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. The study will include female patients with unilateral breast cancer who are scheduled to undergo axillary lymph node dissection. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of arm lymphedema, while secondary outcome measures include drainage amount from operative wounds, occurrence of seroma or lymphocele, patient-reported outcome measures, and occurrence of subclinical lymphedema. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the experimental group receiving immediate lymphatic reconstruction or the control group receiving only axillary lymph node dissection. The study will last for two years.

This clinical trial is a descriptive study of the cosmetic and functional outcomes in patients who received releasing incisions for acute upper limb burns. The study will assess the functional recovery, scar quality, healing time, and need for additional surgeries in patients with hand burns. The study will measure these outcomes at 3 and 6 months after the burn. The eligibility criteria include adult patients with burns of one or both hands or finger burns, with less than 40% of the body surface burned. The study will not include patients who refuse to participate or have less than 1 month of follow-up or death within the first month. The study design involves a single group/arm of adult subjects with deep hand burns who required releasing incisions. The interventions include the assessment of functional and aesthetic criteria using the Quick DASH Score, Visual Analog Scale, scar quality assessment by a surgeon, healing time, and the need for a second surgical procedure. The study aims to evaluate the functional and cosmetic sequelae in hand burns and provide valuable insights for the management of these burns.

The Stanford Plant-based Educational Study (PLANT) is a randomized, delayed intervention trial that aims to test a flexible, multimodal whole-food plant-based diet (WFPBD) educational program for providers at Stanford. The study will involve screening, enrollment, and a 6-week educational intervention program. The intervention will include interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities. The primary outcomes measured will include changes in Diet ID score, mindset about WFPBD, and stage of change (motivation and confidence) over the 6-week period. The study is designed as a health services research with a parallel assignment and no masking. The participants will be divided into two groups: one receiving the educational intervention and the other serving as a delayed intervention group. The study aims to stimulate the adoption of a WFPBD among Stanford physicians.

This clinical trial aims to validate a questionnaire called Patient Reported Outcome (PRO) for assessing rehabilitation needs in patients with early breast cancer. The study will recruit a total of 360 patients, including 80 during the transcultural adaptability phase and at least 280 during the validation phase. The PRO questionnaire consists of 17 items that evaluate various concerns related to survivorship, such as screening, symptom management, and fear of disease recurrence. The questionnaire will be administered twice, 15 days apart, to assess the levels of agreement between the two assessments. The primary outcome measure of the study is the translation and validation of the PRO questionnaire. The study is expected to be completed within 6 months. Participants with cognitive or memory impairment will be excluded from the study.

This clinical trial is titled "A Postpartum Adaptation Study of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience Parenting Program." The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) Program in treating postpartum depression, postpartum anxiety, parenting stress, and improving parent-child relationships. The study will involve enrolling participants in a 12-session CARE parenting group therapy. The primary outcome measures include changes in postpartum anxiety, postpartum depression, parenting stress, parental reflective functioning, and parent-infant bonding. Secondary outcome measures include changes in infant temperament. The study will also assess treatment acceptability and feasibility.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of electroencephalography-based neurofeedback (EEG-NFB) training on cognitive function in healthy young men. The study will include 50 male participants, who will be randomly assigned to either the training group (TR) or the control group (CO). The TR group will undergo 3 weeks of EEG-NFB training, while the CO group will not receive any training. The participants will undergo psychological testing before and after the training period to evaluate executive function. The testing will include measures of cognitive processing speed and executive function. The EEG-NFB training sessions will involve nine sessions over a 3-week period, with each session lasting 30 minutes. The training will be conducted using specific protocols to decrease the EEG TBR value. The study will analyze the data using statistical tests to assess the significance of differences between the pre and post-training sessions and between the TR and CO groups. The primary outcome measures will be the performance times on the trail making test (TMT) and the Stroop test (ST). The study will be carried out in accordance with ethical guidelines and will use appropriate statistical analysis methods.

This clinical trial compares the effectiveness of radial access versus femoral access for thrombectomy in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the different access routes on favorable neurological function and procedure time. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive endovascular recanalization via either radial or femoral approach. The primary outcome measure is favorable neurological function at 90 days post-operation, while the secondary outcome measure is procedure time at the operation 1 day.

The BUNDLE study aims to develop an integrated prenatal care model that combines medical providers and community doulas. The study will conduct focus groups with pregnant individuals and healthcare providers to gather feedback on the integration of doulas and medical providers. It will then compare the effectiveness of the integrated prenatal care model to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement and trust and reducing adverse maternal outcomes. The study also plans to disseminate its findings to scholarly and community-based forums to promote policy-level changes in healthcare systems. The study will include Black/African American pregnant individuals and will randomize participants to either the BUNDLE intervention or standard prenatal care. The primary outcome measure is healthcare engagement, and secondary outcome measures include trust in providers, perceived discrimination, and frequencies of severe maternal morbidity. The study will also assess the impact of the intervention on breastfeeding initiation and medical mistrust.

This clinical trial, titled QUILT-3.100, aims to evaluate the safety and determine the maximum tolerated dose of a drug called IBRX-042 in subjects with HPV-associated tumors. Up to 60 subjects will be screened, and 18 subjects will receive at least one dose of the study drug. The drug will be administered by injection once every 3 weeks for a total of 3 injections. Subjects will continue receiving treatment until they report progressive disease, unacceptable toxicity, withdraw consent, or if the investigator determines it is no longer in their best interest to continue. After completing or withdrawing from the study, subjects will have follow-up visits every 3 months for at least 1 year, and then yearly until death. The study will also collect information on adverse events, survival status, and current cancer treatment regimen. The trial will utilize a dose escalation design and determine the maximum tolerated dose of IBRX-042. The study will assess the rate of dose-limiting toxicities and determine the overall safety profile and reactogenicity of IBRX-042. It will also examine the HPV-specific humoral and cellular immune responses in the subjects.

This clinical trial compared the effects of connective tissue massage and classical massage on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. The study involved a 3-arm randomized controlled trial with 30 participants divided into three groups: the connective tissue massage group, the classical massage group, and the control group. The interventions were administered over a 4-week period, with outcome measurements taken at the beginning and end of the program. The primary outcome measures included the Visual Analog Scale for pain intensity, the Modified Schober Test for lumbar mobility, the Sit and Reach Test for trunk flexibility, the Back Pain Functional Scale for functional activities, the Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire for functional status, and the Short Form-36 Questionnaire for quality of life. The study was designed to adhere to ethical principles and followed the CONSORT guidelines for reporting. Overall, the trial aimed to assess the effectiveness of connective tissue massage and classical massage in managing chronic non-specific low back pain.

This clinical trial aims to compare the outcomes of cataract surgery with OMNI canaloplasty alone versus cataract surgery with OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent. The study will randomize one eye of each participant to receive one of the treatments and will assess the results after one year. The trial will include approximately 80 subjects aged 18 and older. The study visits will consist of various tests and procedures to evaluate eligibility and monitor the participants' progress. The primary outcome measure of the study is the change in unmedicated intraocular pressure from baseline at 12 months. The secondary outcome measures include the reduction in the number of medications needed to control intraocular pressure and the percentage of patients with a greater than 20% reduction in intraocular pressure from baseline. The study is designed as a randomized, open-label trial with parallel assignment.

This is an open-label, randomized, controlled, comparative study comparing the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops to Cosopt eye drops in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma. The study aims to demonstrate the similarity of the efficacy and safety profiles of the two eye drop formulations. The study design is a multicenter, prospective, open-label, randomized, comparative, controlled, parallel-arm study. The study includes 110 patients (55 in each group) with elevated intraocular pressure. The primary outcome measure is the mean change in intraocular pressure from baseline. Secondary outcome measures include the reduction rate of intraocular pressure to target levels, as well as the safety evaluation of adverse events. The study concludes that Dorzotimol is noninferior to Cosopt in terms of efficacy and safety.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of text messaging in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy procedures in a Veterans Affairs (VA) hospital. The study will include participants who have previously undergone a colonoscopy and are due for a repeat screening or surveillance colonoscopy. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive instructional and motivational text messages, or the control group, which will not receive any text messages. The primary outcome measure will be participant satisfaction with the text message intervention, assessed through a survey. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of participants who attend their scheduled colonoscopy appointment and the percentage of participants with adequate bowel preparation.

This is a prospective, randomized clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy and endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage. The primary objective is to compare the efficacy of the two techniques in achieving uterine vacuity at 6 weeks after surgery. Secondary objectives include comparing complication rates, rates of second-line surgical management, rates of synechiae, time to conception, and fertility rates at 2 years after surgery. The study will enroll 220 patients and follow them for up to 26 months after surgery. The primary analysis will compare uterine vacuity rates between the two arms using a Chi-square test. Secondary analyses will compare complication rates, rates of second-line surgical management, rates of synechiae, time to conception, and fertility rates using Chi-square or Fisher's exact tests. The study aims to provide evidence for the optimal management of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage.

This clinical trial aims to study human inference using online testing. The official title of the study is "On-line Crowdsourcing of Multi-Timescale Inference Strategies." The study focuses on behavioral conditions and the intervention/treatment is psychophysics. The eligibility criteria include being an adult Prolific participant with a 95% approval rating and achieving a minimum score of 80% on a pre-test, as well as being fluent in English and located in the US. The study design is a basic science intervention with a single group assignment and no masking. The primary outcome measure is binary behavioral decision responses, which are subject-provided choices between two presented options. The study involves an experimental group that participates in an environmental feature experiment, where subjects are shown pairs of jars with different ratios of red/blue balls and are asked to make various inferences. The study is conducted through online testing and the time frame for data collection is approximately 30 minutes.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of lemborexant, a new medication for insomnia, in adults with early-onset dementia and sleep difficulties. The trial will be conducted as an N-of-1 trial, with each participant receiving lemborexant and a placebo alternately over an 8-week period. The study will measure various sleep outcomes, including total sleep time, sleep onset latency, wake time after sleep onset, number of night awakenings, and quality of sleep. Adverse drug reactions and the participant's willingness to drop out due to these reactions will also be monitored. The trial will provide valuable insights into the use of lemborexant in individuals with early-onset dementia and insomnia.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of sinomenine and glucocorticoid in treating early knee osteoarthritis. The study includes participants aged 40-70 with bilateral knee pain and grade 2 or 3 osteoarthritis. The trial will last for 24 months and will measure outcomes such as the total WOMAC score, tibial cartilage volume, Timed Up and Go test, and 20m walking time. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either sinomenine or glucocorticoid injections every 4 months. The study will be double-blind and multicenter.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of breathing exercises applied with virtual reality glasses on dyspnea, anxiety, and quality of life in COPD patients. The study will be conducted using a single-blind pre-test post-test parallel group randomized controlled experimental design. The sample size will be 48 patients, with 24 in the experimental group and 24 in the control group. Breathing exercises will be applied to the experimental group with virtual reality glasses, while the control group will receive routine treatment and care. Various outcome measures, including oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, forced vital capacity, and quality of life assessments, will be evaluated throughout the study. The data will be analyzed using the SPSS 26 package program.

This clinical trial aims to understand the multilevel determinants of cardiovascular health in Black women. The study will involve Black women between the ages of 18-49 who self-identify as Black or African American and do not have certain health conditions. Participants will undergo lab-based assessments to evaluate their vascular health and will then have a 10-day monitoring period using mobile and wearable devices. The study will measure outcomes such as macrovascular function, arterial stiffness, blood flow measurements, and physical activity levels.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of RCN3028 in treating moderate to severe hot flashes in breast cancer patients. Hot flashes are a common symptom of menopause and are often experienced by women undergoing breast cancer treatment. The study will compare the use of RCN3028 to a placebo and measure the change in frequency and severity of hot flashes over a 12-week period. Other secondary outcomes include assessing the impact on quality of life and responder rates. Eligible participants must be female breast cancer patients who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy and are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. The study will be randomized, double-blind, and parallel in design.

This clinical trial is a retrospective cohort study that aims to determine if higher doses of tranexamic acid (TXA) are associated with a lower incidence of post-operative delirium after cardiac surgery. The study will analyze data collected from routine clinical care and data collection systems. The primary outcome measure is the Richmond Agitation Sedation Score up to 48 hours after surgery, and the secondary outcome measure is 30-day mortality. The study will include all patients undergoing elective or in-house urgent cardiac surgery, except for certain exclusion criteria. The intervention is the administration of tranexamic acid. The results of this study may inform the design of a randomized controlled trial comparing different TXA dosing regimens.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of myofascial decompression and positional release therapies on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain. The study will involve participants between the ages of 25 and 50 who have been experiencing mild to moderate neck pain for at least three months. The intervention groups will receive either myofascial decompression therapy or positional release therapy. The primary outcome measures will include pain intensity measured by the Numerical Rating Scale (NPRS) and neck disability measured by the Neck Disability Index (NDI). Secondary outcome measures will assess range of motion in the cervical spine. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with an open-label approach. The treatment duration will be three sessions per week for four weeks.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of the Ileostomy Dumpling suture method with the Traditional suture method in rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The study will assess the complication rate of the stoma as the primary outcome measure, as well as secondary measures including the state of the skin around the stoma, stoma pain level, and quality of life for patients with stoma. The study will be a randomized parallel-controlled study with participants assigned to either the experimental group receiving the Dumpling suture method or the control group receiving the Traditional suture method. The study will include patients aged 18 to 100 years who are scheduled for rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The study is designed to prevent complications associated with ileostomy and does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to assess the progression of cognitive activities of daily living (ADLs) impairment in Parkinson's disease. The study will involve various assessments, including scales, questionnaires, and neuropsychological tests. The participants will also undergo clinical motor assessments and comprehensive non-motor assessments. Caregiver assessments will be conducted to validate the patients' self-impression. The study will include people with Parkinson's disease who were previously enrolled in the ABC-PD study. The intervention will involve measuring cognition scores and cognitive instrumental ADL scores. The study will measure the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) or mild cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD-MCI) as primary outcomes. Secondary outcomes include the Pfeffer Activities of daily living scale, follow-up score in global cognition, and follow-up cognitive domain performance. The study will span a period of 6-8 years.

This clinical trial aims to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for preventing myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study will include participants between the ages of 18 to 80, with ASA grade I-II. Participants will be randomly assigned to different age groups and will receive rocuronium before the succinylcholine injection. The primary outcome measure is the appearance of myofibrillation, which will be assessed within an average of 45 seconds.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of dietary phospholipids on measures of human brain health and psychological wellbeing. The study will follow a randomised, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel groups design. It will include 220 healthy participants aged between 25-49 years. Participants will receive either 40g per day of bioactive whey protein concentrate powder containing dairy phospholipids or a placebo powder for 12 weeks. The study will measure cognitive function, mood states, perceived stress, physical symptoms, sleep quality, and other psychological factors. Blood samples will also be taken to analyze plasma phospholipid profiles. The study will provide valuable insights into the effects of dietary phospholipids on brain health and psychological wellbeing.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the presence of environmental pollutants in human carotid atherosclerotic plaques and their relationship with the plaque phenotype and clinical outcomes. The study will enroll 300 consecutive patients with asymptomatic carotid stenosis and collect their health records and baseline clinical examination data. Plaque specimens will be obtained and analyzed for the presence and amount of volatile organic compounds and microplastics. The plaques will also be examined using transmission electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry to further understand their structure and composition. The patients will be categorized into groups based on the presence of pollutants in their plaques and followed up for the incidence of a composite outcome consisting of non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, and all-cause mortality. Cox regression analysis will be used to examine the association between the presence of microplastics and the incidence of the composite outcome. Additionally, the abundance of pollutants will be used to categorize patients into terciles and explore the relationship between the burden of microplastics and the outcome. The study will last for 24 months.

This clinical trial is investigating the use of Transarterial Radioembolization (TARE) with Therasphere in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastases. The study aims to compare the effective tumor dose and safe healthy liver dose in patients with and without a response to radioembolization. Secondary outcomes include investigating dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships. The study will evaluate these measures at 3 months and 6 months after treatment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer restorations after enhancement with light emitting diode (LED) radiant heat. The study will involve 18 patients with high caries risk, each with two cavities. One cavity will be restored with conventional glass ionomer without enhancement, and the other cavity will be restored with glass ionomer enhanced with LED radiant heat. The restorations will be evaluated for functional and biological criteria immediately after restoration and at 6 and 12 months using the Federation Dentaire International (FDI) criteria. The primary outcome measures will assess the clinical performance of biological and functional properties of the restorations after 12 months.

The clinical trial, titled "FAPO-X: Assisted Digital Telemonitoring With Wearables in Patients After Cardiovascular Surgery," aimed to develop and validate a telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF). The study was conducted at the Heart Institute of the Clinics Hospital of the Medical School of the University of São Paulo. The study consisted of six phases, including preoperative care, hospitalization, surgical phase, postoperative care, a 30-day telemonitoring period, and an outpatient visit. The telemonitored group used the SAMSUNG Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch for remote monitoring, while the control group received standard care. The primary outcome measures were rehospitalization rate, scheduled consultations, and extra occurrences, while the secondary outcome measures included technological adherence, treatment adherence, and use of the mobile application by patients. The study utilized a parallel assignment model and included participants aged 22 years and above.

This is a pilot study that aims to test the effectiveness of two digital solutions, HSmartBPM and HyperHealth, in managing patients with high blood pressure. The study will be a randomized controlled trial, with patients being assigned to one of the two digital solutions or standard care. The study will measure changes in blood pressure and user satisfaction with the digital solutions. The eligibility criteria include being diagnosed with essential hypertension, having basic ICT knowledge, and being able to provide written informed consent. The study is part of the HSMonitor project and is supported by the EU project HSMonitor - Pre-commercial Procurement of innovative ICT-enabled monitoring to improve health status and optimize hypertension care.

The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled study that aims to screen for liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder. The intervention involves using a diagnostic test called transient elastography to measure liver stiffness. The study is designed with a screening purpose, randomized allocation, and a parallel assignment with concealed allocation to intervention or control. The primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence or light consumption in the last 30 days, assessed 6 months after randomization. Secondary outcome measures include heavy drinking days in the last 30 days and change in AUDIT-C score since randomization. The study is open to participants of all sexes, with a minimum age of 18 years and no upper age limit. Healthy volunteers are not accepted.

This clinical trial aims to assess the value of Trio Exome Sequencing in diagnosing specific non-syndromic language and learning disorders. The study will involve collecting blood samples from index cases and their biological parents, and conducting consultations to deliver the results. Additionally, interviews will be conducted with families who have positive or negative results. The primary outcome measure is the identification of a genetic cause for the disorders. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with no masking. The study will last approximately 4 months.

The Five Days for Health (FDH) trial is a small group-based lifestyle modification program aimed at weight loss in adults who are overweight or obese. The program consists of five days of positive interaction, education, and practical workshops on nutrition, physical activity, and psychological support. Follow-up continues with additional educational lectures and support, along with measurements of body weight and metabolic parameters. Participants are encouraged to stay in contact between meetings through an instant messaging platform. The program focuses on behavioral change, nutrition education, physical activity, and psychological support. The primary outcome measure is weight loss after 12 months, with secondary measures including body composition and metabolic parameters. The trial is open to male and female participants aged 18-70 and accepts healthy volunteers. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the program in achieving weight loss and improving overall health.

This clinical trial, titled "A Phase I Study of BIO-008 Injection for Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, Immunogenicity, and Antitumor Activity in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors," aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and antitumor activity of Bio-008 in patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors. The study includes participants aged 18-75 with confirmed standard therapy failure or no suitable standard therapy. The trial consists of multiple dose groups receiving different doses of Bio-008 monotherapy administered intravenously every 3 weeks. The primary outcome measures include evaluating adverse events, dose-limiting toxicity, maximum tolerated dose, objective response rate, and recommended phase 2 dose. Secondary outcome measures include plasma concentration, immunogenicity, disease control rate, duration of response, and progression-free survival.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of different music listened to during retinopathy examinations on the pain and comfort levels of premature infants. The trial will involve two experimental groups, one listening to rainstick music and the other listening to "The Happiest Baby" music. The control group will receive routine care without music. The primary outcome measure will be a baby information form, while the secondary outcome measure will be the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP). The study will provide valuable insights into the use of music as a non-pharmacological method to alleviate pain and increase comfort in premature infants during retinopathy examinations.

This clinical trial aims to assess the safety and efficacy of a drug called Sovateltide in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke. The trial is a multicentric, randomized, double-blind, parallel, placebo-controlled phase III study. The primary outcome measure is the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at day 90 post randomization, which assesses the functional outcome of the patients. Secondary outcome measures include the proportion of patients with excellent functional outcome, improvement in neurological scores, overall clinical outcome, quality of life, incidence of recurrent stroke, mortality, and adverse events associated with Sovateltide. The study will involve adult males and females aged 18-80 years who have had an ischemic stroke within 24 hours of symptom onset. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either Sovateltide or a placebo (normal saline) along with standard care. The study will be conducted in multiple countries.

This clinical trial is an ambispective cohort study that aims to assess the outcome and influencing factors in patients with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD). The study will collect demographic data, psychiatric diagnosis, therapy data, hospitalization information, and patient contact information from electronic medical records. Prospective follow-up will be conducted through telephone interviews, web-based questionnaires, or in-person assessments. The study will analyze the factors influencing remission of BPD using the Cox Proportional Hazard Model, and factors influencing social function and quality of life using the Generalized Estimating Equation Model. The primary outcome measure is the remission rate of BPD, while the secondary outcome measures include social disability and quality of life. The study will follow patients for a total of 2 years with follow-up intervals of 6 months. The eligibility criteria include a diagnosis of BPD based on ICD-10 and exclusion of comorbid severe physical disease, neurological diseases, and mental retardation. The study includes participants of all ages and does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to assess the management of evaporative dry eye (EDE) by combining intense pulsed light (IPL) treatment and diquafosol tetrasodium (DQS) eye drops. EDE is the most prevalent form of dry eye disease (DED) caused by meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD). IPL is known to stimulate sebaceous glands and improve meibum secretion. DQS stimulates mucin and tear secretion, leading to tear film stabilization. The study will measure outcomes such as tear break-up time, ocular surface disease index, conjunctival and cornea staining, meibomian gland function, tear film lipid layer score, tear meniscus height, and conjunctival hyperemia. The study will include three groups: IPL+DQS, IPL only, and DQS only.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Mindfulness-Based Therapy (MBT) in improving mental health outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. The study also aims to explore patient characteristics that may moderate the relationship between the therapies and patient outcomes, as well as comparing the acceptability and feasibility of CBT relative to MBT. The trial will involve participants aged 18 years and older who meet certain criteria and will be randomly assigned to either the CBT or MBT intervention. The study will measure changes in anxiety and depression symptoms, mental health, psychiatric diagnosis, quality of life, well-being, self-acceptance, functional impairment, disability, potential negative effects of the intervention, and satisfaction with the intervention services.

This clinical trial, titled "Methotrexate for Immune Related Arthritis or Arthralgias (IMPACT 2.1)", aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of methotrexate in treating immune-related arthritis or arthralgias. The study will include patients who were previously on hydroxychloroquine treatment or enrolled in IMPACT 2.0 and developed recurrent grade ≥ 2 immune-related adverse events (irAA) or remained on glucocorticoids for irAA at 3 months. The eligibility criteria include various medical parameters and the ability to provide consent. The study design involves a single arm with participants receiving methotrexate 20 mg orally once a week for 12 weeks, along with folic acid and prednisone. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients who can discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without a recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA. Secondary outcome measures include total steroid usage, development of other immune-related adverse events, adverse events, re-initiation of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy, and progression-free survival.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of general anesthesia and regional anesthesia on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The study will evaluate the changes in sleep patterns and pain and anxiety levels in patients who receive either general anesthesia or regional anesthesia. The primary outcome measure is subjective sleep quality, assessed using the Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale. Secondary outcome measures include subjective anxiety level and subjective pain level, evaluated using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory and Visual Analog Scale, respectively. The study will include a total of 60 patients and will monitor possible complications, mortality, and morbidity in the postoperative period.

This clinical trial is a phase 2/3 study that aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral Atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese participants with episodic migraine. The study will include participants who have a history of migraine and experience 4 to 14 migraine days per month. The participants will be randomly assigned to different treatment groups, including different doses of Atogepant and a placebo group. The primary outcome measure of the study is the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. The study will also assess secondary outcome measures such as changes in mean monthly headache days, mean monthly acute medication use days, and quality of life measures.

This is a Phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of Efgartigimod in patients with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). The trial will include patients aged 18 or older who have been diagnosed with GBS within the past 14 days and have a GBS Disability Scale (GBS-DS) score of 3, 4, or 5. The study will compare the use of Efgartigimod Alfa-Fcab with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg), which is the standard-of-care treatment for GBS. The primary outcome measures will be the GBS-DS score and the number and seriousness of adverse events. Secondary outcome measures will include additional assessments of functional status, neuropathy, and pulmonary function. The trial will be randomized, double-blind, and controlled, with participants assigned to either the experimental group receiving Efgartigimod or the active comparator group receiving IVIg. The study will last for approximately 3 years, with assessments conducted at various timepoints up to 48 weeks.

This is a phase 2b clinical trial to evaluate the effect and safety of the oral medication PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized adults with symptoms of COVID-19. The study will be double-blind, randomized, and placebo-controlled. Participants must be between the ages of 18 and 64 and have confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection. The primary outcome measure is the change in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level from baseline to day 5. Secondary outcome measures include changes in RNA level on different days, incidence of treatment-related adverse events, incidence of serious adverse events, and incidence of abnormal laboratory values, among others. The study will have multiple arms with varying doses of PF-07817883 and a placebo arm.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the therapeutic effect of adding letrozole to the protocol of combined treatment for cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP). The study includes women with confirmed CSP and increasing B-human chorionic gonadotropin (B-hCG) concentrations. The two study arms involve treatment with methotrexate (MTX) alone or MTX with letrozole. Blood parameters are measured at various time points, and women undergo hysteroscopic evacuation of products of conception (POC) after achieving a satisfactory decrease in B-hCG and POC vascularization. The primary outcome measures include blood loss during the procedure, conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage. Secondary outcome measures include the effect of treatment on bone marrow and liver function, as well as kidney function. The study is non-randomized and open-label.

This clinical trial, titled "Blood Salvage From Liver Donors: a Feasibility Pilot Study," aims to investigate the feasibility of salvaging and transfusing red blood cell concentrates from liver donors during liver transplantation surgeries. The study will include adult patients receiving a liver transplant from deceased donors at Fondazione Policlinico A. Gemelli IRCCS. The study will assess the number and percentage of successful liver transplant recipients who receive donor blood transfusions during the surgery. Secondary outcome measures include evaluating the need for additional blood products and the rate of graft failure in the prospective sample compared to controls. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial compares the efficacy of sublingual versus subcutaneous allergen immunotherapy in patients with bronchial asthma. The study was conducted on 100 asthmatic patients, with 50 receiving sublingual immunotherapy and 50 receiving subcutaneous immunotherapy. The primary outcome measures were total IgE levels and sputum eosinophil levels after 6, 12, and 18 months of treatment. The study design was a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking. The eligibility criteria included new cases of allergic asthma and age greater than 18 years. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of sublingual versus subcutaneous immunotherapy in treating bronchial asthma.

This clinical trial aims to determine the minimum number of tissue samples needed for a reliable diagnosis using contrast-enhanced stereotactic biopsy (CESB) for lesions that are visible only on contrast images. The study will be a prospective, observational cohort study involving non-pregnant women who have recently observed recombined-only lesions (ROLs) during a contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM) examination. The participants will undergo CESB, which involves the injection of iodinated contrast agent and the acquisition of images to determine the location and depth of the lesion. A total of 18 tissue samples will be obtained using a biopsy technique, and each specimen will be histologically analyzed to compare the findings with the final histopathological result. The primary outcome measure will be the cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen to establish the minimum number of biopsies required for a reliable diagnosis. Secondary outcomes include patient characteristics, histopathological results, pain experienced during the procedure, and complication rates. The study will last for 2 years.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening and facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in knee osteoarthritis. The study will involve adults aged 50-60 with knee osteoarthritis, and participants will be randomly assigned to either the concentric muscle training group or the kinesiotaping group. The primary outcome measure will be the measurement of temporospatial gait parameters using a mobile app. Secondary outcome measures will include pain assessment, functional status assessment, and strength measurement. The study will last for 6 weeks.

This clinical trial, titled "Family Therapy Training and Implementation Platform (FTTIP) Supplement Study," aims to collect qualitative data to better understand the experiences of trainees and agency leaders using the platform. The study will include 20 trainees and 16 agency leaders from the parent study. The objectives of the supplement are to gather trainees' perceptions and experiences of learning and practicing specific competencies from the platform, as well as gain a deeper understanding from leaders about their experiences in facilitating evidence-based treatments at their agencies. The study will involve qualitative interviews with the participants. The primary outcome measures will assess the trainees' experiences with the platform and the implementation of evidence-based treatments, as well as the leaders' experiences in facilitating treatments and the readiness of their agencies.

This clinical trial is studying the use of a freshly manufactured 35kDa hyaluronan fragment (HA35) in the treatment of pain. The hyaluronan fragment is produced by cleaving macromolecular hyaluronan using recombinant human hyaluronidase PH20 and neutral hyaluronidase. The study aims to evaluate the analgesic effect of HA35 on pain caused by herpes zoster, as well as shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain. The trial involves the injection of HA35 mixed with hyaluronidase and high-molecular-weight HA at the pain point or nerve trunk innervation. The primary outcome measure is the pain scores of patients before and after treatment. The study is a self-controlled, open-label clinical trial and includes both male and female participants aged between 39 and 63 years. The trial does not accept healthy volunteers.

This is a prospective randomized clinical trial that aims to compare two different modalities of hysteroscopic septoplasty in patients with a septate uterus. The study will be conducted over a period of at least 24 months at Mansoura University Hospital. The patients will be randomized into two groups: Group A will undergo septum resection with hysteroscope and scissors, while Group B will undergo septum resection with a resectoscope. The primary outcome measures include operative time, fluid deficit, operative and postoperative complications, and the need for a second intervention. The secondary outcome measures include pregnancy rate and live birth rate. The study will analyze the data using various statistical tests, and ethical considerations will be taken into account. The study aims to enroll a total of 40 patients.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a breathing control technique called cardiac coherence on the symptoms of Long COVID. The study will include patients over the age of 18 who have been diagnosed with Long COVID and are living in Reunion. Participants must have a negative antigen test and attest to their primary infection with SARS-CoV-2. Patients with certain respiratory pathologies or who have practiced respiratory control techniques in the last 6 months will be excluded. The study will have a randomized design with two groups: an experimental group that will receive the cardiac coherence training in addition to usual care, and a control group that will receive only usual care. The primary outcome measure is the reduction in symptomatology of Long COVID, measured by the Long COVID Symptom Tool scale, after 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the decrease in overall symptoms over time, as well as specific symptoms such as fatigue, dyspnea, anxiety and depression, cognitive disorders, and post-traumatic stress disorder. The study will also assess the impact of the disease on daily life using the Long COVID Impact Tool scale.

This clinical trial is titled "Cardiovascular Complications of Ibrutinib Therapy: a Single-center Cohort Study." The study aims to investigate the cardiovascular complications associated with ibrutinib treatment. The participants will undergo ophthalmological examinations and blood tests to assess biomarkers related to cardiovascular complications. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients developing atrial fibrillation (AF) after 12 months of ibrutinib treatment.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal during hemodialysis and blood pH. The study will involve patients with phosphorus metabolism disorders and acid-base balance disorders who have been undergoing hemodialysis for more than 3 months. The patients will be assigned to two different groups and will receive different dialysis fluid compositions. The primary outcome measure of the study is the change in blood phosphorus concentration during hemodialysis, while the secondary outcome measure is the maintenance of acid-base balance. The study will last for 4 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a combined treatment approach for unipolar depression. The treatment involves the use of transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS), a noninvasive neurostimulation technique, along with metacognitive therapy (MCT). The study will be a randomized, double-blind trial with three treatment arms: tDCS alone, MCT alone, and tDCS-MCT combined. The effectiveness of the interventions will be assessed using the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale at multiple time points. Additionally, a subgroup of patients will be studied to evaluate the TMS-EEG correlates of change in depressive symptomatology.

This clinical trial aims to compare the gastrointestinal and cardiovascular events in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) who undergo percutaneous coronary angioplasty and have a moderate risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. The study specifically focuses on the use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) as a preventive measure for these events. The trial will randomly assign patients to either receive a gastric acid secretion inhibitor (PPI group) or not (control group). The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of upper gastrointestinal clinical events, while the secondary outcome measure is the occurrence of a cardiovascular clinical complex. The study will last for 6 months and will collect data through normal medical procedures and endoscopy in case of upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the influence of hot and cold cognition on prospective memory in HIV+ patients. The trial will involve neuropsychological testing of both HIV+ patients and healthy control subjects. The primary outcome measure is prospective memory, which will be assessed using the Memory for Intentions Screening Test (MIST). Secondary outcome measures include the influence of global cognitive performance, hot cognition (cognitive and affective empathy), and cold cognition (figurative fluency) on prospective memory. The study will last for 1 year.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effects of vertical sitting traction versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with chronic radicular low back pain. The study will include patients between the ages of 20-50 years who have been experiencing radicular low back pain for at least 3 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive vertical sitting traction, or the active comparator group, which will receive supine lying traction. The primary outcome measures will include the Oswestry Disability Index and the Numeric Pain Rating Scale.
