The study will provide physiotherapists with valuable information on the best possible position for applying traction in patients with radicular low back pain.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of dry needling and lasertherapy in treating greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS). The study will include participants with lateral hip pain for at least 3 months. The intervention will consist of 6 weeks of treatment, with measurements taken before treatment, after the first week, after the third week, after the end of treatment, and during follow-up at eight and twelve weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity using the Visual Analog Pain Scale (VAS). Secondary outcome measures include changes in hip function and lower limb function. The study will be a randomized blind clinical trial, with participants assigned to either the dry needling or lasertherapy group.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a rapid technique for detecting intestinal anti-transglutaminase antibodies to enable real-time diagnosis of celiac disease. The study will assess the sensitivity and specificity of the rapid anti-TG2 test and EMA assay detected on mechanically lysed intestinal biopsies compared to the reference standard of serology and histopathology. The study will also examine the concordance of the EMA assay and rapid anti-TG2 test with Culture-EMA results. The trial will include patients undergoing an elective esophagogastroduodenoscopy for various gastrointestinal conditions. The study is designed to provide insights into the effectiveness of the rapid technique for detecting celiac disease.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia in nurses with post-COVID-19 condition. The study will include nurses with post-COVID-19 condition who do not have a history of sleep apnea, narcolepsy, or other specific conditions. The minimum age for participation is 20 years, and the maximum age is 65 years. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the experimental group receiving cognitive-behavioral therapy or the control group receiving usual care. The primary outcome measures include insomnia severity, sleep quality, and sleep efficiency, which will be assessed before and after the intervention, as well as at 1, 2, and 3 months after the intervention. Secondary outcome measures include anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life. The study will have a duration of 20 weeks.

This pilot clinical trial aims to evaluate the acceptability and impact of a web-based decision aid called RAPID AFib on the shared decision-making process for stroke prevention therapy in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF). The study will involve a prospective, randomized pilot design, with participants being randomized to either receive the RAPID AFib intervention or standard care. The primary outcome measure will be the Shared Decision Making Questionnaire (SDM-Q-9) completed by the patients immediately after their clinic visit. The study aims to address the knowledge translation challenge of risk-discordant stroke prevention therapy in AF and improve patient knowledge and decision quality.

This clinical trial is a Phase I study that aims to assess the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a new medicine called NNC0491-6075. The study will involve healthy participants and participants with dyslipidaemia (high levels of fat in the blood). The participants will be divided into different groups and will receive either NNC0491-6075 or a placebo. The study will measure the number of treatment emergent adverse events (TEAEs) experienced by the participants, as well as other secondary outcome measures such as the serum concentration of NNC0491-6075. The study has different parts with varying time frames for data collection.

This clinical trial evaluates the efficiency of high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) versus noninvasive ventilation (NIV) in patients with acute hypercapnic respiratory failure. The study includes adult patients admitted to the ICU and divides them into two groups: one treated with HFNC and the other with NIV. The primary outcome measure is the failure of improvement of pH, while secondary outcome measures include mortality and ICU stay. The study aims to determine which treatment modality is more effective in these patients.

This clinical trial aims to implement a digital-first care delivery model for heart failure in Uganda. The study will include a mixed methods process evaluation to make adjustments to the implementation processes based on qualitative feedback and quantitative intervention data. The trial will also explore the cost effectiveness and sustainability factors of the digital health intervention. The study will involve participants with a clinical diagnosis of New York Heart Association Class II-III heart failure who have access to a mobile phone and basic reading skills in one of the offered languages. The interventions include enhanced HF clinical care and a digital health intervention called Medly Uganda. The study is designed as a randomized trial with participants receiving the interventions at different start points within the first six months. The primary outcome measures include the change in self-care of heart failure and clinical effectiveness. Secondary outcome measures include participant fidelity to self-care, facility fidelity to implementation strategy, and various physiological and psychological measurements.

This clinical trial is a comparative pharmacokinetic study of ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablets in healthy adults under fasting conditions. The study aims to determine the bioequivalence of the test product (ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablets) compared to the reference products (ibuprofen tablets and diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablets). The study will measure various pharmacokinetic parameters, including area under the curve, peak concentration, time to reach peak concentration, terminal half-life, and mean residence time. The trial will involve 16 healthy subjects who will be randomly assigned to different treatment groups. The study will also monitor vital signs, conduct physical examinations, and assess any adverse events experienced by the participants. The eligibility criteria include being a healthy adult aged 18 years or older.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of apalutamide in patients with metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer. The study will be a multicenter prospective observational study. The eligibility criteria include being male, 18 years or older, having a confirmed diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of the prostate, and a treatment decision for apalutamide by a clinician. The study will measure the undetectable PSA rate in patients receiving apalutamide as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the impact of apalutamide on fatigue, cognitive function, and health-related quality of life using patient-reported questionnaires. The study will take place from August 2023 to April 2027.

This clinical trial aims to demonstrate the hair and scalp benefits of 0.045% Tazarotene/0.01% Halobetasol Lotion in treating scalp psoriasis. Male or female subjects with moderate to severe scalp psoriasis will be evaluated for study entry. They will receive the lotion once daily for 12 weeks, and their hair growth and reduction in scalp itch will be measured as primary outcomes. The study will be open-label and all participants will receive the lotion.

This clinical trial is testing the combination of idasanutlin and selinexor therapy in children with progressive/relapsed atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) or extra-CNS malignant rhabdoid tumors. The trial will have a dose-finding/safety phase to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination treatment. Patients will receive idasanutlin once daily for 5 days, starting at 80% of the RP2D determined in a previous trial. Selinexor will be given on day 4 of each of the first 3 weeks of a 28-day cycle, with week 4 skipped. The expansion phase of the trial will evaluate the efficacy of the treatment in different patient groups. The primary outcome measures include the MTD and RP2D of the combination treatment, as well as the pharmacokinetics of idasanutlin. Secondary outcome measures include objective response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival.

This clinical trial is comparing the effectiveness of radius and capitate shortening in the treatment of ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease, which is avascular necrosis of the lunate. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with an open-label approach. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving radial shortening and the other receiving capitate shortening. The primary outcome measure will be the Modified Mayo Wrist Score, which assesses wrist pain, hand grip, work status, and range of motion after one year. The study is open to individuals aged 18-65 of any sex and accepts healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program in pancreatic cancer patients undergoing surgery. The program includes physical exercise, nutritional therapy, and psychological interventions. The primary objective is to determine if the prehabilitation program improves functional capacity, nutritional status, and health-related quality of life compared to usual care. Secondary objectives include analyzing the impact of prehabilitation on postoperative morbidity and exploring the effects on circulating molecules involved in cancer cachexia and inflammation. The trial will be randomized and controlled, with participants assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. Various assessments will be conducted at baseline and before surgery, and follow-up evaluations will occur at 30, 60, and 90 days after surgery. The primary outcome measure is the Comprehensive Complication Index, while secondary measures include functional capacity, pro-inflammatory cytokines, cancer cachexia-related factors, time to patient functional recovery, length of stay, body composition, and health-related quality of life. The study aims to recruit 226 patients.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training on balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will include children aged 5-12 years with hemiplegic, monoplegic, unilaterally affected, or diplegic cerebral palsy. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive conventional rehabilitation and dual task exercise training, or the control group, which will receive conventional rehabilitation only. The primary outcome measures include the Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6 Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire. The study will evaluate the participants before and 12 weeks after the interventions.

This clinical trial is titled "Active Surveillance of Influenza Virus Zoonotic Transmission Events: a Pilot Study in Belgium." The study aims to monitor and detect zoonotic transmission of influenza viruses in Belgium. The participants will include workers and volunteers from various groups, such as those involved in avian influenza outbreak farms, poultry farm sentinel network, wild bird/life rehabilitation center sentinel network, and pig industry veterinarian sentinel network. The participants will be requested to perform self-sampling using a nasopharyngeal swab every 2 days or 2 weeks, depending on the group, to collect respiratory specimens. The study will measure the number of participants who test positive for non-seasonal influenza viruses using RT-qPCR tests. Additionally, the study will assess the seroconversion against non-seasonal influenza viruses in outbreak participants using haemagglutination inhibition or seroneutralisation assays. The study is expected to continue until December 2024.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the impact of a canine-assisted therapy program on youth residing in a residential treatment center. The study will use a longitudinal, within-person design with two parallel conditions. One condition involves a 6-week canine therapy intervention, while the other condition follows treatment as usual. The intervention includes structured activities focused on dog obedience and training skills. The primary outcome measures include emotional regulation, attention, inhibitory control, and self-esteem. Secondary outcome measures include attendance, attrition, attitudes towards pets, and significant event reporting. The study will collect baseline and follow-up data from both the treatment and control groups.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled prospective study, with individuals between the ages of 18-25 years being recruited. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: a group that will receive foot core exercises only, and a group that will receive foot core exercises along with self-myofascial release using foam rollers. Both groups will follow a 6-week program of exercises, and measurements will be taken before and after the program to analyze the results. The primary outcome measure will be the change in balance, while secondary outcome measures will include changes in flexibility, power, and gait.

The clinical trial aims to investigate whether training the arms can reduce pain during the insertion of a peripheral venous catheter. The study will also explore the challenges faced by patients receiving cytostatic treatment in relation to vein status. The participants will be randomized into two groups, with one group receiving an 8-week daily arm training program and the other group receiving normal care. The primary outcome measure will be the level of pain measured using the Numeric Rating Scale. Secondary outcome measures will include assessing the vein status through ultrasound. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of arm training in reducing pain and improving vein status in patients undergoing chemotherapy.

This clinical trial aims to study the product of conception derived from ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) in women who have experienced miscarriage or termination of pregnancy (TOP). The study will investigate the genetic factors and immunological abnormalities associated with early pregnancy loss. The researchers will use next-generation sequencing (NGS) to detect copy-number variants and chromosomal mosaicisms. They will also analyze the immune cell populations and activation markers in decidual tissues. The intervention involves performing USG-MVA to remove the uterine contents, and the product of conception will be sent for karyotyping analysis. The primary outcome measures include histopathologic diagnosis of chorionic villi and immunohistochemistry staining of maternal decidua. The study aims to provide insights into the genetic and immunological mechanisms involved in pregnancy loss.

This clinical trial is investigating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamic properties of Lu AF28996 in Japanese men and women with Parkinson's disease. The trial will involve participants who meet specific inclusion criteria, including being diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson's disease and experiencing motor fluctuations. The trial will assess various outcome measures, including the number of participants with treatment-emergent adverse events and the plasma concentration of Lu AF28996. The study design is an interventional, exploratory, open-label trial with a single group assignment. The participants will receive ascending oral doses of Lu AF28996 for 14 days, followed by down-titration as determined by the investigator. The study aims to determine the safety and efficacy of Lu AF28996 in treating Parkinson's disease in Japanese participants.

This clinical trial aims to assess the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and required capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program in selected hospitals in Bangladesh. The study will enroll high-risk individuals, including children aged 6 months to 8 years, pregnant women, individuals aged 60 years and older, and adults with chronic diseases. The intervention arm will receive free influenza vaccination, while the control arm will not. The primary outcomes of the study are influenza vaccine acceptability and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios. Secondary outcomes include perceived susceptibility and severity of influenza, perceived barriers and benefits to vaccination, and required capacity for vaccine doses and self-injection equipment. The study design is quasi-experimental, with random allocation to the intervention and control arms. Data will be collected through surveys, follow-up phone calls, and cost assessments.

The clinical trial is titled "Single-Use Duodenoscopes Performance Characteristics and Technical Outcomes: the SUSPECT Italian Prospective Study." The study aims to evaluate the performance characteristics and technical outcomes of single-use duodenoscopes in patients with diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. The study will include participants who are 18 years or older and willing to comply with the study procedures. Pregnant women and subjects currently enrolled in another investigational study that could interfere with the current study are excluded. The study will measure technical performance and procedural performance of the single-use duodenoscopes over a period of 24 months.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility of a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation program for patients with respiratory disease. The program uses a smartphone app called Active+me REMOTE to deliver remote tracking, education, exercise classes, and personalized care plans. The trial will compare outcomes between patients in the hybrid program and a control group that received standard pulmonary rehabilitation. The study will measure patient recruitment rates, participant retention rates, data availability, success of propensity matching, integration into routine practice, patient and staff acceptability, safety, and various patient outcomes. The results will inform the design of a larger trial to compare the effectiveness of the hybrid program.

This observational study aims to describe the demographics and clinical characteristics of patients who received EVUSHELD as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against COVID-19 in Japan. The study will use secondary data and include all patients with a record of EVUSHELD administration. The patients will be followed up for 6 months after the first administration of EVUSHELD. The study will also measure the event rate and time to event for medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19, and all-cause mortality up to 180 days after the first administration of EVUSHELD. The sample size is expected to be approximately 280 participants.

This clinical trial is a Phase 4 multicenter study that aims to assess the safety and efficacy of subcutaneously injected Risankizumab in adult participants with genital or scalp psoriasis. The study will include participants with moderate to severe genital or scalp psoriasis and will evaluate the achievement of specific outcome measures related to severity of psoriasis and quality of life. The study will be randomized, double-blind, and will have parallel assignment of participants to different intervention groups. The primary outcome measures include the percentage of participants achieving specific scores on the Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia or the Scalp Investigator Global Assessment. Secondary outcome measures include additional assessments of severity and quality of life related to psoriasis. The study will have a treatment period of 52 weeks followed by an 8-week follow-up period. Risankizumab will be administered via subcutaneous injection.

This clinical trial aims to determine the prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock Variation (LCV) in patients with symptomatic thumb CMC arthritis. The study will recruit 500 male and female patients over the age of 35 through convenience sampling. There is no control group, and participants will only need to commit to one visit. The study will collect demographic and dichotomous data to determine if patients have the LCV and if it is present in one or both hands. The study will take place at multiple locations over a two-year period. There are no risks to participants, and they will be informed if they have the LCV during the examination. There is no compensation for participating in the study. The study design is a descriptive cross-sectional study with a primary purpose of screening. The intervention is a clinical examination for the LCV. The primary outcome measure is a positive or negative clinical exam for the LCV.

This is a Phase 3 clinical trial that aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of oral Atogepant tablets in pediatric participants (6-17 years old) with episodic migraine. The study will last for 12 weeks and will be double-blind and placebo-controlled. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcome measures include the change from baseline in mean monthly headache days, mean monthly acute medication use days, percentage of participants who achieve at least a 50% reduction in average monthly migraine days, change from baseline in the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory total score, and change from baseline in the Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment total score. The study will involve different dosage levels of Atogepant and placebo for different age groups within the pediatric population.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effects of a targeted touchscreen training program on the learning potential of patients with Parkinson's disease. The training program involves practicing touchscreen sliding motions on a tablet in the home setting. The study will include 36 PD patients who will be randomized into an experimental group and a control group. The experimental group will receive 10 training sessions over a period of two weeks, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The main outcomes measured will be the average slide duration and performance accuracy on the touchscreen task. Secondary outcomes include retention effects after four weeks without training and consolidation of learning. The study will also assess cognitive function, training compliance, and other non-motor features. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and no masking. The primary purpose of the study is treatment, and the intervention model is a parallel assignment. The experimental group will receive targeted touchscreen training, while the control group will receive no intervention. The study will measure the average slide duration and performance accuracy after two weeks of training as the primary outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures include retention effects after four weeks, consolidation effects of two weeks of training, and cognitive function. The study aims to explore the learning potential and motor skills of patients with Parkinson's disease and determine the effectiveness of targeted touchscreen training in improving these skills.

This clinical trial investigates the influence of intensified tactile contact with a newborn on the emotional transformation of women after physiological delivery. The study uses a non-randomized quasi-experimental design and includes an experimental group that receives intensified tactile contact through Shantali massage, and a control group that receives no intervention. The dependent variables measured include emotions in the negative and positive domains, which are assessed using standardized self-reported questionnaires. The study aims to determine if the direction of the mother's emotional transformation differs between the experimental and control groups. The study involves participants who have had their first physiological delivery and meet specified eligibility criteria. The intervention starts on the 3rd day after birth and lasts until the end of the 12th week postpartum. The measurements of the dependent variables are taken before and after the 12-week observation period. Statistical analysis includes evaluating the internal consistency of the questionnaires and analyzing inter-group differences using appropriate tests. Cluster analysis is also used to identify homogenous subgroups. The study aims to contribute to the understanding of postpartum emotional disorders and their potential treatments.

This clinical trial is evaluating the combination of paclitaxel-bevacizumab with or without atezolizumab in patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have progressed after immunotherapy and chemotherapy. The trial aims to assess the progression-free survival at 6 months as the primary outcome measure, as well as secondary measures such as overall survival, objective response rate, and health-related quality of life. The trial is randomized and open-label, with two treatment arms. The participants will receive the specified drugs intravenously every three weeks until progression. The trial will also evaluate the incidence, nature, and severity of adverse events. The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 39 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in managing persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study will include participants who have experienced at least one symptom of post-COVID-19 for at least 4 weeks after diagnosis. The primary outcome measures will focus on the feasibility of patient recruitment and data completion rates. Secondary outcome measures will assess neurocognitive and psychological symptoms, physical symptoms, global health, and return to work. The study will be conducted over approximately 1 year, with assessments conducted at specific intervals throughout the study period.

This clinical trial aims to compare the use of ICG microangiography and conventional angiography in severe frostbite cases. The study will assess the concordance between these two imaging modalities in demonstrating the presence of ischemic tissue in severe frostbite. The primary outcome measure is the Hennepin Frostbite Score, while the secondary outcome measure is the safety of ICG when delivered with contrast dye. The study will include adult patients diagnosed with severe frostbite who are undergoing thrombolysis. The eligibility criteria include being clinically sober, cognitively able to provide consent, and having normal kidney function. The study design involves the administration of ICG angiogram after conventional angiogram. The study is expected to be completed within an average of 2 years.

This clinical trial aims to assess the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit (GPOU) on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who undergo surgery for colorectal cancer. The study will compare the GPOU group, which receives specific geriatric care in addition to standard care, with the control group that receives classical management in the digestive surgery department. The primary outcome measure is the change in functional status after surgery, measured by the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score. Secondary outcome measures include changes in functional and motor ability, patient satisfaction with care, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, patient quality of life, overall survival, and rate of re-hospitalizations or emergency department admissions. The study will provide valuable insights into the benefits of a multidisciplinary approach in perioperative geriatric care for older patients with colorectal cancer.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) for imaging metastatic solid tumors in patients receiving stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT). The primary objectives of the study are to describe the toxicities of 64CDP positron emission tomography and to identify changes in 64CDP uptake in radiated metastatic lesions pre- and post-SBRT. The study will involve administering pembrolizumab and 64CDP to patients, performing PET scans, and undergoing SBRT. The trial will assess dose-limiting toxicities, changes in 64CDP uptake, changes in standard-uptake value, and the incidence of adverse events. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial is a follow-up study to assess the safety of participants who received the RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination or controls from previous RSV MAT studies during pregnancy. The study will include both retrospective and prospective cohorts of adult/adolescent participants who received the RSVPreF3 vaccine or controls. The primary outcome measures will focus on pregnancy outcomes and adverse events in both maternal and infant participants. The study design is non-randomized and open-label, with two participant groups receiving either the RSVPreF3 vaccine or controls. The study will collect data from participants up to 42 days post-delivery for pregnancies conceived within 2 years of vaccination. The study aims to provide important safety information about the RSVPreF3 vaccine and its impact on pregnancy outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of 19F MRI in healthy children and children with mild cystic fibrosis lung disease. The study will include participants aged 6-17 years old who meet specific inclusion criteria, such as non-smoking and stable lung function. The intervention involves the inhalation of a biologically inert contrast gas, perfluoropropane, combined with 19F-tuned MRI to obtain images of the lungs. The study will measure various outcomes, including participation rate, completion rate, parental and child acceptability scores, and MRI-defined ventilation defect parameters in both healthy participants and those with cystic fibrosis. The trial is designed as a cross-sectional pilot study and will assess these outcomes at a single visit.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of open chain exercises and closed chain exercises on pain, function, and balance in athletes with patellofemoral pain syndrome. The study will be conducted in Pakistan with a sample size of athletes aged 18-40 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the open chain exercise group or the closed chain exercise group. They will undergo 6 weeks of treatment with 3 sessions per week. The primary outcome measures include pain rating, lower extremity function, and a y balance test. The data will be analyzed using statistical software.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The MIND diet is believed to have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that can improve these biomarkers. The study will include 30 athletes divided into two groups: a control group and a group following the MIND diet. Various biomarkers associated with neurodegeneration, inflammation, and oxidative stress will be analyzed before and after a 9-week period. The study will also assess sleep quality, quality of life, and dietary inflammatory index scores. The results of this trial will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of the MIND diet for American football players.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of left bundle branch area pacing in heart failure patients with a below-normal ejection fraction. The study will measure the acute success rate of left bundle branch area pacing and the occurrence of acute complications related to the procedure. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of repeat procedures, pacemaker upgrade to cardiac resynchronization therapy, heart failure hospitalization, cardiovascular death, all-cause death, left ventricular ejection fraction, left ventricular end diastolic diameter, left ventricular end systolic diameter, left ventricular global strain, capture threshold, sensing, and impedance. The study will last for 1 year.

This clinical trial, titled "Safety, Tolerability, and Pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004," is a phase 1a study that aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 injection in healthy adults. The study will involve a single ascending dose of CSX-1004 and a placebo control. The eligibility criteria include being a healthy adult aged 18 to 50 years with a body mass index within a specific range. The study will assess treatment-emergent adverse events, clinical laboratory assessments, vital signs, electrocardiogram, physical examination, and infusion site examination as primary outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures include maximum serum concentration, area under the curve, time to maximum serum concentration, and beta terminal elimination half-life. The study design is randomized, double-blind, and placebo-controlled. The study will last for approximately 5 months.

This clinical trial, titled "Joint Aspiration in Dysfunctional Hip, Knee or Shoulder Prostheses (Chronic Infection or Implant Failure) JAD-Pro," aims to investigate the use of joint aspiration in patients with dysfunctional hip, knee, or shoulder prostheses. The study will collect anamnesis, clinical, radiological, and biological data from patients and classify them into three groups: supposedly septic, supposedly aseptic, or intermediate. Patients will undergo joint fluid aspiration and their bacteriological results will be compared with perioperative samples. The primary outcome measure of the study is the analysis of bacteriological concordance between joint fluid aspiration and perioperative samples. The study is a prospective cohort study and does not involve healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to quantitatively and spatially register airways dysfunction using dynamic 19F MRI in individuals with cystic fibrosis. The study will involve participants who are non-smokers and have a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. The intervention will involve the combination product of 19F MRI, which includes inhalation of a contrast gas called perfluoropropane combined with 19F-tuned MRI. The study will measure various outcomes, including changes in ventilation defect parameter (VDP) and FLVlongtau2 over 14 days and 365 days. Secondary outcomes include changes in MRI severity score and correlations between MRI severity score and VDP/FLVlongtau2. The study does not accept healthy volunteers and has specific eligibility criteria for participation.

This is a bioequivalence trial of a fasting single oral STI-1558 capsule in healthy Chinese subjects. The trial is a randomized, open, single-dose, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-cross design study. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the TR group or RT group. The TR group will take the test preparation (T) on day 1 and the reference preparation (R) on day 8, while the RT group will take the reverse sequence. The trial drug should be taken with water after fasting overnight for at least 10 hours. The study will compare the maximum observed concentration (Cmax) and area under the curve (AUC) of the test preparation and reference preparation to establish relative bioavailability. Secondary outcome measures include comparing Tmax, t1/2, λz, and %AUCex of the two preparations. The trial will assess the safety and tolerability of the subjects.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effectiveness of detaching the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endotracheal tube malposition after a change of position in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The trial will involve patients undergoing thoracic surgery who require a left-sided double-lumen endobronchial tube. The primary outcome measure is the malposition rate of the double-lumen endobronchial tube immediately after a change in body position. The secondary outcome measures include the effects of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and PACU length of stay. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment, and the intervention involves disengaging the breathing circuit when the patient transitions from the supine to the lateral position.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of personalized comprehensive diabetes support among families of children with newly diagnosed Type 1 Diabetes. The study will include families with children aged 16 or younger who have a stable living situation. The intervention involves providing personalized comprehensive diabetes support for 6 months following the diagnosis. The primary outcome measures are the Diabetes Distress Scale and the Problem Areas in Diabetes scale, which assess diabetes-related stress. The study will last for 24 months and is designed as a randomized controlled trial.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine monitoring in the management of major depressive disorder (MDD) in patients following hospitalization. The study will compare the outcomes of patients who receive telemedicine sessions in addition to usual care with those who only receive usual care. The primary outcome measure is the treatment response rate at 6 months, defined as a 50% reduction in the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS-Depression) score. Secondary outcome measures include cost-utility ratio, quality of life, number of relapse episodes, medication compliance, and patient satisfaction. The study will also assess the feasibility and satisfaction of telemedicine tools and identify clinical variables associated with drop-out from the care program. The study is a randomized multicenter clinical trial and will follow patients for 3 years.

This clinical trial aims to improve the accuracy of diagnosing soft tissue sarcomas using artificial intelligence (AI). The researchers will develop an AI algorithm that can differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses. The study will involve acquiring additional quantitative MR images during standard MRI scans, which will add a maximum of 10 minutes to the scan. A subset of patients will also be invited for a second scan to test the reproducibility of the measurements. The primary outcome measure is the diagnostic accuracy of the AI algorithms in distinguishing between benign and malignant lesions. The secondary outcome measure is the classification accuracy of the algorithms in classifying malignant lesions into their pathological grade.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of microneedling alone versus microneedling with hyaluronic acid on thin gingival phenotype. The trial will be conducted over a period of 24 months and will include 20 patients with thin gingival phenotype. The patients will be randomly assigned to receive either microneedling alone or microneedling with hyaluronic acid. The thickness of the gingival tissue and other periodontal indices will be measured at baseline, 1 month, 6 months, and 9 months. The primary outcome measure of the study is the measurement of gingival thickness.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The study will focus on changes in adipose tissue inflammation and its correlation with surgical outcome. The trial will involve participants with primary colorectal neoplasms eligible for elective surgery, aged 20 to 85, and with a BMI ranging from 18 to 40. The study design is a multicenter randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and double masking. The intervention includes the administration of the dietary supplement Oral Impact Nestle or a placebo three times a day for 10 days before colorectal surgery. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of surgical site infection (SSI) within 30 days after the surgical procedure. Secondary outcome measures include anastomotic leakage, length of hospital stay, and various measures related to adipose tissue inflammation. The study will analyze the specimens of subcutaneous adipose tissue and visceral adipose tissue for inflammatory cell count, fibroblast count, and adipocytes cross-sectional area.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of adding an oculomotor therapy treatment to a manual therapy protocol of the cervical region in patients with migraine. The study will involve two groups, a control group receiving cervical treatment and an experimental group receiving both cervical and oculomotor treatments. The primary outcome measures will assess changes in headache impact, while secondary outcome measures will evaluate changes in pain, disability, depression, anxiety, sleep quality, kinesiophobia, catastrophizing, central sensitization, neck disability, head repositioning, strength of deep cervical flexors, ocular movement, range of movement, and quality of life. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks and follow-up assessments will be conducted at 3 months after the intervention.

The clinical trial is evaluating the use of the Cratos™ Branch Stent Graft System in the treatment of descending aorta lesions, specifically aortic dissection Type B, intramural hematoma, and penetrating aortic ulcer. The study is open to individuals aged 18 and above, of any gender, and also accepts healthy volunteers. The primary purpose of the study is treatment, and it involves a single group assignment with no masking. The intervention involves the use of the Cratos™ Stent Graft in a Thoracic Endovascular Repair (TEVAR) procedure for the treatment of aortic lesions. The primary outcome measure being evaluated is all-cause mortality within 30 days.

This clinical trial aims to compare two techniques for ultrasound-guided lumbar plexus block. The study will analyze the depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels using the Trident and Shamrock techniques. The primary outcome measure is the projection of line C on the costiform processes. The secondary outcome measures include the depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and presence of vessels. The study will involve adult participants with a lumbar echography indication.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in reducing stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and improving patient quality of life after Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate (HoLEP). The trial will include male patients scheduled to undergo HoLEP for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). The study will have two groups: one receiving preoperative PFPT and the other receiving postoperative PFPT. The primary outcome measure is the time to continence after surgery, while secondary measures include urine flow rate, residual urine volume, urinary symptom score, operative time, length of hospital stay, catheter duration, infectious complications, and emergency room visits. The trial aims to determine the role of preoperative PFPT in managing SUI associated with HoLEP.

The clinical trial, titled "DETECT-IP: a Clinical Decision Support System and Intelligent Procedures to Counter Some Adverse Drug Events in Older Hospital Patients," aims to reduce acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia adverse drug events in older inpatients. The study involves incorporating specific rules into a computerized support system and dedicated procedures. The trial is a randomized, controlled, single-blind study with stepped-wedge permutations. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse drug events in older hospitalized patients, while secondary outcome measures include the presence of adverse events related to the intervention provided, therapeutic adaptations implemented in case of acute renal failure or hyperkalemia, relevance of CDSS alerts, number of pharmaceutical interventions accepted, changes in ADEs prevention/management work process, and cost-effectiveness of the pharmaceutical intervention. The study will be conducted over an average of 20 days and involves participants aged 65 years and older. The intervention group will receive clinical decision support, while the control group will not receive clinical decision support. The study aims to improve patient safety and optimize medication management in older inpatients.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the mesenteric bacterial translocation in individuals with advanced Crohn's disease. The study will compare the proportions and abundance of bacterial taxa in the mesentery, ileal tissue, and blood between Crohn's disease patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. Additionally, the study will analyze the genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of Crohn's disease patients. The trial will include adults who require an ileocecal resection as part of their Crohn's disease treatment. Controls will consist of individuals who require an ileocecal resection for a different reason and do not have inflammatory bowel disease. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of injection site on the relative bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943 in healthy participants with a high body mass index. The study will include healthy participants with a BMI between 27.0 and 45.0 kg/m² who are willing to receive the study treatment through injections. The trial will be conducted on participants aged 18 to 70 years and will include both males and females. The study design is randomized and participants will be assigned to two experimental groups, with one group receiving LY3437943 subcutaneously and the other group receiving it intravenously. The primary outcome measures will include the pharmacokinetics of LY3437943, specifically the area under the plasma concentration versus time curve and the maximum concentration of the drug. The secondary outcome measures will also assess the pharmacokinetics of LY3437943. The study will span a period of up to 43 days for Part A and up to 71 days for Part B.

This clinical trial is a research registry focused on aggressive pituitary tumors. The study aims to characterize the aggressiveness of these tumors through transcriptome analysis and identify molecular signatures that can predict prognosis. The study will include adult patients with pituitary tumors who have been presented to the national HYPOcare RCP. The study will last for 3 years and is being conducted by the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The clinical trial titled "OPTI-DOSE: Optimal Dosing of Oral Anticancer Drugs in Older Adults" aims to determine if a lower starting dose of oral anticancer drugs can improve treatment tolerability in older patients without compromising the benefits of the treatment. The trial will include 30 patients aged 65 years or older who are starting treatment with one of the specified anticancer drugs. The trial will be randomized with half of the participants receiving the standard starting dose and the other half receiving a lower starting dose, which will be gradually increased if tolerated well. The results of this pilot study will be used to inform the design of a larger phase 2 trial. The study will assess various outcomes including treatment utility, overall survival, progression-free survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, and pharmacokinetic parameters.

This clinical trial, titled "Preoperative Short-course Radiation Followed by Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX for MSS Locally Advanced Rectal Adenocarcinoma," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a combined treatment approach for rectal cancer. The study will involve patients with locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma who will receive neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy combined with immunotherapy and total mesorectal excision surgery. The primary objective is to assess the pathologic complete response rate, while secondary outcomes include tumor regression grade, overall survival, progression-free survival, treatment-related adverse events, surgical complications, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in a randomized, multicenter fashion, with one group receiving the experimental treatment and the other group receiving neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy without immunotherapy.

This clinical trial is a two-stage study that aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of different doses of Levilimab in healthy subjects and subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis. 

Stage 1 of the study involves administering Levilimab to healthy subjects at ascending doses and assessing its safety and tolerability. Stage 2 is a randomized, double-blind study where Levilimab is given to subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis in combination with methotrexate. The primary outcome measures include evaluating the safety profile of Levilimab in healthy subjects and assessing the proportion of subjects with low disease activity in the rheumatoid arthritis group at week 24. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the proportion of subjects achieving remission, pharmacokinetic endpoints, ACR response, changes in disease activity, quality of life, fatigue, functional activity, and X-ray assessment.

The study design involves parallel assignment and masking, and the intervention includes subcutaneous or intravenous injections of Levilimab with placebo. The study is open to both male and female participants aged 18 years and above. The eligibility criteria include meeting certain inclusion criteria and not having any exclusion criteria. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 71 days for stage 1 and up to 52 weeks for stage 2.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of white kidney bean on oral glucose tolerance test. The trial is a randomized, double-blind, cross-over study involving participants with diabetes and high blood sugar. The intervention involves the use of Wonderlab Product and Placebo in two phases. The eligibility criteria include healthy adults aged 25-45 years with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study design is supportive care, with random allocation and a crossover assignment. The primary outcome measures are the change in blood glucose levels based on the oral glucose tolerance test after intervention. The secondary outcome measures include the change in fasting blood glucose levels. The study will assess the efficacy of white kidney bean in improving glucose tolerance.

This clinical trial aims to implement evidence-based facility and community interventions to reduce the treatment gap for depression. The study will include adults (>18 years) who speak English or one of the local languages and reside in the trial clusters. The intervention includes a community intervention delivered by community volunteers to enhance demand for the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) treatment and promote engagement and completion of the treatment. The HAP treatment will be delivered in an individual format and will consist of psychoeducation, behavioral assessment, activity monitoring, activity structuring and scheduling, activation of social networks, and problem-solving. The study will measure outcomes such as contact coverage, effectiveness coverage, sustained effectiveness, remission, response to treatment, out-of-pocket costs, disability assessment, depression awareness, perceived social support, treatment completion, and behavioral activation. The study will be randomized and participants will be allocated to either the experimental community model or the active comparator facility model. The primary outcome measures will be assessed three months post recruitment.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of low-intensity blood flow restriction training in both normoxia and hypoxia conditions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine levels, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults. The study will involve participants performing different types of resistance training exercises under various conditions, including normoxia and hypoxia. The study will measure various outcomes such as force output, one-repetition maximum, muscle stiffness, muscle thickness, catecholamine response, perception of pain and effort, and blood pressure. The study will follow a randomized design with parallel assignment and will include both active comparator and experimental groups. The eligibility criteria require participants to be physically active, experienced in resistance training, and free from any medical risk factors or conditions that could make the protocol hazardous. The study will involve participants aged 18 to 30 years, of any gender, and will accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial is investigating the efficacy and safety of mosunetuzumab, a new bispecific antibody, in patients with follicular lymphoma who have relapsed or progressed within 24 months of initial treatment. The main objective is to determine the progression-free survival 2 years after the initiation of second-line treatment in these patients. Secondary objectives include assessing safety, response rate, duration of response, transformation to higher grade lymphoma, patients' quality of life, and resource usage related to mosunetuzumab. The trial is a phase II, multicenter study and participants will receive subcutaneous mosunetuzumab for up to 17 cycles. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include overall response rate, complete response rate, duration of response, time to new lymphoma treatment, overall survival, percentage of patients with adverse events, and percentage of patients with transformation to aggressive lymphoma.

This clinical trial aims to test the safety and effectiveness of combining two drugs, PLX2853 and Trametinib, in the treatment of advanced uveal melanoma. The primary objectives of the trial are to determine the maximum tolerated dose(s) and recommended phase II dose of the drugs, as well as to evaluate their clinical activity in advanced uveal melanoma. Secondary objectives include evaluating overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and adverse event profile. The trial will consist of a phase I dose-escalation study followed by a phase II study. Participants will receive the drugs orally throughout the study and undergo imaging and blood collection. The study will measure outcomes such as maximum tolerated dose, recommended phase II dose, overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of adverse events, and systemic exposure to the drugs.

The ASCERTAIN study aims to improve the management of Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) in Australia. It will implement a new model of care that includes regular lipid testing, access to a full range of management tools, and improved medication adherence. The study will compare the effectiveness of this new model of care to usual care in patients who have not reached their LDL cholesterol target. Participants will receive maximally tolerated statin and/or ezetimibe therapy, as well as inclisiran, with the treating physician's discretion. The study will include approximately 600 participants and will be conducted at 20 sites across Australia. The primary outcome measure is the effect on LDL cholesterol concentration, which will be assessed at baseline and at day 180. Secondary outcome measures include LDL cholesterol concentration at day 365. The study will involve education for general practitioners on guidelines and management therapy, as well as SMS messages and telephone-based support for participants. Inclisiran will be available in both arms of the study.

This clinical trial compares the effectiveness of ultrasound-guided erector spinae block, thoracic para-vertebral block, and quadratus lamborum block in open renal surgeries. The study aims to measure the total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively. The trial includes 48 patients aged 21-65 years and is conducted in a urology operating theatre. The patients are divided into three groups, and the interventions are performed accordingly.

This clinical trial aims to assess the musculoskeletal health of adult hematological cancer survivors. The study will use a mixed methods approach, including questionnaires and interviews, to evaluate the prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions and related symptoms, calculate the 10-year probability of hip and major osteoporotic fractures, measure the prevalence of sarcopenia and frailty, assess quality of life, and describe the experiences of survivors regarding musculoskeletal health. The study will also analyze risk factors associated with poor musculoskeletal health. The trial will last for a period of 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to study the effectiveness of disitamab vedotin in treating previously treated solid tumors that express HER2. The trial will involve adult subjects with different types of tumors, including squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck, non-small-cell lung carcinoma, ovarian neoplasms, and endometrial neoplasms. The participants will receive disitamab vedotin as the treatment. The primary outcome measure of the study is the confirmed objective response rate, while secondary outcome measures include adverse events, disease control rate, duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, pharmacokinetic parameters, and incidence of antidrug antibodies. The study will last for approximately 5 years.

This clinical trial aims to assess and address the driving safety of older adults who have experienced cognitive decline following a stay in the intensive care unit (ICU). The study will use in-vehicle driving assessments and monitoring to collect data on driving behaviors. The researchers will also conduct neurocognitive assessments to evaluate the relationship between cognitive function and driving behavior and safety. The study will enroll a cohort of older ICU survivors and evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the assessments and data collection. The insights from stakeholder advisory panels will inform the development of a driving assessment system tailored to ICU survivors. The study will provide valuable information for developing interventions and strategies to improve driving safety for this population.

This clinical trial, titled "ACT for Healthy Living: a Brief Acceptance and Commitment Therapy Intervention for Women With Obesity," aims to assess the efficacy of a brief acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) workshop for weight loss in women with obesity. The study will recruit 70 women, with half of them receiving the ACT workshop and the other half serving as a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures include changes in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, and valued living at 1 week and 1 month post-intervention. Secondary outcome measures include changes in weight self-stigma, body image, emotional eating, physical activity, diet quality, and body weight at the same time points. The study design is a parallel assignment with an open-label approach.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the value of minimal residual disease (MRD) detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) patients. It will investigate the effect of a drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival, as well as explore whether it can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations. The study will include GIST patients at high risk of recurrence who have been treated with imatinib for 3 years after surgery and have achieved disease control. The primary outcome measures include progression-free survival, drug re-use rate, and drug retreatment response rate. Secondary outcome measures include overall survival, genetic mutation profiling of ctDNA-MRD, and comparing MRD conversion with disease progression assessed by imaging examination. The study design is an observational clinical trial with one patients cohort.

This randomized control trial aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. The study will include subjects with Down syndrome aged 6 to 12 years old who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The assessment will be done using the Test of trunk impairment scale and Time Up and Go Test. The subjects will be divided into two groups, with one group receiving Dohsa hou therapy and the other group receiving standard treatment protocol. The primary outcome measures will be the trunk impairment scale and the time up and go test, both measured after 6 weeks.

This clinical trial, titled "Supporting Physical Literacy at School and Home (SPLASH) Study," aims to increase physical activity (PA) among elementary school children through a multilevel, comprehensive physical literacy (PL) program. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with 400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools. The intervention group will receive the Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program, which includes a school-based physical education curriculum and a family engagement component. The control group will follow standard school operating procedures. The primary outcome measures will assess baseline and end-point physical activity levels using Actigraph accelerometers. Secondary outcome measures will evaluate fundamental movement skills in running, locomotion, object control, and balance. The study aims to determine the impact of the RNYRR program on children's PL and PA, and whether these effects differ by sex or weight status. The researchers will also explore whether changes in PL mediate changes in daily total PA volume or moderate-to-vigorous PA.

This clinical trial is a Phase III study testing the efficacy and safety of BI 456906, a drug administered subcutaneously, in Japanese patients with obesity disease. The study aims to measure the percentage change in body weight and achievement of body weight reduction at various levels from baseline to Week 76. Secondary outcome measures include changes in BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure, eating behavior, glycemic control, lipid levels, liver fat content, and body composition. The study is designed as a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group trial with participants receiving either BI 456906 or a placebo.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the gastric volume in pediatric patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy surgery. The study will use ultrasound to assess the pre- and postoperative gastric volume in children and compare it to values considered risky for aspiration. The participants will be ASA 1,2,3 patients under the age of 18. The primary outcome measure is the calculation of gastric volume during the operation. Secondary outcome measures include the cross-sectional area of the stomach before intubation, after intubation, and postoperatively, as well as the presence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting. The study will also measure the blood volume in the suction system and the duration of surgery. The study design is a prospective cohort study with a single group assignment.

The clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of pituitrin on the prognosis of patients with pulmonary hypertension after cardiac surgery. The study will include patients aged 18 to 80 years who are scheduled for elective cardiac surgery and have pulmonary hypertension. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the pituitrin group or the normal saline group. The primary outcome measure is a composite endpoint of mortality or severe postoperative complications, while the secondary outcome measures include various postoperative complications and the use of vasoactive drugs. The study will last for 30 days after cardiac surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of initiating noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) in the home environment using remote telemonitoring compared to the standard of care, which involves initiating NiPPV in a hospital polysomnography laboratory. The trial will focus on children with medical complexity (CMC) who require NiPPV for chronic respiratory failure. The study will assess recruitment and retention rates, proportion of eligible patients randomized, and proportion of patients who crossover based on safety criteria as primary outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures include nightly NiPPV usage, proxy-reported and self-reported psychological scales, caregiver reported sense of mastery, patient and family study experience, preference of intervention and barriers, and differences in NiPPV settings between home initiation and polysomnography titration. The study design is a 12-week, open-label feasibility study with two arms: standard of care and home initiation of NiPPV. The study will provide valuable insights into the feasibility and safety of initiating NiPPV at home for children with medical complexity.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of dry needling on vertical jump performance in female athletes with latent myofascial trigger points (MTPs) in the gastrocnemius muscle. The study will be a single-blind randomized trial, with participants randomly assigned to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive a session of dry needling on the identified trigger points, while the control group will wait for a similar amount of time. The primary outcome measure will be the counter movement jump performance. The study will assess jump performance immediately after the needling session and at 72 hours and 7 days after the session. The assessor will be blinded to the group allocation of the participants. Overall, the study aims to determine the impact of dry needling on vertical jump performance in female athletes with latent MTPs.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the clinical features of refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) and the effectiveness of mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) in treating these patients. The study will include pediatric patients aged 3-18 years who meet the diagnostic criteria for HSP and have gastrointestinal involvement. Patients who are resistant to steroids will be treated with MMF. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools, while the secondary outcome measure is the count of red blood cells in the stool. The study will last for 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness and safety of Electroencephalogram (EEG) Enhanced Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (eTMS) as a treatment for Chronic Trauma and Stressor-Related Disorders (TSRD). The study will involve participants who are identified as veterans and have experienced deployment-related stressful events and trauma. The intervention will consist of midline prefrontal, lower intensity, shorter session eTMS, enhanced with EEG. The study will have a staged approach, with an initial cohort of 30 participants followed by an additional 270 participants. The primary outcomes of the study will include the number of participants experiencing device-related serious adverse events and the rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled visits. The secondary outcome will measure the mean change in mental component scores on the Veterans RAND 36-item health survey (VR-36) for participants who completed at least 80% of eTMS sessions.

This retrospective study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of combining radiotherapy with EGFR-TKI (targeted therapy) in patients with stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS). The study includes patients diagnosed with lung cancer, who have undergone genetic testing for EGFR mutation, and meet the criteria for stage III lung cancer. Participants will receive radiotherapy and targeted therapy, and the study will measure PFS over a period of 2 years.

The clinical trial aims to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will focus on streptococci infections and will collect samples from the Northampton General Hospital. Participants must be over 18 years old and consent to participate in the research. The study will measure the identification of streptococci species through DNA analysis and biochemical testing. Secondary outcome measures include patient characteristics, clinical outcomes, and antibiotic treatment. The study will span a duration of 4 years.

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) in women with stress urinary incontinence. The study included 48 women aged 29-49 who had complained of stress urinary incontinence for at least 4 weeks and had given birth. Participants were randomly divided into two groups: one group received FMS and the other group received a PFMT program. Various questionnaires and assessments were used to evaluate urinary incontinence symptoms, quality of life, and pelvic floor muscle strength. The study was conducted over a period of 6 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to optimize the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies for patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA) and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The study will involve phenotyping of synovial immune and stromal cells to generate a comprehensive cellular and molecular atlas of PsA. The participants will be divided into different groups based on their disease status and treatment resistance. The primary outcome measures include achieving minimal disease activity status, PsA development in PsO patients at risk, and remission maintenance. The study will last for 6 to 12 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of artificial tears to prevent nasolacrimal duct obstruction in patients undergoing radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer. The study will include participants who have received a minimum of 150 mCi of radioiodine therapy and are 18 years or older. The participants will be divided into two groups, one receiving artificial tears and the other not receiving any intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of post-radiotherapy nasolacrimal duct obstruction, as determined by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist, over a period of two years.

This clinical trial aims to compare the recurrence-free survival (RFS) of patients with high-risk melanoma who are treated with atorvastatin to those who receive a placebo. The study also aims to compare distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) and overall survival (OS) between the two treatment arms. Additionally, the trial will assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma. Patients will be randomized to receive either atorvastatin or placebo for up to 5 years, and will undergo computed tomography (CT) and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) throughout the study. The primary outcome measure is RFS, and secondary outcome measures include DMFS and OS. The study will also evaluate the clinical utility of gene expression profiling. Eligible participants must have stage IIA cutaneous melanoma and meet certain criteria for inclusion. The study is designed as a decentralized phase II randomized controlled trial, with participants assigned to either the atorvastatin or placebo arm. The study is double-blinded and parallel in design. The primary purpose of the study is treatment. The study will assess the effects of atorvastatin on the recurrence, distant metastasis, and overall survival of patients with resected high-risk melanoma.

This clinical trial aims to test implementation strategies to support the adherence of outpatient clinics to an Outpatient Hypertension Bundle (O-HTN bundle) for pregnant individuals with high blood pressure. The study will involve 20 clinics in central North Carolina and will compare usual care for severe hypertension to care provided after 12 months of implementation support from the ACHIEVE Nurse Coordinator. The primary outcome measures include the percentage of achieving the highest possible score for blood pressure measurement technique and documentation of patient education on hypertension. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of achieving the highest possible score for recognition and response to simulated and actual episodes of severe hypertension. The study design is a non-randomized, parallel assignment with three cohorts of clinics receiving the intervention at different time points. The intervention includes a multi-component implementation strategy delivered by the Nurse Coordinators, including facilitation/coaching, training, and simulation. If successful, the ACHIEVE model will be shared nationally to improve care for pregnant individuals with high blood pressure.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of tailored text messaging programs for reducing alcohol consumption among older adults. The study will compare three different types of text messaging interventions: loss-framed messaging, gain-framed messaging, and a combination of both. The participants will be randomized into one of the three conditions, and the interventions will last for 8 weeks. The study will assess drinking behavior at weeks 4, 8, and 16 through online assessments and weekly mobile assessments. The effects of the interventions will be compared, and attrition from the study will also be tracked. The study will explore how the effects of the interventions are impacted by gender and age. The eligibility criteria include being fluent in English, aged between 50 and 85, having hazardous drinking habits, and being willing to reduce drinking levels. The study design is a randomized controlled trial, with parallel assignment and masking. The primary outcome measures are the weekly sum of standard drinks and heavy drinking days, while the secondary outcome measures include adherence to the daily and weekly drinking assessments, as well as willingness to continue the program.

This clinical trial is studying the use of Fluselenamyl, a drug that can be used in PET imaging to detect beta-amyloid, a protein associated with Alzheimer's disease. The trial aims to determine the safety of Fluselenamyl and its effectiveness in detecting beta-amyloid in healthy individuals and those with mild cognitive impairment. Participants will receive an injection of Fluselenamyl and undergo PET scans to evaluate its biodistribution and toxicity. The study will also compare the results of Fluselenamyl PET imaging with another imaging agent called [11C]-PIB. The trial is expected to last for 2 years.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the long-term effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in patients with primary progressive aphasia. The study will include participants who meet specific inclusion criteria and do not have any exclusion criteria. The intervention involves TMS (active or sham) along with language therapy. The study design is randomized, with participants assigned to either the active or sham TMS group. The primary outcome measure is changes in brain metabolism using FDG-PET imaging. Secondary outcome measures include changes in spontaneous language, language assessment, daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with measurements taken at 0, 3, and 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of methylprednisolone on cognitive deficits in post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS) patients with suspected autoimmune involvement. The trial will be a two-arm, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study that will span 52 weeks. Participants will be stratified based on age, sex, and cognitive screening using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment Scale. They will be randomly assigned to receive either methylprednisolone or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open treatment phase with methylprednisolone. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include long-term improvement in memory satisfaction, improvement in memory ability and memory strategy, improvement in neurocognitive functions, improvement in quality of life, improvement in fatigue, and improvement in mood. The trial aims to provide insights into the pathophysiological processes of PCS and develop more effective therapies for patients.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the factors causing malnutrition, specifically inflammation and oral intake. The study will include patients diagnosed with disease-related malnutrition and inflammation who are eligible for medical nutritional treatment. Participants will be given an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols. The study will measure various blood biochemistry data, including albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, and platelets. Secondary outcome measures include bioelectrical impedance data, functional parameters, and oral intake. The study will follow patients for a period of three consecutive months. The goal is to understand the impact of the intervention on the nutritional status of the participants.

The Kaiser Permanente Evaluating Nutritional Interventions in Food-Insecure High-Risk Adults (KP ENRICH) Study aims to evaluate the effects of nutritional interventions on food-insecure high-risk adults with Type 2 diabetes. The study will randomly assign eligible participants to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive monetary support for healthy foods and free home delivery through the Instacart platform for a duration of 6 months. The control group will only receive free home delivery through the Instacart platform. The study will assess changes in glycosylated hemoglobin levels, medical resource utilization, and patient-reported outcomes such as diabetes quality of life, nutrition security, dietary habits, social needs, and food security. The study will also evaluate the occurrence of hospitalizations or emergency department visits within 12 months after enrollment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of prolonged evaporation time of the solvent in two universal adhesives on the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions. The trial will involve four groups, with each group receiving different adhesive and evaporation time combinations. The primary outcome measure will be the retention of restorations, while secondary outcome measures include marginal adaptation and marginal staining. The trial will last for 24 months and will involve a total of 140 participants.
