This is a Phase II/III clinical trial that aims to evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of the SWIM816 vaccine for SARS-CoV-2. The study will involve cohorts of participants who have previously been vaccinated against COVID-19 with 2/3 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine. The trial will assess the levels of neutralizing antibodies for the Omicron variant and other circulating strains of SARS-CoV-2 after vaccination with SWIM816. It will also compare the neutralizing antibody response of SWIM816 to that of the Pfizer Bivalent vaccine. The trial will evaluate the occurrence of adverse events, including local and systemic reactions, within 7 days and unsolicited adverse events within 28 days after vaccination. Additional endpoints include the assessment of pseudovirus neutralizing antibody levels, seroresponse rates, IgG profiles, and the occurrence of symptomatic cases of SARS-CoV-2 infection. The trial will enroll participants aged 18 years and older and will employ a randomized, double-blinded, parallel-controlled design.

This clinical trial, titled "The Esbjerg Cohort - A Cross-sectional Study About Work Ability and Musculoskeletal Pain in 55 to 70 Years Old Workers," aims to investigate the impact of ergonomic exposure on work ability and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55 to 70 years old. The study will include physical tests, questionnaires, and long-term evaluations of work ability. The study will recruit 336 citizens from 12 groups stratified by gender, age, and occupational group. The primary outcome measure is work ability, assessed using the Work Ability Index questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include various physical measurements, pain assessments, and tests of physical capacity. The study will provide valuable knowledge for treating and counseling the oldest group of workers and optimizing the balance between physical work demands and worker capacity.

This phase I clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and feasibility of using autologous T cells that have been genetically modified to express L1CAM-specific chimeric antigen receptors (CAR) in the treatment of patients with locally advanced and unresectable or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer. The study involves obtaining peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) through leukapheresis for T cell manufacturing, followed by lymphodepleting chemotherapy. Patients receive an infusion of the modified T cells, and additional infusions may be given based on disease response and persistence of CAR T cells. The primary outcome measures include the incidence of adverse events and dose-limiting toxicity rates. Secondary outcome measures include objective response, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.

This clinical trial aims to assess the safety and efficacy of a new technique called Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) as a treatment for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) which traditionally requires total pancreatectomy (TP). The study group consisted of 40 patients who underwent WOTSA, and their clinicopathological characteristics and survival were compared with a control group of 30 patients who underwent TP. The study will measure the remnant pancreatic volume and physiological parameters before and after the operation, as well as postoperative chemotherapy and follow-up. The eligibility criteria include patients with PDAC, while exclusion criteria include patients undergoing palliative pancreatectomy and those with other malignancies with distant metastases.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of breastfeeding education given to fathers on breastfeeding rates. The study will be conducted using a Whatsapp messaging application to provide education to fathers in the postpartum period. The participants will be randomly assigned to different groups, including an experimental group receiving breastfeeding education and control groups with no intervention. The primary outcome measures will assess the breastfeeding support of fathers and the influence of fathers on breastfeeding. The study will evaluate these outcomes at different time points during the postpartum period.

This clinical trial is focused on biomarker testing and treatment patterns among patients with a PIK3CA mutation in advanced breast cancer. The study aims to measure various outcomes such as the number of patients with PIK3CA mutations, the time from diagnosis to evaluation of PIK3CA, the type of biopsy and tissue samples used, and the analytical method for PIK3CA evaluation. Secondary outcome measures include factors such as age at diagnosis, cancer stage, performance status, and treatment patterns. The study will span approximately 6 years and include patients with different hormone receptor and HER2 statuses.

This clinical trial is titled "The Effects of Melatonin on Sleep Spindles in Children With Autism." The study aims to investigate the impact of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study includes male and female subjects with ASD between the ages of 12 and 18 who are able to understand and respond to questionnaires in English. Pregnant or breastfeeding individuals, those with substance abuse or dependence within the past six months, chronic medical conditions that affect sleep, unstable chronic medical conditions, head injuries resulting in prolonged loss of consciousness or other neurological sequelae, IQ less than 70, other neurological disorders, diagnosed sleep disorders, known genetic causes of ASD, and those currently taking melatonin or who have had adverse reactions to melatonin in the past are excluded from the study. The study design is a basic science intervention with a single group assignment and no masking. The intervention involves taking a 5mg melatonin gummy 30 minutes before bedtime for two consecutive nights. The primary outcome measure is the change in sleep spindle density during non-Rapid Eye Movement (NREM) sleep between baseline and melatonin nights, as measured by a portable EEG device. The secondary outcome measure is the change in sleep quality between baseline and melatonin nights. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers. The keywords associated with the study are melatonin.

The DETERMINE Trial Treatment Arm 04 aims to evaluate the efficacy of trastuzumab in combination with pertuzumab in adult, teenage/young adult, and pediatric patients with cancers that have HER2 amplification or activating mutations. The trial will enroll 30 evaluable patients, with the possibility of expanding sub-cohorts if promising activity is observed. The primary outcomes being measured are objective response and durable clinical benefit. Secondary outcomes include duration of response, best percentage change in tumor size, time to treatment discontinuation, progression-free survival, time to progression, growth modulation index, overall survival, occurrence of adverse events, and quality of life assessments. The study design is a non-randomized, single-group assignment, and the intervention involves the administration of trastuzumab and pertuzumab. Eligible participants must meet specific criteria outlined in the trial protocol. The ultimate goal of the trial is to provide new treatment options for rare adult, pediatric, and teenage/young adult cancers.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the causes of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency in children with operated velopalatine cleft. The study will analyze the velopharyngeal motor skills using static and dynamic MRI. The participants will be children aged 7 to 12 years who have undergone cheiloplasty or intravelar veloplasty. The primary outcome measures include the ratio between the diameter of the pharynx at rest and during phonation, as well as the closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The study design is non-randomized and the intervention involves real-time MRI.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the benefits of exercise training on cognition and mobility in older adults with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study focuses on older MS patients who have cognitive and walking impairment. The intervention involves two programs: an aerobic and resistance exercise program and a flexibility and stretching program. The study will assess cognitive function, physical function, lower-extremity function, functional mobility, walking endurance, and walking speed as primary outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures include physical activity level, exercise behavior, and vascular function. The study will be conducted remotely using telerehabilitation, making it convenient and accessible for older adults with MS. If successful, the study will lay the groundwork for larger trials using remotely-delivered exercise interventions for managing the consequences of aging and MS.

This pilot study aims to measure the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration membrane in critically ill patients. The study will involve treatment with the oXiris membrane hemofiltration system and the collection of additional blood samples for analysis. The samples will be analyzed for various angiotensins, enzymes, and markers of endothelial permeability and sepsis-induced immunosuppression. The study will also assess the effect of oXiris treatment on the reduction of vasoinotropic score and mortality at 90 days. The study design is non-interventional and will include monitoring of patients for 3 months.

This clinical trial aims to compare two different methods of urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in cases with previous cesarean section. The study will assess the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures include operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications. The trial will randomly assign participants to either the central urinary bladder dissection group or the lateral urinary bladder dissection group. The study will provide valuable information on the efficacy and safety of these two approaches.

This clinical trial is a 6-month observational study that aims to investigate the association between the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity, and treatment response. The study will include patients who have a possible diagnosis or an established diagnosis of asthma. Participants will undergo various tests, including pulmonary function testing and sample collection from blood, oral rinse, nasopharyngeal swab, exhaled breath condensate, stool, and induced sputum. Some patients will also undergo bronchoscopy for lower airway sampling. The collected samples will be processed and analyzed for microbiome and host transcriptome profiling. The study will also assess the role of the lung microbiome in asthma and its influence on treatment response. The primary outcome measures include describing the microbiome signature across the spectrum of asthma severity, establishing associations between asthma phenotype and microbiome signature, and determining if the microbiome signature can predict treatment response or resistance. The study will include a biologic-naive group and a biologic group, with the latter receiving a biologic agent as part of routine care if considered necessary.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of split-body resistance training and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. The study will have 28 participants divided into two groups, with one group performing split-body exercises and the other performing full-body exercises. The training will be conducted for 6 weeks, and the participants will be assessed using the FMS and the leg press bench press test. The study will analyze the data using SPSS version 25. The primary outcome measures include the bench press test, leg press test, and the 30-second sit-to-stand test. Only male cricketers between the ages of 20 and 30 with no history of systemic disease will be eligible to participate in the study. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and single masking. The intervention for the split-body group includes specific exercises targeting different muscle groups on different days, while the intervention for the full-body group includes a combination of exercises targeting multiple muscle groups on each day.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of breastfeeding training given to fathers on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding self-efficacy level. The study will include parents who are at least primary school graduates and are 20 years or older. The study will have three groups: Experimental Group 1 where breastfeeding training will be given to both mothers and fathers, Experimental Group 2 where breastfeeding training will be given only to the mother, and a Control Group that will receive routine hospital care. The primary outcome measures include breastfeeding self-efficacy, mother to infant bonding, father breastfeeding self-efficacy, paternal-infant attachment, and baby evaluation. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of an Amway bundle combination of products on osteoarthritis and sarcopenia. The study will include Chinese males and females aged between 50-70 who meet specific inclusion criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to different intervention groups, including a bundle group with Nutrilite Lifestyle, a bundle group without Nutrilite Lifestyle, and control groups. The study will measure various outcomes, including changes in Short Physical Performance Battery score, WOMAC Questionnaire scores, Visual Analogue Scale/Score, Chalder Fatigue Scale, fat and muscle portions, hand and grip strength, and bone density. The trial will last for 180 days.

This clinical trial aims to improve access, outcomes, and equity in alcohol and substance use care during the reproductive years. The study will focus on reproductive-aged women at risk for alcohol and substance use disorders and will be conducted in family planning clinics. The intervention will involve screening, brief intervention, and referral to treatment (SBIRT). The study will measure various outcomes, including average drinks consumed, depression scores, fidelity to the intervention, incidence of sex under the influence, number of days of drug use, and incidence of condom and contraceptive nonuse. The results of the study will inform the development of an evidence-based model for integrating alcohol and substance use services in family planning clinics, with the goal of promoting women's health equity across the United States.

This clinical trial is investigating the effects of habitual herbal tea consumption on the gut microbiome and blood markers. The study will recruit participants who will be randomized into one of three intervention groups: green tea control, senna herbal mix, and rhubarb root herbal mix. The participants will be asked to consume a cup of tea daily for 21 days after their last meal/snack of the day. Various blood markers, including total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, triglycerides, and non-HDL cholesterol, will be measured before and after the intervention period. Other outcomes, such as changes in diet choices and BMI, will also be assessed. The study aims to determine the impact of herbal tea consumption on these markers and its potential benefits for obesity and well-being.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, muscle strength, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis. Adult male and female patients with knee osteoarthritis will be randomly allocated to either a control group receiving knee exercises or an experimental group receiving knee exercises plus hip rotator and ankle muscle strengthening exercises. The patients will be assessed for pain, functional level, muscle strength, and knee proprioception before and after a 4-week treatment program. The study will provide insights into the efficacy of adding hip rotator and ankle muscle exercises to knee exercises in managing knee osteoarthritis.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Novabel bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent for the treatment of chronic sinusitis. The study will include participants diagnosed with chronic rhinosinusitis who are scheduled to undergo primary or revision bilateral endoscopic sinus surgery. The primary outcome measure is the non-reintervention rate, which will be assessed 30 days after the surgery. Secondary outcome measures include the Lund-Kennedy score, Lund-Mackay score, VAS score for pain intensity, sinus patency rate, and implantation success rate. The study is randomized and participants will be assigned to either the experimental group receiving the Novabel stent or the active comparator group receiving a marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent.

This clinical trial aims to study the impact of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. The study will involve patients who are receiving care from a provider within the Division of Oncology at the primary Siteman Cancer Center site and reside within the catchment area of a satellite site. The study will compare participants who undergo a care transition to a satellite site with those who do not. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of eligible participants who successfully transfer to the provider at a satellite location. Secondary outcome measures include types of candidacy used for transfer of care, treatment burden, participant-provider interactions, financial toxicity, and participant rationales for opting to transfer or maintain care at their usual site. The study is non-randomized and will collect qualitative data through surveys and questionnaires completed at baseline and approximately 6 months later.

This clinical trial is comparing the use of virtual reality (VR) goggles to nitrous oxide for pain management during dental procedures in pediatric patients. The study will involve pediatric patients aged 4-12 years who require nitrous sedation for dental treatment. Participants will be randomized into a control group or treatment group, with both groups using pain scales to assess their pain or discomfort. The VR goggles will be used as a method of distraction during the procedure. The study will measure the rate of effectiveness of VR goggles in reducing pain compared to nitrous oxide. Secondary outcomes will also be measured to assess the effectiveness of VR distraction compared to nitrous oxide.

This clinical trial aims to identify patients at high risk for recurrent colorectal lesions and design optimal intervals for surveillance colonoscopies. The study will involve examining the mutation profile and mutation burden of patients' index and synchronous lesions, evaluating clinical and histopathological parameters, and correlating them with mutational phenotype and occurrence of metachronous lesions. The mutation profile of lesions from the index period will be compared with the mutation profile of metachronous lesions. The study will also analyze the similarity of mutation profiles in the same or close areas of the colorectum. The primary outcome measure is the development and clinical utility of a new method to identify patients at risk and personalize surveillance based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype. Secondary outcome measures include determining the mutation profile of colorectal lesions and evaluating the mutational profile of metachronous lesions. The study will span a period of 5 years. The study design involves the intervention of colonoscopy to determine the mutation profile of resected colorectal neoplasia. The eligibility criteria include having a colorectal polyp larger than 10mm removed by colonoscopy therapeutic method and signed informed consent. The study is open to participants between the ages of 18 and 75 and accepts both males and females. It also accepts healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted by the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The SAM Project is a clinical trial focused on studying malnutrition. The study aims to identify specific biomarkers of malnutrition through the analysis of data and samples collected from patients affected by malnutrition and healthy controls. The study will analyze various samples including blood, saliva, and fecal samples using techniques such as microRNA expression profiling, metagenomic analysis, and metabolomic analysis. The study will take place over a period of 36 months.

This clinical trial aims to understand how people with Parkinson's disease manage their physical activity and exercise with different levels of support. The study will evaluate the differences in physical activity trajectories between three groups: standard care, written exercise guidance, and consultative physical therapy. Participants will be enrolled in an exercise and physical activity tracking study using a remote therapeutic monitoring platform. The study will recruit participants from two clinics in the Chicagoland area and monitor their physical activity every 3 months for a year. The primary outcome measure is minutes per day of moderate to vigorous physical activity, and the secondary outcome measure is steps per day. The study design is non-randomized with three treatment groups.

This clinical trial aims to use multi-channel time-resolved functional near infrared spectroscopy (tr-fNIRS) to monitor cerebral oxygenation during shoulder surgery in the beach chair position. The current commercial cerebral oximeters have limitations that prevent reliable perioperative neuromonitoring, so the researchers will use tr-fNIRS, which has greater spatial resolution and less signal contamination. The study will monitor the entire brain and detect specific regions at risk of ischemic injury. The participants will undergo standard surgical and anesthetic management, with tr-fNIRS used to monitor brain oxygenation. The surgeons, anesthesiologists, and nurses will be blinded to the monitor readings, and no intervention will be administered based on the tr-fNIRS results. The primary outcome measure is the impact of intraoperative hemodynamic parameters on regional differences in cerebral oxygenation. Secondary outcome measures include assessing cerebral autoregulation and the association between cerebral desaturation events and clinical outcomes such as stroke and delirium. The study will recruit adult patients scheduled for elective shoulder surgery in the beach-chair position under general anesthesia.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility and safety of using Mechanical Insufflation-Exsufflation (MI-E) in critically ill adults who are invasively ventilated. The MI-E sessions will be applied twice a day for a maximum of 7 days. The study will measure the proportion of complete MI-E sessions delivered each day as well as the incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, severe hypoxemia, severe hypotension, and severe hypertension. The study will also assess the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the intervention, as well as the time needed for MI-E, frequency of endotracheal suctioning and manual hyperinflation, incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia, duration of invasive ventilation, mortality at day 28, ventilator-free days at day 28, ICU mortality, hospital mortality, use of supplemental oxygen, length of stay in the ICU, and length of stay in the hospital.

The Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT) is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. The study aims to assess the effects of the SGLT2 inhibitor enavogliflozin on outcomes in patients with functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF). Functional TR is a condition that occurs due to heart failure and other related factors, and it is associated with poor clinical outcomes. Currently, there are no proven medical therapies for TR, and only loop diuretics are recommended for relieving symptoms. SGLT2 inhibitors have beneficial effects on the heart and kidneys, and they may improve outcomes in patients with functional TR. The study will compare the effects of enavogliflozin to placebo on clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in HF patients with functional TR and preserved LVEF. The primary outcome measure is a composite of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for heart failure, or worsening of tricuspid regurgitation. Secondary outcome measures include all-cause death, cardiovascular clinical events, renal events, change in TR on echocardiography, and change in right ventricular strain on echocardiography. The study will last for 18 months, and participants will be randomized to receive either enavogliflozin or placebo in addition to their prior medications.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between daily physical activity and the pharmacokinetics of infused factor VIII concentrate in patients with severe hemophilia A. The study will use a SenseWear armband device to measure daily steps and assess the variability of factor VIII elimination. The primary outcome measures will focus on the association between physical activity and the Area Under the Curve pharmacokinetic parameter. The study will last for 12 months and will include patients aged 12-60 years with severe hemophilia A who are receiving prophylactic treatment with factor VIII concentrates.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the optimal timing for locomotor training in individuals with spinal cord injuries. The study will involve participants with acute and traumatic spinal cord injuries between the ages of 16-74. They will be randomized into one of four intervention groups, based on the timing of additional walking training following the injury. The primary outcome measure will be the 10-meter walk test, assessing walking speed. Secondary outcome measures include the 6-minute walk test, the Walking Index for Spinal Cord Injury, and daily step counts. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment trial with masking.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of education given according to the Health Promotion Model on premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress. The study will be conducted as a pretest-posttest randomized controlled study, with a total of 60 participants. The intervention group will receive training using the Philips 66 technique, while the control group will not receive any training. The primary outcome measures include the Premenstrual Syndrome Scale, Eating Habits During the Premenstrual Period Form, Healthy Lifestyle Behaviors Scale, Emotional Eating Scale, Perceived Stress Scale, and Visual Comparison Scale. The study will also assess the feedback of the training using the Health Promotion Model and Philips 66 technique.

This clinical trial, called the AMP SCZ Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC, is part of the Accelerating Medicines Partnership (AMP) Schizophrenia program. The goal of the study is to develop biomarker-informed functional characterization and clinical profiling of individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis. The data collected will be used to create algorithms to predict the outcomes of these individuals and identify patient populations for early intervention studies in schizophrenia. The study will collect data from two Clinical High Risk research networks and aims to build infrastructure for data processing and quality assurance. The study will also develop stratification tools to identify biomarkers and predict individual outcomes. The data will be archived and made publicly available. The study will assess clinical, cognitive, neurophysiology, neuroimaging, genetics, fluid biomarkers, speech, facial expression, and outcome measures. The study design is non-interventional and will follow participants for 2 years. The primary outcome measure is conversion to psychosis, and secondary outcome measures include remission and continued high-risk condition.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of implementing the Problem Management Plus (PM+) intervention for individuals imprisoned in Dutch prisons. The study will consist of a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) and a qualitative study. The participants will be Dutch-speaking adults who are imprisoned in a Dutch prison and have a remaining sentence length of at least 15 weeks, and who report an elevated level of psychological distress. The treatment group will receive five sessions of PM+ in addition to care-as-usual, while the control group will only receive care-as-usual. The main study parameters include PM+ fidelity, perceptions about PM+ from stakeholders, indicators of intervention delivery, retention rate of PM+ sessions, and recruitment and consent rates. The secondary study parameters include symptoms of depression and anxiety, self-identified problems, daily functioning, symptoms of trauma, and suicidality vulnerability. The study will assess the feasibility and acceptability of the PM+ intervention and its potential effects on various outcomes.

This clinical trial is studying the use of Xevinapant in combination with radiation therapy and chemotherapy for patients with head and neck cancer. The trial aims to determine the best safe dose of Xevinapant when given with radiation and chemotherapy. The study will also measure progression-free survival, side effects, overall survival, locoregional failure, distant failure, and response rate. Participants will be assigned to different dose levels of Xevinapant, and additional cycles of Xevinapant will be given after completion of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of the study medicine ARV-471 in Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer. The trial will involve administering ARV-471 orally once daily with food for 28-day cycles. The study will measure various outcomes including maximum plasma concentration, area under the concentration-time profile, objective response rate, duration of objective response, presence of blood biomarkers, electrocardiogram values, laboratory abnormalities, vital signs, adverse events, and drug clearance. The trial will assess these measures at different time points throughout the study.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a combination therapy of olaparib and alpelisib in the treatment of metastatic breast cancer. The primary objectives are to determine if the combination therapy improves progression-free survival compared to olaparib alone in PARP-inhibitor naive patients (Cohort 2) and to determine the objective response rate of the combination therapy in PARP-inhibitor resistant patients (Cohort 3). Secondary objectives include evaluating the overall survival, clinical benefit rate, and tolerability of the combination therapy compared to olaparib alone in PARP-inhibitor naive patients, as well as assessing the concordance between different tumor mutation profiles. The study consists of three cohorts, with different treatment arms assigned to each cohort. Patients will undergo various imaging scans, biopsies, and blood collections throughout the trial. The study design is a randomized, open-label trial. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival in Cohort 2 and objective response rate in Cohort 3. Secondary outcome measures include objective response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, clinical benefit rate, incidence of adverse events, and concordance of tumor mutation profiles.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether Schema Therapy (ST) of longer duration is more effective than the current treatment for patients with chronic and treatment resistant depression (CTRD). The study also aims to understand the factors that contribute to successful therapy and to refine the Maudsley Staging Model for CTRD. The trial will be a multi-center, two-arm, parallel group, randomized controlled superiority study. Participants will be allocated to either receive 30 sessions of ST or treatment as usual (TAU). The primary outcome measure will be the change in depression symptoms at 12 months after baseline measurements. Secondary outcomes include functional impairment, psychological well-being, personal recovery, anger reactions, negative effects of treatment, and more. The study plans to recruit 129 participants and will analyze the data using the intention-to-treat principle. The trial will also explore the mediators of treatment effect and perform subgroup analyses to detect symptom deterioration.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a paramedical protocol for ventilation in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III trial with a stepped wedge cluster randomized design. The intervention involves ventilatory adjustments by nurses according to a pre-established care protocol, while the control group receives usual management practices for ARDS. The primary outcome measure is a combination of mortality rate and the number of days without mechanical ventilation at day 28. Secondary outcome measures include various measures of ventilation, oxygenation, duration of mechanical ventilation, occurrence of complications, and length of stay in the intensive care unit and hospital. The study aims to assess the impact of the paramedical protocol on patient outcomes and to train nurses in the implementation of the protocol.

This clinical trial aims to test a culturally tailored intervention for Haitian immigrants living with HIV in the US. The intervention, called H-iENGAGE, is designed to improve engagement and retention in care and achieve viral suppression. The study will be conducted as a pilot with participants drawn from two Federally Qualified Health Centers in Miami. The study will collect both quantitative and qualitative data on barriers and facilitators to viral suppression among the participants. The intervention will involve completing research questionnaires, attending individual meetings, and participating in the photovoice portion of the study. The primary outcomes measured will be the change in engagement in care score and viral suppression. The study design is prospective, quasi-experimental, and single-arm. The study aims to improve HIV outcomes among Haitian immigrants in the US.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of different root canal cleaning devices: the Endoclean device, passive ultrasonic irrigation, and conventional preparation. The study will evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement up to a 12-month follow-up, with secondary objectives to assess extended effectiveness and safety up to a 24-month follow-up. The trial will include patients aged 18-75 years with symptomatic and/or asymptomatic apical periodontitis. The study will have a total of 109 participants divided into three arms. The primary outcome measure will be the successful healing of periapical lesion up to 12 months post-procedure, while secondary outcome measures will include safety endpoints and successful healing up to 24 months post-procedure.

The clinical trial, titled FRACT-AI, aims to evaluate the impact of artificial intelligence-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in detecting fractures on plain X-rays. The study will involve emergency medicine doctors, trauma and orthopedic surgeons, emergency nurse practitioners, physiotherapists, general radiologists, and radiographers currently working in the NHS. The participants will be divided into different reader groups based on their specialty and level of experience. They will review X-rays remotely using an online platform and express their clinical opinions through a structured reporting template. The study will also include ground truthers, who are consultant musculoskeletal radiologists, to establish the reference standard for the X-ray findings. The primary outcome measures of the study will assess the performance of an AI algorithm (Gleamer Boneview) in terms of sensitivity, specificity, and area under the ROC curve. The study will also compare the performance of readers with and without AI assistance in terms of sensitivity, specificity, and ROC curve. Additionally, the study will measure reader speed with and without AI assistance. The estimated total involvement in the project is up to 20-24 hours.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the fine motor function in children with Specific Learning Disorders (SLD). SLD is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects reading, written expression, and mathematics. The study will compare the fine motor skills, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics of children with SLD to those of typically developing children. The primary outcome measures include the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2, Purdue Pegboard Test, Hand Dynamometer, and Pinch Gauge. The secondary outcome measures include the Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth questionnaire and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory. The study will assess the impact of fine motor skills on the quality of life and participation in activities of children with SLD.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of combining the Z-track and Airlock techniques during intramuscular injection of Haloperidol decanoate in adult patients with schizophrenia or related disorders. The study will be conducted in two parallel groups, with one group receiving the experimental injection technique and the other group receiving the standard technique. The primary outcome measure is pain reduction, assessed using a visual analogic scale (VAS). Secondary outcome measures include reduction in drug leakage, impact on potential complications, patient satisfaction, therapeutic alliance, and identification of obstacles and levers to changing practices. The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of the Z-track and Airlock techniques in intramuscular injections.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility of using a 5-day hypofractionated radiotherapy (HFRT) regimen as a preoperative treatment for primary soft tissue sarcoma (STS). The current standard treatment involves longer daily treatments over 5-6 weeks. The study will assess the uptake rate of the 5-day HFRT regimen, as well as secondary outcomes including favorable pathologic response, rate of major wound complications, local control, acute toxicity, and late HFRT toxicity. The trial will also explore the use of SFRP2 as a predictive biomarker for favorable pathologic response. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking. The participants will receive the HFRT treatment followed by standard of care wide local excision. The study will last up to 3 years.

This clinical trial is titled "Postoperative Analgesia Outcomes Of Pericapsular Nerve Group Block (PENG Block) Combined With Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve Block After Hip Replacement Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Study." The study aims to compare the effectiveness of two methods of pain relief after hip replacement surgery: intravenous morphine analgesia via patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) and pain relief through pericapsular nerve group block (PENG block) combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) block. The trial will measure the average visual analogue scale (VAS) pain scores at rest and on movement, as well as the rate of side effects such as vomiting/nausea, itching, urinary retention, and respiratory failure. The study will include patients aged 18-80 years with ASA physical status I-III.

This clinical trial aims to study pelvic organ mobility in patients with pelvic endometriosis using dynamic MRI. The study includes patients with and without pelvic endometriosis, with the intervention being the addition of a dynamic MRI sequence during routine MRI examinations. The primary outcome measure is the mean vertical displacement on the anterior wall of the vagina between rest and maximum pushing force during dynamic MRI. Secondary outcome measures include measurements on the cervix and posterior wall of the vagina, as well as the variation in mean vertical displacement on each pelvic organ and the association between symptoms and vertical displacement. The study is limited to female participants aged 18 to 50 years.

This retrospective, observational study aims to provide updated epidemiological evidence on the uptake of the Childhood Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccine (LAIV) and its impact on influenza-related healthcare resource use (HCRU) in children in England. The study will evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines in children aged 2 to 18 years between 2012 and 2020, describe usage patterns of LAIV, assess HCRU associated with laboratory confirmed influenza and/or influenza-like illness (ILI), describe demographics and clinical characteristics of vaccinated and unvaccinated individuals, and estimate a model for LAIV uptake based on demographic and clinical factors. The study will use data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) linked to Hospital Episode Statistics (HCRU) and will employ logistic regression analyses to compare outcomes between vaccinated and unvaccinated children. The results of the study may be used for planning and evaluation of the childhood influenza vaccination program in England.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether fun activities for reciting Tang poems can promote happiness in primary school ethnic minority students in Hong Kong. The trial will involve 10-20 South Asian children in grades 1-2, aged 6-9. The intervention will consist of three 1.5-hour sessions of Tang poem reciting, led by experienced instructors, with adjustments based on performance. Body language, sound, images, and videos will be used to enhance motivation and memory. Participants will receive stamp/sticker collection books and be rewarded for their achievements. Pre- and post-intervention assessments will be conducted to measure the number of successful recited poems, happiness levels, acculturation, ability in speaking Chinese, and attitude in Chinese learning. The feasibility outcomes will also be reported. It is expected that these fun activities for reciting Tang poems may help promote happiness and enjoyment in primary school ethnic minority students in Hong Kong.

This clinical trial aims to develop and test a digital platform called Vira, which is designed to assist in reducing the risk of suicide among high-risk youth. The platform integrates mobile sensing data and communication tools to enhance the delivery of preventative healthcare. The trial will involve 200 adolescent patients aged 13-18 who will be randomized into either the Vira group or a treatment as usual control group. The primary outcome measures will assess suicidal thoughts and behaviors, while secondary outcome measures will evaluate anxiety, risky behavior, sleep quality, depressive symptoms, and social anhedonia. The goal of the trial is to determine if the use of the Vira platform improves clinical outcomes in an intensive outpatient setting.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of sex and age on non-visual light input that affects sleep and circadian rhythms. The study will involve participants aged 18-85 who have a normal physiology and meet certain eligibility criteria. The intervention will include the use of pupillometry and light box exposure. The study design is a single group assignment with participants being randomized to different combinations of light stimuli. The primary outcome measures include pupil size measured by pupillometry, melatonin levels for circadian timing assessment, and melatonin levels for hormone response. The trial will provide valuable insights into the effects of non-visual light input on sleep and circadian rhythms.

This clinical trial, titled "Evaluation of Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA): A New Parent Training Program for Parents With ADHD," aims to assess the efficacy and feasibility of the IPSA program for parents with ADHD. The study is a randomized controlled trial with parallel groups, where participants are block randomized to either the treatment group (IPSA directly) or the control group (continued routine services, with IPSA offered later). The primary outcome measure is parental self-efficacy, and secondary outcome measures include parental stress, household disorganization, and child behavior problems. The study will also explore the moderating or mediating effects of baseline variables and active participation levels on efficacy outcomes. The intervention sessions will be recorded for treatment integrity assessment. The study has been approved by the Regional Ethics Committee of Stockholm, Sweden.

The clinical trial is called "The Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention (SUHRI) for Justice-involved Youth". It is a 1-arm design study that aims to examine the preliminary efficacy of the adapted intervention. The study includes youth aged 14 to 18 who are on community supervision and meet eligibility criteria related to substance use, language, and mental health. The intervention consists of a technology-based application administered via tablet, which addresses substance use and risky sex practices. The study measures outcomes such as problem recognition, decision making, intention to reduce personal risk, service initiation, substance use, and sexual/STI health risk. The study design is single-group assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) in reducing disability progression in patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). RIC involves inducing short periods of cyclical tissue ischemia to trigger protective signals in distant organs. The trial will follow a phase II open-label, single-arm design and will assess the non-futility of RIC in reducing disability progression as measured by the timed 25-foot walk. Secondary outcome measures include upper limb motor function, MRI measures of remyelination, and processing speed. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period, and participants will self-administer the RIC procedure at home using a device provided.

This clinical trial aims to determine if prothrombin time can predict the response to steroid treatment in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis. The study will enroll patients with a clinical diagnosis of severe alcoholic hepatitis who are eligible for corticosteroid treatment. The prothrombin time at diagnosis will be evaluated to see if it correlates with the Lille score at day 7, which is a measure of response to medical treatment. The primary outcome measure is the response to steroid treatment assessed with the Lille score at day 7. Secondary outcome measures include death during hospitalization, early liver transplantation in case of treatment failure, and occurrence of opportunistic infections following steroid treatment. The study will last for 28 days and will involve patients aged 18 to 70 years.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of functional task training versus a functional therapy program on gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy. The trial will involve two groups, with one group receiving functional task training and the other receiving the functional therapy program. The treatment duration will be 8 weeks, and outcome measures will include gross motor function, pediatric balance scale, and goniometer assessments. The data will be analyzed using SPSS version 29, and the study will use a randomized control trial design with convenient sampling. The study is open to children between the ages of 6 and 12 with a diagnosis of cerebral palsy. The study is not open to individuals with deformities, visual disorders, or mental retardation. The study has a primary purpose of treatment, and participants will be randomly allocated to the intervention groups. The study will measure range of motion using a goniometer, balance using the pediatric balance scale, and gross motor function using the Gross Motor Function Measure scale.

This clinical trial is a retrospective observational study on the prognostic value of the neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR) in predicting the outcomes of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair. The study includes patients with ToF and associated cardiac anomalies who underwent ToF primary repair. The preoperative data includes patients' demographic information and complete blood count results. Intraoperative data such as the use of cardiopulmonary bypass and duration of surgery are also collected. Patients are evaluated for complications and postoperative mortality during their hospital stay and followed up for 30 days postoperative. The study measures the number of patients requiring redo surgery, mortality, complications, hospital length of stay, and postoperative length of stay as primary and secondary outcome measures. The study aims to determine the prognostic value of NLR, ALC, and TLR in predicting the outcomes of ToF primary repair.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of patient-applied lidocaine via tampon as a pretreatment for intrauterine device (IUD) placement. The study will compare lidocaine to a saline placebo and measure the procedure time, patient-reported pain level, patient satisfaction, patient interest in subsequent procedures, and provider-reported procedural difficulty as outcome measures. The trial will involve female participants aged 18 to 54 who meet the inclusion criteria and do not have any exclusion criteria. The study design is a randomized, double-blind trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial is a feasibility and acceptability pilot study that aims to assess whether capillary screening for chronic metabolic, cardiovascular, and autoimmune diseases is feasible at a population-based level. The study will enroll volunteers from a specific locality and will measure specific disease markers, estimate disease prevalence, and assess the correlation between disease indicators and population data. Participants will undergo capillary blood sampling for various markers, and blood pressure measurements will also be taken. The study will assess feasibility and acceptability of the screening program, as well as measure various outcomes such as blood glucose and lipid levels, autoantibodies, blood pressure, and glycated hemoglobin.

The clinical trial, titled "SMaRT Mom - Smartphone Management and Responsive Time for Breastfeeding Mothers," aims to study the effects of a smartphone intervention program on breastfeeding mothers. The study will assess the impact of the intervention on various outcomes, including infant temperament, maternal self-efficacy, breastfeeding as a rewarding experience, and maternal attention towards the infant. The study will also measure changes in breastfeeding mothers' neural activity, physiology, and behavior. The intervention involves instructing mothers not to use their smartphones while breastfeeding for one week. The study design is randomized, with participants assigned to either the intervention or control group. Data will be collected through lab visits, self-report questionnaires, video recordings, and physiological measurements. The study is primarily focused on treating smartphone addiction and improving mother-infant interaction.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of Photobiomodulation Therapy (PBMT) for the treatment of plantar fasciitis. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the PBMT group or the Sham-PBMT group. The PBMT group will receive active treatment with PBMT three times a week for three weeks, while the Sham-PBMT group will receive a placebo treatment. The study will measure outcomes such as foot and ankle function, pain levels, and plantar fascia thickness. Participants will be followed up at various time points to assess long-term effects.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the bioequivalence of Entacapone, Levodopa, and Carbidopa tablets in the postprandial state in healthy Chinese subjects. The study will be a single-center, open, randomized, single-dose, completely repeated crossover design. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the test or reference preparation, with a washout period of at least 2 days between doses. The primary outcome measures will include the evaluation of peak plasma concentration (Cmax) and the area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC0-t and AUC0-∞). The trial will involve 36 healthy adult subjects and is open to both males and females aged 18 years or older. The study does not require any masking or blinding.

This clinical trial aims to map brain anatomy and function using a combination of electroencephalography (EEG) and 7 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The study includes healthy participants, as well as individuals with essential tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy. The interventions involve simultaneous EEG-fMRI and structural MRI at 7 Tesla, which are non-invasive techniques. The eligibility criteria include being 18 years or older, able to understand instructions, and able to provide informed consent. The study will measure contrast-to-noise ratio in thalamic nuclei, Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions, and microstate duration in EEG. The secondary outcome is the publication of neuroimaging datasets in public data repositories.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of weight loss on hepcidin levels and iron status in individuals with obesity. The study consists of two phases: a cross-sectional study and a randomized controlled clinical trial. The cross-sectional study will compare hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in people with and without obesity. The randomized controlled trial will assess the impact of weight loss on hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in individuals with obesity and iron deficiency. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two dietary intervention groups and will undergo a 60-day follow-up period with a calorie-restricted diet. Blood samples, anthropometric measurements, and body composition analysis will be conducted to evaluate the outcomes. The primary outcome measure is the change in serum hepcidin concentration, while secondary outcome measures include changes in iron status, inflammatory markers, and various biochemical parameters. The study aims to provide insights into the relationship between weight loss, hepcidin levels, and iron status in individuals with obesity.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of continuous non-invasive electrophysiological monitoring using the Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS) in high-risk pregnancies. The study will include 1911 pregnant women who require hospitalization for maternal or fetal surveillance. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity. Secondary outcome measures include maternal mortality, neonatal morbidity, patient and caregiver satisfaction, duration of pregnancy, obstetric interventions, and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. The study design is a prospective cohort intervention with historical controls. The intervention group will receive continuous eCTG monitoring with the NFMS, while the control group will receive conventional intermittent cardiotocography monitoring.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the genetic susceptibility to severe infections. The study plans to recruit a small cohort of patients with rare and severe infections. The eligibility criteria include being hospitalized or followed in a specialized hospital department, being affiliated to the French Social Security system, and having informed consent signed by the patient or their legal representative. The study will involve drawing blood samples and conducting skin biopsies. The primary outcome measures include identifying chromosomal regions associated with the disease, identifying candidate genes for genetic susceptibility to infectious diseases, and validating these candidate genes. The study is expected to last for an average of 10 years.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence (UI) in married women and its effect on their quality of life. UI is a common condition in women that causes involuntary urinary leakage and can have significant physical, psycho-social, and economic impacts. The study will involve married women over 18 years of age who agree to participate. The participants will undergo a diagnostic test and will be provided with information about the study, including the voluntary nature of participation and the confidentiality of their data. The primary outcome measure of the study is the incontinence quality of life, which will be assessed using a scoring system. The study is expected to take place between October 2022 and July 2023.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) and minimally manipulated adipose tissue (MM-AT) as cell sources for infiltrative treatment of knee osteoarthritis. A total of 204 patients with unilateral knee osteoarthritis will be included in the randomized controlled trial. The patients will be divided into two groups, with one group receiving an intra-articular injection of BMAC and the other group receiving an intra-articular injection of MM-AT. The patients will be evaluated clinically and radiographically at different time points over a 12-month follow-up period. The study will also analyze the effects of the two cell products on peripheral blood and investigate their potential disease-modifying effects. The trial will assess various outcome measures, including pain, stiffness, physical function, and quality of life.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of CBD TPM capsules in reducing the severity of insomnia in adults. The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III trial. The eligibility criteria include adults aged 18 years or older with insomnia disorder symptoms. The participants will be randomly assigned to different groups receiving either placebo capsules or CBD capsules with different doses. The primary outcome measures of the study are the mean change in insomnia severity index (ISI) score and subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to determine the prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infection among cirrhotic patients in Sohag University Hospital. The study will also compare the difference between cirrhotic patients and non-cirrhotic patients without comorbidity in terms of intestinal parasitic infection. The primary outcome measure is to detect the most common risk factors of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients. The study will involve 200 participants, with 100 in the cases group (cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal complaints) and 100 in the control group (non-cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal complaints). The participants will undergo stool analysis as a diagnostic test. The study will last for 12 months.

The rhegmatogenous retinal detachment outcomes study, titled the REDOS Trial, is a factorial, randomized controlled trial that aims to compare different surgical interventions for retinal detachment. The study includes participants aged 18 years and older with a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. The interventions being compared are pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with or without scleral buckle, and the use of sulfur hexafluoride or perfluoropropane gas tamponade. The primary outcome measure is single surgery anatomic success, defined as freedom from reoperation for recurrent retinal detachment. Secondary outcome measures include visual acuity, time to recurrence of retinal detachment, complications, and quality of life. The study is designed as a randomized trial with triple masking.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of different concentrations of ropivacaine on the onset and duration of ankle blocks for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia in patients undergoing forefoot surgery. The study will compare the use of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine and hypothesizes that 1% ropivacaine will result in a faster onset time and longer sensory block duration compared to the lower concentrations. The primary outcome is the difference in sensory block duration, and secondary outcomes include the difference in sensory block onset, postoperative pain scores, and opioid consumption. The study is a randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group interventional study with participants assigned to different ropivacaine groups. The study will measure these outcomes over a specific time frame.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of compression stockings on the complaints, well-being, and sleep quality of pregnant women with restless leg syndrome. The study will include pregnant women between the ages of 18 and 40 who are in their 27th week of gestation or above. Participants must meet certain inclusion criteria and should not have any communication barriers or risky pregnancies. Pregnant women with chronic diseases or certain medications will also be excluded from the study. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the compression stockings group or the placebo sock group. The primary outcome measure will be the RLS Severity Rating Scale, while the secondary outcome measure will be the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The study will assess the changes in these measures after 21 days of wearing the assigned socks.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the efficacy of home-based strength and Tai-chi exercise snacking in improving physical function in older adults. The study will involve a 12-week intervention period, with participants in the intervention group receiving exercise teaching videos and written instructions to perform the exercises at home. The primary outcome measure will be changes in the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) at 4-week intervals. Secondary outcome measures include various physical function tests, quality of life assessments, and measures of attitudes and self-confidence for exercise. The study will be conducted in both Taiwanese and British older adults.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia with ropivacaine with or without dexamethasone for postoperative pain relief in lumbosacral spine surgeries. The study will compare the quality and duration of analgesia, hemodynamic effects, and side effects between the two groups. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either caudal epidural injection with ropivacaine and dexamethasone or caudal epidural injection with ropivacaine only. The primary outcome measures will assess the postoperative pain levels using the Visual Analogue Scale score at different time intervals and the time of rescue analgesia.

This randomized controlled experimental study aims to determine the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on the comfort, care satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study will include 80 participants, with 40 in the intervention group receiving care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory and 40 in the control group receiving standard care. Data will be collected using various scales to measure comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality. The study design is parallel assignment with double masking. The primary outcome measures include the General Comfort Scale, Comfort Behaviors Checklist, and Richard-Campbell Sleep Scale.

The P-KIDs CARE Health Systems Intervention in Tanzania is a clinical trial aimed at addressing health systems delays in providing care for injured children in Tanzania. The study consists of three aims: conducting formative research to inform the development of the intervention, developing the intervention based on the formative data, and piloting the intervention in two study facilities. The intervention, called P-KIDs CARE, includes training healthcare providers on patient assessment and stabilization using the World Health Organization (WHO) Basic Emergency Care Course, as well as a decision support tool for timely referral decisions. The primary outcome measure is mortality, and the secondary outcome measures include time from injury to definitive care, patient disposition, and patient morbidity. The study is designed as a single-group assignment with no masking. The intervention will be piloted in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region, with approximately 200 pediatric injury patients expected to be enrolled.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education in women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. The study will involve two different treatment approaches: one with postural re-education and perineal exercises, and the other with spinal mobilization and perineal exercises. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) score, which assesses the frequency, severity, and impact on quality of life of urinary incontinence. Secondary outcome measures include the change in pain intensity measured by the Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and the strength of pelvic floor muscles measured by the Modified Oxford Scale (MOS). The study will evaluate these measures at baseline, after 5 weeks of treatment, and 1 month after the end of training.

This clinical trial aims to develop a pharmacodynamic model for the administration of propofol in older adults. The study recognizes that older patients require different doses of propofol compared to younger patients and that there is significant variability among older patients. The current pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic (PKPD) model for propofol uses the BIS index as the pharmacodynamic parameter, but this index is not suitable for older adults. The study plans to create a new PKPD model that incorporates new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from frontal EEG signals. The objective is to better predict the hypnotic effect of propofol in older patients and improve the titration of the drug to avoid adverse effects. The study will involve administering propofol to patients over 65 years of age and comparing the performance of the new model with the existing BIS-based model. The primary outcome measure is the performance error, which compares measured and predicted propofol concentrations. Secondary outcome measures include accuracy, bias, time of loss of response, time of burst-suppression, and time of return of response.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of a very short course of antibiotic therapy (ABT) versus a standard course in patients with acute cholangitis after adequate biliary drainage. The study is designed as a multicenter non-inferiority randomized controlled trial, with patients randomly assigned to either the intervention group (one day of ABT) or the comparator group (4 to 7 days of ABT). The primary outcome measure is the clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30. Secondary outcome measures include all-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections, rate of adverse drug events, length of ICU and hospital stay, and quality of life and health utility. The study aims to determine if a very short course of ABT is non-inferior to the standard course in treating acute cholangitis.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of conventional lung recruitment maneuver versus ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuver in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The study will be conducted over one year and will involve 60 patients who will be randomly assigned to either the conventional group or the ultrasound-guided group. The primary outcome measure is the change in lung ultrasound score, while secondary outcome measures include the incidence of atelectasis and intra-operative desaturation. The study will provide valuable insights into the optimal lung recruitment technique for this patient population.

This clinical trial aims to optimize the fractionation schedules for radiotherapy in the treatment of heel spurs. The study hypothesizes that very low total doses of orthovoltage radiotherapy delivered in a single fraction may provide pain relief comparable to higher doses of fractionated radiotherapy. The primary goal is to determine if one-day irradiation (a single fraction) is non-inferior to fractionated radiotherapy over a three-month period in terms of pain relief for heel spur patients. The trial consists of six groups receiving different total doses of radiotherapy. The study will assess pain relief, quality of life, need for reirradiation, and analyze the radiotherapy techniques used in Czechia.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of a lifestyle intervention program in overweight or obese individuals with chronic low back pain (CLBP). The primary objective is to determine if combining a behavioral weight reduction program with pain neuroscience education and cognition-targeted exercise therapy is more effective in reducing pain compared to pain neuroscience education and cognition-targeted exercise therapy alone. Secondary objectives include evaluating the effects of the intervention on other pain-related outcomes, anthropometrics, energy balance-related behavior, and health economics. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with follow-up assessments at multiple time points. The participants will be divided into two groups: one receiving the experimental intervention and the other receiving the control intervention. The study will measure various outcomes including pain intensity, pain interference on functioning, pain distribution and extent, fear avoidance beliefs, body weight and composition, physical activity and sleep, dietary intake, and health economics.

This clinical trial is comparing the outcomes and efficacy of single pyloromyotomy versus double pyloromyotomy in the treatment of refractory and severe gastroparesis using gastric per-oral endoscopic myotomy (G-POEM). The trial aims to measure clinical success, Gastroparesis Cardinal Symptom Index (GCSI) scores, and technical success rate at 3, 6, and 12 months follow-up. Secondary measures include total procedure time, adverse events, and symptom recurrence. Patients with refractory gastroparesis and confirmed impaired gastric emptying are eligible for the study. The study design is a randomized controlled prospective trial with parallel assignment and no masking.

This clinical trial is a single-arm, open-label study that aims to evaluate the efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink with SOD on female nutritional anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome. The study will involve female participants aged 18 to 35 with hemoglobin concentration levels below 110g/L. The participants will be required to drink one piece of the Minayo Yeast Drink product each day for four consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measure of the study is the change in serum ferritin level, while secondary outcome measures include changes in hemoglobin concentration level, superoxide dismutase (SOD) concentration level, glutathione (GSH) concentration level, and skincare measurement (lines/wrinkles). The study is designed as a supportive care intervention with a single group assignment and no masking. The study aims to assess the effects of the Minayo Yeast Drink product on the participants' anemia, skin condition, and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of combining acute intermittent hypercapnic-hypoxia (AIHH) exposure with transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) on cervical neural drive in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (SCI). The trial will involve participants with non-progressive or central cord SCI from C2-T1 and will assess respiratory and upper extremity motor output. The participants will be randomly assigned to different treatment groups, including active AIHH and tSCS-paired strength training, SHAM AIHH and tSCS-paired strength training, SHAM AIHH and SHAM tSCS-paired strength training, and AIHH and SHAM tSCS-paired strength training. The primary outcome measures include changes in respiratory and upper extremity cortical and spinal drive, maximum respiratory voluntary force production, airway occlusion pressure, forced vital capacity, and upper extremity functional assessment. Secondary outcome measures include cardiovascular response. The study will use various techniques such as transcranial magnetic stimulation, surface electromyography, and respiratory assessments to evaluate the effects of the interventions. The trial is designed as a crossover study with random allocation and single masking. The sample size calculation indicates that 29 participants with chronic SCI will be sufficient for the study.

This clinical trial aims to study the effects of different anesthetic maintenance agents (propofol vs. sevoflurane) and vasopressors (phenylephrine vs. ephedrine) on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during surgery. The study will be conducted on adult patients undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. The primary outcome measure is the difference in cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2) during surgery between the different groups. The secondary outcome measure includes the effects of anesthesia induction on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism. The study will use light-based neuromonitoring techniques to measure these parameters. The participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups based on the anesthetic and vasopressor used. The study will provide valuable insights into the impact of these interventions on brain function during surgery.

The clinical trial is a national cohort study on imprinting disorders and their metabolic consequences. The study aims to assess the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of patients with imprinting disorders. It also aims to investigate the association between the metabolic phenotype of patients and their biological profile, determine the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities, estimate the risk for metabolic complications, describe therapeutic approaches, and analyze genetic mutations in proband and relatives. The study will span an average of 10 years and will include both pediatric and adult patients.

This clinical trial compares the use of unipolar versus bipolar interlocking in the surgical treatment of humeral shaft fractures in adults. The study aims to assess the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. The trial will include patients aged 18 and above with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental (unipolar interlocking) group or the active comparator (bipolar interlocking) group. Various questionnaires and scans will be used for evaluation.

This clinical trial, titled EPI-MINN: Targeting Cognition and Motivation in Coordinated Specialty Care for Early Psychosis, aims to address the cognitive dysfunction and impaired motivation in individuals with early psychosis. The trial will involve a combination of cognitive and social cognitive training, delivered remotely, along with the use of a mobile app called Personalized Real-time Intervention for Motivational Enhancement (PRIME). The study will compare this intervention to treatment as usual in early psychosis coordinated specialty care clinics. The primary outcome measures include changes in cognitive function, defeatist beliefs, quality of life, and behavioral inhibition and activation. The trial will also assess secondary outcomes related to depression and anxiety symptoms. The results of this study will provide valuable insights into optimizing coordinated specialty care for individuals with early psychosis and improving clinical trajectories.

This clinical trial aims to assess the use of wearable fitness trackers in prehabilitation programs for patients with non-metastatic oesophago-gastric, hepatobiliary, or lung cancer. The study will compare two groups: one group will exercise based on their rating of perceived exertion (control group), while the other group will exercise based on personalized heart rate zones (intervention group). The primary outcome measure is the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise achieved over an 8-week period. Secondary outcome measures include the volume of physical activity achieved, weekly adherence to exercise, duration and intensity of exercise as measured by heart rate data, and patient feedback on the use of heart rate trackers.

The LA POPA Trial is a randomized controlled trial comparing two minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery alone and pit-picking surgery with sinus laser-assisted closure. The study aims to measure the success rate of treatment at 1 year, as well as secondary outcomes such as long-term success rate, pain scores, patient-reported outcome measures, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation, return to daily activities, recurrence rate, need for secondary or revision surgery, patient satisfaction, and quality of life. The trial will include patients aged 12 years and older with primary pilonidal sinus disease.

This clinical trial aims to identify the sociodemographic and clinical characteristics of patients admitted to the Addiction Management Unit of Assiut University Hospital in Egypt. The study will focus on patients with substance use disorders and will involve supportive psychotherapy as the intervention. The primary outcome measures include identifying sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse among the patients. The study will gather data through surveys, psychiatric interviews, and assessments. The goal is to provide valuable information for planning and implementing prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation programs for substance use disorders.

This is a phase 2 clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of combining immune checkpoint inhibitors and radioembolisation for previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. The study aims to determine the best objective response, rate of abscopal effect, progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of treatment-related side effects, local control rate, and distant control rate. The intervention includes the drugs Durvalumab and Tremelimumab, as well as Yttrium-90 radioembolisation.
