Participants must meet certain eligibility criteria, and the study is not open to healthy volunteers. The study design is a single-group assignment, with no masking. The primary outcome measures will be assessed over a 3-year period.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab in combination with gemcitabine and cisplatin for the treatment of patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. The study will assess the rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable cancer after 4 or 8 cycles of treatment, as well as the incidence of related treatment emergent adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include objective response rate, pathological complete response, overall survival, progression-free survival, rate of R0 resection, relapse-free survival, patient-reported outcomes decline, and event-free survival. The study design is a single-group assignment with an open-label approach. Participants will receive a combination of drugs and undergo surgical resection if the tumor is deemed resectable. The study will be conducted over a period of 36 months.

This multi-center clinical trial aims to establish the normal values of extremity arterial structure and hemodynamics in Chinese Han adults using high-frequency ultrasound. The study will measure the intima thickness and blood flow velocity of the dorsalis pedis artery and proper palmar digital artery. The goal is to provide quantitative reference values for the early diagnosis, evaluation, and observation of extremity arterial structure and blood flow. The study will involve healthy volunteers and will use high-frequency ultrasound as the intervention.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of STERIFY GEL in promoting healing of periodontal pockets after scaling and root planing (SRP). The gel has visco-elastic and mucoadhesive properties that allow it to penetrate deep into the pockets and adhere to the gingival tissue and bone, providing complete coverage. The gel acts as a filler to restore volume and physically prevent bacteria from reentering the pocket, promoting tissue healing. The trial will compare the use of STERIFY GEL with SRP alone. The study design is a split-mouth study, with one or two segments receiving the gel and the contralateral segments serving as controls. The primary outcome measure is pocket depth, and secondary measures include gingival recession, clinical attachment level, plaque index, bleeding index, furcations, grade of mobility, and quantification of bacterial contamination. The trial aims to improve and accelerate healing parameters and prevent recurrent inflammation and infection in patients with moderate to severe chronic periodontal disease.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of combining hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) with hippocampal training in improving memory recovery in veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The trial will include 40 male veterans with combat-associated PTSD and peritraumatic amnesia. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either HBOT alone or HBOT with hippocampal training. The HBOT protocol will consist of 60 daily sessions, while hippocampal training will combine physical and cognitive training three times per week. The study will assess changes in memory gaps, time to inaccessible memory surfacing, brain activity, cognitive performance, and memory tests. The findings will contribute to the understanding of PTSD-related memory impairment and the development of new treatments for PTSD and other memory-related conditions.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis. The current method, 18F-FDG PET/CT, has limitations due to high physiological uptake in normal cardiac muscle. The trial will include patients with suspected or known cardiac sarcoidosis, as well as patients with myocarditis and neuroendocrine tumors as control groups. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT. Secondary outcome measures include rates of adverse outcomes and the distribution of tracer uptake in the heart.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea among renal transplant recipients. The study will be a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial with participants receiving either probiotics or a placebo for six months. The primary outcome measures include the reduction in immunosuppressive drugs-associated diarrhea, analysis of inflammatory biomarkers, and the association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome. The study will collect data through gastrointestinal questionnaires, the Bristol Stool Chart, blood samples, and stool samples.

This clinical trial aims to assess the efficacy of inhaled sevoflurane compared to current intravenous sedation practice in improving pulmonary function in ICU patients at high risk for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will be a randomized, parallel-group trial with blinded outcome assessment and concealed allocation. The primary outcome measure is the longitudinal evolution of the PaO2/FiO2 ratio within 5 days from randomization. Secondary outcome measures include progression to ARDS, rate of pneumonia, ventilator-free days to day 28, organ failure to day 5, mortality at day 28, length of ICU-stay up to 28 days, and various physiological measures. The study will collect biomarker samples for further investigation of the effects of inhaled sevoflurane in ARDS patients.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the outcomes of different treatment modalities for massive rotator cuff tendon tears. The study will include patients aged 50 to 80 years with grade III tears according to the Davidson and Burkhart classification. The surgical procedures will be performed by experienced orthopaedic surgeons, and patients will be randomized to receive either arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation, arthroscopic partial rotator cuff repair, or arthroscopic complete rotator cuff repair. Patients who refuse surgery will be followed as a conservative treatment group. The primary objective of the study is to assess the functional status of the participants, while the secondary objective is to confirm tendon integrity using magnetic resonance imaging. Various outcome measures will be used, including shoulder strength, range of motion, functional scores, and pain scores. The study will also evaluate the quality of life and kinesiophobia scores of the participants. The results of this trial will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of different treatment approaches for massive rotator cuff tendon tears.

This clinical trial, titled "The IRIS Program: A Novel Pathway to Optimize Treatment of Injection-related Infections for People Who Inject Drugs in Hamilton, Ontario," aims to optimize treatment for injection-related infections in individuals who inject drugs. The study will utilize a holistic injection-related injection treatment program, which includes diagnosis and treatment of infections, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination. The primary outcome measure of the study is the number of emergency department visits and hospital readmissions within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrollment. Secondary outcome measures include completion of treatment, hospital readmissions specifically for the infection, number of emergency department visits, initiation or continuation of substance use treatment, mortality rates, and rates of program drop-out and reasons for discontinuation. The study will be open-label and will involve a single group assignment.

This clinical trial aims to compare the use of a mobile app called CanImmunize to a web-based platform for surveillance of adverse events following influenza immunization. The trial is a randomized controlled trial with two groups: one using the mobile app and the other using the web-based platform. The study will assess the usability of both platforms by measuring participants' perceived ease of use, perceived usefulness, attitudes and intention of use, and vaccine confidence and safety. The trial includes participants who have been immunized with the seasonal influenza vaccine and have an active email address and telephone. The study design is a parallel assignment with participants randomly allocated to either the mobile app or web-based platform group. The primary outcome measure is usability, and participants will complete a user experience survey after completing the safety survey. The study accepts healthy volunteers and includes participants of all sexes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between peri-implantitis and COX-2 gene polymorphisms, active MMP-8 levels, and the characterization of associated microbiota. The study will involve patients with peri-implantitis and a control group of healthy individuals. The participants will undergo genetic testing for MMP-8 gene polymorphisms, and samples will be collected to analyze the levels of active MMP-8 and identify the microbiota associated with peri-implantitis. The study is designed to last for three years.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of virtual reality on pain, anxiety, and patient comfort during trigger point injections. The experimental group will be shown videos of their choice through virtual reality glasses, while the control group will continue with routine practice. The participants' anxiety, comfort, and pain levels will be evaluated before and after the injection. The study design is randomized with parallel assignment, and the primary outcome measures include state anxiety scale, general comfort scale, and visual analog scale for pain assessment.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy in patients with achalasia. The study will include patients who are scheduled to undergo the procedure and will assess the wobble of systolic arterial pressure during surgery as the primary outcome measure. The study will involve two groups: patients with autonomic dysfunction and patients with normal autonomic function. General anesthesia will be administered according to standard care, and monitoring will be conducted throughout the procedure. The study is designed as a prospective observational study.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of virtual reality glasses during inhaler treatment in children, specifically those aged 2-5 years. The study is designed as a prospective, single-blind, randomized, controlled trial. Children with certain medical conditions and those who have used virtual reality before are excluded from the study. The children are divided into three groups: one group uses virtual reality glasses with roller coaster videos, another group uses virtual reality glasses with wild dolphin videos, and the third group does not use any additional equipment. The study measures the crying times, changes in respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, and heart rate during the inhaler treatment, as well as the children's anxiety levels before and after the treatment. The primary outcome measure is the change in the pain scoring system.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a transdiagnostic psychological treatment for anxiety and depression in children and youth. The study will include children aged 7-17 seeking help for anxiety and depression in primary care. The participants will undergo screening and assessment, and those who meet the criteria will be informed about the project and provide consent. The treatment will be conducted in a group format, with both children and parents receiving therapy. Various self-report scales will be used to assess treatment satisfaction, feasibility, and acceptability. The primary outcome measure will be the Emotion Regulation Index for Children and Adolescents, while secondary outcome measures include measures of anxiety, depression, mental health, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in two primary care clinics, and a randomized controlled trial is planned for the future.

The PALISA Study aims to assess pain levels during the Less-Invasive-Surfactant-Administration (LISA) procedure in premature infants. The study will measure skin conductance and record videos of the procedure for later pain assessment. The primary outcome measure is the median peaks per second at specific time-points during the procedure. Secondary outcome measures include the Neonatal Pain, Agitation, and Sedation Scale (N-PASS), apneas, desaturations, bradycardia, arterial hypotension, blunt surfactant reflux, and differences in heart rate, oxygen saturation, and SpO2/FiO2-ratio. The study will also evaluate LISA failure, intubation, air-leaks, and the incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility of a home-based depression care intervention delivered by lay providers to older people in Nigeria. The study will include participants aged 60 and above who have a PHQ-9 score of 11 or higher. The intervention involves the use of emhGAP-Age, which includes adapted problem-solving therapy and support/supervision from lay providers. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the experimental group receiving emhGAP-Age or the active comparator group receiving generic emhGAP-IG. The primary outcome measure is depression remission, measured by a PHQ-9 score of less than 6 at six months post-trial entry.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using a bone/PrP-composite in reducing tunnel widening and improving graft-bone integration in ACL reconstruction surgery. The study will compare the use of the composite in the tibial tunnel to standard ACL reconstruction without the composite. The primary outcome measure is the change in tibial tunnel diameter, and secondary measures include femoral tunnel diameter, graft incorporation, graft maturation, and knee function. The study will involve 107 patients and will follow them for 24 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of high flow oxygen in preoxygenation during rapid sequence induction in infants and small children. The study will randomize patients into three groups: face-mask preoxygenation, high-flow nasal oxygen cannula (HFNOC) preoxygenation, or a combination of both. The primary outcomes of the study are the impact of HFNOC preoxygenation on oxygen saturation and heart rate during anesthesia induction. Secondary outcomes include safety of the rapid sequence induction protocol, airway management difficulties, number of intubation attempts, and incidence of regurgitation/aspiration. The study will be a randomized controlled pilot trial with a single masking. The study will measure various outcome measures related to oxygen saturation, time to desaturation, intubation conditions, and complications. The study is designed to support the use of high flow oxygen in preoxygenation during rapid sequence induction in infants and small children.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the long-term safety, tolerability, and effectiveness of a combination therapy of Pozelimab and Cemdisiran in adult patients with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH). The study will assess various outcomes such as the incidence and severity of adverse events, control of hemolysis, transfusion avoidance, breakthrough hemolysis, hemoglobin stabilization, changes in fatigue and physical function, and quality of life. The study design is non-randomized and open-label, and participants will be assigned to different arms based on their previous treatment history and C5 polymorphism status. The study will follow participants for up to 108 weeks.

This 24-week prospective study aims to examine predictors of initial subscription and subscription renewal rates for the WayBetter app. The study will include approximately 400 adult users who are new to the app and have engaged in a 7-day free trial. The study will collect data on socio-demographics, past health behaviors, psychological determinants, and app engagement metrics. The primary outcomes are rates of initial subscription and subscription renewal at six months. The study will also describe app engagement over 24 weeks using specific metrics. The study will use regression models and analysis to examine engagement correlates and determine underlying subgroups of users. The study will also conduct a sensitivity analysis to examine the effects of different methods of WayBetter account creation.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida females. The study will be a randomized clinical trial conducted in two hospitals over a period of ten months. Forty-two participants will be randomly assigned to either the aerobic exercise group or the Pilates exercise group. Both groups will perform warm-up and cool-down exercises for ten minutes. Data will be collected at baseline and after eight weeks of treatment using questionnaires. The primary outcome measures will be assessed using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D Scale) and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). The study will help determine the effectiveness of these exercises in improving depression and sleep quality in primigravida females.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of swaddling and inhaling breast milk odor on the pain and comfort experienced by term infants during the placement of a peripheral intravenous catheter. The study includes 120 term infants who are equally assigned to three experimental groups and a control group. The infants in the experimental groups are either swaddled, made to inhale breast milk odor, or both, while no procedure is applied to the control group. The pain and comfort levels of the infants are assessed before, during, and after catheter placement using various scales. The study aims to determine the impact of these interventions on pain and comfort in infants.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the biological mechanisms underlying the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression using the Near-Infrared Functional Imaging System (fNIRS). The study will assess changes in oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin levels in different brain regions and activation levels of these regions during different stages of depression and treatment. The trial will utilize medication therapy, psychotherapy (specifically Interpersonal Psychotherapy), and a combination of both in patients with depression. The effectiveness of psychotherapy will be evaluated through fNIRS assessments and standardized psychological assessments. Blood samples, cranial magnetic resonance images, and electroencephalograms will also be collected for further exploration of treatment mechanisms in the future. The study will measure changes in fNIRS and remission rates of depression symptoms using various rating scales as primary and secondary outcome measures.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of indium In 111 panitumumab as a molecular imaging agent in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). The primary objective is to assess the safety of the imaging agent, while the secondary objective is to compare the sensitivity and specificity of identifying sentinel lymph nodes using systemic injection of 111In-panitumumab versus conventional local injection with an optical dye. The study also includes exploratory objectives to determine if systemic injection of the imaging agent can identify tumor-positive lymph nodes on preoperative SPECT/CT imaging. The trial involves the administration of panitumumab and 111In-panitumumab, as well as various imaging procedures and blood sample collection. The study will assess adverse events and measure the sensitivity and specificity of the imaging agent in identifying sentinel lymph nodes.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and mechanism of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation in the treatment of Generalized Anxiety Disorder. The study will include participants who meet the DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder and have a Hamilton Anxiety Scale score of more than 14 and a Hamilton Depression Scale score of less than 17. The study will have two groups: one receiving medication-combined transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation and the other receiving medication-combined sham stimulation. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale scores at baseline and week 2 of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale and Hamilton Depression Scale scores at baseline and week 4 of treatment, changes in the Generalized Anxiety Scale at baseline and week 2 and 4 of treatment, changes in brain function indicators, and incidence of adverse events in each group.

This clinical trial study aims to evaluate the clinical characteristics and treatment outcomes of patients with nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) using dacryoendoscopy. The study will use dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation (DLDI) as the treatment intervention. The participants will be divided into three groups based on the location and severity of the obstruction. The primary outcome measure of the study is the cumulative success rate of DLDI within a 2-year follow-up period. The study will provide insights into the factors associated with treatment failure and contribute to improving treatment outcomes for NLDO.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesiotaping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke. The study includes participants who have been diagnosed with hemiplegia due to hemorrhagic or ischemic stroke for more than 6 months and are able to walk independently for over 10 meters without assistive devices. The interventions include lower leg kinesiotaping, PNF, and a combination of PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping. The study will measure outcomes such as balance, gait velocity, step length, stride length, ankle dorsiflexion, and functional mobility using various assessment tools.

This clinical trial aims to develop and evaluate an algorithm for vascular access management. The study is divided into three phases and includes both quantitative and qualitative data collection. Phase 1 involves gathering pre-intervention data on current practices in peripheral venous catheter placement. Phase 2 focuses on implementing the A-DIVA Scale and evaluating its impact on practitioners' approaches to catheter placement. Phase 3 involves implementing the algorithm composed of the A-DIVA Scale and a decision-making tree and evaluating its impact on the quality of catheter placement. The primary outcome measure is the number of venipunctures performed per patient after algorithm implementation. Secondary outcome measures include the approval of the co-constructed algorithm, acceptability and feasibility of using the A-DIVA Scale and algorithm, patient pain scores, and various measures of professional practices.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the STARgraft-3 shunt for hemodialysis in patients with end-stage renal disease. The trial will involve implanting the shunt in the upper arm and using it for hemodialysis access. The eligibility criteria include factors such as age, consent, communication ability, and vein and artery diameter. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of subjects without access thrombosis or procedures to maintain patency at 6 months post-implantation. Secondary outcome measures include patency rates, frequency of interventions, blood flow rates, and safety outcomes.

The Primary Care Online Emotion-regulation Treatment (POET) is a randomized clinical trial aimed at determining the efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment for adolescents with mental health problems. The study will compare the effects of POET to an active comparator, both of which include therapist support and are delivered in a blended treatment format. The primary endpoint is post-treatment, and the primary objectives are to test the effects of POET on mental health problems and emotion regulation. Secondary objectives include testing if emotion regulation mediates reductions in mental health problems, if POET is cost-effective, if it works better for some individuals than others, and if there are detectable differences in distal outcomes between POET and the active control 12 to 60 months post-treatment. The study measures various outcome measures related to symptom severity, symptom improvement, depression and anxiety, global impairment, functioning, affect, emotion regulation, and more.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of different radiotherapy strategies in older patients with non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) who have undergone surgery. The trial will compare the outcomes of surgery alone, surgery with moderate hypofractionation radiotherapy (HF), and surgery with extreme HF. The primary endpoint is local tumor control at 3-year follow-up. Secondary endpoints include quality of life, toxicity rates, regional recurrence, progression-free survival, and overall survival. The trial will also collect geriatric evaluation and quality of life data for older patients with skin cancers.

The clinical trial, titled "Surveillance Colonoscopy in Older Adults: The SurvOlderAdults Study," aims to examine the risks and benefits of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults with a history of polyps. The study will compare the cumulative risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) in older adults with and without prior polypectomy, as well as assess the effectiveness of surveillance colonoscopy in reducing CRC risk. The trial will also gather stakeholder perspectives to inform future use and VA policy regarding surveillance colonoscopy in older veterans. The primary outcome measures include colorectal cancer incidence and mortality, while secondary outcomes include stakeholder perspectives on surveillance in older adults.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effect of early bedside cycling exercises on physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery. The study will involve fifty patients diagnosed with valve heart disease who are undergoing valve replacement or intervention. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive bedside cycling in addition to medical treatment and physiotherapy, or the control group, which will receive routine physiotherapy treatment and medical treatment. The primary outcomes that will be measured include functional capacity, forced vital capacity, psychological status, activities of daily living and functional level, quality of life, and length of hospital stay. The study will also assess secondary outcomes such as functional capacity, psychological status, quality of life, incidence of adverse events, and Prothrombin International Normalized Ratio (INR).

This clinical trial, titled "Molecular Analysis of Screen Detected Non-invasive Breast Cancer and Atypical Breast Hyperplasias Identified by the Sloane Project," aims to analyze the molecular characteristics of non-invasive breast cancer and atypical breast hyperplasias identified by the Sloane Project. The study includes participants with DCIS, LCIS, Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia, and Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia. The primary outcome measure of the study is the progression of breast disease, which will be measured from diagnosis to the end of 2016. The study is open to female participants who meet the eligibility criteria.

This clinical trial is titled "Tirzepatide for the Concurrent Treatment of Obesity and Type 1 Diabetes." The study aims to investigate the effects of tirzepatide, a drug, on individuals with obesity and type 1 diabetes. The eligibility criteria include being between 18 and 70 years old, having a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes for less than 12 months, and having a body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to 30kg/m2. Participants must be willing to self-inject tirzepatide once a week and use effective contraception if applicable. The study will involve two groups: one receiving tirzepatide in addition to their usual insulin therapy and the other only receiving insulin therapy. The study will measure various outcomes such as body weight, hbA1c levels, time in range of glucose levels, and insulin dose. The study will last for 32 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to determine the efficacy of Losartan in preventing paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in breast cancer patients. The study will include females over 18 years old with biopsy-confirmed breast cancer who are scheduled to receive paclitaxel. The participants will be divided into two groups: a control group receiving standard-of-care management for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, and an intervention group receiving standard-of-care management plus Losartan. The primary outcome measures of the study include the incidence of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy and the grade of neuropathy. Secondary outcome measures include patient quality of life and the level of nerve growth factor in the serum.

This clinical trial is studying the use of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets in patients with diabetes-related dementia. The study includes two treatment groups, with one group receiving the experimental treatment of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets combined with conventional hypoglycemic treatment, and the other group receiving conventional hypoglycemic treatment alone. The study aims to assess cognitive function using various tests and measures, including the Montreal Cognitive Assessment Basic (MoCA-B) and the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Scale (ADAS-cog). The trial will also measure changes in blood biomarkers and vascular function. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with a 6-month treatment period.

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of different treatment regimens for severe aplastic anemia (SAA) in elderly patients. The first treatment regimen consists of ciclosporin A (CsA), anti-thymocyte immunoglobulin (ATG), and avatrombopag (AVA). The second treatment regimen includes CsA and AVA. The study will assess the overall response rate, complete response rate, relapse rate, and adverse event rate as primary and secondary outcome measures. The trial will be randomized and open-label, with participants allocated to either the experimental CsA+ATG+AVA group or the CsA+AVA group.

This clinical trial aims to determine the sensitivity and specificity of zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab for detecting indeterminate metastatic lesions in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. The trial will compare the sensitivity and specificity of standard imaging modalities to 89Zr-panitumumab-PET/CT. The study will also assess the rate of intervention versus non-intervention in patients with indeterminate metastatic lesions. The participants will receive panitumumab and 89Zr panitumumab intravenously and undergo PET/CT. The primary outcome measures are the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab. The secondary outcome measures include the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab compared to standard imaging modalities. The study design is a single group assignment with no masking. The study will last for up to 7 years.

This is a prospective, open-label, multicenter, randomized controlled Phase III study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of prophylactic central neck dissection in low-risk papillary thyroid cancer. The study will include patients aged 18-70 years with thyroid nodules measuring 11-40 mm on ultrasound and cytology indicating papillary thyroid carcinoma. The primary outcome measure is the excellent response of cN0 low-risk papillary thyroid cancer, while the secondary outcome measure is recurrence-free survival. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the test group, receiving prophylactic central neck dissection, or the control group, receiving no central neck dissection. The study will assess the effect of prophylactic central neck dissection on the outcomes mentioned above.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of two next-generation insecticidal nets for the control of malaria in Cote d'Ivoire. The study will be conducted in the Tiebissou department of Southern Bouake city, which has a high prevalence of malaria and pyrethroid resistance in the main malaria vectors. The trial will be a three-arm, cluster-randomized trial, with each arm testing a different type of net: Veeralin LLIN (containing PBO and alpha-cypermethrin), Interceptor G2 LLIN (containing chlorfenapyr and alpha-cypermethrin), and standard LLIN (containing only alpha-cypermethrin). The study will recruit 50 children per cluster in 33 clusters for a 12-month follow-up. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of malaria cases in children aged 6 months to 10 years. Secondary outcome measures include malaria infection prevalence, vector density, sporozoite rate, and mean number of infective malaria vectors collected. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the next-generation nets in reducing malaria transmission and controlling insecticide-resistant malaria vectors.

The PRECISION study is a phase II clinical trial that aims to test the safety and effectiveness of a new treatment approach for prostate cancer. The study will use advanced radiotherapy machines and a unique image guidance system called RayPilot to deliver stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) in only three fractions, given on consecutive days. The goal is to reduce the number of treatments required for cure and minimize side effects. The study will enroll 100 male patients with low or intermediate risk prostate cancer and will assess the acute and late toxicity of the treatment, as well as patient-reported outcomes and quality of life measures. The study design is non-randomized and open-label. The primary outcome measures include urinary and bowel toxicity at 12 weeks post-treatment, while secondary outcome measures include late toxicity at 24 months post-treatment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing root resorption during intrusion movement in adult patients with deep overbite. The study will compare traditional orthodontic treatment (control group) with LLLT using a diode laser. The primary outcome measures include changes in root volume and length, which will be assessed using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images before and after the incisor intrusion procedure. The study design is a randomized controlled clinical trial with parallel assignment. The eligibility criteria include specific characteristics related to overbite and oral health. The study will provide valuable insights into the role of LLLT in reducing root resorption during orthodontic treatment for deep bite.

This clinical trial, titled "Italian Study on the Right Hemicolectomy: How the Lymphadenectomy is Performed," aims to investigate the lymphadenectomy procedure performed during right hemicolectomy surgery. The study will involve high-volume specialist centers in Italy, with a minimum of 25 interventions per year. A total of 788 patients were enrolled in the study. Data will be collected independently and anonymously using a common code. The parameters examined include patient data, neoplasm stage, type and duration of surgery, post-operative course, complications, and lymphadenectomy details. After 6 months of observation, the data will be processed anonymously. The study is titled "Lymphadenectomy in Right Hemicolectomy: Italian Multicenter Study (CoDIG-2)" and includes patients with colon cancer and lymph node metastasis. The intervention is right hemicolectomy. The eligibility criteria include patients aged 18 years and above who have undergone laparoscopic right hemicolectomy or video-assisted surgery for colic adenocarcinoma. The study design involves the procedure of right hemicolectomy, which includes a thorough laparoscopic inspection, dissection, and anastomosis. The primary outcome measure is the analysis of lymphadenectomy in relation to surgical radicality, including the number and positivity of lymph nodes. The secondary outcome measure focuses on the variability of vascular anatomy and its impact on lymphadenectomy. The study will last for 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey exercises on balance and quality of life in children with hearing deficits. The study will include children between the ages of 7 and 12 with diagnosed sensorineural hearing deficits and normal vision. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the Cawthorne Cooksey exercises group or the Swiss Ball exercises group. The primary outcome measure will be the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale, which assesses balance function. Secondary outcome measures will include the Four-step square test, which evaluates mobility. The study will last for 12 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to explore the psychological impact of Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) on women who have completed chemotherapy treatment. The study will involve 20 participants who have received chemotherapy for GTN and will conduct semi-structured telephone interviews to gather insights into the emotional impact of GTN post-treatment, the adequacy of psychological support provided by health professionals, sources of support accessed by patients post-treatment, and potential areas of improvement in follow-up support. Thematic analysis will be used to analyze the data and generate in-depth descriptions of patient experiences. The study aims to improve the support and provision of care for GTN patients after treatment completion.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation in patients with malunited distal radius fractures. The study will involve two groups, one receiving bone grafting and the other without bone grafting. The primary outcome measures include complications, quality of life, and time to complete bone healing. The secondary outcome measures include subjective and objective functional outcomes, as well as cost effectiveness. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief, individually-tailored behavioral teacher training program for children with behavioral difficulties at school. The primary objective is to examine the short-term effectiveness of the training program on the severity of four daily rated target behaviors in specific classroom situations. Secondary objectives include assessing the training's impact on secondary outcome measures such as behavioral difficulties of the child at school and at home, teacher-student relationship quality, and teachers' sense of efficacy. The study will be conducted as a two-armed randomized controlled trial, with teachers randomly assigned to receive the brief teacher training or practice as usual. The study will be conducted in Dutch elementary schools, and data will be collected before randomization, one week after the training (or eight weeks after baseline for the control group), and three months after the training (for the intervention group only). The study aims to recruit 60 participants. The brief teacher training consists of three sessions spread over a maximum of six weeks and uses individually-tailored behavioral techniques to address specific target behaviors in the classroom. The intervention group will also have the option to receive practice as usual. The study will analyze data using multilevel analyses and investigate potential moderators of treatment effects. Ethical considerations and data handling procedures are also outlined in the document.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of a tele-rehabilitation program for chronic non-specific neck pain. The intervention includes immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education. The study will measure various outcomes, such as retention rate, adhesion to treatment, safety, implementation at home, number and duration of online consultations, satisfaction with the tele-rehabilitation, and usability of the virtual reality system and online consultations. Secondary outcomes include changes in range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, and global perceived effect. Experiences of the intervention will also be evaluated through semi-structured interviews.

This clinical trial aims to assess the implementation of a home-based HABIT-ILE intervention for children with bilateral cerebral palsy. HABIT-ILE is an intensive therapy that focuses on motor skill learning and has shown significant improvements in children with cerebral palsy. The trial will compare the effectiveness of HABIT-ILE therapy at home versus therapy on-site, as well as the benefits of a follow-up therapy at home. The study will measure various outcomes, including gross motor function, hand function, activities of daily living, self-esteem, and brain imaging. The trial will be a single-blind, randomized controlled trial with four participant groups. The intervention will involve remote telerehabilitation sessions supervised by trained HABIT-ILE supervisors. The study aims to determine if HABIT-ILE at home is not inferior to on-site therapy and if a follow-up therapy at home can improve the transfer of learned skills into daily life.

This clinical trial compares the use of speculum exams versus digital exams in patients with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM). The study aims to measure the pregnancy latency, as well as secondary outcomes such as maternal chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, maternal wound infections, maternal ICU admission, maternal death, composite neonatal morbidity, length of neonatal ICU admission, need for respiratory support in neonates, neonatal sepsis, neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, neonatal pneumonia, neonatal death, and patient satisfaction with exams. The trial is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and single masking. The intervention arms include speculum exams and digital exams. The study will enroll female patients between 22 weeks 0 days gestation to 33 weeks 5 days gestation who have confirmed PPROM.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The study will assess the overall survival and tumor-free survival of patients who undergo SALT. The trial will enroll patients aged 18-75 who meet specific inclusion criteria. The intervention involves a SALT operation plan, which includes hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation, followed by residual liver resection. The primary outcome measure is overall survival, while the secondary outcome measure is disease-free survival. The study will be conducted as a single-center, prospective, single-arm study.

This clinical trial aims to establish the validity and reliability of a Dexterity Assessment Tool in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) and healthy individuals. The study will measure dexterity using the tool in both patient and healthy participant groups. The primary outcome measures include assessing the dexterity of patients with DCM, correlating the Dexterity Assessment Tool with another validated tool (GRASSP-M), and measuring inter-rater and test-retest reliability in healthy participants. The study is open to individuals between the ages of 18 and 75 and accepts both males and females. The study design involves one-time dexterity measurements for patients and two-time measurements for healthy participants. The study will provide valuable information on the validity and reliability of the Dexterity Assessment Tool.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® IOL implantation. It is a non-interventional, single center, multi-surgeon, observational study. The study will include individuals implanted with Clareon® Vivity® and Vivity® Toric IOLs. The study will review IOL implantations starting from May 2022 until 100 implanted patients (200 eyes) are reached. The study will involve retrospective chart review of pre-operative and operative implantation data, as well as collection of postoperative data through examination. The primary outcome measure is monocular best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA) at 4 meters. The secondary outcome measures include the decentration and tilt of the IOL, as well as various visual acuity measurements. The study does not provide any intervention or treatment. The eligibility criteria include age ≥ 18 years and a history of adult cataract and refractive cataract surgery with Clareon® Vivity® or Vivity® Toric IOL implantation. The study accepts both males and females and does not include healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the efficacy of a new technique called Serratus Posterior Superior Interfascial Plane Block (SPSIPB) for postoperative pain control in female patients undergoing mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery. The study will compare postoperative pain scores, the need for rescue analgesics, block-related complications, dermatome level, and side effects associated with opioid use. The trial will be a randomized, prospective, controlled study with two groups - one receiving the SPSIPB and the other serving as a control group. The primary outcome measure is the comparison of pain scores, and the secondary outcome measures include the need for rescue analgesia, adverse events related to opioid use, and dermatomal analyses.

The clinical trial aims to assess the clinical value of delayed ductal imaging using contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) in patients with pathological nipple discharge. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of the diagnostic dimension of the disease, the safety of the radiation dose, and the patient's tolerance. The trial will enroll female participants aged 18-65 who have completed routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of changes in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging. Secondary outcome measures include the diagnostic accuracy of delayed ductal imaging, changes in imaging diagnosis in patients with dense breasts or non-palpable breast masses, kappa values for evaluating diagnostic imaging results, and scores for the diagnostic confidence of radiologists. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking.

This clinical study aims to investigate the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in transplant patients, specifically in heart transplant recipients. The study will measure blood lipid levels, graft/patient survival, and left ventricular ejection fraction over a period of 4 years. The study will include patients who are at least 18 years old and have had symptomatic heart failure for at least 6 months prior to screening. Participation in other clinical studies within 30 days prior to screening is excluded. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of virtual pelvic floor physical therapy with a pelvic floor trainer in the treatment of stress urinary incontinence. The study will include women over the age of 18 with symptoms of stress urinary incontinence. Participants will be randomized to one of three arms: using the Pelex Upp device only, using the Pelex Upp device with pelvic floor physical therapy, or receiving pelvic floor physical therapy only. The primary outcome measure will be the change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms as measured by the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire. The study will last for four weeks.

This clinical trial aims to improve attendance and engagement in the Community Wise intervention, a behavioral intervention designed to reduce alcohol and substance misuse in marginalized communities. The trial will use a 23 full factorial experiment design to identify efficient strategies for improving attendance and reducing substance misuse. The intervention delivery strategies to be tested include recruiting individuals under supervision, incentivizing intervention attendance, and delivering the intervention in an open group format. The primary outcome measure is the number of sessions attended, with a goal of at least 50% attendance. The study will also compare the effect of different strategies on reducing substance misuse and measure intervention satisfaction. The trial will include men and women with a history of substance use disorder living in marginalized communities.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two different anesthesia techniques in managing postoperative pain in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The first technique is the interpectoral area block + serratus anterior area block, which has been used in previous studies. The second technique is the erector spinae block, which has also shown positive results. The study will measure postoperative pain scores, opioid consumption, recovery criteria, intraoperative changes, and CPOT scores. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the interpectoral area block + serratus anterior area block group or the erector spinae group. The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of these anesthesia techniques in thoracic surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of Botox injection and internal sphincterotomy in pain relief after hemorrhoidectomy. The study will include patients with grade III and IV hemorrhoids who have failed conservative treatment. The participants will be randomly assigned to different groups, including one group receiving Botox injection, one group undergoing internal sphincterotomy, and a control group receiving only hemorrhoidectomy. The primary outcome measure will be post-operative pain assessed using the visual analogue scale (VAS) after 2 weeks. The secondary outcome measure will be the time taken to return to daily activities without complaint after 4-6 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of modified fruquintinib as maintenance treatment for colorectal cancer liver metastases. The trial is a phase II, single-arm prospective study. The inclusion criteria include patients with colorectal adenocarcinoma liver metastasis who have previously received first-line chemotherapy and achieved disease control, and have undergone curative local treatment and achieved no evidence of disease. The primary outcome measure is the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate. The secondary outcome measures include the 2-year disease-free survival rate. The study will assess the clinical efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as maintenance therapy for advanced colorectal cancer patients who achieve no evidence of disease after adjuvant chemotherapy. Participants in the experimental group will receive fruquintinib maintenance treatment for six months or until tumor recurrence, metastasis, or intolerable drug toxicities occur within six months. Various imaging and laboratory tests will be performed at regular intervals to monitor disease progression.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of methylphenidate (MPH) in treating posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with associated neurocognitive complaints in veterans. The trial will involve 70 veterans who will receive sequential 4-week periods of MPH and placebo, in randomized order, for a total of 20 weeks. The trial will assess the efficacy of MPH in reducing PTSD and depression symptoms, as well as its impact on neurocognitive functioning. The trial will also evaluate baseline predictors of treatment response to MPH and assess any risks associated with its use. If the results support the use of MPH, it could provide a new treatment option for veterans with PTSD.

This clinical trial aims to validate the use of CFRflow as a predictor of angina in patients with INOCA (ischemia with no obstructive coronary arteries). The study also aims to identify hemodynamic and clinical factors related to angina persistence, establish prevalence of coronary microvascular dysfunction, identify predictors of major cardiovascular events, and validate the pathological value of MMR and AF measurements. The study will evaluate the concordance between different measures of coronary microvascular function and their concordance with clinical characteristics. The intervention is a diagnostic test for coronary flow reserve. The primary outcome measure is angina status assessed by the Seattle Angina Questionnaire, and secondary outcome measures include quality of life and accuracy of continuous thermodilution coronary flow reserve. The study is open to participants over 18 years of age with clinical indication for coronary angiography and without contraindications for microvascular function study.

This clinical trial aims to determine the safety and efficacy of adding ruxolitinib to the standard graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis regimen in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). The primary objectives are to assess the safety of the combination therapy and evaluate the 1-year GVHD-free and relapse-free rates. Secondary objectives include estimating the incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, overall and progression-free survival, relapse/progression rate, infection rate, and development of second malignancies. The study also aims to evaluate hematologic recovery, immune reconstitution, and the pharmacokinetics of ruxolitinib. The study design is a single-group assignment with participants receiving ruxolitinib, tacrolimus, and methotrexate, and undergoing various procedures and tests. The study will assess the incidence of adverse events and the GRFS rate as primary outcome measures.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of a Temple Stay experience in improving symptoms and quality of life in patients with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). The study hypothesizes that a Temple Stay, which provides dietary regulation and stress control, can lead to symptom improvement by altering the microbiome and stabilizing psychosocial factors. The study will observe patients with diarrhea-predominant IBS who participate in a Temple Stay for up to 8 days. The primary outcome measure is the IBS-SSS symptom score, and the secondary outcome measure is the fecal microbiome composition. The study will assess these measures before, during, and 4 weeks after the Temple Stay experience.

This clinical trial aims to assess asthma patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons and prescribers' willingness to prescribe a different inhaler for environmental reasons at the patient's request. The study will also evaluate patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and their importance in comparison to other factors such as cost and ease of use. The intervention involves an educational intervention for asthma patients, providing them with information on the climate impact of inhalers and the option to change inhalers. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants who change their inhaler from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler within 30 days. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of failure of the intervention, proportion of patients who fill the prescription for Bricanyl but do not possess the medication, patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers, patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons, and providers' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the durability of endoscopic plications, weight loss outcomes, and improvements in obesity-related co-morbidities for the combined hybrid argon plasma coagulation plus endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) procedure compared to traditional endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) alone. The study will be a single-center, randomized, single-blinded trial involving adult patients seeking ESG. The primary outcome measure is the durability of plications and endoscopic sutures on repeat endoscopy at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include weight loss, blood pressure, HbA1c percentage, quality of life, depression, eating behavior, and incidence of esophagitis. The trial will compare the efficacy and safety of HAPC-ESG to ESG alone.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effectiveness of cancer education based on the Health Belief Model on the awareness and participation of women with disabilities in cancer screenings. The study will involve women with physical disabilities between the ages of 18-65, who will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group receiving cancer awareness training based on the Health Belief Model or a control group receiving standard cancer education. The primary outcome measure will be the increase in awareness of gynecological cancers, while the secondary outcome measure will assess the barriers to breast self-examination and mammography. The study is designed as a randomized controlled experimental trial with a parallel assignment.

This systematic review analyzed nine clinical trials to assess the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and Trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The review found that among the 1,209 patients who received this treatment, the overall pCR rate was 42%. The trials used different chemotherapy and targeted therapy regimens, as well as varying dosages of Trastuzumab. The primary outcome measure was the pCR rate. The review provided detailed information about the trials' design, patient characteristics, treatment regimens, and endpoints.

This clinical trial aims to assess the feasibility of a coach-led digital platform using an intelligent coaching assistant. The study will focus on providing accessible, expert-led motivational support to Irish citizens in promoting healthy lifestyles and preventing lifestyle-related diseases. The digital platform will be augmented by an Intelligent Coaching Assistant (ICA) and will involve collaboration between partners. The ICA will assist human coaches by taking on administrative tasks and gathering data for the coaching sessions. The study will be conducted in the community of Athy, with participants having access to educational content, a health coach, and data from wearable devices. The primary outcomes of the study include assessing the feasibility of the digital platform using recruitment rates, engagement, and adherence measures, as well as evaluating the implementation of the ICA through qualitative interviews and focus groups. The study will also examine the needs of vulnerable groups and evaluate changes in mental health and lifestyle practices of participants. The study plan outlines the timeline for various milestones and deliverables of the study. Overall, this pilot study aims to determine the feasibility of the coach-led digital platform and its potential to improve accessibility and availability of coaching services.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and deep breathing exercises on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The PMR exercise was applied twice a day, every weekday, for eight weeks, and training on the application of these exercises was given to the patients individually. Deep breathing exercises were also taught to another group of patients individually. The study will measure the outcomes using the Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and Asthma Fatigue Scale, the Dyspnea-12 Scale, and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The trial is designed as a randomized controlled clinical trial with parallel assignment. The study will determine the effectiveness of these exercises in improving the symptoms experienced by COPD patients.

This clinical trial aims to assess the functional diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in the evaluation of de novo coronary artery lesions. The study will include patients with stable or unstable angina pectoris or those who have had a recent myocardial infarction. The primary outcome measure is to determine the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level, using fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the reference standard. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the sensitivity and specificity of UFR at the vessel level, evaluating the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis, and determining the area under the receiver-operating characteristic curve of UFR for coronary stenosis. The study will use diagnostic tests such as FFR, UFR, and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) to gather the necessary data.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of Balint group activities on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China. The study will involve nurse leaders in clinical departments who voluntarily participate. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive Balint group activities for three months, or the non-Balint group. The primary outcome measures include emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and personal accomplishment assessed through the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS). The secondary outcome measure is general self-efficacy assessed through the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES). The assessments will be conducted at baseline and three months later after the completion of Balint group activities.

This clinical trial aims to test non-pharmacological and Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM)-based treatments for cognitive impairment in individuals with Long COVID symptoms. The study will include participants who have been diagnosed with SARS-CoV-2 infection at least 3 months prior and have mild cognitive impairment or cognitive symptoms persisting for 12 weeks or longer after recovery. The interventions include acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management, either individually or in combination. The study will measure global cognitive function as the primary outcome, as well as secondary outcomes such as cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, quality of life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and will last for 8 weeks.

The clinical trial, myCare-102, aims to assess the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports in guiding treatment decisions for pan-cancer patients. The study involves patients with cancer who have already received first-line therapy and patients with relapsed or refractory cancer. The primary outcome measure is to determine the majority view of physicians and molecular tumor boards regarding the Cellworks reports. Secondary outcome measures include patient demographics (sex, ethnicity, age), institution demographics (type, number and placement of orders), and patient disease status (indication, ECOG score). The study will span approximately 24 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) on apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and activities of daily living in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. The trial will be conducted in a single center using an experimental research design with a pretest-posttest control group. The CST intervention will consist of 14 sessions over a period of 2 days per week. The primary outcome measures include assessing the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and activities of daily living using standardized scales. The study will contribute to the knowledge and practice of CST in Alzheimer's patients.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effect of counseling and follow-up after breast cancer education on early diagnosis behaviors and healthy lifestyle behaviors. The study will involve 160 female administrative staff working at Mersin University. The participants will be randomly divided into two groups: group A (study) and group B (control). Both groups will receive one-hour training on breast cancer and its risk factors. Group A will receive counseling for 6 months after the training and will also receive reminder messages via SMS. Group B will not receive any additional intervention. Data will be collected before and 6 months after the training using various forms and scales. The study will analyze the data using descriptive statistics. The official title of the study is "The Effect of Counselling and Follow-up After Breast Cancer Awareness Education on Early Diagnosis and Healthy Lifestyle Behaviours: 'Reduce Risks, Increase Life Chances'". The eligibility criteria include being 35 years and older, having no visual impairment or physical problems that would prevent breast self-examination, and not having been previously diagnosed with breast cancer. The study design is a prospective, parallel, two-arm randomized controlled experimental study. The primary outcome measures include behaviors for early diagnosis of breast cancer, counseling, and healthy lifestyle behaviors.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management on the application skills, satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy of midwifery students. The study includes 78 third-year students who volunteered to participate and were randomly assigned to either the intervention group (n=39) or the control group (n=39). The intervention group received practical training using a high-reality simulator, while the control group received training on a standard patient model. Various scales and forms were used to assess the outcomes before and after the training. The study design is a randomized controlled single-blind experimental study. The primary outcome measures include student satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy. Secondary outcome measures include the evaluation of simulation-based learning and postpartum bleeding skill assessment.

This clinical trial is studying the effect of a mangrove sword bean food bar on older people. The treatment group received 50g of the food bar each day for 15 days, while the control group received a different sword bean food bar. Both groups received balanced nutrition education during the first week of the study. Compliance monitoring was conducted through home visits, weight measurement, food recall, and bar distribution checks. The study aims to measure the weight of older people and their balanced nutrition knowledge. The study is non-randomized and has a parallel assignment design. The primary outcome measure is the effect of the food bar on weight, while the secondary outcome measure is the change in nutrition knowledge. The study is conducted on older people affected by a disaster. The study is being conducted at the School of Environmental Sciences at the University of Indonesia.

The pAIn-sense study aims to develop a telemonitoring system using artificial intelligence and wearable sensors to monitor and understand the nature of pain experienced by patients. The system will collect physiological, psychosocial, and pain information to provide personalized treatments. The study will involve patients with nociceptive pain or neuropathic pain, as well as healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include pain level, psychosocial components of pain, physiological components of pain, and medication intake. Secondary outcome measures include the correlation between rehabilitation or physiotherapy attendance and pain, the correlation between sleep, activity, and other daily factors with pain, predictors of chronification from acute pain to chronic pain, quality of life, pain interference, and responsiveness to medication.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intracystic administration of TARA-002 in participants between 6 months to less than 18 years of age for the treatment of macrocystic and mixed cystic lymphatic malformations. The study will assess the proportion of participants with clinical success after one treatment cycle of TARA-002, as well as various safety measures. The trial design is a single-arm open-label study, and all participants will receive up to 4 intracystic injections spaced approximately 6 weeks apart. The study will also evaluate other secondary outcome measures such as durable response, clinical success by LM type, investigator assessment, and quality of life.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiglitazar, a drug for insulin resistance, when added to the treatment of type 2 diabetes patients who have poor blood sugar control despite using insulin and metformin. The study will include 128 patients who will be randomly assigned to receive either Chiglitazar or a placebo in addition to their current treatment. The primary outcome measure is the change in HbA1C levels after 18 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in insulin dose, triglyceride levels, fasting blood glucose levels, and fasting C-Peptide levels. The study design is randomized, double-blind, and placebo-controlled.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the robustness of the EarSwitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements in people with assistive needs. The study will also gather information on how well participants can perform voluntary eardrum movements and gather feedback on current switch technologies. Healthy participants will also be recruited for comparison. The study will involve co-design questionnaires, earbud insertion, ear rumbling tests, and optional usability testing. The primary outcome measure will be the robustness of the Earswitch technology, while secondary outcome measures will assess participant performance, differences between assistive technology users and healthy participants, comfort and ease of use, and the physical comfort of the Earswitch device.

This clinical trial aims to prospectively validate and implement an electronic health record (EHR)-based pancreatic cancer risk prediction model. The study will use a multi-center prospective cohort design, enrolling individuals from 44 healthcare organizations in the USA. The primary endpoint is the development of pancreatic cancer within a 3-year follow-up period. The study will evaluate the discriminative performance and calibration of the risk model using metrics such as the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC), sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and calibration plots. The study will also assess the performance of the risk model in identifying high-risk individuals for direct screening and medium-risk individuals for biomarker testing. Secondary outcome measures include evaluating the timing of incident pancreatic cancer occurrence and tumor stage at diagnosis. The study will involve the use of a neural network model (PrismNN) and a logistic regression model (PrismLR) to stratify individuals into risk groups based on EHR data.

This clinical trial is a comparative study between two treatments, autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage and microfracture, for the treatment of articular cartilage defects in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these treatments by assessing the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scores after one year. The trial will include participants between the ages of 18 and 60 and will use a randomized allocation and parallel assignment design.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between exercise training and recovery on physical performance and health indices. The study will compare three groups: a control group following a standard exercise regimen, a group with reduced exercise volume, and a group with longer recovery intervals between exercises. The primary outcomes will measure the effect of different recovery strategies on the immune system, cardio-metabolic markers, and endocrine response. Secondary outcomes will assess changes in body strength, aerobic capacity, and body composition. The study will involve baseline measurements and assessments at 4 and 8 weeks. The eligibility criteria include being a highly active participant between the ages of 18 and 45. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking. The study will measure changes in immune system markers, cardiometabolic measurements, endocrine measurements, aerobic capacity, and body composition. The keywords related to the study are recovery, exercise training, performance, cardiometabolic health, and immune response.

This clinical trial aims to determine whether phosphodiesterase 4B (PDE4B) can be accurately measured in the human brain and if it is reduced in individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD). The study will use a PET scan with the drug [18F]PF-06445974 to image PDE4B. The primary objective is to determine if PDE4B is reduced in the brains of individuals with MDD experiencing a major depressive episode. Secondary objectives include determining the optimal length of scanning, retest variability and reliability of [18F]PF-06445974, and assessing the correlation between PDE4B binding and clinical rating scales. The study will include participants with MDD and healthy controls, and the primary endpoint is the measurement of PDE4B density in the brains of individuals with MDD compared to healthy volunteers. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking, and the primary outcome measure is the measurement of distribution volume. The study will also measure the optimal length of PDE4B scans, whole-brain distribution volume in a retest setting, and the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding. The study will be conducted over a period of 36 months and will accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the importance of weight-bearing and flexion in the 3D joint space evaluation of knee osteoarthritis. The study will use a weight-bearing MRI as a diagnostic test. The participants will be patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis. The primary outcome measure is the medial joint space width in four scan positions, and the secondary outcome measure is the lateral joint space width.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). Dysphagia, or disordered swallowing, is prevalent in neurodegenerative conditions and can lead to aspiration pneumonia, a leading cause of death in PD. The current paradigms of swallowing therapy lack biofeedback and long-term therapeutic intervention at home, resulting in regression to baseline levels. The study will compare the impact of the BiSSKit program with daily home therapy to traditional swallowing therapy models in PD. The primary outcome measures include the Penetration Aspiration Scale Score (PAS) and Total Pharyngeal Residue, while the secondary outcome measure is the Eating Assessment Tool-10 (EAT-10). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the i-BiSSkApp group or the Traditional Treatment group, and the study will span 12 weeks.

The Global Burden Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) study aims to estimate the prevalence and incidence of high-risk HPV (HR HPV) infection in low socio-economic populations. The study will be conducted in 8 countries using a harmonized protocol. The study will include cross-sectional surveys (CSS) to estimate the point prevalence of HPV infection in girls and women aged 9-50 years, and longitudinal studies (LS) to estimate the incidence of persistent HPV infection in sexually active girls and young women. The study will also include qualitative sub-studies in selected countries. Various samples, including urine, self-collected vaginal swabs, and blood, will be collected for testing. The study will collect data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, and other potential risk factors. The study aims to generate comparable data and provide insights into HPV burden and related factors.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the efficacy of strategic memory training coupled with non-invasive brain stimulation techniques in healthy aging individuals and those with subjective cognitive decline. The study will use transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) as a form of non-invasive brain stimulation and will assess its effect on memory function. The trial will consist of 5 sessions of strategic memory training combined with either active tDCS or sham tDCS. The primary outcome measures will be the scores on various memory tests, and the study will also include follow-up visits to assess the long-term effects of the intervention. The trial will include healthy older adults and individuals with subjective cognitive decline, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. Overall, this study aims to determine if the combination of strategic memory training and tDCS can enhance memory function in aging individuals and those with subjective cognitive decline.

The clinical trial, titled "Predicting Incident Heart Failure From Population-based Nationwide Electronic Health Records: Protocol for a Model Development and Validation Study," aims to develop and validate a predictive model for identifying the risk of new onset heart failure. The study will use anonymized patient-level data linked to administrative data and will consider various factors such as age, sex, ethnicity, lifestyle factors, and socioeconomic status. The study will analyze data from January 1998 to February 2022 and will utilize a multivariable Cox proportional hazard model to identify and quantify predictors of heart failure.

This clinical trial aims to assess the impact of the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption of sexual intercourse on sexual function. The study will compare two groups, one resuming sexual activity at 4 weeks postoperatively and the other at 8 weeks postoperatively.
