The primary outcome measure is the FSFI® score, while secondary outcome measures include postoperative complications and follow-up to the recommendation. The trial will last for one year.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether human skeletal muscle possesses an epigenetic memory of testosterone. The study will include sedentary males aged 55-70 years old with testosterone levels above 8 nmol/L. The participants will be randomly allocated to different groups, including a placebo group, a testosterone group, a resistance exercise training + placebo group, and a resistance exercise training + testosterone group. The study will measure outcomes such as fat-free mass, skeletal muscle size and cross-sectional area, skeletal muscle fiber CSA, DNA methylation, gene expression, myonuclei, satellite cells, isometric muscle strength, dynamic muscle strength, and muscle force-velocity profiling. The study aims to provide insights into the effects of testosterone and resistance exercise training on skeletal muscle.

This clinical trial is a dengue sero-prevalence study in the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires. The study will use a two-stage stratified design and will sample dwellings in primary units areas. The sample size will be 1,487 participants. The study will test for Dengue Immunoglobulin G antibodies using ELISA. The primary outcome measure is the seroprevalence of dengue fever, while secondary outcome measures include the prevalence of other flaviviruses and the specific dengue serotype. The study will be conducted over an average of 1 year.

This clinical trial aims to assess the performance of COVID-19 antigen rapid diagnostic tests (AgRDTs) and algorithms in low-prevalence settings. The study will evaluate the sensitivity, specificity, and overall agreement of rapid SARS-CoV-2 detection kits, including the Standard Q COVID-19 Antigen Test and the Panbio™ COVID-19 Ag Rapid Test, compared to standard nucleic acid testing using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests. Additionally, the study will assess the potential use of multi-test algorithms based on AgRDTs with or without RTPCR for low-prevalence screening programs. The primary outcome measure is the performance characteristics of the AgRDTs in detecting SARS-CoV-2 antigens in nasal swabs at ports of entry. The secondary outcome measure is the cost estimates of Ag testing compared to PCR testing for COVID-19 case detection. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

The DESC-HBR trial aims to compare the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy to full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors in high bleeding risk patients with recent acute coronary syndrome. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with optimal platelet reactivity measured at peak level after drug maintenance dose. Secondary outcomes include bleeding events, platelet reactivity at different timepoints, adverse clinical events, and cost-effectiveness. The study is designed as a randomized, open-label trial with parallel assignment. Participants will be assigned to one of four treatment groups: de-escalation to clopidogrel, de-escalation to prasugrel, de-escalation to ticagrelor, or continuation of full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitor. The study will evaluate patients at baseline, 14±2 days, 3 months, and 5 months after randomization.

This clinical trial aims to stratify prediabetes using multi-omics profiling after food intake. Participants will be screened and provided with a Continuous Glucose Monitor (CGM) and Fitbit fitness tracker. They will follow a specific meal plan for 10 days, including consuming white rice and various mitigator foods. Microsamples of blood will be collected at different time points. Optional metabolic tests may also be conducted. The study will measure blood glucose levels, postprandial metabolites response, postprandial proteomic responses, and personal metabolic states throughout the day. The study design is an open-label, single-group assignment. The primary outcome measures are the comparison of blood glucose levels and changes in postprandial metabolites response. Secondary outcome measures include changes in postprandial proteomic responses and personal metabolic states throughout the day.

This clinical trial aims to adapt and test a behavioral intervention to prevent fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) and adverse infant outcomes. The study will involve pregnant or breastfeeding women who report alcohol, tobacco, or cannabis use. The intervention includes contingent incentives and text-based support to promote abstinence from these substances. The study will measure outcomes such as urinalysis results for alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis use, self-reported substance use, gestational incidents, and infant weight and measurements. The trial will use a randomized allocation and parallel assignment design.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of operant conditioning in reducing phantom limb pain in individuals with limb amputation. Participants will undergo three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months. The study will assess pain intensity, pain quality, and neurophysiological sensorimotor response. The intervention group will receive operant conditioning feedback with peripheral stimulation, while the control group will receive peripheral stimulation only. The primary outcome measures include changes in pain as measured by the Short form-McGill Pain Questionnaire and changes in somatosensory evoked potential amplitude and latency. Secondary outcome measures include changes in the impact of pain on quality of life.

This clinical trial is titled "Ultrasound-guided Axillary Vein Catheterization in the Trauma Intensive Care Unit: A Single-Center Retrospective Study." The study aims to evaluate the accuracy and safety of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in trauma patients admitted to the trauma intensive care unit (TICU). The intervention involves performing axillary vein catheterization under ultrasound guidance. The primary outcome measure is the accurate placement of the catheter tip for measuring central venous pressure (CVP) or invasive hemodynamic monitoring. The secondary outcome measures include puncture complications, thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, TICU length of stay, and duration of ventilator support. The study will be conducted from October 1, 2021, to April 30, 2023.

This clinical trial is a Phase 2 study of Cevostamab consolidation following BCMA CAR T cell therapy for relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The study aims to assess the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of Cevostamab in this patient population. Participants must have received a BCMA-directed CAR T cell product as standard of care between 6 and 10 weeks prior to enrollment. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants who achieve MRD-negative complete remission at 12 months post-CAR T cell therapy. Secondary outcome measures include the safety and tolerability of Cevostamab, the feasibility of its administration post-CAR T cell therapy, and its impact on other clinical outcomes such as overall response rate and MRD-negativity. The study is open-label and participants will receive Cevostamab as an IV infusion once every 3 weeks for a planned 8 cycles.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging on core muscles function in patients with visceral adiposity. The study includes 45 subjects between the ages of 25 and 45 who have a waist circumference exceeding 102 cm for men and 88 cm for women, and a body mass index (BMI) between 25 and 29.9 kg/m2. The participants will be randomly assigned to different intervention groups, including cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis, RUSI (rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging) guided core muscle exercise, and a combination of cavitation and RUSI. The primary outcome measures include diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominis contraction ratio, measured through ultrasound imaging. The secondary outcome measures include visceral fat thickness and waist circumference, measured through ultrasound imaging and tape measurement, respectively. The study will last for five weeks.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin. The study will use cardiac MRI with a contrast agent to measure the atrial fibrosis surface area. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of AF lasting more than 30 seconds on the implantable loop recorder at a 3-year follow-up. The study design is a prospective cardiac MRI pilot study with a single group assignment and no masking. The study is not open to healthy volunteers and has specific eligibility criteria.

This is a phase II clinical trial studying the use of immunotherapy, hormone therapy, and an AKT inhibitor in premenopausal women with estrogen receptor positive breast cancer. The study aims to compare the objective response rate and progression-free survival among different treatment arms. The participants will be randomized into four treatment groups and will receive different combinations of goserelin, fulvestrant, capivasertib, and durvalumab. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival. The study design is open-label, randomized, and parallel assignment. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using an artificial intelligence-powered risk score called the RecuR Score to identify patients at high risk of unplanned hospital readmission. The study will be conducted at the University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center (UM CRMC). Patients with a high readmission risk will be randomized to receive either standard care or enhanced care interventions. The primary hypothesis is that the enhanced interventions will result in a 30% reduction in 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions in the high-risk group. The study will also assess secondary outcomes such as post-discharge mortality, emergency department usage, and 90-day readmission rates. The data will be analyzed using statistical tests, and the intent-to-treat principle will be followed. The study aims to provide insights into the effectiveness of targeted interventions in reducing readmission rates.

This clinical trial, called the ANCAR Trial, aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in allergic rhinitis (AR). The study is relevant because AR affects a large number of people worldwide and has significant effects on quality of life and economic costs. The trial will compare the effects of acupuncture to azelastine nasal spray. The acupuncture protocol consists of 8 treatments over 6 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the comparison of nasal congestion after 6 weeks of treatment using a Visual Analog Scale (VAS). Secondary outcome measures include the effects of acupuncture on other nasal and ocular symptoms, peak nasal inspiratory flow, general health, concentration, energy level, and equalization of middle ear pressure. The study is an open-label, randomized trial and will be conducted at a single center.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the feasibility, safety, and effectiveness of using transcoronary cooling and dilution during primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The study will recruit 60 patients and randomly assign them to receive either the intervention (transcoronary cooling and dilution) or standard care alone. The primary outcome measures include recruitment rate, feasibility of collecting all planned measurements, and safety of the intervention. Secondary outcome measures include various physiological assessments, biomarker analysis, imaging studies, and clinical outcomes such as hospitalization for heart failure and mortality. The study will last for one year, and data will be collected at multiple time points.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the feasibility of targeting the maternal gut microbiome to improve mental health outcomes in pregnant women with a history of anxiety and/or depression. The study will recruit 100 pregnant women and assign them to one of four study groups. The participants will complete six study visits over the course of 12 months, during which data on dietary intake, mental health scores, and stool samples will be collected. The primary outcome of the study is feasibility, measured by recruiting the targeted number of participants within the expected timeframe and completion of at least 4 of the 6 visits by each participant. The study will also measure adherence to supplement intake and dietary protocols, as well as completion of study visits. Secondary outcomes include identifying any obstacles to the study and comparing actual rates to expected rates. The study interventions include dietary supplements such as fish oil and probiotics, as well as behavioral interventions focused on improving diet quality.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors. The study includes a baseline run-in and randomized stage I and stage II studies. Participants in the baseline run-in receive written instructions, an instructional video, and supportive materials. In stage I, participants are randomized to two different arms, both participating in the online ¡Vida! program with health education sessions, dietary modifications, and home-based exercise sessions. In stage II, participants who achieve at least a 2% weight loss continue their assigned interventions, while non-responders are re-randomized to different arms. The interventions include online health education sessions, dietary modifications, exercise sessions, lifestyle health education sessions, individualized telephone health coaching sessions, and grocery deliveries. The study measures the percentage of weight loss at month 12 as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include examining whether the effectiveness of the interventions is moderated by baseline patient characteristics.

This is a retrospective study that aims to evaluate the use of high dose follitropin delta in a mixed protocol with human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study will measure the number of good quality blastocysts produced. The study includes women aged 18-42 who meet certain inclusion criteria and do not have certain exclusion criteria. The study will have two participant groups, each receiving a different combination of treatments. Overall, the study will assess the effectiveness of this treatment protocol in improving IVF outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine in the treatment of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). The study will involve 60 patients with IBD and will last for 1 year, with 6 months of patient enrollment and 6 months of telemedical intervention. The inclusion criteria include being 18 years or older and having a diagnosis of Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis. Exclusion criteria include severe cognitive dysfunction, acute mental illness, and lack of technical ability to participate in telemedical intervention. The study will be conducted in three stages, including selection of patients, outpatient observation with or without telemonitoring, and re-hospitalization for evaluation. The primary outcome measures include changes in quality of life and clinical remission, while secondary outcome measures include changes in adverse drug reactions, satisfaction with treatment, and psychological well-being. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment with a single masking. The intervention group will receive telemedical intervention, including monthly questionnaires, online consultations with a gastroenterologist, and access to educational information about IBD. The study aims to determine the impact of telemedicine on IBD.

The SAUNA Trial is a clinical trial studying the effectiveness of continuing somatostatin analogues in patients with gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. The trial aims to measure the difference in progression-free survival and time to deterioration in patients who continue or stop second-line therapy with somatostatin analogues. Secondary outcomes include overall survival, response rates, quality of life, cost-effectiveness, and drug safety. The study will last for 6.5 years and involve patients aged 18 years and older.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer-mediated intervention for children with language impairment in inclusive preschool classrooms. The study involves 25 classrooms, with 12 assigned to the treatment group and 13 to the control group. The focal participants are children with low pragmatic language skills who are isolated from their classroom social network. The target child is selected based on their centrality score and pragmatic language skills. The treatment involves peer-mediated pivotal response training, facilitated by a classroom teacher or teaching assistant. The facilitator trains two peer buddies to engage with the target child using specific strategies during center time. The study measures the impact of the intervention on language, social, and behavioral outcomes using various assessments.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of combining dalfampridine, a pharmacological intervention, with physical therapy for improving mobility in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will compare the combined intervention to physical therapy alone, dalfampridine alone, and explore the mechanisms of treatment effects. The primary outcome measure is the change in Timed 25-Foot Walk, a test that assesses walking speed. The trial will enroll 48 participants with MS-related mobility deficits, and the findings will inform future research on effective interventions for MS.

This clinical trial aims to assess the test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability of the CLEFT-Q questionnaire, which measures health related quality of life in patients with cleft lip and palate. The study involves 50 patients who will answer the CLEFT-Q questionnaire multiple times over a period of 1-2 weeks or 6 months or 1 year, depending on the specific surgery they are undergoing. Additionally, 20 healthcare professionals will be interviewed about their experiences with the CLEFT-Q questionnaire. The primary outcome measure is the change scores in the CLEFT-Q questionnaire, while secondary outcome measures include photographs before and after surgery and recordings of speech. The study includes participants aged 8-29 years and accepts both males and females.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of core stabilization exercises and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the severity, frequency, duration, and intensity of pain in primary dysmenorrhea. The study will involve unmarried girls aged 18-25 who are nulliparous. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the stretching exercise group or the dynamic core stabilizing exercise group. The primary outcome measures include the WaLIDD score, side bridge test, McGill Quality of life questionnaire, and PFSD scale. The study will last for 8 weeks.

This clinical trial aims to measure variations in cerebral perfusion during changes in blood pressure under general anesthesia. The goal is to identify a relationship between changes in mean velocity and the 95% spectral frequency front during changes in mean arterial pressure. The study will involve non-invasive measurements of cerebral blood flow, cerebral oxygen adequacy, and brain function parameters in adult patients undergoing scheduled surgery. The primary objective is to establish a linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front. Secondary objectives include evaluating the relationship between mean velocity and EEG markers, as well as measuring cerebral oxygen saturation. The study will include a total of 100 patients and will be conducted using non-invasive monitoring techniques.

The clinical trial, titled "The PediQUEST Response to Pain Of Children With Neurologic Disability Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial (PQ-ResPOND)", aims to evaluate the feasibility of a full-scale randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing the effects of the PediQUEST ResPOND intervention to usual care in children and adolescents with severe neurologic impairment (SNI) who experience recurrent pain. The intervention combines parent-mediated and pediatric palliative care (PPC) team-mediated strategies to address child distress and symptom burden. The study will assess the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention by evaluating recruitment, adherence to the intervention, and retention rates. The study will also explore the potential efficacy of the intervention by estimating effect sizes and variability of outcomes related to child pain and symptom burden, as well as parent outcomes. The study will be a single-site Phase II pilot RCT with 45 participants, with 30 assigned to the intervention arm and 15 to the usual care arm. The study will collect quantitative and qualitative data to evaluate feasibility and acceptability outcomes. The results of the study will inform the need for a full-scale Phase III RCT and help with study design and sample size calculations.

This observational study aims to monitor minimal residual disease (MRD) dynamics in the treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer with first-line serplulimab plus chemotherapy. The study will assess the progression-free survival, overall survival, objective response rate, and disease-control rate of participants. Eligible participants will receive 6 cycles of serplulimab plus chemotherapy, and MRD testing will be performed at various time points. The study will include participants with an ECOG performance status of 0 or 2 and confirmed extensive small cell lung cancer. The study is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this treatment approach.

This clinical pilot study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention in supporting regular physical activity levels following completion of a Phase II rehabilitation program for individuals with cardiovascular diseases. The study will compare the intervention group using the aktivplan app with the control group receiving usual care. The study will measure various outcomes such as recruitment rate, drop-out rate, data completeness, adherence to the intervention, usability of the intervention, user experience, user acceptance, technical stability, use of alternative strategies, patient experiences and perspectives, rehabilitation professionals' perspectives, exercise capacity, physical activity behavior, weight, blood pressure, blood cholesterol, HbA1c, smoking habits, health-related quality of life, exercise self-efficacy, and patient safety. The study will last for 10 weeks and will include participants aged 18 years and older.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of intranasal oxytocin on social and repetitive behaviors in youth with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, 2-period crossover design. Participants, aged 12-20, will receive either oxytocin nasal spray or a placebo for four weeks. The primary outcome measures are social behavior and repetitive behavior, assessed by caregiver reports. Secondary outcome measures include behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, repetitive cognition, and vagally-mediated heart rate variability.

This clinical trial aims to create and validate a clinical evaluation scale for the abdominal condition of premature infants. The study will involve daily evaluations of the patients by nurses, physiotherapists, and residents over a period of 21 days. The evaluations will be done using the ECAP scale, which takes less than 3 minutes to complete. The study will also assess the impact of abdominal massage on the ECAP scale and the validity of the scale in the term of birth population. The trial will include newborns born prematurely and hospitalized in neonatal intensive care units.

This clinical trial aims to address pain care inequities by evaluating the effects of Empowered Relief (ER) delivered by ASPMN nurses. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with participants who have persistent pain. The feasibility and acceptability of ER will also be assessed using qualitative descriptive methods. The study will include 170 adults aged 18 and above who meet the inclusion criteria. Participants will be randomized to either the ER group or a wait-list control group. The ER group will receive a 2-hour ER class delivered by an ER-trained ASPMN nurse, while the control group will continue their usual pain care. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain catastrophizing, and the secondary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity. The study design is a crossover assignment, with the control group offered the ER class after the ER group has completed their intervention. The study will assess participants at baseline and at 2, 4, and 8-week timepoints.

This clinical trial aims to improve pain communication for patients' health by studying the mental effort and confidence in pain intensity ratings. The trial will compare the mental effort of choosing and understanding different pain intensity rating scales. It will also compare patients' and nurses' perceptions of mental effort and determine the relationship between perceptions of mental effort and the importance of decreasing that mental effort. The trial will evaluate the equivalence of patients' and nurses' confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns and test the relationship between confidence in the accuracy of these patterns and the importance of increasing that confidence. The study will involve surveys and include patients with chronic pain and nurses who routinely assess musculoskeletal pain. The primary outcome measures will focus on mental effort and the importance of decreasing mental effort, while secondary outcome measures will assess confidence in the accuracy of pain intensity ratings.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) for the treatment of poor graft function (PGF) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The study will include patients aged 18 to 60 years old who meet certain eligibility criteria. The primary outcome measure is the hemogram recovery of patients after treatment, including white blood cell, red blood cell, and platelet counts. Secondary outcome measures include infection rate, graft-versus-host disease, and survival rate. The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking. The MSCs treatment group will receive weekly injections of MSCs for four consecutive weeks. The study will assess the outcomes within specific time frames ranging from 20 to 60 days after transplantation and up to one year after transplantation.

This clinical trial, called MOVIN' CARE for PD, aims to investigate the effectiveness of two mind-body interventions (yoga and arts-based therapy) in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being of Parkinson's disease (PD) patients. The study will be conducted using a 2-arm randomized controlled design, with participants being assigned to either the mindful yoga intervention or the arts-based therapy intervention. The primary outcome measures include changes in perceived stress level, overall quality of life, quality of life specific to PD, PD-related symptoms, and self-compassion. Secondary outcome measures include changes in self-efficacy, perceived social support, constipation severity, bowel habits, gut microbiota composition, and user satisfaction. The study will involve adults diagnosed with idiopathic, mild-to-advanced PD, and participants must be able to give written informed consent and have access to the internet and a smartphone/tablet/laptop. The study is designed as a parallel randomized controlled trial, with participants being randomly assigned to one of the two interventions. Data will be collected at baseline and at 3-month, 6-month, and 9-month follow-up assessments.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a newly developed comprehensive treatment program, called Quit Genius Alcohol (QG-A), for adults with Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD). QG-A combines cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy, and is delivered through a mobile health app. The trial will compare the efficacy of QG-A with usual care, which consists of medical management with naltrexone. The study will assess the impact of the interventions on alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes. The trial design is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment, and participants will be followed up for 12, 24, 36, and 52 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in past 30-day alcohol use.

This clinical trial, titled "The Seven Trial: Exploiting the Unfolded Protein Response," aims to investigate the use of unfolded protein response (UPR) agents to induce apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells and improve survival rates. The trial will involve the administration of multiple drugs, including botensilimab, balstilimab, chloroquine phosphate, and celecoxib, in combination with chemotherapy. The study will assess the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of botensilimab and evaluate its safety and tolerability. The primary outcome measures include determining the MTD and assessing safety and tolerability. Secondary outcome measures include evaluating complete response rate, overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, disease control rate, and changes in carbohydrate antigen levels. The study will be non-randomized and will consist of a dose escalation phase and an expansion cohort phase.

This clinical trial is comparing the effectiveness of frozen embryo transfer (FET) in natural cycles versus substituted cycles. The study aims to evaluate the clinical pregnancy rate of FET in both types of cycles. The eligibility criteria include women under 40 years old who have undergone FET cycles at Clinique OVO. Exclusion criteria include a history of recurrent miscarriages, the use of certain medications or treatments to improve endometrial thickness, uterine abnormalities, abnormal hormonal profiles, and a history of recurrent implantation failure. The study design involves two participant groups or arms: one receiving FET in a substituted cycle and the other receiving FET in a natural cycle. The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate, which will be assessed 6 to 8 weeks after FET.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of intravenous anesthesia and inhalational anesthesia on older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery. The primary outcomes being studied are the incidence of postoperative delirium and postoperative cognitive dysfunction. Secondary outcomes include delirium severity and duration, blood biomarkers, postoperative functional decline, and patient-reported outcomes. The trial will be a randomized, double-blind study with participants assigned to either the inhalational anesthesia group or the intravenous anesthesia group. The study will assess the outcomes over a period of one year.

This clinical trial aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease and develop a protocol to prevent nutritional deficiencies and promote normal growth in these children. The study will involve a detailed assessment of the patients' medical history, including perinatal and postnatal factors, feeding history, and general and systemic examinations. Anthropometric measures such as weight, height, length, head circumference, mid-arm circumference, and BMI will be taken and plotted on standardized growth charts. The study will include children aged 5 weeks to 18 years with cyanotic and acyanotic congenital heart disease, while excluding those with comorbidities or receiving immunosuppressive therapy. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of nutritional status at baseline.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of pH sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer echo planar imaging (CEST-EPI) for the resection of glioblastoma. CEST imaging can detect tumor cells in non-enhancing regions surrounding the main tumor. The trial will enroll patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma and randomize them into two groups: standard of care resection or CEST-based resection. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include overall survival and quality of life metrics. The study design is a randomized, non-blinded trial with parallel assignment. The intervention involves using pre-operative CEST MRI to identify regions of interest for tumor resection. The trial aims to recruit 60 participants and has a power of 95% to detect a meaningful difference in progression-free survival. The study will also assess surgical complication rates and post-operative performance scale changes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan. The study will focus on understanding the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. The study will be conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital and will span from 2020 to 2022. All Sudanese patients living in Darfur with a urinary bladder mass and above 18 years of age are eligible to participate. Patients who do not live in Darfur or refuse to participate will be excluded. The primary outcome measure of the study is the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. A total of 1000 patients undergoing colonoscopy were included in the study, and their physical and mental stress levels were assessed using questionnaires. The correlation between stress and bowel preparation quality was analyzed using the Boston Rating Scale. The primary outcome measure was the quality of bowel preparation, assessed using the 9-point Boston bowel preparation scale.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of playful interactions on cognitive, social, and mood outcomes in older adults. The study will compare the effects of playful interactions in both online and face-to-face formats. The researchers will also examine the mediating role of personality traits and cognitive functions in the beneficial effects of playful interactions. The study will include 80 participants and will use a randomized crossover design. The interventions will involve playful interactions based on dramatic improvisation techniques and active control conditions. Various measures, including cognitive tests, mood assessments, and self-reports, will be collected before and after each session. The data analysis will use a mixed-level linear model to examine the effects of the interventions. The study aims to provide insights into the physiological, cognitive, and emotional mechanisms and outcomes of playfulness in online and face-to-face interactions.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using the SkillFlix for Parents online video library in improving the sexual health communication skills of parents of teenagers with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The trial will be a randomized controlled study, with participants being parent and youth dyads. The study will assess the impact of the resource on parent skill demonstration and confidence, conversation frequency, and teen knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors. The intervention group will have access to the SkillFlix ASD web site and mobile app, while the control group will receive written materials. The study will measure various outcomes, including demonstrated skill scores, frequency of discussions, conversation quality scores, parent and teen confidence, family sex communication quotient score, and teen's sexual health knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of DDX17 in orchestrating septic vascular endothelial pyroptosis by controlling gasdermin D pore formation. The study will collect data on patient population information, disease-related information, treatment measures, and laboratory examination results. Patients will be followed up for 28 days and divided into survival and non-survival groups. Blood samples will be collected for ELISA content detection of DDX17 and GSDMD. The primary outcome measure is 28-day mortality, while secondary outcome measures include the correlation between plasma levels of DDX17 and GSDMD and vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients. The study is open to individuals between the ages of 18 and 80, of any gender, and does not accept healthy volunteers.

This is a single-center prospective study aimed at finding non-invasive methods for diagnosing postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study will include patients eligible for liver transplantation and will measure the occurrence of early allograft dysfunction (EAD) according to specific criteria. The study will be conducted over a period of two weeks from the date of liver transplantation.

This clinical trial aims to compare the safety and efficacy of adding Elemene to the Stupp Protocol versus using the Stupp Protocol alone for newly-diagnosed glioblastoma (GBM) patients. The Stupp Protocol is the current standard of care for GBM patients, but no other treatment options have shown survival benefits. Elemene is a Chinese anti-tumor medicine that has shown promising results in preliminary studies. The trial will be a multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled trial. The primary outcome measure will be the overall survival rate in the 12th month, and secondary outcome measures include overall survival, progression-free survival, progression-free survival rate in the 6th month, and adverse events. The study will include newly-diagnosed supratentorial GBM patients who are IDH-wildtype and have a Karnofsky performance status score of 60 or higher.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the physiological effects of the prone position compared to the supine position on lung recruitability in infants and children with acute respiratory distress syndrome. The study will include patients who meet certain criteria and will involve the use of different positions (prone and supine) for a specific duration. The primary outcome measure will be the PaO2/FiO2 ratio, while secondary outcome measures will include gas exchanges, ventilatory ratio, lung volume, tidal volume distribution, lung dynamic strain, and safety endpoints such as displacements of the endotracheal tube and oxygen desaturations. The study design will be a 2x2 crossover design, and participants will be assigned to either the control group or the experimental group.

This clinical trial aims to investigate and compare the effects of progressive relaxation training (PRT) on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with tension-type headache (TTH) and migraine. The study will involve two groups of women, one with TTH and the other with migraines, who will receive PRT intervention for six weeks. The primary outcome measures include occupational self-assessment, World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule, Pain Catastrophizing Scale, Headache Impact Test-6, and Visual Analog Scale for pain intensity. The secondary outcome measure is the Migraine Disability Assessment Scale. The study will provide valuable insights into the impact of PRT on women with TTH and migraines and help clinicians develop more comprehensive intervention approaches for these conditions.

This clinical trial aims to understand the microRNA response to opioid withdrawal in newborns and evaluate their potential use as biomarkers for neonatal abstinence syndrome. The study will involve newborns with chronic in-utero opioid exposure and will collect buccal swab saliva for genetic testing. The study will measure neurodevelopmental outcome scores, the maximum concentration of morphine required for withdrawal symptom control, and the levels of specific microRNAs in saliva. The study is designed to assess the relationship between microRNA levels and opioid withdrawal in newborns.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedic and traumatology patients. The study consists of a randomized controlled experimental research design with an intervention group and a control group. The intervention group receives patient education on pain management, while the control group does not receive this education. The study includes 52 patients who underwent elective surgery and met the inclusion criteria. Data collection tools such as the Information Form, Fear of Pain Scale-III, and Visual/Visual Analogue Scale are used to collect data on pain level and fear of pain. The study period is from December 15, 2021, to March 15, 2022. The primary outcome measure is pain level, assessed using the Visual/Visual Analogue Scale, and the secondary outcome measure is fear of pain, assessed using the Fear of Pain Scale-III. The study design is a parallel assignment with no masking. The study aims to provide evidence on the impact of patient education on pain management in orthopedic and traumatology patients.

The clinical trial, titled "Using the Transdermal Patch for BupRenorphine Induction DurinG PrEgnancy: A Randomized Controlled Trial (The Patch BRIDGE Trial)", aims to study the effectiveness of a transdermal patch for buprenorphine induction during pregnancy. The trial will include pregnant women with opioid use disorder who receive prenatal care at a specific clinic. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, where they will receive the buprenorphine transdermal matrix patch, or the placebo group, where they will receive a sham patch. The primary outcome measure of the study is the severity of induction withdrawal, measured using the Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS) scores collected during the induction period. The study will also measure secondary outcomes such as induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success.

This clinical trial aims to assess the use of transcutaneous oximetry in diagnosing vascular compression in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome. The study will compare the TcpO2 values recorded during dynamic maneuvers with the rate of compression determined on dynamic angiography. The primary outcome measure is the variation in upper limb ischemia estimated by TcpO2 measurement and the calculation of DROPmin (TcpO2 variation regarding a reference) based on the type of damage. The secondary outcome measure is to assess the correlation between the severity of upper limb ischemia and the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography.

This clinical trial, titled "Feasibility Study of a Mobile Health App for Symptom Monitoring in People With Chronic Pancreatitis: The SmartCP Study," aims to determine the feasibility of using the SmartCP mobile app in managing patients with chronic pancreatitis. The app includes features such as symptom tracking, diet and physical activity logging, alert systems, quality of life assessment, and educational content. The study will be conducted as a single-arm, unblinded feasibility study, with participants receiving the intervention for 16 weeks. The primary outcome measures include recruitment feasibility, acceptability of the intervention, retention, incidents reported by patients, and user statistics. Secondary outcome measures include crisis events, symptom frequency and severity, quality of life, hospitalization, and app usage.

This clinical trial is a retrospective cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the incidence of anal fissure among survivors of COVID-19 virus infection. The study was conducted at a tertiary referral center in Mansoura, Egypt over a period of three months. Patients who had been diagnosed with COVID-19 and experienced anal fissure during their follow-up were included in the study. The study collected data through telephone calls and electronic medical records, and patients were asked about their symptoms, risk factors, and outcomes. The primary outcome measure of the study is the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors, while the secondary outcome measure is the identification of risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure. The study will be conducted over a period of six months to one year.

This clinical trial aims to assess the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting. The study includes patients with gingival recession who require root coverage surgery. The participants are divided into two groups: a test group that receives PRF application and a control group that does not receive any additional treatment. The thickness of the palatal tissue and tissue vascularization are evaluated using ultrasonography at various time points. The primary outcome measure is tissue thickness, while the secondary outcome measure is the pulsatility index. The study design is a randomized prospective controlled study, and the data analysis is performed using statistical tests.

The ARRC III Trial of Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) is a pilot registry study being conducted at the Royal Adelaide Hospital. The study aims to collect high-quality data on the ARRC model of care, which has been shown to improve patient outcomes, reduce complications, and decrease mortality compared to usual ward care. The study will measure the number of days spent at home after surgery as the primary outcome, as well as in-hospital complications, mortality, and cost-effectiveness as secondary outcomes. The study is open to participants who are scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery and are staying in the hospital for at least one night after surgery. The study does not accept healthy volunteers. The study is designed to refine the ARRC II study database into an ongoing registry and potentially allow benchmarking across institutions.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) in mobile men in Sub-Saharan Africa. The study will compare the use of oral PrEP and long-acting injectable cabotegravir (CAB-LA) in men who are at high risk of HIV due to their mobility for work. The primary objectives are to assess PrEP persistence patterns and adoption rates among the participants. Secondary objectives include evaluating coital coverage, safety and tolerability, reach of PrEP, implementation of different PrEP strategies, and cost analysis. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial in South Africa and Uganda, with a target sample size of 400 participants. The implementation framework used is the RE-AIM framework, and data will be collected through mobile and outreach clinics. The study design is a Phase 3b, open-label, hybrid type 2 trial. The primary outcome measures include PrEP persistence and adoption rates. The study will provide valuable evidence to inform PrEP implementation guidelines and resource allocation in African countries.

This clinical trial is titled "Preliminary Assessment of the Psycho-emotional State of Patients With TMD." The study aims to assess the psycho-emotional state of patients with temporomandibular disorder (TMD) using a diagnostic test and questionnaire. The study includes two groups: a study group of 130 TMD patients and a control group of 130 patients without TMD. The primary outcome measure is a questionnaire survey consisting of 30 questions related to the emotional state of the respondents over the past 4 weeks. The questionnaire results will be divided into four sections. The study is expected to take place from 2021 to 2023.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of different types of touch on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The study will compare the effects of osteopathic manipulative treatment, affective touch, and static touch on brain changes, electroencephalogram (EEG) changes, and changes in urinary metabolites. The study will assess these outcomes at different time points ranging from 1 hour to 40 weeks. The trial design is randomized and participants will be assigned to different intervention groups. The primary purpose of the study is treatment and the study is designed as a parallel assignment with masking.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) regimen for patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and compromised organ function. The primary objective is to assess the success rate of the regimen in terms of engraftment and absence of acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) or chronic GVHD at 1 year post-transplant. Secondary objectives include event-free survival, overall survival, incidence of recipient-type hemoglobin, myeloid chimerism, acute and chronic GVHD, viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications, hematologic malignancies, transplant-related mortality, impact on organ function and quality of life. The study also involves gene therapy research using autologous CD34+ cells. The intervention consists of non-myeloablative haploidentical peripheral blood stem cell transplantation with the addition of briquilimab and abatacept. The study design is a sequential assignment with two cohorts receiving different doses of PT-Cy (post-transplant cyclophosphamide). The primary outcome measure is the success rate of the regimen at 1 year post-transplant. Secondary outcome measures include event-free survival, overall survival, viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications. The study is open to participants aged 4 to 100 years of any gender, and healthy volunteers are also accepted.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two different methods of sperm preparation, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploidy rate of pre-implantation genetic testing (PGT) in couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study will involve women undergoing PGT and will evaluate various outcomes, including the euploid rate of blastocysts, live birth rate, pregnancy rates, DNA fragmentation, and more. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the microfluidic chip group or the density gradient centrifugation group. The study will provide valuable insights into the impact of different sperm preparation methods on IVF outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) gene polymorphism and nerve growth factor as risk factors that increase the severity of allergic rhinitis. The study will involve genotyping and measuring BDNF gene polymorphism, nerve growth factor serum level, IL-1 serum level, and C-reactive protein serum level in blood samples. The participants will be chronic allergic rhinitis patients not on anti-allergic therapy, aged between 20 and 70 years. The measurements will be taken over a period of 2 months.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of mindfulness on EEG brain activity for cognitive and psychological well-being in the elderly. Sixty older adults will be enrolled and undergo cognitive and psychological evaluation, as well as EEG recording. They will then participate in a mindfulness-based intervention program for 8 weeks. Follow-up evaluations will be conducted after 2 weeks and 24 weeks. The study will analyze the data using descriptive statistics, correlation analysis, and longitudinal analysis. The primary outcome measures include changes in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive mindfulness. The secondary outcome measure is the change in EEG alpha power. The study design is a single-group assignment with no masking. The eligibility criteria include age between 60 and 75 years, normal cognition, and exclusion of certain medical and psychiatric conditions. The study is designed for prevention and accepts healthy volunteers.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the prevalence of Mycoplasma Genitalium (MG) infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected males in Hong Kong. The study will recruit 750 participants attending an HIV specialist clinic who will self-administer an online questionnaire and provide urine, rectal, and pharyngeal samples for MG, Chlamydia trachomatis (CT), and Neisseria Gonorrhoeae (NG) screening. Clinical data will also be collected from medical records. The primary outcome measures will include the prevalence of MG infection and MG resistance mutations. Secondary outcome measures will assess the prevalence of other STIs such as CT, NG, syphilis, and HCV. The study will last for one year and participants will receive self-sampling kits for STI testing in the laboratory.

This clinical trial, titled "Dalpiciclib With Endocrine Therapy for Advanced Breast Cancer After CDK4/6 Inhibitor Failure (DAWNA-FES)," aims to explore the efficacy of combining Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy for hormone receptor-positive and HER2-negative recurrent/metastatic breast cancer patients who have experienced treatment failure with CDK4/6 inhibitors. The study will use 18F-FES PET/CT imaging to evaluate the expression of estrogen receptors in various systemic lesions of the patients. The primary outcome measure is investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS), and secondary outcome measures include objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS). The study design is a randomized parallel assignment with two arms: Arm A receiving the combination of Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy, and Arm B receiving chemotherapy selected by the physician. The study will include participants aged 18 to 80 years with advanced breast cancer.

This clinical trial, titled the FISSION Study, aims to investigate the efficacy and safety of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab as conversion therapy for gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis. The study will include participants aged 18-75 years who meet specific inclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, while secondary outcome measures include overall survival, objective response rate, disease control rate, duration of response, translational rate, and adverse events. The study design is a prospective single-arm, multicenter study, and the intervention involves the administration of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of alternative incentives in promoting physical activity among older adults. The study will recruit 200 participants and randomly assign them to receive either prosocial incentives (meal donations) or personal incentives (monetary rewards) for meeting a step goal. The investigators will track the step count of the participants using Fitbit devices for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in step count, while the secondary outcome measure is the change in mental health as measured by the CES-D score. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial is an interrupted time series study conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH) neonatal ward in Kenya. The study aims to evaluate the clinical impact and cost-effectiveness of a wireless vital sign monitor called neoGuard for hospitalized newborns. The study will compare the use of neoGuard in 4 sub-units (intervention group) to the standard-of-care monitoring in 4 other sub-units (comparison group). The effectiveness of neoGuard will be measured by its ability to detect abnormal physiological signals, the proportion of valid alarms that result in necessary interventions, and the difference in newborn complication rates and treatment outcomes between the two groups. Medical staff will also participate in user surveys to assess their experience with neoGuard. The study will include newborn patients admitted between April 2022 and June 2023. The primary outcome measures include the nurse's response time to distress signals and the percentage of actionable alarms. Secondary outcome measures include the incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and frequency of key interventions. The study will assess the feasibility and sustainability of using neoGuard in a hospital setting.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of pre- or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in aged or fragile patients (≥ 70 years old or ≥ 65 years old) with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma. The study will assess the rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, and geriatric parameters. The trial will involve two experimental cohorts, one receiving radiation therapy prior to surgery and the other receiving radiation therapy after surgery.

This is a retrospective study conducted at the department of ENT-Head and Neck Surgery of Shree Birendra Hospital in Nepal. The study aimed to determine the prevalence of head and neck cancer in this hospital. Data was collected from the medical records of patients who underwent treatment between May 2022 and April 2023. The data included demographic details, diagnosis, treatment, and histopathology. Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS software. The study measured the age-wise distribution of head and neck cancers, distribution of cancers according to subsite, histopathology, TNM staging, and treatment modalities. The study did not include healthy volunteers and had specific eligibility criteria. The primary outcomes were measured over a period of one year. The study focused on keywords such as head and neck cancer, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy.

The clinical trial aims to evaluate the impact of involving parents in a clinical decision support system for detecting obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in children. A health communication message in the form of an infographic will be provided to parents to educate them about OSA symptoms and their impact. Parents will be randomized to either receive the message or usual care. The primary outcome measure is the rate of completed referrals for OSA evaluation, and secondary outcome measures include rates of OSA referral, evidence-based evaluation, OSA diagnosis, OSA treatment, and parent activation. The study will be conducted with children aged 2 to 13 years.

This clinical trial, titled "UPlift", aims to assess the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of Upadacitinib in adult participants with moderate to severe Crohn's disease (CD) in real-world clinical practice. The study will last for 3 years and will take place in multiple countries. The eligibility criteria include a diagnosis of moderate-to-severe CD, initiation of Upadacitinib as part of routine clinical care, and compliance with study requirements. The study will measure the time to achieve the first clinical response and the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission. The study will use the Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) to assess clinical remission and response.

This clinical trial aims to test the online version of the QAPS (Quantitative Analysis of Prewriting Skills) tool for assessing prewriting skills in children. The study includes children between the ages of 3 and 7 and involves various activities such as playing a drawing game on a tablet, copying shapes using a pencil, writing letters, and cutting paper with scissors. Parents will also complete surveys about their child's development. The study measures various outcomes, including the child's ability to draw shapes on a tablet, copy shapes of increasing difficulty, perform functional hand tasks, and complete surveys about demographics, emotionality, attentional behavior, and ego resiliency.

The clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) model for individuals with serious mental illness who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in Portugal. The intervention involves Community Mental Health Workers (CMHWs) and Peer Support Workers (PSWs) delivering mental health care according to a manualized recovery-oriented program. The intervention focuses on developing durable connections to support systems and providing practical and emotional support during a critical transition period. The study will assess health-related quality of life, unmet needs, psychopathology, level of disability, orientation toward recovery, self-stigma, and substance use as outcome measures. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the intervention group receiving CTI-PS services or the control group receiving usual care.

This clinical trial aims to create a registry for vascular trauma and follow-up examinations. The study will include patients who have experienced vascular injury and will assess the conditions resulting from the trauma through regular follow-up examinations. The primary outcome measures include assessing the patency of vessels/grafts using non-invasive examinations such as ultrasound and ABI-measurement. Some patients may require CT or MRI scans for further evaluation. Secondary outcome measures include the reintervention rate and the development of treatment patterns. The study will be conducted over a period of one year, with assessments performed at 3, 6, and 12 months after the trauma.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy on patients undergoing open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) surgery for distal radius fractures. The study will be a prospective randomized control trial, dividing subjects into two groups based on age and then randomly assigning them to either the control group or the BFR group. The control group will receive standard rehabilitation protocol for the hand and wrist, while the BFR group will undergo a modified rehabilitation protocol that includes the use of a tourniquet for blood flow restriction during selected exercises. The primary outcome measures of the study include body composition/bone density, forearm girth, grip strength, and pinch grip strength. Secondary outcome measures include patient-reported surveys to assess pain/symptoms and functional ability.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effectiveness of the Stand up for your Health® computer app in reducing sitting time, improving musculoskeletal symptoms, and enhancing cardiometabolic markers in office workers. The trial will involve two groups, with the experimental group receiving the computer app plus educational information, and the control group receiving only educational information. Measurements will be taken at baseline, 3rd, and 6th months using accelerometers, questionnaires, and blood tests. The study will also explore barriers and facilitators to adherence to the intervention program. The primary outcome measure is sedentary behavior, while secondary outcome measures include cardiometabolic biomarkers, anthropometric measurements, and musculoskeletal symptoms. The study will last for six months and will be conducted in office workers over 18 years of age.

This clinical trial aims to study the chronic effects of low-load blood flow restriction and creatine supplementation in women. The study will run for an estimated 10 weeks with a total of 27 visits. Participants will be asked to complete questionnaires, blood draws, and perform exercises using exercise machines while using a blood pressure cuff during some exercises. Other tests will measure hydration, nervous system function, and body composition. The study will include different intervention groups, including a control group with no supplement or exercise procedures, an experimental group with creatine and blood flow restriction exercise, an active comparator group with creatine and no blood flow restriction exercise, a placebo comparator group with placebo and blood flow restriction exercise, and a sham comparator group with placebo and no blood flow restriction exercise. The study will measure strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, endothelial function, and mood states as outcome measures.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the potential of certain biomarkers, specifically GDF-15 and cytokines, as targets for the treatment of anorexia nervosa (AN). The study plans to assess the levels of GDF-15, neurofilament light chain (Nfl), and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) in AN patients and matched controls. Body composition and energy expenditure will also be measured. The findings will inform the development of a follow-up study using neutralizing antibodies or inhibitors against GDF-15 and cytokines for AN treatment. The trial aims to challenge the perception of AN as solely a psychological condition and highlight its biological aspects. The study will include 8 AN patients with restrictive-type, non-exercising subtype, 8 AN patients with restrictive-type, exercising subtype, and 16 age- and sex-matched control participants. The primary outcome measures include GDF-15 levels in plasma and cerebrospinal fluid. The assessment will take place 3 weeks after screening.

This clinical trial, called PROSPECT, aims to collect data on complications and outcomes of patients undergoing pleural procedures. The study will collect various data including demographics, medical history, radiological findings, and procedural information. Complications will be objectively defined and recorded at 1 month. At least 20 centers will be approached to collect data on pleural interventions and outcomes. Ultrasound findings will be recorded with varying degrees of detail depending on the expertise of the center. Patients may also complete a visual analogue scale for chest pain and breathlessness before and after the procedure. The study is extendable to non-specialist centers in the future. The data collected will establish best practice standards for pleural interventions.

The study aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-based model for risk stratification of coronary artery disease (CAD). The model will integrate various imaging and clinical parameters to identify patients at high risk of disease progression. The study will include a retrospective cohort of 2500 patients and a prospective cohort of 500 patients who undergo coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) for CAD evaluation. The primary outcome measure is a composite of cardiovascular death or non-fatal myocardial infarction, while the secondary outcome measure includes all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization. The study aims to provide a more personalized management approach for CAD and overcome the current limitations in integrating AI into clinical workflow.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol concentrate for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The trial is divided into two periods, with dose escalation in the first period based on safety assessment. The primary outcome measures include the incidence of serious adverse events up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, while secondary outcome measures include mortality rate, proportion of subjects with adverse events, modified Rankin Score, Glasgow Outcome Score, and changes in NIH Stroke Scale, among others.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection. The study will be a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. The participants will be middle-aged and elderly outpatients diagnosed with COVID-19 in the convalescent phase. The intervention group will receive Manzhi Guben granules, while the placebo group will receive a placebo. The primary outcome measure will be the results of the 6-minute walking test on day 14 after treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include the results of the 6-minute walking test on day 28 and pulmonary ventilation function on day 14 and 28.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the neural bases of decision-making and executive functioning in healthy individuals. The study will involve 150 participants and will use a combination of behavioral assessments and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine the relationship between executive skills and decision-making. The fMRI session will include measures of brain activity, brain structural morphometry, and brain structural connectivity. The results of this study will provide insights into how decision-making and executive functioning may change with aging. The study is non-interventional, meaning there will be no specific treatment or intervention provided to participants. The eligibility criteria include being a healthy individual between the ages of 18 and 60. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of decision-making skills, specifically loss aversion. Secondary outcome measures include executive functioning skills, brain activity related to decision-making and executive performance, and brain structure related to decision-making and executive performance. The keywords associated with this study are decision-making, executive functioning, fMRI, and aging.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the usability of Neutrocheck among healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals. The study will assess the identification of use errors, close calls, and use difficulties associated with selected hazard-related use scenarios. Participants will also complete a questionnaire to evaluate the effectiveness of key safety information and their satisfaction with the use of Neutrocheck. Additionally, the study will compare task completion rates and user satisfaction between two groups using different instructions (paper vs. app). The trial will last for 2 months.

The clinical trial aims to identify obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease (PD) in adopting technology to improve their gait. The trial will use the Heel2Toe sensor to monitor participants' gait patterns and assess changes over a 3-month period. The study will use a stepped-wedge design, with clusters of participants randomized to receive the sensor and training at different intervals. The primary outcome measures include changes in ankle velocity during different phases of the gait cycle, while secondary outcome measures include motivation, walking behavior, and quality of life. The trial will provide valuable insights into the use of technology to improve walking for people with Parkinson's disease.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of a 4-week laughter yoga program combined with mindfulness activities on the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities. The study will include 40 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the laughter yoga program consisting of 8 sessions over 4 weeks, while the control group will receive routine care. The primary outcome measures include mood, anxiety, and loneliness, which will be assessed before and immediately after the intervention. The study will use statistical analysis to compare the outcomes between the two groups. The study design is a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment. The study is measuring the effects of the laughter yoga program on mood, anxiety, and loneliness in adolescents with disabilities.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women in cervical cancer screening. The study will include Indian, Pakistani, and Nepalese women aged 25 to 64 who have a history of sexual activity and can read or communicate in English, Hindi, Urdu, or Nepali. The participants should not have a history of cervical cancer or total hysterectomy and should not have had a Pap/HPV test in the past 3 years. The intervention will involve three groups: one receiving a printed screening decision aid, one receiving a leaflet about healthy lifestyles, and one receiving a mobile screening decision aid. The study will measure primary outcomes including decisional conflict and cervical cancer screening uptake. Secondary outcomes will include risk perception, screening decision choice predisposition, and screening decision choice question. The trial will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of decision aids in increasing participation in cervical cancer screening among South Asian women.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the additional effect of correcting forward head posture (FHP) on temporomandibular dysfunction (TMD). The study will be a randomized controlled trial with participants who have been diagnosed with TMD and have FHP. The intervention will involve conservative management with or without the use of a Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic device. The study will measure outcomes such as TMD symptoms, craniocervical angle, mouth opening, orofacial pain, and mandibular opening. The results of this trial will provide insight into the potential benefits of correcting FHP in managing myogenic TMD.

This clinical trial compares the efficacy of two topical gels, Clindamycin Phosphate 1% Gel and Dapsone 5% Gel, in the treatment of moderate acne vulgaris. The study will assess the efficacy using the Global Acne Grading Score (GAGS) and will last for 3 months. The trial includes participants of both genders between the ages of 20 and 50. Both gels have antibacterial and anti-inflammatory effects and are applied once daily. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial aims to determine the relationship between the severity of rotator cuff tears and the activation patterns of scapular and rotator cuff muscles. The study will use surface electromyography (sEMG) to assess muscle activation during functional tasks in participants with small, medium, large, and massive rotator cuff tears. The primary outcome measure is muscle activation amplitude, while the secondary outcome measure is the identification of differences in muscle activation patterns based on tear size. The study will include participants aged 18 to 60 years with diagnosed rotator cuff tears confirmed by an orthopedic surgeon.

This clinical trial, called the SENIOR RCT, aims to evaluate the efficacy of a 6-month sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults. The trial will be conducted in two North Italian hospitals and will last for 24 months, including a 6-month intervention period and a follow-up after 6 months. The primary objective is to assess the improvement in nutritional status, measured by changes in body weight and strength, between the experimental group receiving the nutrition protocol and the control group receiving standard care. Secondary objectives include evaluating changes in blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life, and sarcopenia. The study will enroll older adults over 65 who are diagnosed with malnutrition according to the GLIM criteria. The experimental group will receive a personalized nutritional protocol, while the control group will receive standard care. Various measurements, including blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life, and strength and locomotion evaluations, will be taken at different time points throughout the study. The trial will provide valuable insights into the development of a sustainable eating pattern to limit malnutrition in older adults.

This clinical trial is titled "Dynamic Changes of Torquetenovirus Load in Chinese Renal Transplant Recipients During Immunosuppressive Therapy: A Double-blind Multicenter Prospective Observational Cohort Study." The study aims to observe the changes in Torquetenovirus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. The primary outcome measures include biopsy-proven acute rejection and clinically diagnosed acute rejection of the renal allograft. The secondary outcome measures include various infections requiring hospitalization or treatment, the development of donor-specific antibodies, and changes in donor-derived cell-free DNA. The study will involve kidney transplant recipients between the ages of 18 and 65 years. The study does not accept healthy volunteers. The study will last from day 0 to day 365 after kidney transplantation. The keywords related to the study are kidney transplantation, rejection, infection, donor-specific antibodies, cell-free DNA, Torque Teno Virus, and immuno-monitoring.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether vitamin B12 or vitamin B3 therapy can reduce the severity of traumatic brain injury (TBI) in children. The study will involve 300 children aged 6 to 15 years old with severe TBI. The children will be divided into two groups, with one group receiving vitamin B3 and the other group receiving vitamin B12. The effects of the treatment will be evaluated through follow-up tests to assess cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and memory. GCS measurements will be taken before and after treatment, and neurobehavioral testing will be conducted three weeks and one year after treatment. The study will also include gait analysis. The primary outcome measure will be the change in Stair Climb Test (SCT) score after 18 months. The study design is non-randomized with parallel assignment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Pyrotinib, a drug, in women with high-risk early or locally advanced stage breast cancer. The study will assess the invasive disease-free survival at 2 years as the primary outcome measure, and disease-free survival at 2 years, overall survival, invasive disease-free survival at 5 years, and adverse events as secondary outcome measures. The study will involve a single group assignment and will be conducted in an open-label manner. Participants will receive Pyrotinib orally daily for one year.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of consuming pasta at different times of the day on various health outcomes. The study will focus on normal-weight subjects and will assess sleep quality, anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, and the composition and functionality of the gut microbiota.
