The trial will be a randomized controlled crossover study, with participants assigned to either start with consuming pasta at dinner or lunch for a period of three months. Various measurements and assessments will be conducted throughout the study to evaluate the effects of pasta consumption timing on the specified health outcomes.

This is a phase II clinical trial evaluating the use of 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT imaging in participants with multiple myeloma. The objective is to determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in detecting and measuring tumor burden in multiple myeloma. The trial will enroll up to 55 participants, divided into two cohorts based on disease status. Participants will undergo 18F-fluciclovine injection followed by PET/CT scans at three time points. The primary outcome measure is the concordance rate between 18F-fluciclovine and 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging. Secondary outcome measures include evaluating the efficacy of 18F-fluciclovine in measuring disease volume, identifying minimal residual disease, evaluating treatment response, and assessing the safety of 18F-fluciclovine as a radiotracer.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the arm swing during walking in early multiple sclerosis (MS) patients. The study will also include functional tests to understand changes in functional mobility. The participants will be divided into two groups: early MS patients and healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include arm swing amplitude in various directions, step speed, Two Minute Walk Test (2MWT), Timed Up and Go (TUG), and Timed 25Foot Walk Test (T25FW). The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months.

This clinical trial is titled "Adjuvant Pyrotinib and Capecitabine For HER2 Positive Micro Invasive Breast Cancer". It aims to study the effectiveness of the combination of Pyrotinib and Capecitabine as adjuvant treatment for HER2 positive micro invasive breast cancer. The study will include women aged 18-70 with stage I breast cancer. The intervention will involve the administration of Capecitabine and Pyrotinib. The study is designed as a randomized trial with two arms. The primary outcome measure is invasive disease-free survival, and secondary outcome measures include distant disease-free survival and overall survival.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of video biofeedback and behavioral therapy in the treatment of paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM). PVFM is characterized by shortness of breath and can greatly impact daily life. The trial will include men and women aged 18 or older with concerns for PVFM. The primary endpoint is the change in Dyspnea Index score before and after treatment. The trial will also collect data on patient expectations, reasons for seeking additional treatment, and perceived benefits of the intervention. The investigators hypothesize that there will be no clinically meaningful difference between the two treatments. This pilot trial will provide important data for designing a larger trial and guiding treatment for PVFM.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the implementation of a multifaceted and multidisciplinary protocol to promote an improvement in sleep quality in critically ill patients. The study will assess the sleep quality of sequential patients admitted to the ICU and identify disruptive elements. The multidisciplinary team will be trained on the importance of sleep for critically ill patients, and a protocol of interventions will be implemented to promote sleep quality improvement. The sleep quality of the patients and the clinical impact of the protocol will be reevaluated. The study will measure changes in sleep quality, perception of factors influencing sleep, incidence of delirium, patient and family satisfaction, knowledge of the multidisciplinary team, and sleep quality of hospitalized patients. The study will also evaluate the sleep quality of surviving patients at ICU discharge.

This pilot study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the PACHA program in enhancing adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy (AET) among breast cancer survivors. The study will be conducted in approximately 66 pharmacies in Quebec, Canada, with participating pharmacies randomly assigned to two groups. In the intervention group, pharmacists and women will have access to the PACHA program in addition to usual services, while the control group will receive usual services only. The PACHA program consists of web-based training for pharmacists, standardized consultation guides, and evidence-based resources for both pharmacists and women. The study will measure various outcomes related to adherence, knowledge, attitudes, social support, and side effects. Qualitative interviews will also be conducted to gather participants' perspectives. The results of this pilot study will be used to optimize the PACHA program and potentially design a larger randomized controlled trial.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of a formulated Melissa officinalis extract in phytosome form on sleep quality and duration. Melissa officinalis has been used since ancient times for its beneficial properties in treating anxiety and sleep disorders. The extract has been shown to reduce anxiety manifestations and improve insomnia. The study will use wearable devices to monitor sleep duration and different sleep phases. The secondary objectives include assessing perceived sleep quality, anxiety levels, quality of life, and monitoring any adverse effects. The study will be randomized and participants will be assigned to either the Melissa phytosome or placebo group. The primary outcome measure is sleep duration, while secondary outcome measures include perceived sleep quality, anxiety, quality of life, and adverse symptoms.

This clinical trial is investigating the effectiveness of lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy as a first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with positive PD-L1 and low tumor microenvironment score (TMEscore). The study aims to measure progression-free survival (PFS) as the primary outcome, as well as secondary outcomes such as overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and duration of response (DoR). The trial design involves two arms: an experimental arm receiving intensive treatment of lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy, and an active comparator arm receiving conventional treatment of tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy. The study is expected to last for 3 years.

This clinical trial, titled "Promoting Social Connection to Prevent Late-Life Suicide," aims to assess the effectiveness of Social Engage Coaching (S-ENG) in improving social connection among older adults experiencing loneliness and suicide ideation. The trial will include 30 participants aged 60 and older who reside in a senior living community. The intervention involves 10 individual coaching sessions over a period of up to 4 months, focusing on addressing barriers to action plan implementation and challenges in processing positive outcomes. The primary outcome measures include loneliness, satisfaction with social activities, time in conversations, and time outside the home. The trial will utilize ambulatory assessment via smartphones to gather data. The study design is a single-arm trial with open-label assignment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI). The study involves women with karyotypically normal spontaneous POI who have been on standard-dose estradiol hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for at least 12 months. The participants will be assigned to receive either transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% 1.5mg/day or transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% 2.0mg/day, along with vaginal administration of micronized progesterone for 14 days per cycle. The primary outcome measures include the evaluation of estrogen deficiency symptoms, assessment of quality of life, and assessment of menopause-related quality of life. The study also aims to measure changes in sex hormone levels, including estradiol and testosterone, as well as changes in bone mineral density after 12 months of higher doses of estrogen therapy.

This clinical trial, titled "The Symbiont-Restore Study," aims to investigate the immunological effects of synbiotic supplementation with a probiotic strain known as Limosilactobacillus reuteri (L. reuteri) PB-W1™ and a prebiotic blend. The study will compare the effects of the synbiotic, probiotic alone, prebiotic alone, and placebo controls on markers of immune health, host metabolome, and gut microbiome in adults with a BMI of 30-40 kg/m². The trial will be conducted on individuals between the ages of 21 and 45 who self-identify as White and are in good health. The study will use a single-blinded, 2 × 2 factorial design and involve four different participant groups receiving different interventions. The primary outcome measure will be changes in the immune profile at 8 weeks, while secondary outcome measures include changes in gut microbiome composition, metabolic profile, satiety rating, and gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fiber. The study will provide valuable insights into the potential health benefits of L. reuteri and the effects of synbiotic supplementation on immune function, metabolism, and gut microbiome.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 tablets in adult healthy subjects after a single administration. The study will involve participants aged 18-45 years and will assess various parameters such as adverse events, laboratory test results, vital signs, electrocardiogram readings, physical examination findings, and pharmacokinetic parameters of AD16. The trial will be randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, and dose-increasing, with participants receiving different doses of AD16 or a placebo. The primary outcome measures include the number of adverse events and serious adverse events, as well as the number of participants with abnormal laboratory test results, vital signs, electrocardiogram readings, and physical examination findings. The study will also measure the pharmacokinetic parameters of AD16, including Tmax, Cmax, t1/2z, AUC 0-∞, AUC 0-t, CL/F, Vd/F, λz, and MRT. Secondary outcome measures include the amount of drug excreted in urine and feces, as well as renal clearance.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. The study will involve 54 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, receiving urolithin A supplementation, or the control group, receiving a placebo. Data will be collected at baseline and after 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in arterial function and local stiffness, while secondary outcome measures include changes in blood flow, cerebral blood flow, and biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effects of vibration therapy on pain, functionality, and proprioception in individuals with cervical disc herniation. The study will include individuals diagnosed with cervical disc herniation who have been experiencing neck pain for at least 3 weeks and have limited neck joint range of motion. The participants will be divided into two groups: a control group that will receive a conventional treatment program, and an experimental group that will receive vibration therapy in addition to the conventional treatment. The vibration therapy will be applied to the trapezius, levator scapula, and cervical paravertebral muscles with a percussion massage gun for 3 minutes for each muscle group, three days a week for three weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the evaluation of joint position sense using the Laser Cursor Assisted Angle Repetition Test. Secondary outcome measures will include the Neck Disability Index, Visual Analogue Scale for pain intensity, and the Tampa Kinesiophobia Scale to evaluate kinesiophobia.

This clinical trial aims to create a register of patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) to assess the influence of various factors on outcomes. The study will collect data on patient characteristics, comorbidities, drug therapy, body composition, congestion, and biomarkers. The study will involve diagnostic tests such as echocardiography, bioimpedance, and immunoassay. The primary outcome measure is the number of secondary hospitalizations within 6 months. The study also aims to analyze the association of biomarkers with clinical characteristics and develop diagnostic algorithms for HFpEF. The trial will include patients with acute decompensation of HFpEF and a control group of healthy individuals.

This clinical trial, called Tele-B6, aims to adapt and pilot a group-level intervention called Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers (B6) for telehealth delivery. The intervention will be delivered through synchronous, online videoconference sessions over a six-week period. The study aims to improve engagement in HIV care among young Black gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men living with HIV. The trial will include a tele-B6 intervention group and a waitlist control group. Various outcome measures will be assessed, including acceptability, recruitment rates, retention, intervention fidelity, safety, perception of structural racism and discrimination, perception of discrimination, perception of HIV stigma, perception of internalized homonegativity, intersectional stigma, logistical barriers, individual resilience processes, community resilience processes, and perception of minority stress.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of caregiver training on the outcomes of Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing (DTTC) treatment in children with Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS). Forty children with CAS will receive DTTC treatment twice a week over an 8-week period, along with home practice with a caregiver. The participants will be randomized into two groups: Direct Training Group and Indirect Training Group. The Direct Training Group will receive DTTC treatment from the speech language pathologist (SLP) and the caregiver will observe and receive direct coaching. The Indirect Training Group will only receive DTTC treatment from the SLP while the caregiver observes. Caregivers in the Direct Training Group will receive specific guidance on practice techniques, while caregivers in the Indirect Training Group will be instructed to apply what they observe during SLP-administered DTTC. The study will measure the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training on word accuracy, phoneme accuracy, speech intelligibility, and functional communication at post-treatment and maintenance. The study duration is 16 weeks in total duration.

This clinical trial aims to test and validate the creation of self-help and support groups for laryngectomized patients. The study will include patients who have had a total laryngectomy and are willing to participate in these groups. The sessions will involve presentations, interventions, and group assessments. Patients will complete questionnaires to assess their quality of life before and after the program. A control group will also complete the questionnaires. The primary outcome measure is the difference in quality of life scores between the program and non-program control groups. Secondary outcome measures include changes in overall quality of life scores and ENT-specific quality of life scores, as well as the evaluation of the participation rate in each session. The study aims to include about forty patients and will be conducted over four months.

The clinical trial, titled "MS-DETECT: Early Detection of Multiple Sclerosis Progression With MSCopilot® Detect," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the MSCopilot® Detect mobile application in detecting disability worsening in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study will assess the sensitivity of the application in detecting disability worsening based on revised-MSFC scores and EDSS scores. Other secondary outcome measures include evaluating the application's ability to detect disease progression, its association with clinical scores, and its reproducibility and reliability. The trial will also assess patient quality of life, the ability to discriminate between a relapse and disability worsening, and the safety and adherence of the MSCopilot® Detect application. Overall, the study seeks to provide early detection of MS progression using digital tests and questionnaires.

The PCOS Challenge Study aims to collect information to advance research and improve care for patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). The study includes individuals diagnosed with PCOS, self-diagnosed individuals with PCOS, and those exhibiting PCOS symptoms. The study also includes a control population of individuals who have not been diagnosed with PCOS and do not have symptoms. The study will measure information such as survey responses over a one-year period.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of low molecular weight heparins in the treatment of anticoagulant and venous thromboembolism conditions. The study will involve the use of two different drugs, Dalteparin and Tinzaparin, and will measure various outcomes such as 30-day mortality, bleeding requiring blood transfusion, blood transfusion during admission, risk of pulmonary embolism, risk of deep venous thrombosis, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, length of hospital admission, and days alive out of the hospital. The study will be a cluster-randomized trial and will include patients over the age of 18.

This clinical trial aims to compare two respiratory muscle training protocols (inspiratory muscle training vs expiratory muscle training) in patients with acquired brain injury. The study will measure inspiratory and expiratory muscle strength, as well as pulmonary volume and flow as primary and secondary outcome measures. The participants will undergo an 8-week training program, supervised by healthcare professionals, using specific devices for each training protocol. The study design is randomized and participants will be allocated to either the inspiratory or expiratory muscle training group. The study does not include healthy volunteers and all sexes are eligible to participate.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of technological balance and gait rehabilitation in patients with multiple sclerosis. The study will recruit 24 patients and divide them into two groups. One group will undergo specific rehabilitation for balance disorder using a robotic platform for four weeks, followed by four weeks of observation. The other group will undergo four weeks of observation followed by the same rehabilitation treatment. The study will measure various outcomes including balance, fatigue, walking ability, and cognitive function. The trial will take place over a period of eight weeks.

The ASARD-TMA study aims to automate surveillance, alert, and rapid diagnosis of Thrombotic Microangiopathies (TMAs). The study will include patients admitted to the emergency ward or inpatients with suspicion of TMA. The eligibility criteria include a predictive probability of TMA ≥90% according to the diagnostic algorithm. The study will measure the time of diagnosis and treatment of TMAs using an algorithm to speed up the process in smaller hospitals without a 24-hour hematological guard service. The study will last for 24 months.

This clinical trial aims to develop a faucet with advanced features to enable individuals with spinal cord injuries (SCI) to access water more independently for daily activities. The faucet incorporates electromechanical controls and software programs that adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. Subjects, including individuals with SCI and controls, were recruited to test the functionality of the faucet using eye gaze, voice, and motion sensors. The study measures the participants' ability to drink, rinse, and groom using the faucet and assesses the usability of the device. The trial is designed as a device feasibility study and includes quadriplegics with injuries above C7.

This clinical trial, titled "Effect of an Activity Wristband-based Intermittent Teaching Unit in Physical Education on Students Physical Activity and Its Psychological Mediators: A Cluster-randomized Controlled Trial," aims to evaluate the impact of an intermittent teaching unit on students' physical activity and its psychological mediators. The study will be conducted in schools and will involve students in seventh to tenth grade. The intervention group will participate in an intermittent teaching unit twice a week for eight weeks, while the control group will continue with regular Physical Education lessons. The study will measure changes in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation toward Physical Education, self-determined motivation towards physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity. The data will be collected pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after a 6-week follow-up period.

This clinical trial aims to assess the agreement between a non-invasive blood pressure measurement device and a reference device in patients with autonomic dysfunction and orthostatic intolerance. The study will measure the agreement of blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output between the investigational and reference devices during different tests, including supine baseline period, Valsalva maneuver, deep breathing period, and head-up tilt table testing. The study will use scatterplot and Bland-Altman analysis to evaluate the agreement between the devices.

This clinical trial aims to develop and implement an AI-driven online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific online cognitive behavioral therapy (e-CBT) program for post-secondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region in Ontario, Canada. The program will be delivered through a regional mental healthcare hub and will target a broad population of students, offering both online psychoeducation and e-CBT programs. The study will involve three phases: pre-adoption, delivery, and post-adoption. In the pre-adoption phase, surveys and focus groups will be conducted to assess the current mental health landscape of post-secondary students and inform the development of the psychoeducation and e-CBT programs. The delivery phase will evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the programs compared to treatment as usual. The post-adoption phase will monitor the success and fidelity of the programs and aim to scale the project to other Canadian municipalities. The study will involve a randomized allocation and participants will either receive access to the online psychoeducation program or treatment as usual. The primary outcome measures include changes in anxiety severity, depression severity, stress severity, quality of life, resilience, social anxiety severity, and ADHD severity. The study seeks to develop and implement a successful digital care plan to improve post-secondary student mental health care.

This clinical trial aims to assess the efficacy of a combination therapy of Omnivirol and salicylic acid for the treatment of cutaneous warts, with a focus on persistent warts. The study will compare the cure rate and recurrence rate of the combination therapy versus standard salicylic acid treatment. The trial will also evaluate the safety of both treatments and compare the time to clearance, change in size, and number of remaining warts between the two treatment groups. Additionally, the study will investigate the distribution of wart-associated HPV types in the Belgian population and the prevalence of mucosal HPV types in cutaneous warts.

This clinical trial aims to assess the efficacy of Letrozole compared to methotrexate in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy. The study will include 75 women diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy, who will be randomly allocated to three groups. The first group will receive a single dose of methotrexate, the second group will receive letrozole twice a day for 10 days, and the third group will receive letrozole three times a day for 5 days. The levels of hCG and antimullerin hormone will be measured at different time points throughout the study. The study design is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label trial. The primary outcome measures are the levels of βhCG on day 14 and antimullerin hormone at 3 months.

This cross-sectional study aims to evaluate the effect of fenestrated closure compared to non-fenestrated closure on the left ventricular size in patients with atrial septal defect (ASD) and pulmonary hypertension. The study will measure the improvement in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole before and after the closure procedure. The study will include patients who underwent surgical closure of ASD with either a fenestrated or non-fenestrated patch. The primary outcome measures will be assessed from January 2017 to October 2021.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will measure various outcomes, including H202 generation in cancer and normal tissues, TERT mitochondrial localization in tumors, TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines, and mitochondrial oxidative stress generation, proliferation, apoptosis, and migration in cell lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors. Additionally, the study will also conduct genetic characterization and expression profiling of tumor tissues. The eligibility criteria include patients with papillary thyroid cancer who can provide consent and have adequate tissues for analysis. The study design is not provided in the document.

The study, called COOLING in Mild Encephalopathy Versus Targeted Normothermia (COMET), is a phase III clinical trial that aims to compare the effectiveness of whole-body hypothermia and targeted normothermia in treating neonatal encephalopathy and newborn asphyxia. The trial will involve babies born at or after 36 weeks of gestation who require prolonged resuscitation at birth or have severe birth acidosis. The participants will be randomly assigned to receive either whole-body hypothermia or targeted normothermia within 6 hours of birth. The primary outcome measure of the study is the mean cognitive composite scale score from the Bayley IV examination at 22 to 26 months of age. Secondary outcome measures include neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care, duration of hospital stay, duration of mechanical ventilation, duration of inotropic support, and other factors related to the baby's health and development. The study will also involve follow-up assessments at 2 years of age using the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development IV and other neurological examinations. The data will be collected through a paper case report form and entered into an electronic database. The study aims to determine the most effective treatment for neonatal encephalopathy and improve long-term outcomes for affected babies.

This clinical trial is investigating the safety and tolerability of a novel T cell immunotherapy called pTTL in patients with advanced colorectal cancer. The therapy involves using autologous T cells that have been activated and expanded in vitro using personalized neoantigens derived from the patient's own tumor. The trial will target up to 36 neoantigens. The starting material for pTTL is derived from tumor-draining lymph nodes. The trial consists of three parts: patient identification and screening, production of pTTL, and treatment with pTTL followed by a safety follow-up period. The primary outcome measure is the safety of pTTL administration, and secondary outcome measures include objective response, time to treatment response, duration of treatment response, time to tumor progression, kinetics of tumor progression, overall survival, progression-free survival, and disease-specific survival. The trial is open to adults with stage IV colorectal cancer who have received standard of care treatments or for whom further standard of care treatments are not suitable.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the diagnostic and prognostic role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study will measure the correlation of SAA levels with various factors such as disease severity, biomarkers of inflammation and lung fibrosis, pulmonary function test results, radiologic extent of disease, changes in lung function tests and HRCT disease extent over a period of 4 years. The trial will also assess the correlation of SAA levels with the need for therapy after 3 years of follow-up. Participants include patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis and healthy controls. There will be no intervention in the study.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study will be a randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial. The participants will be divided into two groups: one group will receive the blank culture transfer procedure, while the other group will undergo the sham transfer procedure. The primary outcome measure of the study is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between the two groups, measured at 12 weeks of amenorrhea. Secondary outcome measures include the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, live birth, differential cost-result ratio, and total estimated expenditure. The study will assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium in improving pregnancy outcomes in IVF.

This clinical trial aims to construct a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life for patients with primary solid malignant cancers who are receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study will collect baseline information before treatment and follow-up information after treatment to analyze the factors that impact the efficacy and prognosis of immunotherapy. The outcome measures include disease-free progression survival, overall survival, and questionnaire evaluation results. The study aims to provide evidence-based medical evidence for the selection of immunotherapy schemes and the improvement of patient survival prognosis.

This clinical trial aims to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled experimental study, with a sample size of 70 participants. The participants will be divided into an acupressure group and a control group. Data will be collected using an Introductory Information Form and Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for assessing back pain. The acupressure group will receive acupressure treatment, while the control group will receive routine care. The primary outcome measure will be the VAS score for assessing back pain before and after the application. The study will evaluate the effectiveness of acupressure in reducing back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section.

This clinical trial is investigating the effectiveness of confidential social network referrals for HIV testing. The study will take place in Moshi, Tanzania and participants must be at least 18 years old. The trial will compare two interventions: CONSORT referrals and card referrals. The primary outcome measure is the uptake of HIV testing within 30 days of the testing offer. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment with no masking.

This clinical trial is titled "Effects of Paroxetine on Cardiovascular Function in Septic Patients: a Randomized Placebo Controlled Trial." The study aims to determine the effects of Paroxetine on cardiovascular function in patients with sepsis and septic shock. The eligibility criteria include patients over 18 years of age who have been diagnosed with septic shock for less than 48 hours and are using a minimum dose of noradrenaline. Pregnant women and patients with certain conditions or intolerances are excluded from the study. The study design involves randomization and allocation to either a placebo or Paroxetine group. The primary outcome measure is the time to discontinuation of vasopressors for at least 48 consecutive hours. Secondary outcome measures include cumulative vasopressor dose, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score, length of stay in the ICU, and mortality during ICU stay. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers and is masked.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a tele-education program for patients with moderate depressive episodes. The program consists of 5 individual remote sessions, focusing on educational, psychological, and behavioral aspects of managing depression. The sessions will cover topics such as symptoms of depression, health and diet measures, destigmatization of the illness, and various treatments. The primary outcome measure is medication adherence at 6 months, and secondary outcome measures include changes in self-efficacy and barriers to treatment. The control group will receive usual care from their general practitioner. Patients in both groups may also be monitored by a psychologist and will complete questionnaires.

This pilot observational study aims to assess the ability of continuous 'home' EEG to accurately diagnose narcolepsy and demonstrate the response to treatment. The study will evaluate the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of the Dreem Headband compared to the standard ICSD-3 protocol for diagnosing narcolepsy type 1. The study will be conducted over a period of two years and will include participants aged 12 to 25 years. Participation criteria include not having any physician diagnosed sleep disorder or medical or psychiatric disorder that could explain excessive daytime sleepiness, and not using medications that affect sleep or participating in another concurrent research study.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of a transdermal microneedle patch loaded with lignocaine versus a standard EMLA patch for topical analgesia before venepuncture procedures in adults. The study consists of two phases. Phase I is a safety and tolerability assessment of the lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch in adult patients undergoing routine vein-puncturing procedures. Phase II is a randomized, double-blind study comparing the efficacy of the lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch to the EMLA patch. The primary outcomes measured are the participants' Visual Analogue Score (VAS) and skin conductance algesimeter index for pain induced by venepuncture. The study will also assess the pharmacokinetic properties of lignocaine delivered through the microneedle patch. Eligible participants must be aged 18 years and above and require venous cannulation for blood investigations before eye surgery.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of psychopharmacological treatment, cognitive behavioral couple therapy (CBCT), and a combination of both in reducing distress symptoms and improving quality of life in perinatal couples. The study will be conducted through a randomized clinical trial and will also examine the impact of different interventions on distress, coping strategies, social support, quality of life, and well-being. Participants will be randomly assigned to different treatment modes and will undergo pre-test and post-test assessments using various scales and interviews. The study will take place over a period of six months and will assess outcomes such as changes in distress, social support, coping, well-being, and quality of life. The study will also measure blood concentrations of medication and monitor treatment-related adverse events.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a single intravenous administration of SAR444836 in adult participants with Phenylketonuria (PKU). The study will include adult participants with PKU who have a historical plasma Phe value ≥ 600 μmol/L while on Phe restricted diet therapy. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events. Secondary outcome measures include assessing the proportion of participants with sustained plasma levels of Phe<360 μmol/L, changes in plasma levels of Phe and dietary protein intake, and the duration of viral vector shedding of SAR444836. The study design is an open-label, dose-escalation, and dose expansion study.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for FDG-position emission tomography (PET) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The study will assess the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline, as well as the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism according to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile. Secondary outcomes include analyzing differences in brain hypoperfusion patterns based on amyloid and tau status, correlating brain hypoperfusion with neuropsychological tests, assessing the predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and hypometabolism for conversion to dementia, and analyzing correlations between brain hypoperfusion and CSF and blood biomarkers. The study will involve brain MRI with pCASL sequence as the diagnostic test. The eligibility criteria include patients with MCI or SCD, aged between 18 and 80 years, and without enrollment in anti-amyloid or anti-tau drug trials. Healthy volunteers are not accepted in the study.

This clinical trial is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study of Tafamidis Capsule in patients with Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The study aims to assess the safety of Tafamidis Capsules by monitoring adverse events that occur within 6 months from the first dosing. The eligibility criteria include adult patients with a diagnosis of ATTR-CM who are prescribed Tafamidis Capsules. The study will only include patients with ATTR-CM in India and will not accept healthy volunteers. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse events with Tafamidis. The study design involves participants being observed while on Tafamidis treatment.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients after sternotomy. The study will include patients undergoing surgery that requires median sternotomy and have certain risk criteria. The primary outcome measure of the study is sternal stability, which will be evaluated using the sternal instability scale. The study will also assess secondary outcome measures such as safety, device deficiencies, reinterventions, sternal wound infections, and chest pain. The study design is a parallel assignment with participants being assigned to either the STERN FIX device group or the standard of care group using wires. The study will be double-masked and will last for 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of an active break intervention on reducing low back pain (LBP) and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with pre and post-intervention assessments. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive recommendations for active breaks every 30 minutes of sitting with specific exercises, or the control group, which will receive self-care recommendations. The primary outcomes will include pain intensity, disability, perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting, and the global perceived effect. Secondary outcomes will include a post-intervention questionnaire. The study will provide evidence-based practice for reducing LBP and musculoskeletal discomfort in young people.

A clinical trial is being conducted to evaluate the performance and safety of tocopherol acetate (vitamin E) administered vaginally in pre-peri and postmenopausal women. The trial aims to assess the effects of tocopherol on the acidity of vaginal secretions, vaginal mucosa dryness, mucosal integrity, mucosa pallor, quantity of vaginal discharge, whiff test results, lactobacillus grade, microbiological evaluation, and adverse events. The study will be conducted over a period of 14 days, and various measures will be taken to evaluate the outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in patients with polycythemia vera and secondary erythrocytosis. The study will collect data on clinical manifestations, history of thrombosis, and various investigations including complete blood picture, serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status, and bone marrow aspiration and biopsy. Patients with secondary erythrocytosis will be included as controls. The primary outcome measures include the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in both groups. The study will be conducted from December 2022 to September 2023.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of perfusion index (PI) measurement on emergency triage classification in patients with dyspnea. Adult patients presenting with dyspnea had their PI values measured using the Masimo Radical-7 device at admission, one hour after admission, and two hours after admission. The study compares the PI and oxygen saturation measurements obtained from finger probes, and evaluates their superiority in determining emergency triage classification. The study design is a single group assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measures include the use of PI for determining triage status at different time frames after admission. The study keywords include dyspnea, emergency, perfusion index, and triage.

This clinical trial, titled "Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) in Palliative Care," aims to investigate the effects of LSD on various aspects of palliative care, including pain, anxiety, depression, demoralization, psychological distress, quality of life, caregiver burden, fear of death, and existential distress. The study will be a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled Phase II trial. Participants must be at least 25 years old and have a life expectancy between 12 weeks and 2 years. They will receive either LSD or an active placebo and will be assessed using various questionnaires and measurements to evaluate outcomes such as changes in state anxiety, pain levels, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, and quality of life. Adverse events and vital signs will also be monitored throughout the study.

The clinical trial is titled "Teaching by Texting to Promote Health Behaviours in Pregnancy" and focuses on pregnant individuals. The study aims to compare the effects of SmartMom text messaging intervention with control text messaging intervention on various outcomes related to pregnancy. The participants will be assigned to either the SmartMom messaging group or the control messaging group. The primary outcome measures include changes in weight during pregnancy and attendance at prenatal care visits. Secondary outcome measures include changes in health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, changes in substance use, rates of planned vaginal birth after cesarean, rates of exclusive breastfeeding, rates of adverse pregnancy outcomes, and incremental costs per incidence of suboptimal weight gain and inadequate prenatal care avoided. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and has an open-label design. The participants will receive text messages either with evidence-based information to promote healthy behaviors during pregnancy (SmartMom group) or with general information about pregnancy (control group). The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of text messaging interventions in promoting health behaviors during pregnancy.
